12-15-89_-_LaRosa_Annual_Christmas_Party.title: La Rosa Corporation Christmas Party at Nona Maria’s (Dec 15, 1989)
12-15-89_-_LaRosa_Annual_Christmas_Party.summary: Archival home‑movie style coverage of the La Rosa Corporation’s annual Christmas party held at Nona Maria’s restaurant on December 15, 1989. Shot and narrated by family friend Louis (Louie) Ellis, the footage focuses on the elaborate buffet prepared by chef Raymond Priscillo, the bar setup, and numerous informal portraits and interviews with employees, retirees, friends, and LaRosa family members. The tone is warm and humorous, emphasizing food, hospitality, and the close, family‑like culture around the LaRosa businesses years before the Pete Dye Golf Club opens.

characters.name: Louis (Louie) Ellis
characters.description: Older man in a red blazer, introduced on camera as “your film director and producer.” He narrates the event, jokes with guests and staff, praises the food, and repeatedly timestamps and contextualizes the party.

characters.name: Jimmy LaRosa (Jimmy Joe / Jimmy Joe LaRosa)
characters.description: Appears with his wife; described as one‑third of the organization along with James D. LaRosa. Speaks about hosting staff and friends at the Christmas party.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.description: Referred to as “Mr. LaRosa” and “James D.” in the audio. He is spoken about (e.g., bread gift given to him, his rule about Louie paying once doors open) and appears briefly in buffet/bar context, but has limited direct, clear on‑mic speech in this excerpt.

characters.name: Raymond Priscillo
characters.description: Named repeatedly as the person who prepared and displayed the food. Male voice giving a detailed guided tour of the buffet (“Uncle Louis? Let me tell you what we have…”). Also appears in kitchen and buffet setup shots in white shirt and apron.

characters.name: Mike Renzelli
characters.description: Younger man behind the bar in a white shirt. Identifies himself as “Mike Renzelli,” jokes about being on commission and about tips and football bets. Related by marriage to “Louie Rhoda.”

characters.name: Whip Gabriel
characters.description: Older man introduced as “Mr. Whip Gabriel,” seated with his wife Julie. States he worked for the LaRosas for 21 years after 21 years in the Navy.

characters.name: Julie Gabriel
characters.description: Sits beside Whip Gabriel; identified by him as his wife of 46 years. She does not have extended dialogue in the transcript.

characters.name: Ann Nash
characters.description: One of three women introduced on camera; she gives her name and confirms they did the cooking/food prep.

characters.name: Bob Smallwood
characters.description: Man identified on camera as “Bob Smallwood,” says he is doing general maintenance and dishwashing at the event.

characters.name: Unnamed LaRosa/office staff & guests
characters.description: Numerous women and men who give first names (e.g., Regina, Pat, Rita Forsythe, Linda Brady, Bill Belcher, Jimmy Dwine, Lois LaRosa, Mr. Bacastro, Johnny B. and Mary N. Gotti, Gary, Jack Anderson, etc.). They appear in quick interviews or greetings, representing the broader LaRosa corporate and social circle.

chapters.title: Opening: Louie Ellis Introduces Himself and the Party
chapters.summary: Louis (Louie) Ellis appears on camera in a red blazer with his personalized director’s chair, introducing himself as “your film director and producer.” He explains that he is filming the La Rosa Corporation’s annual Christmas party at Nona Maria’s restaurant on December 15, 1989, around 2 a.m. He praises the food prepared by chef Raymond Priscillo, jokingly rates it a “10 out of 10,” and offers a warm “God bless you all” before announcing he’ll go film the buffet while waiting for the crowd to arrive.

chapters.title: Cold Table & Seafood: Guided Buffet Tour
chapters.summary: The camera moves from Louie’s intro to detailed shots of the cold appetizer table. An off‑camera male voice, likely chef Raymond Priscillo, addresses “Uncle Louis” and walks through the spread: a “Mexican variety” with sauces and jalapeños, potato salad, vegetable dip with fresh vegetables, crackers, fresh crab dip made from snow crabs, a hollowed‑out pumpernickel bread with spinach dip, and multiple cheeses (jalapeño pepper cheese, sharp cheese, mozzarella, baby Lorraine Swiss, Kobe Longhorn). He highlights a large shrimp display, calling them the prettiest shrimp he’s seen in years. Louie and Raymond banter about giving Louie a taste so he doesn’t “stain anything,” underscoring their friendly rapport.

chapters.title: Sweets Table and Hot Buffet Line
chapters.summary: The tour continues to the sweet table placed between the cold and hot tables. The camera lingers on platters of homemade cookies, Italian Christmas cookies, canapés, and nuts. Raymond explains the layout: cold table, then sweets, then hot food. The camera then shows chafing dishes with Italian sausage and hot peppers, buffalo wings, fried meatballs and meatballs in sauce, and covered pans awaiting more hot dishes from the kitchen. A massive crusty braided loaf of bread—gifted to Mr. LaRosa by fellow countryman Frank T. from Country Club Bakery in Fairmont—is presented and admired. Louie jokes about getting a free lunch until the doors open, at which point James D. makes him pay. The sequence ends with a cut to the bar, where bartender Mike Renzelli is introduced and jokes about working on commission and tips.

chapters.title: Bar Setup and Bartender Banter
chapters.summary: The camera focuses on the bar area and bartender Mike Renzelli. Louie asks his name for the camera and whether he’s related to Louie Rhoda; Mike confirms he’s Rhoda’s son‑in‑law and jokes that’s where he got his experience, calling Rhoda “the best.” Louie playfully tells someone to give Mike a raise. Mike mentions he’s on commission and riffs about tips, even joking about taking the Steelers on Sunday when Louie asks about tips. This section establishes the bar as another hub of hospitality and humor at the party.

chapters.title: Carving Station and Smoked Turkey
chapters.summary: Louie films a carving station where a “master” is carving a smoked turkey. He asks for the platter to be brought over so the camera can get a good look. The carver confirms it’s smoked turkey, and Louie praises Raymond again: “Raymond has the best.” This reinforces the emphasis on food quality and presentation.

chapters.title: Jimmy LaRosa on Hosting Staff & Friends
chapters.summary: Louie turns the camera on Jimmy LaRosa (“Jimmy Joe”) and his wife. Jimmy explains that the Christmas party is for their staff and all the friends they’ve worked with throughout the year and that they’re “just getting started.” Louie teases that Jimmy is “this organization,” and Jimmy clarifies he’s one‑third, with James D. as another third. Louie jokes that he’s the only non‑paid member of the organization, and Jimmy counters that Louie has been getting paid lately. Louie quips that once the doors open, James D. makes him pay, so he’ll go to Shoney’s. They exchange Merry Christmas wishes, capturing the LaRosa family’s leadership role and their easy, joking relationship with Louie.
characters_present: Jimmy LaRosa (Jimmy Joe / Jimmy Joe LaRosa)

chapters.title: Kitchen & Support Staff Introductions
chapters.summary: Louie films three women who have been working on the food. One identifies herself as Ann Nash and confirms that they “did all the cooking.” Louie then films Bob Smallwood, who gives his name and says he’s doing general maintenance and dishwashing. Louie jokes that if Bob needs a helper, he knows all about dishwashing. These quick interviews acknowledge the behind‑the‑scenes workers who made the party possible.

chapters.title: Retiree Whip Gabriel & Long Service to LaRosa
chapters.summary: Louie introduces “Mr. Whip Gabriel” and his wife Julie. Whip proudly notes they were married 46 years the previous Tuesday. Louie confirms Whip is retired and asks where he worked; Whip says he worked for the LaRosas for 21 years, after 21 years in the Navy. Louie asks about Whip’s brother Vic, “the one that makes a lot of noise,” and learns he’s over at Northview. This segment highlights loyalty and long‑term relationships between the LaRosa family and their employees.

chapters.title: Crowd Arrivals, Guest Portraits, and Bar Socializing
chapters.summary: As more guests arrive, Louie roams the room capturing couples and small groups in front of Christmas trees, balloon clusters, and the bar. He films three women by the balloons, an older man in an apron (likely kitchen staff), and various couples and groups at the bar and in the dining room. Many of these interactions are brief, with Louie asking for names or simply capturing smiles and greetings. The visuals show a mix of LaRosa employees, spouses, and friends, dressed in late‑1980s holiday attire, mingling, drinking, and chatting while the earlier food narration continues as voice‑over in parts. This builds a sense of a close‑knit, semi‑formal corporate family gathering.

chapters.title: Office & State/Bank Staff: Quick Interviews and Complaints
chapters.summary: Louie moves into more rapid‑fire introductions. He films Regina (Gina Carter), who says she works in the office as a secretary and jokes she thought Louie was working for the state police because he was spotlighting the bar. He calls over Pat, teasing that she’s important because he always calls his checks in late to her; she gives her name for the camera. Jimmy Dwine introduces himself and says he’s there for the celebration. Lois LaRosa appears and is identified. Louie jokingly interrogates “Mr. Bacastro” for his name, Social Security number, and prison number, then asks if he paid his taxes; Bacastro jokes that’s why he’s smiling. Louie films Johnny B. and Mary N. Gotti, calling them celebrities and wishing them happy holidays from Louie and Nancy Ellis. He also records Gary and some ladies, wishing them happy holidays and joking about Gary’s driving. This chapter shows Louie using humor to document the extended network of business and state/banking contacts around the LaRosa organization.

chapters.title: Mr. LaRosa’s On‑Camera Greeting & Gratitude
chapters.summary: Louie turns the camera on Mr. LaRosa (James D.) for a brief statement. Louie says he’s glad to be there for the annual holiday and invites Mr. LaRosa to say a few words. James D. replies that he’s glad all his friends are there—people they do business with and people who work with them in the company. He notes the nice layout of food, that everybody is in good spirits, and that it looks like it’s going to be a fine party. Louie thanks Nancy for allowing him to film, jokes again about “no charge” on his side, and asks about the food; James D. says Louie can have all he wants, “there’s no charge.” They exchange Merry Christmas wishes. This is the clearest expression of the host’s gratitude and the party’s purpose.

chapters.title: More Guests, Light Refusals, and Closing Dining Shots
chapters.summary: Louie continues to capture guests: Linda Brady explains they’re there to celebrate the annual Christmas dinner/reception with the fuel company; Louie wishes Merry Christmas. He interviews Bill Belcher, who gives his name and hints at his professional role but demurs on details. One guest asks Louie not to take their picture, and he respects the request. Louie asks someone named Jim if the food is good. The camera then shows buffet lines, bar clusters, and couples posing by the Christmas tree. The final shots in this block show guests seated at tables eating and drinking, with ambient chatter and clinking dishes, before the tape briefly cuts to black, indicating a pause or end of this reel.

chapters.title: Audio‑Only Recap of Buffet Description (Black Frames)
chapters.summary: The last portion consists of black frames with continuous audio from Louie and Raymond’s earlier introduction and buffet walkthrough. Louie again identifies himself, the date (12‑15‑89), the location (Nona Maria’s), and praises Raymond Priscillo’s food as a “10 out of 10.” The off‑camera guide repeats the detailed description of the Mexican variety, potato salad, vegetable dip, crackers, fresh crab dip made from snow crabs, hollowed‑out pumpernickel with spinach dip, cheeses, and shrimp, then transitions to the sweets table with homemade and Italian cookies. The visuals are missing (likely a transfer issue), but the audio reinforces the centrality of food and hospitality to the event.

highlights.title: Louie’s Self‑Introduction as “Film Director & Producer”
highlights.description: Louie Ellis appears in a red blazer beside a director’s chair labeled with his name, introducing himself as “your film director and producer,” blessing the audience, and rating the food a perfect 10 while timestamping the event as 12‑15‑89 around 2 a.m.

highlights.title: Chef Raymond’s Detailed Buffet Tour
highlights.description: Addressing “Uncle Louis,” Raymond walks through the cold table, describing Mexican appetizers, potato salad, vegetable dip, snow crab dip, pumpernickel spinach dip, multiple cheeses, and shrimp, while Louie jokes about being fed so he doesn’t “stain anything.”

highlights.title: Jimmy LaRosa on the Purpose of the Party
highlights.description: Jimmy LaRosa, with his wife beside him, explains that the Christmas party is for their staff and all the friends they’ve worked with all year, and that they’re just getting started. Louie teases him about being one‑third of the organization and about Louie being the only non‑paid member.
characters_involved: Jimmy LaRosa (Jimmy Joe / Jimmy Joe LaRosa)

highlights.title: Whip Gabriel’s 21 Years with the LaRosas
highlights.description: Retiree Whip Gabriel, sitting with his wife Julie, shares that they’ve been married 46 years and that he worked 21 years for the LaRosas after 21 years in the Navy, underscoring long‑term loyalty to the family business.

highlights.title: Mr. LaRosa’s Host Message
highlights.description: James D. LaRosa thanks his friends, business partners, and employees for coming, praises the food layout, notes everyone is in good spirits, and says it looks like it’s going to be a fine party. He tells Louie he can have all the food he wants, “no charge,” as they exchange Merry Christmas wishes.

highlights.title: Louie’s Mock Interrogation of Mr. Bacastro
highlights.description: Louie jokingly asks Mr. Bacastro for his name, Social Security number, and prison number, then asks if he paid his taxes. Bacastro quips that’s why he’s smiling this year, turning the mock interrogation into a playful tax joke.

highlights.title: Johnny B. & Mary N. Gotti as “Celebrities”
highlights.description: Louie films Johnny B. and Mary N. Gotti, saying he was instructed to take pictures of all the celebrities. He and Nancy Ellis wish them happy holidays on camera, treating them as honored guests.

quotes.text: This is Louis Ellis, your film director and producer. Tonight is the annual Christmas party by the La Rosa Corporation held at the Nona Maria's restaurant.
quotes.speaker: Louis (Louie) Ellis
quotes.context: On‑camera introduction, establishing himself and the event at the very start of the tape.

quotes.text: And the food is being prepared by that one and only Raymond Priscillo. So I want to say the food was good.
quotes.speaker: Louis (Louie) Ellis
quotes.context: Introductory narration praising the chef and setting up the focus on the buffet.

quotes.text: And God bless you all. And we're going to rate that food 1 to 10 and I rate it number 10. How about that?
quotes.speaker: Louis (Louie) Ellis
quotes.context: Louie’s warm sign‑off and humorous endorsement of the meal during his opening remarks.

quotes.text: It's 12, 15, 89. It's almost 2 o'clock. And we're waiting for the crowd.
quotes.speaker: Louis (Louie) Ellis
quotes.context: Louie timestamps the footage and notes that guests have not fully arrived yet.

quotes.text: Uncle Louis? Yes sir? Let me tell you what we have. We'll start down the line. This is a little Mexican variety here. We've got everything from the piccata sauce all the way down to some jalapeno peppers.
quotes.speaker: Raymond Priscillo
quotes.context: Chef/host begins a guided tour of the buffet, addressing Louie as “Uncle Louis.”

quotes.text: We've got a hollowed out crusty pumpernickel with a spinach dip.
quotes.speaker: Raymond Priscillo
quotes.context: Describing one of the centerpiece appetizer presentations on the cold table.

quotes.text: And since you haven't eaten today, we better give you a little bit.
quotes.speaker: Raymond Priscillo
quotes.context: Playfully offering Louie some food while showing the bread bowl and dip.

quotes.text: The only reason you gave it to me is you didn't want me to stain anything.
quotes.speaker: Louis (Louie) Ellis
quotes.context: Louie jokes back after being given a sample from the buffet.

quotes.text: And then we've got three different kinds of cheese here. We've got jalapeno pepper cheese, a sharp cheese, and a mozzarella. And then you've got some baby Lorraine Swiss with Kobe Longhorn. And then we have some gorgeous shrimp. Probably the prettiest shrimp I've seen in years.
quotes.speaker: Raymond Priscillo
quotes.context: Continuing the detailed rundown of the cold table and seafood display.

quotes.text: Well, actually, this is one loaf of bread. That's one loaf of very, very good crusty bread. It was given to Mr. La Rosa by a fellow countryman of his, Frank T. Chargerot, of Country Club Bakery in Fairmont.
quotes.speaker: Raymond Priscillo
quotes.context: Explaining the origin and significance of the large braided loaf presented at the party.

quotes.text: Only at Easter would that happen.
quotes.speaker: Raymond Priscillo
quotes.context: Responding jokingly when Louie asks if there’s an egg in each hump of the braided bread.

quotes.text: We have the master carving out the turkey. That's a smoked turkey. Oh, it is? Well, how about that? Raymond has the best.
quotes.speaker: Louis (Louie) Ellis
quotes.context: Narrating at the carving station while praising Raymond’s smoked turkey.

quotes.text: We're having our staff and all of our friends in today who we've worked with all year and we're just getting started.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa (Jimmy Joe / Jimmy Joe LaRosa)
quotes.context: Jimmy explains the purpose of the Christmas party while on camera with his wife.

quotes.text: And you are this organization, right? I'm part of it. And this is the other part? James D's another one? That's right. One third.
quotes.speaker: Louis (Louie) Ellis and Jimmy LaRosa (Jimmy Joe / Jimmy Joe LaRosa)
quotes.context: Louie teases Jimmy about being the organization; Jimmy clarifies he’s one‑third along with James D.

quotes.text: As I always tell your dad, I'm the only non‑paid member of this organization.
quotes.speaker: Louis (Louie) Ellis
quotes.context: Louie jokes about his unofficial role with the LaRosa company.

quotes.text: Well, I heard you've been being paid lately. Well, I think I might start keeping the company then.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa (Jimmy Joe / Jimmy Joe LaRosa) and Louis (Louie) Ellis
quotes.context: Jimmy counters Louie’s joke about not being paid; Louie responds that he’ll start keeping the company if that’s true.

quotes.text: Whip, you are retired. Is that correct? Right. And you did work for? The Roses. How many years? 21. Oh, my goodness. That's great. 21 before that with the Navy.
quotes.speaker: Louis (Louie) Ellis and Whip Gabriel
quotes.context: Louie interviews retiree Whip Gabriel about his years with the LaRosas and his Navy service.

quotes.text: I'm Mike Renzelli. Yes sir. And are you related to Louie Rhoda? Louie Rhoda's son‑in‑law. This is where I got my experience. Okay. Well I tell you you couldn't have had a better teacher. He's the best. He's the best.
quotes.speaker: Mike Renzelli and Louis (Louie) Ellis
quotes.context: Louie introduces the bartender and draws out his connection to Louie Rhoda, praising Rhoda as a teacher.

quotes.text: I'm Linda Brady, and we're here to celebrate our annual Christmas dinner, a reception with the fuel company.
quotes.speaker: Linda Brady
quotes.context: Linda explains the nature of the gathering during a brief on‑camera introduction.

quotes.text: Yes, I'm glad that all my friends are here today. We do business with people that work with us in the company. It seems like we have a nice layout of food. Beautiful. Everybody's in good spirits. Looks like it's going to be a fine party.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Mr. LaRosa gives his host’s message about the party, the guests, and the food.

quotes.text: And Mr. LaRosa, I've always said on this side there's no charge. Now what about the food as far as I'm concerned? Yes, I think you can have all you want. There's no charge.
quotes.speaker: Louis (Louie) Ellis and James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Louie jokes about “no charge” on his side; James D. assures him the food is free for him as well.

quotes.text: I'm Bill Belcher. And you're with—? Oh, I am. Well, I have a case here. Okay. All right, that's all I can tell you.
quotes.speaker: Bill Belcher and Louis (Louie) Ellis
quotes.context: A guest, Bill Belcher, gives his name but jokingly withholds details about his work, adding to the light tone.

9-1-90_Friends_of_James_D__s_Dinner_at_N.title: Florida Friends Party & Pool Exhibition for James D. LaRosa
9-1-90_Friends_of_James_D__s_Dinner_at_N.content_type: family gathering / social event at home & clubhouse (with billiards exhibition)
9-1-90_Friends_of_James_D__s_Dinner_at_N.summary: This tape is a home‑movie style record that Louie Ellis (“film director and producer”) and his wife Nancy made specifically for James D. (“Papa Jim”) LaRosa and Jimmy Joe LaRosa. It documents an Italian‑American friends’ reunion built around food, storytelling, and a pool/billiards get‑together, likely tied to the Italian Festival and the Pete Dye Golf Club era. The footage moves from a luncheon with elaborate Italian dishes and guest roll‑call, to outdoor mingling at the LaRosa home, and then into a basement/game room where legendary pool champion Willie Mosconi gives an informal exhibition against local friends and family, including Jimmy Jr. The through‑line is friendship, loyalty, and gratitude to James D. for hosting his Florida and out‑of‑state friends year after year.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.description: Older Italian‑American man, central host of the luncheon and home gathering. He repeatedly says he has all his good friends from Florida visiting and that he looks forward to it every year. Seen at the luncheon table and later at home and in the pool room.

characters.name: Jimmy (Jimmy Joe) LaRosa Jr.
characters.description: James D.’s son, referenced as Jimmy Joe / Jimmy Jr. He appears at the party and in the pool room, is challenged to play Willie Mosconi, and is teased about ‘sleeping in the tent’ if he loses.

characters.name: Louie Ellis
characters.description: Older friend of the LaRosas who shot this tape. Opens the video sitting in a director’s chair labeled “FILM DIRECTOR & PRODUCER LOUIS R. ELLIS,” dedicating the tape to James D. and Jimmy Joe. Roams the room interviewing guests, narrating food, and later narrating the pool game. Often signs off as the ‘film director and producer.’

characters.name: Nancy Ellis
characters.description: Louie’s wife, referenced in Louie’s opening and closing thanks (“from Louie and Nancy”). She is not clearly seen speaking but is part of the couple gifting the tape.

characters.name: ‘Sheriff’ (Florida friend)
characters.description: Older man in light shirt who gives a long, heartfelt roll‑call of friends from California, Florida, North Carolina, etc., and thanks Jimmy LaRosa. He is repeatedly addressed as ‘Sheriff’ and stands at the luncheon and later in the game room. Not a law‑enforcement official here, just a nickname.

characters.name: Willie Mosconi
characters.description: Introduced explicitly as “the great Willie Mosconi.” Older man in vest and shirt, holding a cue, giving a short on‑camera comment about playing the Sheriff 35 years earlier and then performing shots in the pool room. The Sheriff and James D. both refer to him by name.

characters.name: Frank (storyteller from Miami)
characters.description: Older Italian‑American man from Florida who delivers long, animated monologues about stealing coal, Irish cops, undertaker work, the FBI’s Italian founder, and George Washington being ‘Italian.’ He is addressed as Frank and is clearly a central storyteller at the luncheon.

characters.name: Raymond (chef/caterer)
characters.description: Man in the kitchen/buffet area who explains the Italian dishes for the luncheon (tomato salad with Louie’s basil, sausage and peppers, shrimp a la Grelle Romeo, stuffed peppers, artichokes, baked ziti).

characters.name: Unidentified professional chef(s)
characters.description: Several chefs in tall toques and white coats appear in the kitchen, smiling and speaking briefly to camera about preparing Italian specialties for Mr. LaRosa’s friends and the Italian Festival.

characters.name: Vice Mayor Louie Aquino
characters.description: Identified on camera as ‘the Vice Mayor, Louie Aquino.’ He praises the food (anchovies, peppers, prosciutto, cheese) and appears at the luncheon as a friend of James D.

characters.name: Various Florida & out‑of‑state friends (Vito & Ron Verga, Whitey Bridges, Benny Lorenzo, Frank Luccio, etc.)
characters.description: Named by the Sheriff and Louie: Vito and Ron Verga (Miami), Whitey Bridges (originally North Carolina, now Miami/Hialeah), Benny Lorenzo (Lorenzo’s Restaurant, North Miami), Frank Luccio (Miami), James Gwynn (California), Buzz Bozzini (lifelong buddy), and others. They appear at tables and in the pool room, often being interviewed about where they’re from and how many times they’ve visited West Virginia.

characters.name: Gene Glenn
characters.description: Introduces himself as Gene Glenn, Emory’s nephew, born in Clarksburg, now from Torrance, California. Talks about moving west and loving West Virginia, maybe retiring there.

characters.name: Julian (LaRosa cousin)
characters.description: Introduces himself as Julian, first cousin to Jim LaRosa (their mothers were sisters). Appears at the luncheon.

characters.name: Steve Konya & son
characters.description: Introduce themselves as Steve Konya and his son, from Fairmont. Recall meeting Jimmy Joe at a restaurant and coming ‘to taste this good food.’

characters.name: Steve (coal‑miner / pool player)
characters.description: Referred to as ‘my good friend Steve Konya’ in one place and ‘Steve’ in the pool context; James D. says Steve wanted to be the next Willie Mosconi but became a coal miner. He is backed to play Willie in the pool exhibition.

characters.name: Emory (Emory Fazenda / Emory Patia)
characters.description: Mentioned by Gene Glenn as his uncle (Emory Fazenda/Patia). Also addressed casually (“Hey Emory, you like Florida?”) during the home gathering.

characters.name: Various women guests (Mrs. Aquinas, Mrs. Marscotti, others)
characters.description: Women seated at tables and walking on the lawn. Louie repeatedly asks them their names and where they’re from (Philadelphia vs. Florida). They are part of the extended social circle.

chapters.title: 1. Louie’s Dedication & Sheriff’s Roll‑Call at the Luncheon
chapters.summary: The tape opens with Louie Ellis seated in a director’s chair labeled “FILM DIRECTOR & PRODUCER LOUIS R. ELLIS,” addressing the camera and dedicating the film to James D. and Jimmy Joe LaRosa. He explains that this is the party they gave for their friends. The camera then roams an indoor banquet room where tables are set and a large buffet of Italian food is laid out. Louie prompts a guest nicknamed ‘Sheriff’ to speak. The Sheriff delivers a long, heartfelt roll‑call of his ‘good friends’ from California and Florida: James Gwynn, Vito and Ron Verga, Buzz Bozzini, Frank Luccio, Whitey Bridges, Benny Lorenzo (of Lorenzo’s Restaurant), and others. He jokes about seeing ‘Willie Marconi’ (correcting to Mosconi) escorted by Louie Aquino’s wife, and repeatedly thanks Jimmy LaRosa for hosting such a great occasion where they can ‘break bread’ together. Louie moves table to table, interviewing women (Mrs. Aquinas, Mrs. Marscotti) and men, asking where they’re from (Florida vs. Philadelphia) and capturing candid reactions. James D. appears on camera, explaining that he has all his good friends from Florida visiting and that he looks forward to it every year.
characters_present: Various Florida & out‑of‑state friends (Vito & Ron Verga, Whitey Bridges, Benny Lorenzo, Frank Luccio, etc.)
Various women guests (Mrs. Aquinas, Mrs. Marscotti, others)

chapters.title: 2. Kitchen Tour & Italian Feast for Mr. LaRosa’s Friends
chapters.summary: Louie shifts to the kitchen and buffet line. Chef Raymond and other white‑hatted chefs proudly describe the menu prepared for Mr. LaRosa’s Italian friends and the Italian Festival: tomato salad with fresh basil (grown by Louie Ellis), sausage and hot peppers, shrimp a la Grelle Romeo, stuffed hot peppers, stuffed artichokes, and baked ziti. Louie jokes about ‘sneaking up’ on the chef and promises to edit out any embarrassing moments. The chefs emphasize that everything is Italian specialties for Mr. LaRosa’s guests. Back in the dining room, Louie continues to film the long banquet table, capturing older men seated under a mural, toasts being made, and the Sheriff’s speech wrapping up with the line about not trading old friends for new ones. The mood is warm and proud, with food as a central expression of hospitality.
characters_present: Various Florida & out‑of‑state friends (Vito & Ron Verga, Whitey Bridges, Benny Lorenzo, Frank Luccio, etc.)

chapters.title: 3. Stories of West Virginia, California & Growing Up Italian
chapters.summary: Louie conducts a series of sit‑down interviews at the luncheon tables. Gene Glenn introduces himself as Emory’s nephew, born in Clarksburg’s St. Mary’s Hospital, now living in Torrance, California. He recalls moving west after the war and says he loves West Virginia and might retire there. A cousin Julian explains he is Jim LaRosa’s first cousin (their mothers were sisters). Steve Konya and his son from Fairmont recall meeting Jimmy Joe at a restaurant and coming ‘to taste this good food.’ The Sheriff and others continue to talk about their backgrounds. Then Frank, an older Italian‑American friend from Florida, launches into long, animated monologues: childhood in New York tenements, stealing coal from freight trains out of necessity, Irish cops beating kids in pool rooms, working for an undertaker and overcoming his fear of coffins, and being a pinweight boxing champ at St. Agnes Convent. He jokes about the FBI being founded by an Italian (Charles Bonaparte) and riffs on George Washington being ‘Italian’ in mock‑Italian phrases. Louie notes he has ‘videoed 90%’ of what Frank said and jokes not to give it to the FBI. The tone is nostalgic, comic, and deeply Italian‑American.
characters_present: Various Florida & out‑of‑state friends (Vito & Ron Verga, Whitey Bridges, Benny Lorenzo, Frank Luccio, etc.)

chapters.title: 4. Transition to the LaRosa Home: Lawn Gathering & Scenic Grounds
chapters.summary: The setting shifts from the restaurant/club banquet room to the LaRosa home, a large brick house with multiple white‑railed balconies overlooking a manicured lawn and rolling hills. Guests arrive in cars, walk across the grass, and are greeted by James D. in his plaid shirt. Louie films James D. chatting with two women on the lawn and welcoming groups of older men from Florida and other states. The camera then lingers on the property: stone walls, mature trees, a shed, and fairway‑like grass with distant hills, visually tying this social world to the West Virginia landscape that would later host the Pete Dye Golf Club. The house and grounds are presented almost like a private clubhouse, underscoring James D.’s success and hospitality.
characters_present: Various Florida & out‑of‑state friends (Vito & Ron Verga, Whitey Bridges, Benny Lorenzo, Frank Luccio, etc.)
Various women guests (Mrs. Aquinas, Mrs. Marscotti, others)

chapters.title: 5. Introducing Willie Mosconi & Inviting Everyone to the Pool Exhibition
chapters.summary: Back indoors, likely at or near the LaRosa home, Louie films James D. and the Sheriff standing together. The Sheriff formally introduces ‘the great Willie Mosconi’ and notes he played Willie 35 years ago and that Willie ‘hasn’t slowed down.’ Willie himself speaks briefly, joking that the Sheriff is no different now than decades ago. James D. then addresses the room, saying he’s thrilled his Florida friends come every year and teasing that next year he might have to charge them because the club will be open for business. He challenges Willie to a pool game at his son’s house and says he’s backing his friend Steve, who once wanted to be the next Willie Mosconi but became a coal miner instead. James D. invites everyone to his son’s house for a ‘two‑minute exhibition’ by Willie, with the only rule being no smoking because his daughter‑in‑law just had a baby. He jokes about riding with the mayor and tickets costing five dollars. The segment ends with a toast of ‘bon appétit’ and more of Frank’s humorous storytelling about priests, Ireland, and his time in an orphanage.
characters_present: Various Florida & out‑of‑state friends (Vito & Ron Verga, Whitey Bridges, Benny Lorenzo, Frank Luccio, etc.)

chapters.title: 6. Arrival at Jimmy Jr.’s House & Setting Up the Pool Room
chapters.summary: The group moves to Jimmy Jr.’s house, where a wood‑paneled basement or game room houses a tan‑felt pool table under a stained‑glass light, with a mounted fish on the wall. Men greet each other at the sliding glass doors, shake hands, and pet a large dog. Louie’s camera captures James D., Jimmy Jr., Steve, and several Florida friends mingling near a home bar. The pool table is racked, and Willie Mosconi, in a light sweater vest and shirt, begins setting up shots. Younger men in striped shirts and white pants stand by with cues, while older men in plaid shirts and red polos sit and watch. Louie’s narration and the Sheriff’s earlier references make clear this is the promised exhibition at Jimmy’s house.
characters_present: Various Florida & out‑of‑state friends (Vito & Ron Verga, Whitey Bridges, Benny Lorenzo, Frank Luccio, etc.)

chapters.title: 7. Willie Mosconi’s Informal Exhibition & Jimmy Jr.’s Challenge
chapters.summary: In the pool room, Willie Mosconi and the local players begin a series of games, mostly nine‑ball. Louie and others provide a running commentary: calling shots, teasing about ‘two balls in hand,’ and joking that ‘the table is off’ or ‘you play with what’s there.’ Jimmy Jr. is urged to ‘go for the nine’ and not to choke. Spectators shout encouragement: ‘Come on Jim, don’t miss,’ ‘We’ll take a picture of you if you beat Willie.’ There is good‑natured heckling about soft racks, hustling, and who will be ‘sleeping in the tent’ if they lose. The Sheriff and Louie act as impromptu announcers, turning the basement into a mock TV broadcast from ‘the LaRosa’s baseball team, Bristol, West Virginia.’ The mood is boisterous and competitive but affectionate, with everyone clearly in awe of Willie’s skill and enjoying the chance to play against him.
characters_present: Various Florida & out‑of‑state friends (Vito & Ron Verga, Whitey Bridges, Benny Lorenzo, Frank Luccio, etc.)

chapters.title: 8. Extended Pool Room Banter, Hustling & Storytelling
chapters.summary: The pool games continue with rotating shooters: Willie, Steve, Jimmy Jr., and others. The Sheriff and Louie keep up a stream of commentary: calling out ‘two ball, Willie,’ ‘bank the three,’ ‘skin it, Sheriff,’ and predicting scratches. There is constant joking about ‘two balls in hand,’ ‘party’s over,’ and who is behind the eight‑ball. Between shots, Frank and others slip in more stories—about running 30 balls on Willie in Clarksburg, about being chased around the block with no money, and about being laughed at when he got up to play the piano but making people cry when he shot pool. The atmosphere is that of a private, late‑night pool hall among old friends, but in a family basement. The camera stays mostly on the table and torsos, emphasizing the game and the camaraderie rather than formal portraits.
characters_present: Various Florida & out‑of‑state friends (Vito & Ron Verga, Whitey Bridges, Benny Lorenzo, Frank Luccio, etc.)

chapters.title: 9. Closing Thanks from Louie & Nancy to James D.
chapters.summary: As the pool games wind down, an older gray‑haired man jokes about having ‘one bad eye and the other…’ and missing by ‘19 inches,’ then says he meant to play it safe. Willie is told he can put the ball anywhere he wants. After a few more shots and laughs, Louie steps back into his ‘film director’ role and delivers a closing message directly to James D.: with that smile of his, from friends north, south, east, and west, and from his family and relatives, ‘Louie and Nancy’ want to thank him for everything, say God bless you, and ‘we love you.’ He signs off as ‘your film director and producer, Louie Ellis.’ This frames the entire tape as a love letter from the Ellis couple and the Florida friends to James D. and Jimmy Joe, celebrating years of friendship and hospitality.
characters_present: Various Florida & out‑of‑state friends (Vito & Ron Verga, Whitey Bridges, Benny Lorenzo, Frank Luccio, etc.)

highlights.title: Louie’s On‑Camera Dedication in the Director’s Chair
highlights.description: Louie Ellis sits in a red blazer in a director’s chair embroidered “FILM DIRECTOR & PRODUCER LOUIS R. ELLIS,” holding a camera and speaking directly to James D. and Jimmy Joe LaRosa, explaining that this tape was made especially for them to remember the party they gave for their friends.

highlights.title: Sheriff’s Roll‑Call of Friends from Across the Country
highlights.description: At the luncheon, the man nicknamed ‘Sheriff’ delivers a long, heartfelt list of his friends from California, Florida, North Carolina, and beyond, naming James Gwynn, Vito and Ron Verga, Buzz Bozzini, Frank Luccio, Whitey Bridges, and Benny Lorenzo, and thanking Jimmy LaRosa for bringing them together to ‘break bread.’
characters_involved: Various Florida & out‑of‑state friends (Vito & Ron Verga, Whitey Bridges, Benny Lorenzo, Frank Luccio, etc.)

highlights.title: Raymond’s Tour of the Italian Buffet
highlights.description: Chef Raymond stands at the buffet and proudly describes the Italian dishes prepared for Mr. LaRosa’s friends: tomato salad with Louie’s basil, sausage and hot peppers, shrimp a la Grelle Romeo, stuffed hot peppers, stuffed artichokes, and baked ziti. Louie thanks him and jokes about being asked to ‘video everybody.’

highlights.title: Frank’s Wild Orphanage & FBI Monologue
highlights.description: Frank, an older Italian‑American friend, tells a long, animated story about being in an orphan home, boxing Irish kids, getting beaten by Irish cops, working for an undertaker, and then claims Italians founded the FBI (Charles Bonaparte) and jokes that if Italians really were mafiosi they’d ‘straighten this country out one, two, three.’ Louie remarks he’s recorded 90% of it and jokes not to give it to the FBI.

highlights.title: James D. Invites Everyone to Willie Mosconi’s Exhibition
highlights.description: James D. stands at the luncheon and tells his Florida friends he’s thrilled they come every year. He then announces he has challenged Willie Mosconi to a pool game at his son’s house, backing his friend Steve, who once wanted to be the next Willie but became a coal miner. He invites everyone to come watch a ‘two‑minute exhibition’ and jokes about no smoking because his daughter‑in‑law just had a baby.

highlights.title: Willie Mosconi’s On‑Camera Introduction
highlights.description: In a brief on‑camera moment, the Sheriff introduces ‘the great Willie Mosconi’ and Willie remarks that he played the Sheriff 35 years ago and that the Sheriff ‘hasn’t slowed down.’ It quietly confirms that the legendary pool champion is present and about to play in the LaRosa basement.

highlights.title: Basement Pool Room Turns into a Mock TV Broadcast
highlights.description: In Jimmy Jr.’s wood‑paneled pool room, as Willie and the locals play nine‑ball, the Sheriff and Louie provide a running commentary, calling shots, teasing about ‘two balls in hand,’ and joking that they’re broadcasting from ‘the LaRosa’s baseball team, Bristol, West Virginia.’ Spectators shout ‘Don’t choke, Jim!’ and promise to take a picture if he beats Willie.

highlights.title: James D.’s Simple Statement of Why This Matters
highlights.description: Asked why he’s so happy, James D. replies that he has all his good friends from Florida visiting and that he looks forward to it every year. It’s a concise expression of the emotional core of the gathering.

highlights.title: Louie & Nancy’s Closing Thank‑You to James D.
highlights.description: After the last pool shots, Louie speaks directly to James D., saying that from his friends north, south, east, and west, and from his family and relatives, ‘Louie and Nancy’ thank him for everything, say God bless you, and ‘we love you.’ He signs off as ‘your film director and producer, Louie Ellis.’

quotes.text: Well, it's your film director and producer, and this tape was made special for you, James D. and Jimmy Joe La Rosa. This is the party that we all enjoyed so much that you gave for your friends and all of us. Thank you. I'm Louie and Nancy. God bless you both and your family.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Opening dedication while seated in a director’s chair, explaining the purpose of the tape.

quotes.text: Well, today I've got all my good friends. I've got all my good friends from California, Florida. I've got James Gwynn from California. I've got Vito Verga from Miami, Florida, along with his brother, Ron Verga… My good friend Whitey Bridges… my good friend Benny Lorenzo, who has Lorenzo's Restaurant in North Miami… Anytime when you get good friends, you can make friends like this and break bread, it's great.
quotes.speaker: ‘Sheriff’ (Florida friend)
quotes.context: Standing at the luncheon, giving a roll‑call of out‑of‑town friends and thanking Jimmy LaRosa.

quotes.text: I got all my good friends from Florida here to visit with me. I look forward to it every year.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Responding on camera when Louie asks why he’s so happy at the luncheon and later at the home gathering.

quotes.text: Today for the Italian Festival for some friends of Mr. LaRosa, we've done all Italian specialties, and we hope you enjoy it.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified chef
quotes.context: In the kitchen, explaining the menu prepared for Mr. LaRosa’s friends and the Italian Festival.

quotes.text: You don't trade your old friends for a friend.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified older guest (likely Sheriff or Frank)
quotes.context: At the luncheon, offering a ‘slogan’ about loyalty to old friends while reminiscing.

quotes.text: We lived in tenement houses… We used to go to the freight trains and steal coal… We done nothing to hurt anybody. We done it because of necessity. That's a hell of a word, isn't it?
quotes.speaker: Frank (storyteller from Miami)
quotes.context: Telling childhood stories about growing up poor in New York and stealing coal out of necessity.

quotes.text: Who do you think founded the FBI, the Federal Bureau of Investigation? The Italians. You bet your sweet platoon. His name was Charles Bonaparte… People don't realize that. They call us all mafiosos. I wish we were mafiosos. We'd straighten this country out one, two, three.
quotes.speaker: Frank (storyteller from Miami)
quotes.context: Continuing his humorous monologue about Italian pride and American institutions.

quotes.text: I'm just thrilled. I look forward to it now, so you got to come back every year. And next year I might have to charge you because we'll be open for business… I challenged Willie to a pool game… If he doesn't beat Willie, then you're in a lot of trouble… He thought he was going to be the next Willie Mosconi, but he didn't make it, so he took up coal mining. Not bad.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Addressing his Florida friends at the luncheon, inviting them to the pool exhibition at his son’s house and teasing Steve.

quotes.text: No, I'm here because I played this guy 35 years ago. And he's no different now than he was 35 years ago. He's still a stat in the chair. He never slowed down.
quotes.speaker: Willie Mosconi
quotes.context: On‑camera comment after being introduced as ‘the great Willie Mosconi,’ referring to playing the Sheriff decades earlier.

quotes.text: Hey, Sheriff, this tape's only two hours long.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis (or another off‑camera friend)
quotes.context: Lightly teasing the Sheriff to wrap up his long list of introductions and thanks.

quotes.text: You don't learn that in school. You learn that on the street.
quotes.speaker: Frank (storyteller from Miami)
quotes.context: Explaining his rough upbringing and street smarts while telling stories about judges and fights.

quotes.text: Frank, I have videoed 90% of what you've said… Don't give it to the FBI.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Reacting to Frank’s long, colorful monologue about crime, cops, and the FBI.

quotes.text: I'm going to show us a little bit of your skill here on the lake. We've got a little time… There's no smoking in the house at all… Other than that, it's about ten minutes from here.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Inviting guests to his son’s house for Willie’s pool exhibition and setting house rules.

quotes.text: Come on Jim. Don't choke, Jim. Don't choke. Come on, Jim… We'll take a picture of you if you beat Willie.
quotes.speaker: Various spectators (Sheriff / friends)
quotes.context: Shouting encouragement and teasing Jimmy Jr. during a nine‑ball game against Willie Mosconi in the basement.

quotes.text: Well, Jim, with that smile of yours, from your friends south, north, east, west, your family, your relatives, Louie and Nancy, we all want to thank you for everything. God bless you and we love you. Keep the good work up. And this is your film director and producer, Louie Ellis.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Closing the tape with a direct message of thanks and love to James D. LaRosa after the pool games.

Aug_1985_PDGC_Construction_Cleaning_out_.title: Simpson Creek Restoration & Early Course Construction (August 1985)
Aug_1985_PDGC_Construction_Cleaning_out_.content_type: Construction footage and on‑site narrated walkthrough
Aug_1985_PDGC_Construction_Cleaning_out_.summary: Archival footage from August 1985 documents early construction at the future Pete Dye Golf Club, focused on dredging and reshaping Simpson Creek and adjacent hillsides. Jimmy LaRosa (on camera and in voiceover) explains how end loaders, backhoes, scrapers, and multiple bulldozers remove decades of sediment, debris, and mine‑polluted water, then reuse the material to soften steep banks, build walls, and prepare sod farms. The footage also shows blasting out old bridge abutments and rock humps, loading shot rock into trucks, towing loaded trucks out of the riverbed with a D6 dozer, and planning for navigable water, boating, fishing, and future golf holes (notably the 18th and 5th). Jimmy repeatedly ties the heavy work to long‑term design goals—natural‑looking, mowable slopes, dramatic water hazards, and a clubhouse overlooking the river—while Louie Ellis films and occasionally appears on audio as the informal documentarian.
