chapters.title: Telecast Opening & Course Introduction
chapters.summary: The Golf Channel opens its coverage of the inaugural Pete Dye West Virginia Classic, introducing Pete Dye Golf Club as a par‑72, 7,200‑yard “mountain retreat” and “hidden treasure” now on the Nationwide Tour schedule. Brian Anderson and Kurt Byram in the booth describe the course as visually spectacular and intimidating, note that it’s the only course bearing Pete Dye’s name, and highlight the reclaimed coal‑mine setting. They introduce key storylines: D.A. Points’ surprising 65, Nick Cassini’s 66, Darron Stiles’ 66, and Australian Paul Gow’s three playoff losses without a win. Early highlight packages show birdies and strong play from Greg Bruckner, Tom Scherrer, Troy Matteson, D.A. Points, Nick Cassini, and Mario Tiziani, while a conditions graphic notes soft greens, light wind, and 70°F temperatures.

chapters.title: Front‑Nine Highlights & Early Scoring
chapters.summary: On‑course reporters Jerry Foltz and Val Skinner join, following groups that include Ryuji Imada, Paul Gow, Scott Gump, Hunter Haas, Franklin Langham, Scott Gutschewski, and others. Highlights show Imada’s precise irons, Gow’s aggressive but erratic play, and Gump’s conservative fairway‑wood strategy. Mario Tiziani birdies the tough par‑3 16th; Bryce Molder continues his hot streak with birdies at 14–16; D.J. Trahan and Ty Tryon are shown taking advantage of drivable par‑4s and reachable par‑5s. The booth notes that soft greens and minimal wind are allowing lower scores than expected, with 40–60 players under par. Leaderboards are repeatedly shown, with D.A. Points at -7, Cassini and Stiles at -6, and a large pack at -3 to -4.

chapters.title: Course Architecture, Coal‑Mine Heritage & LaRosa–Dye Story
chapters.summary: Between live shots and highlights, the booth delves into the course’s 15‑year construction on a reclaimed coal mine. Byram explains that the LaRosa family assembled the land in 1979 and gave Pete Dye unusual creative freedom, resulting in what Dye considers his favorite project. They describe how the owners initially wanted to erase coal‑mining remnants, but Dye insisted on keeping coal gobs, tipples, and shafts, saying he wouldn’t return if they were removed. Camera shots linger on the coal tipple, mine shafts, tunnels, and strip‑mine scars integrated into holes like the par‑3 7th and the dramatic 18th. The commentators emphasize that the LaRosas were in no hurry, wanting every hole to be special, and that the club now has about 500 members from 27 states and five countries, functioning as a national retreat.

chapters.title: Mid‑Round Live Coverage: Key Groups & Scoring Moves
chapters.summary: Live coverage focuses on several feature groups. The Imada–Gow–Gump group is followed closely: Imada hits strong irons but struggles with putts; Gow scrambles for pars with creative recoveries; Gump plays steady, conservative golf. Hunter Haas navigates the picturesque par‑3 7th (reached via a coal‑mine tunnel) and the reachable par‑5 8th, where he lags a long eagle putt. Franklin Langham battles early bogeys but shows touch with pitches and putts at 3, 5, 8, and 9. Scott Gutschewski, the “big man from Omaha,” uses his length to reach par‑5s in two and makes back‑to‑back birdies to reach -2. Bryce Molder continues his run of four straight top‑10s with birdies at 14, 15, and 16. The booth repeatedly notes that all four par‑3s are playing over par and will be difficult every day.

chapters.title: Golf Central Updates: Open Championship & B.C. Open
chapters.summary: Several cutaways to Golf Central in Orlando, hosted by Mike Ritz, provide updates from the 133rd Open Championship at Royal Troon and the PGA Tour’s B.C. Open. Ritz reports Paul Casey and Thomas Levet leading at -5, with Michael Campbell, K.J. Choi, Vijay Singh, Ernie Els, Retief Goosen, John Daly, Tiger Woods, Phil Mickelson, and others at various scores. He also announces the death of former PGA Tour player Jeff Julian from ALS and recalls his courage in playing Q‑School and Tour events after diagnosis. Another graphic shows Nationwide Tour graduates (Jason Bohn, Tom Carter, Lucas Glover, Tommy Tolles, Craig Bowden, Jason Dufner, Ted Purdy, Vaughn Taylor, Blaine McCallister, Tripp Isenhour, Guy Boros) performing well at the B.C. Open, reinforcing the Nationwide Tour as a pipeline to the PGA Tour.

chapters.title: Player Profiles, Trivia & Alumni Stories
chapters.summary: The telecast includes lighter feature content and alumni profiles. Jerry Foltz hosts a “Teed Up” trivia segment with Todd Demsey, asking pop‑culture and golf questions (Eddie Murphy’s character in Trading Places, first internationally famous board game, capital of West Virginia, Masters champion who was 1998 Q‑School medalist, etc.), scoring answers as birdies or bogeys. A profile graphic highlights John Daly’s path from Nationwide Tour (9th on money list) to winning the 1991 PGA and 1995 Open. The booth also discusses other Nationwide alumni like Mark Hensby, who just won on the PGA Tour, and notes his controversial decision to skip the Open Championship. Throughout, they emphasize that many current PGA Tour winners and major champions came through this tour, reinforcing the tagline “where the future is playing now.”

chapters.title: Late‑Afternoon Conditions & Course Philosophy
chapters.summary: As the afternoon wave progresses, Anderson and Byram discuss how soft greens and light winds have made the course more scoreable than locals expected, but note that when it firms up, Pete Dye’s undulating greens will be far more punishing. They explain that the LaRosas gave Dye nearly 15 years and full creative freedom, unusual in golf architecture, and that Dye refused to accept some suggested changes. They describe the 18th as a dramatic finishing par‑4 where players can’t see the green from the fairway, adding psychological difficulty. They also highlight the par‑3 13th with a severe ridge and the par‑3 4th as one of the toughest holes, where three is a good score. Leaderboards show D.A. Points at -7, Cassini and Stiles at -6, and a large pack at -3 to -4, with about 60 players under par. The course’s reclaimed‑mine visuals (coal tipple, shafts, strip‑mine scars) are repeatedly shown and praised as “unique, picturesque, and visually stimulating.”

chapters.title: Ongoing Live Coverage & Scoring Stories
chapters.summary: Live coverage continues to follow key players through the middle and late holes. Hunter Haas navigates bunker‑to‑bunker trouble at 9 but nearly pulls off a “double sandy.” Franklin Langham uses his putting strength from the fringe to save par and later makes his first birdie at 8 to offset earlier bogeys. Scott Gutschewski converts back‑to‑back birdies to reach -2 at the turn. Ryuji Imada hits strong second shots into par‑5s but struggles to convert eagle and birdie putts, missing several to the right despite working on a straight‑back, straight‑through stroke with a putting track. Paul Gow continues a roller‑coaster round, hitting excellent wedges (e.g., 103 yards at 8) but also finding deep rough and bunkers, “inventing new ugly ways to make par.” Bryce Molder, Hunter Haas, Ty Tryon, and others are shown taking advantage of reachable par‑5s and drivable par‑4s, while the booth notes that afternoon wind is picking up and making scoring slightly tougher than in the morning.

chapters.title: Golf Central Update & Wrap‑Around Context
chapters.summary: Another Golf Central update from Mike Ritz revisits the Open Championship leaderboard, noting that a third player (Alastair Forsyth) has joined Casey and Levet at -5, with Vijay Singh at -3 and big names like Tiger Woods, Davis Love III, and Phil Mickelson at or around par. Ritz recounts Darren Clarke’s double bogey at 18 after going out of bounds. Back at Pete Dye, the booth continues to emphasize the course’s long gestation (land assembled in 1979, course finished in 1994) and the LaRosas’ patience in letting Dye “do exactly what he wanted with every hole.” They reiterate that Dye considered this his favorite project, partly because of that creative freedom. Live shots show Jimmy Walker flirting with Simpson Creek at 18, Hunter Haas nearly holing a bunker shot at 9, and Franklin Langham choosing to putt from the fringe rather than risk a wedge, demonstrating his putting strength. The segment ends with a comprehensive leaderboard rundown, showing players from -7 down through +5 and reinforcing how many Nationwide Tour alumni are now succeeding on the PGA Tour and in majors.

highlights.title: D.A. Points’ 65 Sets the Pace
highlights.description: D.A. Points fires a 7‑under 65 in soft, calm morning conditions, surprising commentators who expected Pete Dye Golf Club to play tougher. His round includes multiple birdies and no major mistakes, establishing the target score for the field.

highlights.title: Greg Bruckner’s Four Straight Birdies and 30 on the Front
highlights.description: Greg Bruckner strings together four consecutive birdies, then hits his second shot at 18 to within a foot and converts to turn in 30 with six birdies and no bogeys. The booth highlights his aggressive drive down the left near the hazard and precise approach.

highlights.title: Mario Tiziani’s Birdie at the Brutal 16th
highlights.description: Mario Tiziani, a Monday qualifier and Steve Stricker’s brother‑in‑law, hits a strong tee shot on the 209‑yard par‑3 16th and holes the uphill birdie putt, briefly reaching -5 before a bogey‑bogey finish. The booth notes the hole can be stretched to 240+ yards and praises his 20 putts through 16 holes.

highlights.title: Scott Gutschewski’s Power and Touch
highlights.description: Described as a “corn‑fed Nebraskan” with a 305‑yard average, Gutschewski unleashes long drives on par‑5s, then shows finesse with wedges and putts. He reaches the par‑5 8th in two, nearly makes eagle, and converts back‑to‑back birdies at 8 and 9 to reach -2 at the turn.

highlights.title: Bryce Molder’s Run of Four Straight Top‑10s
highlights.description: Bryce Molder, who started the year with no status, is highlighted for playing his way onto the tour via Monday qualifiers and sponsor exemptions. He continues his hot streak with birdies at 14, 15, and 16, showing confident wedge play and putting.

highlights.title: Pete Dye’s Coal‑Mine Aesthetic Preserved
highlights.description: The broadcast shows coal tipples, shafts, strip‑mine scars, and a tunnel between the 6th and 7th holes while Byram explains that the LaRosa family wanted to erase the mining remnants, but Pete Dye insisted they be kept, saying he wouldn’t come back otherwise. The result is praised as unique, picturesque, and visually stimulating.

highlights.title: Hunter Haas’ Long Eagle Try at the 8th
highlights.description: From “another zip code” at about 60 feet, Hunter Haas lags an eagle putt on the par‑5 8th that breaks multiple ways. He leaves it just short but secures an easy birdie, prompting praise for his lag putting and body language that shows both frustration and satisfaction.

highlights.title: Franklin Langham’s Fringe Putting Saves
highlights.description: Langham, described as strong with the putter, repeatedly chooses to putt from the fringe rather than chip, including a key up‑and‑down at 9. Val Skinner notes that putting from the short fringe is often the smarter play, and Langham’s touch finally shows after a rusty stretch.

highlights.title: Ryuji Imada’s Aggressive Second at the 8th
highlights.description: From 219 yards on the par‑5 8th, Imada takes an aggressive line with his second shot despite ball‑above‑feet lie and severe right‑to‑left fairway slope. He holds the green in a low spot about 15 feet left of the hole, setting up an eagle chance and showcasing his iron prowess.

highlights.title: Scott Gutschewski’s Back‑to‑Back Birdies to -2
highlights.description: After a solid front nine of mostly pars, Gutschewski makes his first birdie at 8, then hits a wedge to about two feet at the 9th and converts for back‑to‑back birdies, reaching -2. The booth notes he has “plugged along” hitting many good shots and that the birdies finally start to fall.

quotes.text: When you get the developer, the LaRosa family, behind the event like they have, you know it’s going to be a first‑class event, and it definitely is.
quotes.speaker: Kurt Byram
quotes.context: In‑booth discussion early in the telecast about why this inaugural Nationwide Tour event is already viewed as a premier stop.

quotes.text: Pete Dye, it’s the only golf course Pete Dye has designed that bears his name. He believes this is his best work, best collection of holes that he’s ever designed.
quotes.speaker: Brian Anderson
quotes.context: Booth introduction of Pete Dye Golf Club’s uniqueness and Dye’s own view of the course.

quotes.text: It’s very unusual that you would ever give a golf course architect that kind of time and have that kind of patience. But they were in no hurry. They wanted this thing to be special. They wanted Pete Dye to be able to do exactly what he wanted to do with every hole.
quotes.speaker: Kurt Byram
quotes.context: Extended commentary on the LaRosa family’s long‑term commitment and Pete Dye’s creative freedom in building the course.

quotes.text: We sit in sort of a valley where this old coal mining operation was, and that wind swirls around a lot here. It looks to me like he misjudged the wind right there.
quotes.speaker: Val Skinner
quotes.context: On‑course analysis after Brad Ott’s tee shot at the par‑3 13th goes long right, illustrating how the reclaimed mine topography affects play.

quotes.text: Interesting, this golf course, as you mentioned, on an old coal mining operation. And the owners, the LaRosa family, wanted to kind of lose the coal mining aspect, but Pete Dye says, he said, ‘Keep it in there. I want to see the coal gobs and I want to see…’ It is very unique and really, really picturesque and visually stimulating.
quotes.speaker: Kurt Byram
quotes.context: Booth discussion while cameras show coal tipples and shafts behind the 18th green, explaining Dye’s insistence on preserving mining features.

quotes.text: All the par threes are over par on the scoring average. It won’t be just today. It’s going to be every day. These are some really good par threes.
quotes.speaker: Kurt Byram
quotes.context: Commentary on the difficulty of the par‑3s at Pete Dye Golf Club after several players struggle at the 4th and 13th.

quotes.text: He’s inventing new ugly ways to make par today, and he’s going to have his work cut out for him here.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Foltz
quotes.context: On‑course description of Paul Gow scrambling from deep rough and false fronts to save par, highlighting his gritty but erratic play.

quotes.text: You can definitely make a mistake with a sand wedge trying to pitch it, but with this putter you’re going to be somewhere around the hole.
quotes.speaker: Kurt Byram
quotes.context: Booth analysis as Franklin Langham elects to putt from the fringe at the 9th instead of chipping, emphasizing smart short‑game strategy.

quotes.text: Playing the Nationwide Tour to win the PGA Championship the next year, just like that—that’s what this game is all about. Anybody can win. Names don’t mean anything. You’ve got to play golf. You’ve got to get the ball in the hole.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified Nationwide Tour alumnus (voiceover in profile piece about John Daly)
quotes.context: Voiceover in a feature segment about John Daly’s path from the Nationwide Tour to major champion, underscoring the tour’s role as a springboard.

quotes.text: We’ll be thinking of Jeff Julian today on the day that he passes away. Of course it grabbed Bruce Edwards during the Masters earlier this year. So Jeff Julian passes away of ALS today, July 15th.
quotes.speaker: Brian Anderson
quotes.context: Somber moment in the booth as they acknowledge the death of former PGA Tour player Jeff Julian from ALS and reflect on his courage.

themes: Pete Dye’s design philosophy and creative freedom
Reclaimed coal‑mine landscape as course identity
Nationwide Tour as a pipeline to the PGA Tour and majors
Scoring vs. course difficulty (soft greens, wind, par‑3 toughness)
Player perseverance and near‑miss storylines (Paul Gow, Ty Tryon)
Family and developer commitment (LaRosa family’s long project)
Broadcast framing of “future stars” and alumni success
Short‑game strategy and putting on severe Dye greens

Harrison_Co__Chamber_of_Commerce_Citizen.title: Harrison County Chamber of Commerce Dinner – 1995 Citizen & Business Awards (James D. LaRosa Honored)
Harrison_Co__Chamber_of_Commerce_Citizen.content_type: Civic / Chamber of Commerce awards banquet and keynote presentation
Harrison_Co__Chamber_of_Commerce_Citizen.summary: This video documents a 1995 Harrison County Chamber of Commerce annual dinner and awards banquet in Clarksburg/Bridgeport, WV. The evening combines formal Chamber business (introductions, committee recognition), a substantial keynote on health care and managed care, and multiple awards – most notably the Harrison County Chamber of Commerce Citizen of the Year presented to James D. LaRosa, founder of the Pete Dye Championship Golf Course in Bridgeport. The footage also includes the Executive Director’s Small Business of the Year award to Oliverio’s Italian Style Peppers and the Ambassador of the Year award. The event is framed by an invocation from Father King of All Saints Catholic Church, a color guard, and a recurring humorous “Healthy West Virginia” skim‑milk toast. A major portion of the program is a detailed health‑care systems talk by Dr. Charles Jacobson (introduced by United Hospital Center CEO Bruce Carter), illustrated with slides about U.S. health‑care history, costs, and Minnesota’s integrated care model. The video closes with Ellis Productions’ credit card, indicating Louis and Nancy Ellis as the videographers.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.role: Honoree – Harrison County Chamber of Commerce Citizen of the Year; local developer and golf‑club founder
characters.description: Older West Virginian businessman, long‑time Clarksburg/Bridgeport resident, recognized for extensive civic, charitable, and business contributions including coal, retail, education, health care, and the Pete Dye Championship Golf Course in Bridgeport. Seen at the podium giving a brief, modest acceptance speech.

characters.name: Walter Barnes (MC / Executive Director)
characters.role: Master of ceremonies and Executive Director of the Harrison County Chamber of Commerce
characters.description: Middle‑aged man in a brown/tan jacket and glasses at the podium for much of the evening. He welcomes guests, runs the program, delivers the humorous ‘Healthy West Virginia’ skim‑milk toast with “Walt,” presents the Executive Director’s Outstanding Small Business of the Year award, and later presents the Ambassador of the Year.

characters.name: Gary Bowden
characters.role: President of the Harrison County Chamber of Commerce (1995–96)
characters.description: Introduced as Chamber president; appears at the head table and at the podium for portions of the program, including introducing the Citizen of the Year segment and thanking speakers. Professional demeanor, in dark suit and tie.

characters.name: Dr. Fred (or Harry) Murray
characters.role: Past president of the Harrison County Chamber of Commerce
characters.description: Referred to as past president who served in 1994; delivers remarks about Chamber growth, regional cooperation, and staff recognition. Middle‑aged man in suit at the podium.

characters.name: Father King
characters.description: Clergyman from All Saints Catholic Church in Bridgeport. Seen at the podium in clerical/dark suit attire delivering the opening prayer blessing the community and honorees.

characters.name: Bruce Carter
characters.role: President and CEO, United Hospital Center
characters.description: Hospital executive who comes to the podium to thank the Chamber for honoring health‑care providers and to introduce keynote speaker Dr. Charles Jacobson. Middle‑aged man in suit, speaking on behalf of the two local hospitals.

characters.name: Dr. Charles Jacobson
characters.role: Keynote speaker – health‑care reform and managed care expert
characters.description: Physician and former President/CEO of Park Nicollet Medical Center in Minneapolis; at the time Vice President of Clinical Services for SunHealth. Gives a long, slide‑supported talk on U.S. health‑care history, costs, managed care, and Minnesota’s integrated system. Speaks in a measured, explanatory style.

characters.name: Frank Oliverio & Mark Oliverio
characters.role: Owners of Oliverio’s Italian Style Peppers – Small Business of the Year honorees
characters.description: Father and son from a family pepper‑canning business that grew from a Glen Elk kitchen to a modern plant on Stiles Street and new offices on Ohio Avenue. They come to the front to accept the Executive Director’s Outstanding Small Business of the Year award and briefly thank the Chamber.

characters.name: John Lowe (or Love)
characters.description: Retired gentleman and Chamber ambassador, recognized for attending ribbon cuttings, open houses, and Chamber events in a distinctive purple ambassador jacket. Comes forward when the Ambassador of the Year is announced.

characters.name: Louie Ellis
characters.description: Chamber friend and long‑time documentarian of local events. Not often on camera, but his presence is implied by the Ellis Productions credit card at the end. Known for filming Chamber and Pete Dye Golf Club–related events.

characters.name: Mary Beth (office manager) & Madeline Phillips
characters.description: Two women recognized from the podium for their work at the Chamber office; Mary Beth is the newer office manager, Madeline is called the ‘resident consultant’ and ‘First Lady of the Chamber.’ Seen standing briefly when introduced.

chapters.title: Opening Ceremony, Invocation, and ‘Healthy West Virginia’ Toast
chapters.summary: The video opens on the 1995 Harrison County Chamber of Commerce annual dinner in a hotel/banquet hall. A color guard presents the colors, and Father King from All Saints Catholic Church in Bridgeport delivers an invocation blessing the community and those to be honored. The master of ceremonies (Executive Director Walter Barnes) then shifts to a humorous health‑themed segment, asking how many attendees can find skim or 1% milk in local stores and introducing a recurring ‘Healthy West Virginia’ toast. He and ‘Walter’ (or ‘Walt’) pledge to drink skim milk instead of wine to ‘save us both from cholesterol,’ joking that the program has been so successful they now ‘wear copper 50s.’ This sets a light, convivial tone while nodding to statewide health initiatives.

chapters.title: Chamber Business, Introductions, and Board/Staff Recognition
chapters.summary: The emcee and Chamber leadership formally recognize the head table, including President Gary Bowden, past president Dr. Murray, vice presidents Anthony Mancuso and Bob Kaplan, and other officers. Board members are asked to stand, identified by flowers on their lapels. Chamber staff Mary Beth (office manager) and Madeline Phillips (‘resident consultant’ and ‘First Lady of the Chamber’) are introduced and praised for their work. A representative from the Marion County Chamber (Charlie Reese) and political figures such as the mayor of Shinnston (Wanda Ashcraft), gubernatorial candidate David McKinley, and a representative from Congressman Alan Mollohan’s office are acknowledged. The emcee stresses the importance of small business membership and committee involvement, and thanks volunteers who organized the event.

chapters.title: Keynote Focus: Honoring Health‑Care Providers and Introducing Dr. Jacobson
chapters.summary: The Chamber dedicates this year’s recognition theme to health‑care providers in Harrison County. Attendees associated with hospitals, clinics, and medical facilities are asked to stand and be thanked. Bruce Carter, President and CEO of United Hospital Center, speaks on behalf of the two local hospitals, emphasizing that the most important group to recognize are the frontline staff working three shifts a day, especially during blizzards when many stayed at the hospital for days. He then introduces Dr. Charles Jacobson, a physician and former President/CEO of Park Nicollet Medical Center in Minneapolis, now with SunHealth. Carter frames Minneapolis as the ‘laboratory’ of managed care and notes Jacobson’s West Virginia ties through training at WVU. Dr. Jacobson is invited to give a keynote on health‑care reform and managed care.

chapters.title: Dr. Jacobson’s Health‑Care Reform Keynote (Slides: History, Problems, and Minnesota Model)
chapters.summary: Dr. Charles Jacobson delivers a detailed, slide‑supported talk on U.S. health care. He begins by acknowledging the complexity of the topic and joking about the political debate around health care and the Clintons. He stresses that health care has done ‘absolutely profoundly wonderful things’ for society but is now in crisis due to costs and access. Slides trace four historical drivers: individual freedom, a large country of small towns, employer‑based health insurance, and the creation of the National Institutes of Health. He explains how solo small‑town doctors were paid in kind, how employers in the 1940s used health insurance to retain workers, and how post‑WWII science (atomic bomb, air travel) led to NIH and explosive medical advances (pacemakers, bypass surgery, MRI, CAT scans, mammograms, transplants, artificial joints, cancer cures, modern hypertension and lipid drugs). Subsequent slides labeled ‘1995 Problems’ outline issues: science driving costs, doctors overwhelmed by knowledge and working in disconnected ‘cottage industry’ practices without integrated records, and insurance companies controlling costs despite limited clinical knowledge. Jacobson uses a ‘1953 Corvette’ analogy to illustrate the dysfunction of buying complex systems piecemeal with a third party paying the bills. He contrasts externally controlled systems (like national HMOs) with community‑built, internally controlled systems, arguing that communities should create integrated health‑care systems to keep control and profits local. He presents Minnesota’s experience: merging Park Nicollet and Group Health, integrating hospitals, reducing redundant technology (CTs, surgery centers, cancer centers), standardizing best practices among 3,000 physicians (including Mayo Clinic), and achieving 20% lower costs with high quality (e.g., low cardiovascular mortality). He concludes that American health care, if allowed to experiment, can become the envy of the world and a major export, and urges local business leaders to help build integrated, patient‑focused systems rather than cede control to distant corporations.

chapters.title: Optimism, Telemedicine, and Call to Local Action
chapters.summary: In the latter part of his talk, Dr. Jacobson discusses the need for integrated systems, robust information technology, and a shift from disease treatment to health promotion. He notes that technology that ‘bites us’ on cost can also help if used properly (e.g., ambulatory information systems, guidelines at the point of care, medical records in patients’ homes). He describes Minnesota’s reductions in hospital beds and costs without sacrificing quality, and mentions Park Nicollet’s low cardiovascular mortality. He outlines ‘future drivers’ of U.S. health care: individual rights, health vs. disease treatment, care systems vs. insurance systems, and human values vs. pure science. He expresses strong optimism that American medicine will innovate its way to being the envy of the world, with private enterprise exporting health‑care expertise. He references telemedicine and teleradiology as examples of emerging opportunities. Jacobson closes by stressing that ‘it is your health care system, it is your community,’ urging local businesspeople and citizens to create their own integrated systems rather than be controlled by distant entities like New York or L.A. The audience applauds, and the Chamber presents him with a ‘low‑cost health‑care package’ of West Virginia food products as a humorous thank‑you gift to take back to Carolina.

chapters.title: Citizen of the Year: Honoring James D. LaRosa
chapters.summary: After the keynote, the program moves into the recognition portion. Chamber President Gary Bowden (or another officer) invites the president, Gary Godwin/Bowden, to present the 1995 Harrison County Chamber of Commerce Citizen of the Year. The presenter reads an extensive citation describing the honoree: a loyal West Virginian, devoted Harrison Countian, and committed Clarksburger; graduate of Washington Irving High School and West Virginia University; successful coal businessman; former director of the Chamber, Lowndes Bank, and the WV Surface Mining and Reclamation Association; appointee to the WV Coal Commission; founder and former chairman of the WV Italian Heritage Festival. The honoree donated and built the WVU Hospital Medivac helipad and established a surgical research endowment. Numerous institutions—Harrison County YMCA, Wheeling College, United Hospital Center, Clarksburg Library, Humane Society, youth sports leagues, Upshur County schools, Buckhannon Fire Department, Fraternal Order of Police, and the Statue of Liberty restoration fund—are listed as beneficiaries of his generosity. Awards include a Doctor of Humane Letters from Salem College, nomination by Senator Byrd to the Presidential Christopher Columbus Quincentennial Jubilee Commission, Distinguished West Virginian honors from Governors Moore and Rockefeller, a Distinguished Service Award from the Clarksburg Arts Center, and an American Legion citation for support of baseball. The presenter then reveals that the Citizen of the Year is James D. LaRosa, noting that he built and developed East Point Shopping Center, recently finished the Pete Dye Championship Golf Course in Bridgeport, owns the Rose Garden Theater, and sold land for the WV Life Sciences Center and the future Robert C. Byrd High School. The audience gives a standing ovation. LaRosa comes to the podium, jokes that he won’t touch the microphone, and gives a brief, humble speech: he has lived all his life within a couple of miles of his high school and considers himself a ‘native son’; he thanks the Chamber and hopes he has helped the quality of life for all; he credits his parents’ love, support, and teaching for his success. The presenter calls the award ‘well deserved, long overdue.’

chapters.title: Executive Director’s Outstanding Small Business of the Year: Oliverio’s Italian Style Peppers
chapters.summary: Executive Director Walter Barnes introduces the next award: the Executive Director’s Outstanding Small Business of the Year. He explains his background in big business and his realization, through Chamber work, that ‘in West Virginia, small business is big business,’ noting that about 70% of Chamber membership is small businesses (75 or fewer employees). He cites mission‑statement words—growth, stability, commitment, recognition of product/services, and community association—as criteria. He then describes the winning business without naming it at first: started in a small Glen Elk kitchen by a woman preparing peppers for her corner grocery; production grew from 65 bushels in two weeks to over 600 bushels in one day; expanded from the grocery kitchen to a large modern facility on Stiles Street (‘the Pepper Plant’) and a new administrative building on Ohio Avenue; workforce grew to 35–40 employees, more during peak canning; three generations of family involvement; major commitment to expansion announced the previous summer; products now on shelves across West Virginia and up and down the Atlantic seaboard, shipping to every state in the continental U.S. He then reveals the honoree: Oliverio’s Italian Style Peppers. Quoting Frank Oliverio about wanting to always do a job they can be proud of, Barnes praises the family and calls them an outstanding promotion for Harrison County. Frank and Mark Oliverio come up to accept; they modestly say neither is a speaker and simply thank the Chamber before returning to their seats. Barnes jokes that Frank hopes he doesn’t have to go back and cut peppers and ‘cut his finger off the way you said that.’

chapters.title: Ambassador of the Year and Closing Remarks
chapters.summary: The final award is the Ambassador of the Year, normally presented by LaDonna Fox, chair of the Ambassadors Committee, but she is absent, so Walter Barnes reads hastily prepared remarks. He explains that the award goes to the person who best exemplifies the Chamber’s role in the community—visible at most Chamber functions (open houses, ribbon cuttings, business after hours, dedications, groundbreakings, and any event drawing two or more people). The recipient must be dedicated, willing to give time and effort to represent the Chamber. This year’s honoree is a retired gentleman who travels a lot but still makes special efforts to attend events. Barnes jokes that when people saw him and another man (Brett) in purple jackets, they might think they got a deal at Gabriel’s, but the jackets signify their role as Chamber ambassadors. He announces the Ambassador of the Year for 1995 as Mr. John Lowe (or Love), who comes forward wearing the same purple jacket. After this, Barnes notes that the program is at its end, thanks Walt Williams, Frank Abruzzini, and office staff for organizing the event, and encourages members to get involved in Chamber committees listed on the back of the program. He invites people to stop by the Chamber office at 348 West Main Street, promising coffee, candy from Mary Beth, or a smile from Madeline. He emphasizes that without members’ support and involvement, the Chamber is nothing, and closes with wishes for a safe trip home and ‘we’ll see you next year.’ The tape ends with an Ellis Productions title card crediting Louis P. Ellis as producer/director, confirming that Louie and Nancy Ellis documented the event.

highlights.title: Citizen of the Year Award to James D. LaRosa
highlights.description: The Chamber presents its 1995 Citizen of the Year award to James D. LaRosa, citing his extensive civic, charitable, and business contributions, including building East Point Shopping Center, finishing the Pete Dye Championship Golf Course in Bridgeport, and supporting hospitals, schools, and cultural institutions. LaRosa gives a brief, heartfelt acceptance speech, calling himself a ‘native son’ and crediting his parents.

highlights.title: Executive Director’s Small Business of the Year: Oliverio’s Italian Style Peppers
highlights.description: Executive Director Walter Barnes tells the story of a family pepper business that grew from a Glen Elk kitchen to a modern plant and national distribution, then reveals Oliverio’s Italian Style Peppers as the 1995 Outstanding Small Business of the Year. Frank and Mark Oliverio accept the award modestly, thanking the Chamber and returning quickly to their seats.

highlights.title: Ambassador of the Year: John Lowe
highlights.description: In the absence of the Ambassadors Committee chair, Walter Barnes improvises remarks to present the Ambassador of the Year award. He describes the honoree as a retired gentleman who travels extensively yet still makes time to represent the Chamber at countless events, and jokes about their purple ambassador jackets. He announces Mr. John Lowe as the 1995 Ambassador of the Year.

highlights.title: Dr. Jacobson’s Minnesota Health Care Case Study
highlights.description: Dr. Charles Jacobson explains how Minnesota’s major employers pushed for change, leading Park Nicollet and Group Health to merge with hospitals and health plans to create an integrated system. He describes eliminating redundant CT scanners and surgery centers, standardizing best practices among 3,000 physicians (including Mayo Clinic), and achieving 20% lower costs with high quality outcomes.

highlights.title: ‘Healthy West Virginia’ Skim‑Milk Toast
highlights.description: The emcee asks how many attendees can find skim or 1% milk in local stores, jokes that managers can’t keep it in stock, and introduces a ‘Healthy West Virginia’ toast. While others drink wine, he and ‘Walt’ pledge to drink skim milk to avoid cholesterol, joking that the program has been so successful they now ‘wear copper 50s.’

quotes.text: I lived here all my life and moved a few times, but never more than a couple miles from my high school. I guess that makes me a native son. That’s what I want to be.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Acceptance speech after receiving the Harrison County Chamber of Commerce Citizen of the Year award.

quotes.text: I want to thank the Chamber and its members for giving me this recognition. I hope in some small way I helped the quality of life for all of us. I couldn’t really accept this without recalling my parents. Without their love, support, teaching, I wouldn’t be standing here.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Continuing his Citizen of the Year acceptance, LaRosa expresses gratitude and credits his parents.

quotes.text: In West Virginia, small business is big business. Within the Harrison County Chamber of Commerce, some 70 percent of our membership is made up of small business entities.
quotes.speaker: Walter Barnes (MC / Executive Director)
quotes.context: Introducing the Executive Director’s Outstanding Small Business of the Year award.

quotes.text: Our small business that we’re recognizing this evening was started in a small kitchen in Glen Elk by a fine lady preparing a delicious product and selling it in her corner grocery store… Over the past three generations, the family production of this product has increased from the canning of some 65 bushels of peppers in two weeks to a production level of over 600 bushels in one day.
quotes.speaker: Walter Barnes (MC / Executive Director)
quotes.context: Building suspense before revealing Oliverio’s Italian Style Peppers as the Small Business of the Year.

quotes.text: Well, I felt so, and that is why I have selected for the 1995 Executive Director’s Outstanding Small Business of the Year, Oliverio’s Italian Style Peppers.
quotes.speaker: Walter Barnes (MC / Executive Director)
quotes.context: Announcing the winner of the Small Business of the Year award.

quotes.text: First of all, on behalf of the two hospitals in town, we want to thank you for honoring us. But I think the board members and our physicians would agree with me that it’s important, if you’re going to recognize somebody in the healthcare system, the most important group to recognize is the people across the street right now who are working on all of those units… without them, the rest of us couldn’t get anything done.
quotes.speaker: Bruce Carter
quotes.context: United Hospital Center CEO Bruce Carter thanking the Chamber for honoring health‑care providers and emphasizing frontline staff.

quotes.text: Health care historically is not a problem. Health care is becoming a problem because of the changes in our society. It is not a group of bad people, but there are problems that are occurring in health care and we must admit they’re there.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Charles Jacobson
quotes.context: Early in his keynote, explaining that systemic issues, not bad actors, are driving the health‑care crisis.

quotes.text: We as a society created the American health care system, and we as a society will restructure it in ways that will make it work better in the future.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Charles Jacobson
quotes.context: Framing his analysis of U.S. health care as the product of collective societal choices.

quotes.text: Car manufacturers need systems to create cost‑effective quality automobiles… Health providers need systems to create cost‑effective quality health care. We cannot continue to play like we have health care, quality health care, in non‑systems.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Charles Jacobson
quotes.context: Using a systems analogy to argue for integrated health‑care delivery.

quotes.text: I am absolutely confident that 10 to 15 years from now, American medicine is going to be the envy of every country in the world… because we are living in a time of dramatic change that will lead to very great opportunities in health care.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Charles Jacobson
quotes.context: Closing his keynote with an optimistic prediction about American health care’s future.

quotes.text: It is your health care system. It is your community. You have the right to set it up the way you wish. I hope that you choose to create your own system. I hope you do not wish to be controlled by New York City or L.A. or some other place.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Charles Jacobson
quotes.context: Final exhortation to the local business and civic audience to build their own integrated health‑care systems.

quotes.text: In West Virginia, small business contributes heavily to the success of our so‑called large businesses—our banks, our utilities, our schools, and yes, even our hospitals.
quotes.speaker: Walter Barnes (MC / Executive Director)
quotes.context: Explaining why the Chamber is honoring a small business and how small firms underpin larger institutions.

quotes.text: This award is given to the person that best exemplifies the Chamber’s role in the community. This person is visible at all or most functions in which the Chamber participates… it takes a person dedicated to their Chamber and to their community and to give their time and efforts to represent the Chamber at these particular events.
quotes.speaker: Walter Barnes (MC / Executive Director)
quotes.context: Describing the criteria for the Ambassador of the Year award before announcing John Lowe.

quotes.text: Ladies and gentlemen, for years, if you needed a helping hand in this community, you simply said, ‘Let’s call Jim.’ Well, tonight we’re calling Jim. We’re calling him a hero, a gentleman, a giver, and a true citizen.
quotes.speaker: Gary Bowden or award presenter
quotes.context: Culminating the introduction of James D. LaRosa as Citizen of the Year.

themes: Civic recognition and community leadership
Small business as economic backbone
Health‑care reform and managed care
Local vs. external control of systems (health and economic)
Public health and lifestyle change (‘Healthy West Virginia’)
Family‑run enterprise and generational growth
Integration of faith, business, and community life
Documentation and memory (Ellis Productions’ role)

Highlites_of_the_Pete_Dye_-_LaRosa_Flof_.title: Pete Dye & LaRosa Front-Nine Interview + Dogs & Cats Reel (Oct 1989–Oct 1990)
Highlites_of_the_Pete_Dye_-_LaRosa_Flof_.content_type: mixed: construction interview, informal site meeting, TV news insert, family celebration, pets home‑movie
Highlites_of_the_Pete_Dye_-_LaRosa_Flof_.summary:
This tape is a compiled home‑movie style reel assembled by Louis Ellis covering:
- An extended, informal on‑site interview and work‑session with Pete Dye and James D. (“Jim/Jimmy”) LaRosa in October 1989 while the front nine of the Pete Dye / LaRosa golf course is under construction.
- B‑roll of greens and fairway construction (especially #6 and #9), bridge delivery, and seeding work through late 1989–1990, with commentary from staff like superintendent Gary and friend Harris.
- A TV sports news segment on the dedication of La Rosa Field at Wheeling College, featuring James J. LaRosa.
- A birthday party sequence for James D. LaRosa with family, friends, and a priest offering blessings.
- A Christmas/holiday banquet with a roving violinist entertaining guests.
- A long, affectionate catalog of James D. LaRosa’s many dogs and cats, plus caretaker Bernadine, filmed around his home and on the course.

The central narrative thread is Pete Dye and Jim LaRosa reflecting on the uniqueness, difficulty, and aesthetics of the course as it’s being built, intercut with social and family life that surrounded the project. The reel ends with Louis Ellis explicitly stating it was made for Catherine LaRosa.

characters.name: Pete Dye
characters.role: Golf course architect; main interview subject
characters.description: Appears repeatedly in the October 6, 1989 construction‑trailer and on‑course interviews, in a light sweater and glasses, joking about his name and the difficulty of the 8th hole, and giving detailed commentary on strategy, contours, and aesthetics.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.description: Older LaRosa seen in the construction‑trailer meeting (blue cardigan, white hair) introducing Pete, Max Robertson, and Bob Andrew, and later in on‑course segments in a striped golf shirt. Also appears extensively in the dogs‑and‑cats section, narrating each animal and praising caretaker Bernadine.

characters.name: Jimmy LaRosa
characters.description: Younger LaRosa who, in the September 28, 1990 on‑course segment, stands in a striped golf shirt with a microphone, introduces Pete and the crew (Sheriff DeAnna, Mike Delaney, Tom Hansberry, Woody Podesta, Keith “Sparky” Sparkman), and asks Pete for comments about the course.

characters.name: Louis Ellis
characters.description: Identifies himself on camera in a red blazer as “Film Director & Producer Louis P. Ellis,” and throughout the tape narrates construction scenes, prompts Pete (“Mr. Pete, you’re on now…”), interviews Harris, Gary, Sam Oliverio, and closes the reel with a direct address to Catherine LaRosa.

characters.name: Max Robertson
characters.description: Named repeatedly by LaRosa and Pete as “Max Robertson, his right‑hand man on the job.” Seen in construction shots operating equipment and doing final shaping; referenced by Pete in design anecdotes (“I told Max…”).

characters.name: Bob Andrew
characters.description: Introduced by James D. as “my right‑hand man on the job.” Appears in construction segments (bridge move, site work) and is greeted in the dogs‑and‑cats section. Not clearly heard speaking in the provided transcript.

characters.name: Harris (Harris Holt)
characters.role: On‑course explainer; likely same Harris Holt later narrator
characters.description: Appears on #6 fairway on Sept 12, explaining sod, burlap erosion mat, and the mine tunnel between #6 and #7 to Louis. Calm, descriptive voice, likely the same Harris Holt who later narrates a course overview professionally.

characters.name: Gary Grandstaff
characters.description: Identified by Louis (“Good morning, Gary”) on Oct 3 at #9. Explains lime and rock phosphate, irrigation, drain risers, and seeding schedule. Seen in work clothes on the course.

characters.name: Sam Oliverio
characters.role: Friend/PR voice; technical and humorous commentary
characters.description: Appears multiple times: explains sand/peat/fertilizer topmix and why trucks avoid the green, jokes about PR, and is thanked for still photos. Also appears taking stills of James D. and the dogs.

characters.name: Sheriff DeAnna
characters.description: Appears on #1 green celebration, joking that it “takes your heart to take a divot on this golf course,” and praising Pete’s Honors Course and the beauty of the new course. Called “Sheriff” and “our PR guy.”

characters.name: Mike Delaney
characters.description: Stands with Sheriff and James D. on the mountain; when prompted, calls the course “the greatest.”

characters.name: Keith “Sparky” Sparkman
characters.description: Named by Jimmy in the Sept 28, 1990 segment as “Keith… we call him Sparky, that’s in charge of the construction of it.” Seen in a green hat doing final shaping and seeding work.

characters.name: James J. LaRosa
characters.role: Grandson; appears in TV news segment
characters.description: Identified in the Wheeling College TV7 sports piece as “James J. La Rosa, grandson of the man the field is dedicated to,” who speaks on camera about Father Acker and the facility.

characters.name: Father Thomas Acker
characters.description: Appears in the TV7 sports insert at La Rosa Field dedication, giving the formal dedication and being referenced by James J. LaRosa.

characters.name: Unidentified priest at birthday
characters.description: At James D.’s birthday party, a priest is teased about telling Jimmy he’ll “need more than that” to get to heaven; he responds briefly and offers many more years.

characters.name: Bernadine
characters.description: Appears in the dogs‑and‑cats section holding a small black kitten “Midnight,” and later in the window with multiple dogs. James D. praises her for caring for 13 dogs and 4 cats and calls them “her babies.”

characters.name: TV7 Sports reporter George Kellis
characters.description: Narrates the Wheeling College La Rosa Field dedication package, signs off as “For TV7 Sports, I’m George Kellis.”

characters.name: Unidentified violinist
characters.description: Older man in short‑sleeve shirt and tie playing violin table‑side at a December 22, 1989 Christmas party, singing “Happy Birthday” and other tunes for guests.

characters.name: Catherine LaRosa
characters.description: Not seen speaking, but Louis closes the program saying the tape was made “special for you, Catherine LaRose,” addressing her directly.

chapters.title: 1. Louis Ellis’ Intro & Trailer‑Office Interview with Pete Dye (Oct 6, 1989)
chapters.summary: Louis Ellis opens the reel, identifying it as footage from October 1989–October 1990 plus James D.’s dogs and cats. We cut into a wood‑paneled trailer/clubhouse where James D. LaRosa, Pete Dye, and their lieutenants share a working lunch. Louis prompts Pete to introduce himself; Pete jokes about spelling “Dye” and they banter about the brutally hard 8th hole. James D. formally records the date (Oct 6, 1989) and introduces Pete, Max Robertson, Bob Andrew, and coordinator Johnny. Pete insists he hasn’t made “changes” but “modifications” and “additions,” and begins a long, candid reflection on how unique this course is in the U.S., emphasizing its contours, vistas, and the ambition of the design.

chapters.title: 2. Pete on Strategy, Ambience & Comparing to Crooked Stick
chapters.summary: Still in the trailer, Pete expands on his design philosophy. He compares this West Virginia site to Crooked Stick, noting that Crooked Stick sits on a flat cornfield with good strategy but no topography, houses, and roads, whereas here the mountains and mining landscape create unmatched ambience. He describes standing on the knob of the 8th fairway, looking back to 7 and down to 4, calling it “all golf” and hard to express. He promises the back nine will be as dramatic as the front once the “little subtleties” are added. He praises specific holes—4, 6, 17—and credits Jim for sparking the idea for 17 (even though Pete will execute it “100% in reverse”). He stresses “balance” across 2–9 and repeats his mantra to Jim: “Don’t go broke or die.”

chapters.title: 3. Playability, Cleaning Up the Woods & Big Contour Greens
chapters.summary: Pete explains what makes a course playable for members: they don’t mind bunkers or water as long as they can find and hit their ball; the real enemy is losing it in unplayable woods. He talks about cleaning up underbrush so people can “negotiate” shots out of ditches and mounds. He argues that modern courses are being “cleaned up” to keep play moving while still looking dramatic. He references Pebble Beach, Pinehurst, and St Andrews, and describes classic big‑contour greens where a ball can roll 40–80 feet yet stay on the surface. He notes they don’t yet have a hole like Augusta’s 16th or St Andrews’ 1st in that sense, and outlines how a large, multi‑flat green could create that effect without bunkers—purely through contour.

chapters.title: 4. Louis’ Construction Narration: #9 Green Build & #6 Fairway/Mine Tunnel
chapters.summary: Louis cuts to October 16, 1989 on #9 green, narrating the USGA‑style build: drainage pipe installed, then #8 stone, then choker gravel, then green mix and seeding. He notes the gravel came from the Ohio River. We then jump to Sept 12 on #6 fairway, where Harris explains seeding, Sparky’s leveling work, sod on the steep banks, and the use of perforated burlap‑like matting to hold soil. Harris points out the mine entrance between #6 and #7, explaining that while you could climb the hill, most golfers will enjoy the cool tunnel on hot days. These segments show the technical and logistical side of turning a rugged coal property into a playable course.

chapters.title: 5. #1 Green Sand Topmix & Mountain‑Top Celebration
chapters.summary: On a mountaintop green site, Louis hands the camera to Sam Oliverio so he can appear on film. Sam explains why sand/peat/fertilizer topmix is dumped in front of the green and pushed with a tractor instead of driving trucks over the tile drainage. He details the mix composition and percolation goals. Sheriff DeAnna and Mike Delaney arrive with James D. and dogs; Sheriff jokes that it “takes your heart to take a divot” on such a beautiful course and calls it “the greatest.” They celebrate finishing their first green, with Louis and Sam documenting the moment while they wait for Pete and Tom Hansberry to hike up. The mood is proud and playful, blending technical explanation with local color.

chapters.title: 6. Gary & a California Friend on #9: Lime, Drain Risers & Torrey Pines
chapters.summary: On Oct 3, superintendent Gary Grandstaff stands with a visiting friend from California (James Fezio) at #9. Fezio marvels at the billiard‑table smoothness of #1 green, comparing it favorably to Torrey Pines and noting that this cool‑season grass won’t grow in San Diego or Florida. Gary explains the white material on #9 is lime and rock phosphate for soil correction, that irrigation has just been finished, and that drain risers under the fairway will allow play an hour after rain. He outlines the seeding schedule (bent on fairways, blue/rye in rough) and how quickly the hole will “look like a golf hole.” Louis and Gary reminisce about school days and Fezio’s world travels, underscoring the course’s emerging reputation.

chapters.title: 7. Bridge Move & Site Logistics
chapters.summary: Louis rides along as Bob Andrew and crew move a large steel bridge on a flatbed into the interior of the course, joking that he’s forgotten which hole it’s for. We see heavy trucks, a crane, and the bridge being staged along dirt roads and cut banks. Louis narrates that they’re heading toward #10 or thereabouts, and later we see Jimmy and a tall guest at the bridge site as the structure is prepared for installation. These shots highlight the engineering and logistical challenges of building a course across ravines and former mining cuts.

chapters.title: 8. Pete & Jimmy’s On‑Course Ceremony at #1 Green (Sept 28, 1990)
chapters.summary: On Sept 28, 1990, Jimmy LaRosa stands on the nearly finished #1 green with Pete Dye, Sheriff DeAnna, Jim Varner, Tom Hansberry, Woody Podesta, Mike Delaney, and Keith “Sparky” Sparkman. Jimmy, holding a mic, jokes about Sheriff making commercials and introduces each friend. He explains that the dozer is spreading sand/wood mulch/fertilizer and that Sparky is in charge of construction. Jimmy quips that he’s spent 11½ years trying to teach Pete to do it “his way,” but Pete “hasn’t bent yet.” Pete then delivers a heartfelt on‑camera statement: praising the Clarksburg site’s potential, recounting Sparky’s comment that there’s “nothing like Jim LaRosa’s job,” and insisting they must finish it “before we all drop from this world.” He reiterates that the course’s strategy and vistas are unlike anything else he’s built, even compared to oceanfront work in the Dominican Republic.

chapters.title: 9. Holiday Banquet & Christmas Violinist (Dec 22, 1989)
chapters.summary: The tape jumps to a December 22, 1989 Christmas party in a dining room. Guests in suits and dresses sit at round tables with holiday decorations. An older man in a short‑sleeve shirt and tie roams the room playing violin and singing “Happy Birthday” and other tunes table‑side. We see multiple tables, including a woman in a blue headpiece, older men in jackets, and a man in a red sweater. The violinist jokes, thanks the crowd, and is applauded. This sequence shows the club’s early social life and the LaRosa circle’s festive gatherings, contrasting with the muddy construction scenes.

chapters.title: 10. James D. LaRosa Birthday Party & Priest’s Blessing
chapters.summary: At an indoor birthday celebration, guests sing “Happy Birthday” to Jimmy/James D. A priest is teased about having once told Jimmy he’d “need more than that” to get to heaven; he good‑naturedly affirms it and offers wishes for many more years. Various family and friends—John, Jack, Rosa, a cousin with an Italian accent, a guest from Australia (“down under”), and others—offer on‑camera birthday greetings. James D. jokes about rumors of his age, calling them a smear campaign and denying he’s 39, while a friend/“attorney” humorously disputes his age. The segment ends with a singer/entertainer declaring “Charge is no charge” and putting it “on their other bill,” echoing Louis Ellis’s own “no charge” sign‑off style.

chapters.title: 11. TV7 Sports: La Rosa Field Dedication at Wheeling College
chapters.summary: A TV7 Sports package (narrated by George Kellis) covers the dedication of La Rosa Field at Wheeling College. Under a VIP tent, officials and Father Thomas Acker preside as the athletic complex is named for the late James La Rosa of Clarksburg. The LaRosa company, now run by James D., redesigned three fields with proper drainage, a six‑week, $100,000 project. James J. LaRosa, the grandson, speaks on camera about Father Acker’s persistence and their feeling for the school. We see him throw out the first pitch for a Lady Cardinals softball game, and a player wearing a “Jim McMahon” headband is highlighted. This segment situates the LaRosa family’s sports philanthropy beyond the golf course.

chapters.title: 12. More Construction: #2 Fairway, #6 Green & Seeding Work
chapters.summary: Louis returns to the course, alone on #2 fairway on a 95‑degree day, narrating that Aerosol is at the gas station, Johnny is answering phones, and Jim LaRosa is “wherever,” while he tries to show the work. Harris joins on #6, explaining sod on the banks, burlap‑like erosion mat, and the mine tunnel. We see workers seeding, picking rocks, and installing drain risers. Later, Louis and Gary describe lime and rock phosphate being spread, irrigation completion, and the plan to seed #9 by dark. These sequences document the painstaking, manual phases of grow‑in and erosion control that follow the heavy earthmoving.

chapters.title: 13. Long Dogs & Cats Catalog for Catherine LaRosa
chapters.summary: The final third of the tape is a detailed, affectionate catalog of James D. LaRosa’s many dogs and cats, filmed around his home, Bernadine’s house, and on the course. James D. narrates each animal’s name, origin story, age, temperament, and quirks: Bobo the former bandit dog; Coal Dust from a strip mine; Bunker the pit‑bull mix; Bogey found near Greenbrier #2; Prince the former neighbor’s dog with a broken leg; Tiger, Mr. Putter, Cinders, and Midnight the cats; Penny from his father’s Buckhannon coal tipple; Maurice the gray poodle; Mia, Gigi, Pepper, Salty, Plunger, Maggie, Bruce Lee, and others. Bernadine appears holding kitten Midnight and is praised for caring for 13 dogs and 4 cats. We see the animals following James D. on walks, crowding windows, and lounging on porches and beds. Louis, Sam Oliverio, and others take stills and video. The segment ends with Louis addressing Catherine LaRosa directly, saying the tape was made especially for her and hoping she enjoys it as much as he did making it.

highlights.title: Pete Dye’s Name Joke & 8th Hole Comparison
highlights.description: Prompted by Louis, Pete introduces himself: “My name is Pete Dye. D for Ducky, Y for Yoko, and B for Ever the H.” James D. laughs that he can’t figure it out and says it’s like the 8th hole—he can’t figure that one either. Pete quips that you can’t play the 8th, so it’s really a seven‑hole course.

highlights.title: Pete on Ambience & Uniqueness vs Crooked Stick
highlights.description: Pete contrasts Crooked Stick’s flat cornfield site with the dramatic topography and mining landscape in Clarksburg. He says when you stand on the knob of #8 and look to #7 and #4, “the ambience is just too much… it’s all golf,” and declares there’s “nothing like this golf course in the United States.”

highlights.title: Credit to Jimmy for Inspiring #17
highlights.description: Pete tells James D. that 17 might be the most talked‑about hole he’s ever done and that “Jim came up with the idea.” He jokes that they’ll do what Jim said “only 100% in reverse,” but insists the spark was Jim’s, acknowledging the owner’s creative input.

highlights.title: Pete’s Philosophy on Playability & Cleaning Up the Woods
highlights.description: Pete explains that members don’t mind bunkers or water; they mind losing balls in unplayable woods. He stresses cleaning up underbrush so players can always “negotiate” a shot, even from ditches and mounds, and notes that modern courses are being “so cleaned up” to keep play moving while still looking dramatic.

highlights.title: Gary & Fezio on #1 Green vs Torrey Pines
highlights.description: James Fezio from California tells Gary that #1 green is so smooth “you can shoot a pool table on there,” and that even people at Torrey Pines had “never seen anything like it.” Gary explains the agronomy and drainage that make such conditions possible in West Virginia.

highlights.title: Jimmy’s 1990 #1 Green Speech & Pete’s Response
highlights.description: On Sept 28, 1990, Jimmy LaRosa, mic in hand, introduces Pete and the crew, jokes about trying to keep Pete straight for 11½ years, and hopes for an Indian summer to finish the front nine. Pete responds with a heartfelt endorsement of the site’s potential, recounts Sparky’s praise, and urges that they finish “before we all drop from this world.”

highlights.title: James D.’s Birthday Toast & Age Joke
highlights.description: At his birthday party, James D. jokes about a rumor regarding his age, calling it “a foul rumor spread by the opposition on a smear campaign.” A friend playing his “attorney” insists he’s not 39 “by any stretch of the imagination,” and they banter about whether he’s one over or under 39.

highlights.title: TV7 Sports: La Rosa Field Dedication
highlights.description: The TV7 Sports segment shows the dedication of La Rosa Field at Wheeling College. James J. LaRosa explains how Father Acker’s persistence and their feeling for the school led to the project, and he praises the finished facility. The piece underscores the LaRosa family’s broader impact on West Virginia sports.

highlights.title: James D. Introducing Every Dog & Cat
highlights.description: In a long, tender sequence, James D. walks through his yard and Bernadine’s house, introducing each dog and cat by name and backstory—rescues from strip mines, coal tipples, motels, and neighbors. He explains their injuries, temperaments, and sentimental value, especially Penny from his father’s Buckhannon coal tipple, and praises Bernadine’s care.

highlights.title: Louis’ Sign‑Off to Catherine LaRosa
highlights.description: Louis closes the tape directly to camera, saying the program was made “special for you, Catherine LaRose,” and that he hopes she enjoys it as much as he did making it. He thanks her and says good night, echoing his signature “no charge” ethos.

quotes.text: My name is Pete Dye. D for Ducky, Y for Yoko, and B for Ever the H. How about that? Dye.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Louis prompts Pete in the trailer‑office to state his name on camera; Pete responds with a playful, nonsensical spelling that sets a humorous tone for the interview.

quotes.text: You can’t play the eighth hole. The only place is a seven hole golf course. You get to eight, you stop. You can’t drive a car, you can’t play it. It’s all there.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Continuing the name joke, Pete and James D. riff on the notorious difficulty of the 8th hole, framing it as almost unplayable and emblematic of the course’s toughness.

quotes.text: I told Max, I’ll never live long enough, but there’s nothing like this golf course in the United States. Nothing. I know it’s the best or it’s the worst, but let’s put nothing in the equal.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: In the Oct 6, 1989 trailer interview, Pete reflects on the uniqueness and extremity of the design, acknowledging it could be polarizing but insisting it has no equal.

quotes.text: The views, the vistas, the way it looks, the visual appearance, there’s not another golf course I’ve ever seen in the United States.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete elaborates on why he considers the course unique, emphasizing the surrounding mountains, mining landscape, and visual drama as central to its identity.

quotes.text: Member players, they don’t mind the bunkers, they don’t mind the water, they don’t mind the hazards, as long as you can just get the area cleaned up where they can find the ball… As long as they can negotiate, they’ll play golf.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Discussing playability, Pete explains that golfers accept hazards if they can find and hit their ball, arguing for cleaning up woods and underbrush rather than softening strategic features.

quotes.text: You should never talk about your children or your golf course. I’ve never had any opportunity like this… This has got something else. It really does.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Comparing this project to others, including his Dominican Republic work, Pete admits he’s never had a site like this and hints at a personal, almost parental attachment to the course.

quotes.text: We’re trying to finish this front nine here before the weather gets too bad.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: In the trailer meeting, James D. explains the immediate construction goal and seasonal pressure, anchoring the footage in the fall 1989 schedule.

quotes.text: Not changes, Jim. They’re modifications. You’ve got to modify. They’re additions.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Responding to a question about changes made that day, Pete reframes them as “modifications” and “additions,” revealing his iterative design mindset.

quotes.text: Well, Jimmy, you know, you’re going to be a much better commentator after 11½ years. You and Louie have got this thing down pat… God knows we’ve always felt the potential is really here in Clarksburg more so than any place I’ve ever seen.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: On Sept 28, 1990, Pete teases Jimmy about his on‑camera skills, then earnestly praises the Clarksburg site’s potential during the #1 green celebration.

quotes.text: Sparky… we just finished a golf course that had 10 holes on the ocean and not a house in sight… When he came back here to work this fall he says, ‘Pete, there’s nothing like Jim LaRosa’s job here in Clarksburg.’ And I said, ‘Well, Sparky, for God’s sakes, we’ve got to get her finished before we all drop from this world.’
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete recounts Keith “Sparky” Sparkman’s praise for the project and uses it to underscore both the course’s uniqueness and the urgency to complete it.

quotes.text: There’s a rumor going around about my age, and I don’t believe it… It’s a foul rumor spread by the opposition on a smear campaign.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: At his birthday party, James D. jokingly denies being as old as people say, using political language to mock the idea of aging as a scandal.

quotes.text: Charge is no charge. He said he’d put it on their other bill.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified entertainer at birthday
quotes.context: After singing at James D.’s birthday, the entertainer jokes that there’s “no charge,” echoing Louis Ellis’s own “no charge” sign‑off and the family’s generous spirit.

quotes.text: Father Acker’s persistence, that was one. Two is a feeling that we have for the school… after visiting the site a couple times and just getting involved, I think, basically with the people here.
quotes.speaker: James J. LaRosa
quotes.context: In the TV7 sports piece, James J. explains why the LaRosa family invested in Wheeling College’s fields, citing Father Acker’s persistence and their connection to the school community.

quotes.text: This tape was made special for you, Catherine LaRose. I hope you’ve enjoyed it as much as I have doing it for you. Thank you, and good night.
quotes.speaker: Louis Ellis
quotes.context: Louis closes the program directly to Catherine, framing the entire reel as a personal gift and summing up his role as the family’s unofficial documentarian.
