Interview_With_Pete_Dye_7-10-94.title: On-Site Interview with Pete Dye & LaRosa Team – Clinton Story and Crew Introductions (1994)
Interview_With_Pete_Dye_7-10-94.summary: This archival segment, largely dated July 10, 1994, captures an on-site interview and walk-through on the under-construction Pete Dye Golf Club. Cameraman/narrator Louis (Louie) Ellis informally interviews Pete Dye, James D. LaRosa, Jimmy (Jimmy Joe) LaRosa, and key staff while they stand on raw dirt fairways and around heavy equipment. Pete delivers a long, humorous anecdote about playing a heavily guarded fundraising round with President Bill Clinton, then shifts into a thoughtful mini-lecture on how golf courses must evolve over time. Jimmy introduces the professional staff and construction crew (including Bill Stines, Gary Grandstaff, Keith “Sparky” Sparkman, shaper Mike Langkau, and Director of Golf Jim Jamieson). The piece closes with James D. and Jimmy reflecting on the project’s meaning and future, and Louie Ellis giving his trademark “no charge” sign-off. The visuals alternate between live construction footage and a still snapshot of Louie with Pete, underscoring the personal relationships behind the project.

characters.name: Pete Dye
characters.role: Golf course architect and primary on-camera storyteller
characters.description: Older man in light flat cap, glasses, white/light long-sleeve shirt, often with arms folded or gesturing while standing on the dirt construction site. He tells the Clinton/Quickstick story and gives detailed commentary on course evolution and green speeds.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.role: Founder / owner, on-site with Pete and later introduced as “James D.”
characters.description: Older Italian-American man in a bright pink dress shirt and dark tie in some shots; elsewhere appears in casual white T-shirt on site. Speaks about the long journey of the project, his son Jimmy Joe running operations, and wanting to make Pete proud.

characters.name: Jimmy LaRosa
characters.role: Project co-manager and on-camera host introducing staff
characters.description: Younger/middle-aged man in white dress shirt and patterned tie, often standing beside Pete on the dirt fairways. He introduces the professional staff and crew (Bill, Gary, Keith, Mike, Jim Jamieson) and frames the project as entering a new phase.

characters.name: Louis (Louie) Ellis
characters.description: Shorter man in white short-sleeve shirt and patterned tie in the still snapshot and some on-site shots; identified in text as “Louis P. Ellis – Producer/Director.” He narrates the opening (“here I am, Louis Ellis, with Pete Dye”), expresses admiration for Pete, and closes with his signature “no charge” sign-off.

characters.name: Bill Stines
characters.description: Professional-looking man in golf attire (not distinctly isolated visually here) introduced by Jimmy as having joined from The Honors Course in Ooltewah, Tennessee, now serving as head golf professional.

characters.name: Gary Grandstaff
characters.role: Golf course superintendent and construction lead on back nine
characters.description: Course superintendent, described by Jimmy as having been there 15 years and involved with “about every blade of grass,” in charge of back-nine construction and conditioning. Visually likely one of the older crew in work clothes, but not uniquely identifiable in a single frame.

characters.name: Keith “Sparky” Sparkman
characters.description: Referred to as “Keith Sparkman, Sparky,” Pete’s right-hand man who has “turned over about every blade of dirt 10 or 12 times.” Likely one of the men in work shorts/T-shirt or blue golf shirt, but not uniquely isolated visually.

characters.name: Mike Langkau
characters.description: Construction shaper introduced by Jimmy as being in his third season, busy shaping the back nine, previously worked at Indy Speedway and other Pete Dye courses. Visually one of the younger crew in shorts, but not clearly singled out.

characters.name: Jim Jamieson
characters.role: Director of Golf, former tour player
characters.description: Described by Jimmy as a world-class golfer and gentleman, Director of Golf, former PGA Tour player and former golf director at The Greenbrier. Likely one of the taller, athletic men in golf attire, but not clearly isolated in the provided visual notes.

characters.name: Unidentified crew and staff
characters.role: Construction workers, superintendents, and club staff
characters.description: Multiple men in white T-shirts, caps, sunglasses, and golf shirts appear listening to Pete’s stories and standing with equipment. They represent the working crew and management team but are not individually named in the transcript except where Jimmy introduces roles generically.

chapters.title: Ellis Productions intro and snapshot with Pete
chapters.summary: The video opens with an “ELLIS PRODUCTIONS” title card identifying Louis P. Ellis as producer/director. Over this, Louie’s voice announces an interview with Pete Dye, James D., Jimmy Joe LaRosa, and the working crew. The image cuts to a still snapshot of Louie standing with his arm around Pete Dye at a table, dated 7/10/90, as Louie says it’s an honor to be with Pete and mentions they play together weekly.

chapters.title: On-site Clinton security story at Crooked Stick
chapters.summary: On the raw dirt of the future Pete Dye Golf Club, Pete Dye (in cap and glasses) holds court with Jimmy LaRosa, James D., and the crew. He tells a long, humorous story about playing a heavily secured fundraising round with President Bill Clinton and a governor at Crooked Stick. Pete describes Woody Mellon, an Arkansas security man called up to head presidential security, and the 17 CIA/FBI agents shadowing them. As darkness falls on the 16th and 18th holes, security tries to pull Clinton off the course, but Clinton insists on finishing. Pete vividly recounts Clinton’s strong drive on 18 near a lake, his own shot coming up short, and joking to Woody that the agents should worry less about a submarine in the pond and more about the Republican homeowners in the bushes on the left. The crew listens, laughs, and reacts as Pete animates the story with gestures and course references.

chapters.title: Design philosophy: golf courses must evolve
chapters.summary: Still on the construction site, Pete shifts from storytelling to a reflective discussion of golf-course evolution. He argues that saying “don’t change the original design” is wrong, citing Donald Ross at Pinehurst No. 2, who would move tees back if he saw modern players like Brandie Burton overpowering holes. Pete explains how Augusta National (the Masters) is tweaked every year, and how tree growth at Harbour Town has narrowed corridors by 30 feet, forcing controversial tree removal. He references Crooked Stick’s greens being softened for the PGA because mowing technology made original contours too severe, and notes that at The Honors Course he never imagined today’s green speeds. He concludes that greens are almost out of date before they’re built, but believes the greens at Pete Dye Golf Club are now tuned to modern speeds and that “the test of golf is here,” especially on the dramatic 15th hole, which he calls a setting he may never equal again.

chapters.title: Pete praises the 15th hole and hands off to Jimmy
chapters.summary: Pete stands on the unfinished 15th hole, reflecting that he has worked on similar concepts around the world but never with a setting like this, and likely never will again. He emphasizes the continuity and uniqueness of this golf course. Then he invites “Jimmy Joe” to introduce the people around them and explain what they’ve done, transitioning the focus from design philosophy to the team that built and will run the club.

chapters.title: Jimmy LaRosa introduces the professional staff and construction team
chapters.summary: Jimmy LaRosa, in a white shirt and tie, introduces key staff members standing around him on the dirt fairway. He starts with head golf professional Bill Stines, who joined from The Honors Course in Ooltewah, Tennessee. He then highlights superintendent Gary Grandstaff, with the club for 15 years and involved in “about every blade of grass,” overseeing back-nine construction and conditioning. Next is Keith “Sparky” Sparkman, Pete’s right-hand man who has turned over “about every blade of dirt 10 or 12 times,” with Pete joking that one turnover for him is eleven for Jim. Jimmy introduces shaper Mike Langkau, in his third season, who has worked on several Pete Dye courses including Indy Speedway, and has been busy shaping the back nine. Finally, he introduces Director of Golf Jim Jamieson, a world-class golfer and gentleman, former tour player and former golf director at The Greenbrier, praising his contributions to the club’s atmosphere and even his emceeing and dancing.

chapters.title: James D. LaRosa and Pete reflect on the long journey
chapters.summary: Jimmy turns the spotlight to “James D.,” introducing his father. Pete jokingly asks whether he is James D.’s assistant or vice versa; James D. insists he is Pete’s assistant and always will be. They note they are the same age and have weathered “all the gas attacks and everything” together. James D. reflects that, despite people wondering about the long timeline, the project has been as much fun as anything he’s done in his life, even if occasionally frustrating. He jokes that as long as Jim doesn’t find another coal mine under the course, they’ll be fine. James D. then speaks proudly of his son Jimmy Joe, who will run the operation, and introduces Jimmy’s son Jameson. Admitting he doesn’t know much about golf operations, he expresses total confidence in Jimmy Joe to run the club, maintain a level of quality that befits Pete’s genius, and keep members happy. Pete and James D. agree that condition is everything and that this is not an end but the beginning of a new phase, since golf courses must always be worked on.

chapters.title: Louie Ellis’ heartfelt “no charge” sign-off
chapters.summary: As the group stands on the dirt fairway, Louie Ellis steps verbally into the foreground. He lists the people present (“Jimmy, James D., CISO, Pete, Bill, Gary, Sparky, Mike”) and then delivers an emotional thank-you. He recalls saying “no charge” 14 years earlier and repeats that there is still no charge today. He mentions waiting an hour and a half so he wouldn’t miss Pete, calling the team “tough to find” and Pete even harder. Louie says he has enjoyed every bit of documenting the project and is glad to have been part of the organization, noting that somewhere down the line they’ll have all the tapes and see him and the rest of it. He thanks them for having him do the work, repeats “no charge,” and someone jokes about the red light still being on. Another voice urges someone to grab the camera “before we hurt him.” Louie closes formally: “We are at the end of our interview. Always nice having Pete around. Good night and God bless you all,” providing a warm, personal capstone to the construction-era footage.

highlights.title: Pete Dye’s Clinton-at-Crooked-Stick security story
highlights.description: Standing on the raw dirt of the future Pete Dye Golf Club, Pete tells a vivid, humorous story about playing a fundraising round with President Bill Clinton at Crooked Stick under heavy CIA/FBI security. He describes Woody Mellon, the Arkansas security chief, 17 armed agents, Clinton insisting on finishing 18 holes in near-darkness, and Pete joking that the agents should worry less about a submarine in the pond and more about Republican homeowners in the bushes.

highlights.title: Design philosophy: courses must change with the game
highlights.description: Pete delivers an impromptu masterclass on why golf courses must evolve. He cites Donald Ross at Pinehurst No. 2, tree growth at Harbour Town, green softening at Crooked Stick for the PGA, and unexpected green speeds at The Honors Course. He concludes that greens are almost out of date before they’re built and asserts that the greens at Pete Dye Golf Club are tuned to modern speeds and will provide a true test of golf.

highlights.title: Jimmy LaRosa’s roll call of the team
highlights.description: Jimmy stands on the unfinished course and introduces the core professional and construction team by name and role: head pro Bill Stines, superintendent and back-nine construction lead Gary Grandstaff, Pete’s right-hand man Keith “Sparky” Sparkman, shaper Mike Langkau, and Director of Golf Jim Jamieson. The moment formally acknowledges the people who turned Pete’s design into reality.

highlights.title: James D. LaRosa entrusts the future to Jimmy Joe
highlights.description: James D. speaks candidly about the long, sometimes frustrating but deeply enjoyable journey of building the club. He publicly hands operational responsibility to his son Jimmy Joe, expresses full confidence in him despite his own limited golf-operations knowledge, and states his desire to make Pete proud by maintaining a level of quality that matches Pete’s genius.

highlights.title: Louie Ellis’ emotional ‘no charge’ farewell
highlights.description: Louie Ellis, the self-appointed documentarian, thanks the LaRosas, Pete, and the crew for letting him film the project for years. He recalls promising “no charge” 14 years earlier and repeats that there is still no charge, emphasizing that he waited an hour and a half so he wouldn’t miss Pete. He notes that they’ll have all the tapes someday and see him and the rest of it, then signs off with gratitude and a blessing.

quotes.text: We have an interview with Pete Dye, James D., Jimmy Joe LaRosa, and part of the working crew. And here I am, Louis Ellis, with Pete Dye. With a snapshot. It's an honor to always be with Pete.
quotes.speaker: Louis (Louie) Ellis
quotes.context: Voiceover introduction over the Ellis Productions title card and a still snapshot of Louie with Pete, framing the footage as an interview and personal keepsake.

quotes.text: We play once a week, every week. I don't care what, I play once a week.
quotes.speaker: Louis (Louie) Ellis
quotes.context: Narration over the still photo of Louie with Pete, emphasizing their regular golf routine and close relationship.

quotes.text: And they had 17 guys out there going around with us on the golf course. And they didn't let the press go, so it was just the governor and Clinton and myself.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: On the construction site, Pete describes the heavy security and exclusivity of a fundraising round with President Clinton and a governor at Crooked Stick.

quotes.text: Clinton was dark when we were coming down the 16th hole of Crooked Stick. I mean, it gets darker and heavier. And these guys are just paranoid trying to get him off the golf course. ‘Wait a minute, wait a minute, can't we do it?’
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete recounts security’s anxiety as daylight fades and Clinton insists on continuing the round, entertaining the assembled crew.

quotes.text: Woody, you worried about a submarine coming out of that goddamn pond and gonna take a shot at the goddamn president? I said, all those Republicans that live in those houses over there, I said, you guys better get the hell over there by those bushes.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Punchline of Pete’s Clinton story, joking with security chief Woody Mellon about where the real threat might come from, drawing laughter from the group.

quotes.text: You know, you have to work on a golf course. Golf courses are a growing thing. The minute somebody says, ‘Don't change the original design,’ it's an erroneous statement.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete transitions from anecdote to design philosophy, arguing that courses must evolve with equipment, players, and nature.

quotes.text: I know if Donald Ross was alive today and he was back at his favorite spot, Pinehurst No. 2, and he saw Brandie Burton hit a drive and a 9-iron to the first green, he'd move the tee back into the parking lot.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Illustrating his point about course evolution by imagining how Donald Ross would react to modern power golf.

quotes.text: Ever since we built it, it's been over 20 years, and the membership, you know, they're very protective of that golf course. When I cleared Harbour Town and made the corridor to the fairway, they were pretty tight. And in 20 years, the pine trees have grown in 15 feet on each side. Now you take 30 feet, that's tremendous, tremendous.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete explains how tree growth has dramatically narrowed Harbour Town’s corridors, and how members resist necessary tree removal.

quotes.text: They built the greens in 1964, and they didn't have any modern equipment to cut the greens as fast as they do today. So for the PGA, I went back and softened all the greens so they would be acceptable to the boys.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Discussing Crooked Stick’s greens and how advances in mowing technology forced him to soften contours for championship play.

quotes.text: The greens are almost out of date before they're built. But today, I think we've got them pretty well in tone of what we know what they're playing today. So I think that the greens will putt acceptably to all kinds of speed. And I think that the test of golf is here.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete concludes his design commentary by asserting that Pete Dye Golf Club’s greens are tuned to modern speeds and will provide a lasting test.

quotes.text: I felt like I've worked on this 15th hole in different places around the world, but I've never had a setting like this. I may never have a setting like this. I'll never have a setting like this ever.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Standing on the unfinished 15th, Pete praises the unique natural setting and suggests it’s unmatched in his career.

quotes.text: This is Bill Stines. Bill joined us this year from The Honors Course in Ooltewah, Tennessee, another one of Pete's great designs. Bill's position now is head golf professional.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa
quotes.context: Jimmy begins introducing the key professional staff to camera, starting with head pro Bill Stines.

quotes.text: Gary Grandstaff has been with us for how many years now, Gary? Fifteen. Fifteen? It's been a long time, but Gary has been involved in about every blade of grass that's been grown here. He's our superintendent. He's also in charge of construction on the back nine.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa
quotes.context: Jimmy highlights superintendent Gary Grandstaff’s long tenure and central role in both construction and conditioning.

quotes.text: Keith Sparkman, Sparky, has been with us about as many years, I think. Fifteen and a half. Keith has been principally Pete's right-hand man on the project. He's been involved in turning over about every blade of dirt 10 or 12 times.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa
quotes.context: Jimmy introduces Keith “Sparky” Sparkman as Pete’s right-hand man in the dirt-moving and shaping work.

quotes.text: Mike Langkau joined us last year… This is his third season… Mike's been here also. He's worked with Pete as a shaper and has been very busy shaping this back nine and getting it in a condition where we can get finished.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa
quotes.context: Jimmy introduces shaper Mike Langkau and notes his role in finishing the back nine, including prior work on other Pete Dye courses.

quotes.text: Jim Jamieson's been with us for two years. This is his second year. Jim's been a world-class golfer, a world-class gentleman. He's our director of golf and a good friend. He certainly adds a lot to the atmosphere that we're trying to develop here. He's one hell of an emcee and a great dancer.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa
quotes.context: Jimmy introduces Director of Golf Jim Jamieson, praising both his professional pedigree and his personality.

quotes.text: Am I your assistant, or are you my assistant?
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Light-hearted exchange as Pete and James D. joke about their working relationship in front of the camera.

quotes.text: No, I'm your assistant, Jim. I'll always be your assistant, I guarantee it.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: James D. responds to Pete’s joke, humbly positioning himself as Pete’s assistant despite being the owner/founder.

quotes.text: You know, this whole project, I've talked about it for so many years. People wonder, but it's probably been as much fun as I've ever had in my life, trying to put this thing together. Sometimes I get just a little frustrated, but not too often.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: James D. reflects on the long journey of building the club, acknowledging both the challenges and the joy.

quotes.text: I'd like to say something about my son Jimmy Joe here. He's going to run the operation. This is his son Jameson here. I don't know much about the game of golf or how he's running the golf business, so I'm totally confident in Jimmy Joe running this operation.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: James D. publicly hands operational responsibility to his son Jimmy Joe and expresses full confidence in him.

quotes.text: I'd like to make Pete proud of it. He's built it for us, and now we've got to maintain a certain level of quality that befits his genius. I guess it goes together, the design and the condition.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: James D. articulates his desire to honor Pete’s work by maintaining high standards of conditioning and operations.

quotes.text: We got Jimmy, James D., CISO, Pete, Bill, Gary, Sparky, Mike. I'll tell you one thing I want to say. Like I said 14 years ago, no charge. And there's no charge today.
quotes.speaker: Louis (Louie) Ellis
quotes.context: Louie begins his closing remarks, listing those present and repeating his long-standing promise to film the project at no charge.

quotes.text: I waited over there and sat there for an hour and a half so I wouldn't miss this fella. And because these guys are tough to find and he's harder. And I've enjoyed every bit of it and I'm glad to have been a part of this organization.
quotes.speaker: Louis (Louie) Ellis
quotes.context: Louie explains his dedication to capturing Pete and the team on film and expresses gratitude for being included.

quotes.text: Somewhere down the line you got all the tapes. You're going to see me and the rest of it. And thank you all for having me do this work. You're great. One more thing… Thank you, Jim. No charge. There will be no retakes. Red light's still on.
quotes.speaker: Louis (Louie) Ellis
quotes.context: Louie underscores that his work has been a labor of love, reiterates “no charge,” and jokes about the camera still rolling.

quotes.text: Well, we are at the end of our interview. Always nice having Pete around. Good night and God bless you all.
quotes.speaker: Louis (Louie) Ellis
quotes.context: Louie formally closes the on-site interview segment with a warm farewell and blessing.

Joe_Dimaggio_Special_Guest_At_the_PDBC.title: Joe DiMaggio Visit & VIP Luncheon at Pete Dye Golf Club (1995)
Joe_Dimaggio_Special_Guest_At_the_PDBC.summary: Archival home‑video and photo‑montage coverage of a special Joe DiMaggio visit and luncheon at Pete Dye Golf Club (summer 1995). Shot informally by Louie and Nancy Ellis, it documents DiMaggio at the head table, autograph signings, posed photos with families and local dignitaries (including the governor and the course architect), clergy giving a blessing, and general banquet socializing. Much of the original PA audio is missing, so the videographer narrates over silent sections, repeatedly identifying people (notably a local figure he calls “Joe Mangin/Manchin”) and reflecting on the significance of the day and the baseball heroes represented in his autographed poster.

characters.name: Joe DiMaggio
characters.description: Older man in dark suit and tie with dark sunglasses, repeatedly labeled on‑screen as “GUEST JOE DIMAGGIO.” Seen seated at the head table, eating, signing autographs, and posing for numerous photos with adults and children.

characters.name: Louie Ellis
characters.description: Voice behind the camera providing running commentary, technical disclaimers, and identifications of guests. References his wife Nancy Ellis and their company Ellis Productions, and describes getting DiMaggio’s autograph for Nancy.

characters.name: Nancy Ellis
characters.description: Not clearly visible in this reel but named by Louie as the recipient of DiMaggio’s autographed poster. Also appears on the Ellis Productions title card photo.

characters.name: Unidentified Governor (likely Governor Gaston Caperton)
characters.description: Referred to repeatedly as “the governor.” Seen circulating under the tent, shaking hands and chatting about an upcoming wedding. Exact face not clearly resolved, but context indicates the sitting West Virginia governor attending the club event.

characters.name: Unidentified Course Architect (not clearly Pete Dye on camera)
characters.role: Architect credited for the course’s beauty
characters.description: Several times Louie says “He’s the architect. He’s the one who made the beauty of this golf course,” over shots of men in shirts and ties or polos. The visuals do not clearly match known images of Pete Dye, so the specific individual remains uncertain, but the narration is explicitly crediting the course architect.

characters.name: Unidentified Clergyman
characters.description: Older man in light jacket with clerical collar seated at the head table. Seen speaking while Louie overdubs a translation of a Latin blessing and later explains that no sound system was operating.

characters.name: Justin Velcastro
characters.description: Named by Louie as “a proud boy, Justin Velcastro, right next to Joe DiMaggio” in a photo. Visually corresponds to a boy in a plaid shirt seated or leaning beside DiMaggio in several posed shots.

characters.name: Joe Mangin / Joe Manchin (local dignitary)
characters.role: Prominent local guest; speculated future governor
characters.description: Adult man Louie repeatedly identifies as “Joe Mangin/Manchin,” joking that he “may be our next governor” and clarifying “Not the little guy, the bigger guy.” Seen in posed portraits with a young boy, then later seated at table beside DiMaggio. The audio strongly suggests this is Joe Manchin, but the tape’s spelling/pronunciation is inconsistent.

characters.name: Unidentified boy with Joe Mangin
characters.description: Young boy who appears in multiple posed shots with the suited man Louie calls Joe Mangin/Manchin, and later in a portrait where the man stands behind him with hands on his shoulders.

characters.name: Unidentified club members & family guests
characters.description: Numerous men and women in semi‑formal attire, plus children, seated at banquet tables or standing for photos with DiMaggio and dignitaries. They represent the club’s membership, local community, and families.

chapters.title: Ellis Productions Intro & Filming Disclaimers
chapters.summary: The video opens with an Ellis Productions title card showing Louie and Nancy Ellis and their services. Over this, Louie introduces the piece as coverage of a “special event at the P. Dye Golf Club” featuring Joe DiMaggio. He immediately warns viewers that they were not scheduled to film, their seat was poor, and they were even told not to film, setting expectations for shaky, obstructed footage and explaining the semi‑guerrilla nature of the recording.

chapters.title: Tent Luncheon Begins: Governor & Architect Identified
chapters.summary: Black‑and‑white and color shots under a large white tent show a formal luncheon in progress. A head table is visible with chandeliers overhead and wooded views outside. Louie’s camera, often blocked by other guests, tries to capture VIPs. He repeatedly points out “the governor” as he circulates, shaking hands and chatting about an upcoming wedding. Louie also points to a man and says, “He’s the architect. He’s the one who made the beauty of this golf course,” making sure that contribution is on record. Throughout, Louie notes that there was no sound system and that some speech audio could not be captured.
characters_present: Unidentified Course Architect (not clearly Pete Dye on camera)

chapters.title: Clergy Blessing & Latin Toast (Audio Missing)
chapters.summary: The camera settles on the head table where a priest in a clerical collar delivers a blessing. Louie overdubs an English translation of a Latin phrase—“ADMIRE EVERYTHING, TASTE EVERYTHING AND REJOICE IN EVERYTHING FOR THE BLESSING OF GOD, AMEN”—while explaining that the original audio could not be picked up due to the lack of a sound system. The priest and nearby dignitaries, including a woman in sunglasses and other older men, are shown in close‑up as they speak and socialize, but their actual words are inaudible.

chapters.title: Joe DiMaggio at the Head Table: Autographs & Heroes
chapters.summary: Joe DiMaggio, in a dark suit and sunglasses, is now clearly visible at the head table, often labeled on‑screen as “GUEST JOE DIMAGGIO.” Louie narrates that he has just gotten DiMaggio to autograph a poster for his wife, Nancy Ellis—a poster featuring DiMaggio, Ted Williams, and Stan Musial. He calls them “great heroes on one picture,” underscoring the emotional weight of the autograph. Shots show DiMaggio eating, listening to remarks, and being surrounded by guests, while Louie apologizes again for missing live audio from parts of the program.

chapters.title: Families, Youth, and the ‘Next Governor’
chapters.summary: The focus widens to show families and younger attendees interacting with DiMaggio and other VIPs. Louie points out “a proud boy, Justin Velcastro, right next to Joe DiMaggio” in a photo and then jokes that another attendee, “Joe Mangin,” might be “our next governor,” clarifying that he means “not the little guy, the bigger guy.” The camera pans across the head table and guest tables, capturing children standing by the table, servers moving through, and the governor and architect mingling. Louie’s narration blends pride in youth, local political speculation, and reverence for the celebrity guest.

chapters.title: Blessing Refrain & Dessert Banter

At one point, someone jokes about dessert (“How about a little dessert… I don’t take dessert”), and there is a light aside about keeping something “for the airway safety,” reinforcing the casual, convivial tone. The visuals show DiMaggio and companions finishing their meal, servers circulating, and guests relaxing into conversation.

chapters.title: Helicopter Arrival & VIP Movement (Briefly Revisited)

He complains again that “they won’t let me film” and jokes that he “stopped your camera” so staff can’t interfere. Back under the tent, he continues to identify the governor and the architect and notes that he has “things to do in New Orleans,” capturing snippets of small talk and movement as dignitaries circulate.

chapters.title: Photo‑Montage: DiMaggio with Families & Dignitaries

Still photographs and very steady posed shots are filmed off prints: DiMaggio at the head table with a boy in plaid (Justin Velcastro) and a blonde woman; DiMaggio flanked by club members, clergy, and a woman in sunglasses; and group portraits labeled “GUEST JOE DIMAGGIO” with multiple adults. Louie narrates over these stills, again describing his autographed poster, pointing out Justin, and repeatedly naming “Joe Mangin/Manchin” as a possible future governor. He also films a printed group photo dated “8 28 95,” anchoring the event in late summer 1995.

chapters.title: Joe Mangin/Manchin Highlight & Seated with DiMaggio
chapters.summary: Louie devotes a long sequence to a man he calls “Joe Mangin/Manchin.” He films posed portraits of this suited man with a young boy, then a labeled shot of the man and boy under the tent opening with the “GUEST JOE DIMAGGIO” overlay. Louie repeats the name many times, clearly trying to document it. The same man later appears seated beside DiMaggio at the table, reinforcing his status as a key local dignitary. Meanwhile, more posed shots show DiMaggio with various club members, a man in a patterned sweater, and a heavyset man in a dark polo. Louie’s narration continues to loop the name “Joe Mangin,” blending admiration, humor, and archival note‑taking.

chapters.title: Closing Credits & Ellis Productions Card
chapters.summary: The segment closes with a still image labeled “GUEST JOE DIMAGGIO,” followed by a simple title card reading “COPIED / EDITED BY / ELLIS PROD.” Over this, Louie reiterates that they were not scheduled to film and that their vantage point was poor, and he jokes again about being told not to film. A brief black screen follows as the audio transitions back into conversational snippets, signaling the end of this edited DiMaggio reel.

highlights.title: Ellis Productions Title & Filming Disclaimer
highlights.description: A static Ellis Productions sign introduces Louie and Nancy Ellis as the videographers. Louie explains they were not scheduled to film, their seat was bad, and they were even told not to film, framing everything that follows as candid, semi‑unauthorized documentation.

highlights.title: Course Architect Credited on Camera
highlights.description: As the camera finds a man in a shirt and tie walking toward the tent, Louie says, “He’s the architect. He’s the one who made the beauty of this golf course. That’s on camera,” making a point to preserve the architect’s contribution in the record.

highlights.description: Louie proudly reports, “I just got Joe DiMaggio to autograph a picture for my wife, Nancy Ellis. The poster had the pictures of Joe DiMaggio, Ted Williams, and Stan Musial. What great heroes on one picture,” tying his wife, the club, and baseball history together.

highlights.description: Louie, narrating over shots of the head table, says, “I might insert that there may be our next governor. Joe Mangin. Not the little guy, the bigger guy,” then repeats the name many times, playfully elevating a local dignitary’s status.

highlights.description: As dessert is discussed at the tables, Louie repeats, “TASTE EVERYTHING AND REJOICE IN EVERYTHING FOR THE BLESSING OF GOD AMEN,” turning the priest’s blessing into a recurring motif over scenes of people enjoying their meal.

highlights.description: Louie films a printed group photo of DiMaggio at the head table, labeled “GUEST JOE DIMAGGIO” with a date stamp “8 28 95,” visually anchoring the event in late August 1995 and preserving a key keepsake image.

Joung_JJL_Coal_Mining_Footage_No_Sound.title: Jim Compton & The Land Before Pete Dye Golf Club
Joung_JJL_Coal_Mining_Footage_No_Sound.content_type: Historical prologue & archival montage (family home movies, mining/industrial footage, early site work, community life)
Joung_JJL_Coal_Mining_Footage_No_Sound.summary: This archival reel functions as an extended prologue to the Pete Dye Golf Club story, centered on Jim Compton and the land’s pre–golf-course life. Over repeated narration, it traces the decline of the mining economy in 1978, introduces Compton’s biography, and explains his realization that corporate West Virginia needed an upscale meeting place. Visually, the piece weaves together decades of family home movies (babies, children, winter play, vacations, parades, youth football), extensive coal-mining and industrial footage, and early earthmoving on scarred mine land. It shows the family’s deep roots, the industrial backbone of the region, and the raw, post‑mining terrain that will later be transformed into Pete Dye Golf Club. The recurring off‑camera question “Are you sure you want to retire?” hints at a later‑life interview with Compton or another principal, framing the project as a refusal to step away and a choice to reinvent both self and land.

characters.name: Jim Compton
characters.description: Marketing and advertising professional from Clarksburg who returns after 20 years and recognizes the need for an upscale corporate meeting place, using family land as the basis for development. He does not appear clearly on camera but is the focus of the narration.

characters.name: Unidentified narrator
characters.description: Unseen voice delivering the repeated biographical and contextual narration about 1978, the fading mining industry, and Jim Compton’s life and vision.

characters.name: Unidentified interviewer / family voice
characters.description: Voice heard asking, “Are you sure you want to retire?”, likely in a later‑life interview or family conversation, used as a motif over various archival images.

characters.name: Unidentified family members (multiple)
characters.description: Adults, children, and infants appearing throughout in winter play, yard scenes, vacations, parades, and youth sports; they represent Compton’s extended family and community but cannot be reliably named from the footage alone.

chapters.title: Economic Decline & Introduction of Jim Compton
chapters.summary: The film opens with black frames and analog static while a narrator sets the historical context: in 1978, as mining’s family backbones faded, the area had to reinvent itself. Jim Compton is introduced—born and raised in Clarksburg, he left for a 20‑year career in marketing and advertising before returning as a seasoned professional. The narration explains that he saw a need for an upscale corporate meeting place and began thinking about how to use family land as his relatives sold off their holdings. Over this, the visuals gradually shift from black to snowy family home‑movie scenes: children and dogs playing in yards, modest houses, and neighborhood streets. The recurring line “Are you sure you want to retire?” appears for the first time, bridging formal narration and more personal material.

chapters.title: Family Roots: Home Movies, Babies, and Neighborhood Life
chapters.summary: A long montage of vintage home movies establishes multi‑generational family life. We see infants bundled in snow, adults in suits carrying babies to and from houses and churches, children sledding with dogs, and women and men in Sunday clothes walking to cars and up church steps. Warm‑weather footage shows babies in prams, toddlers learning to walk, children playing in yards, and family members gathering on porches and stairways. The narration about 1978, Jim’s biography, and his development ideas repeats over these images, tying the abstract story of economic change and land holdings to specific faces and homes. The line “Archival footage from Pete Dye Golf Club story (1978–2004)” is spoken over clearly aged film, explicitly framing these as the historical foundations of the club’s story.

chapters.title: From Backyard to Open Land: Rural Property & Ponies
chapters.summary: The imagery moves from tight domestic spaces to more open rural land. Children and adults visit fenced pastures with ponies and horses, walk along dirt roads bordered by wire fences, and observe expansive fields and hills. A vehicle travels the rough road as dust rises. The narration continues to describe Jim’s realization about corporate West Virginia’s need for an upscale meeting place and his family’s sale of holdings. Visually, the sequence suggests the kind of raw, underdeveloped property that could be repurposed into a golf course or corporate retreat, while still grounded in family outings and casual site visits.

chapters.title: Infancy & Legacy: Symbolic Baby Montage
chapters.summary: A concentrated series of close‑ups of a baby—calm, curious, then crying—plays under repeated narration about the fading mining industry, Jim’s life arc, and the family selling land. The baby’s shifting expressions—from neutral to distressed to soothed—visually echo the emotional stakes of economic upheaval and family decisions. The question “Are you sure you want to retire?” is juxtaposed with shots of the crying infant, suggesting anxiety around major life choices. The sequence ends with calmer images of the baby resting in a pram and being held by a smiling woman, reinforcing themes of generational continuity and the idea that decisions about land and development are made with future generations in mind.

chapters.title: Seasonal Family Life & Neighborhood Winter
chapters.summary: The film returns to broader family scenes: mothers pushing strollers, multiple children posing against brick walls, kids playing with toys in the yard, and then a shift to winter—deep snow, children with sleds, and a loyal dog. Adults help children shovel, walk hand‑in‑hand down snowy streets, and play in front of modest brick houses and garages. The narration about 1978, Jim’s background, and the need for reinvention continues over these images, grounding the macroeconomic story in the rhythms of ordinary family life in a West Virginia neighborhood.

chapters.title: Parades, Civic Pride, and Community Gatherings
chapters.summary: The focus widens to public life: colorful parade floats covered in paper flowers, marching bands, majorettes, costumed characters, and crowds lining downtown streets. Overhead decorations and storefronts evoke a mid‑20th‑century small town. The narration about Jim’s leadership and his family selling land plays over these scenes, linking his personal story to a broader civic context. The parades and community celebrations underscore that this is a place with strong traditions and public gatherings—an environment where an upscale meeting place and, later, a golf club could become a new focal point for events and pride.

chapters.title: Youth Football & Everyday Community Life
chapters.summary: A long series of youth football footage shows kids in white uniforms practicing and playing on modest school fields, with coaches, parents, and younger siblings on the sidelines. Bench shots highlight jersey numbers, while wide views show school buildings, hillsides, and small crowds. The narration about mining’s decline, Jim’s Clarksburg roots, his marketing career, and his vision for an upscale corporate venue repeats over these scenes. The contrast between the humble high‑school‑style fields and the idea of an upscale meeting place underscores the gap Jim perceives. Occasional close‑ups of children off the field—smiling at the camera—re‑center the story on family and community as the ultimate beneficiaries of any redevelopment.

chapters.title: Industrial Past: Coal Mines, Trains, and Tipples
chapters.summary: The montage shifts decisively to the region’s industrial backbone: coal trains marked B&O, long strings of loaded cars, elevated tipples and conveyors, dark coal piles, and muddy mine yards. We see processing buildings on stilts over tracks, silhouetted industrial structures, and rough, rutted ground. Occasional workers appear as small figures under the structures. The narration about 1978 and the fading mining industry plays directly over these images, visually reinforcing the economic context. Shots of rail lines, mine cars, and abandoned or aging facilities emphasize that this land and infrastructure are at the end of their original purpose, setting up the need for reinvention that Jim Compton will lead.

chapters.title: From Active Mining to Raw Post‑Mine Landscape
chapters.summary: We see active mining operations: draglines and shovels swinging buckets over snowy pits, bulldozers pushing earth, trucks being loaded with dark material, and smoke or dust rising from deep cuts. Then the footage transitions to quieter but still scarred landscapes—rocky corridors, exposed earth walls, muddy tracks, and barren hillsides. The narration continues to track Jim’s biography and his realization that corporate West Virginia needs an upscale meeting place. These visuals show the literal ground he is starting from: a heavily worked, winter‑bare strip‑mine environment that must be reclaimed and reshaped before it can host a golf course or corporate retreat.

chapters.title: Early Site Visits, Family Presence, and First Earthmoving
chapters.summary: The camera follows cars along muddy access roads into leafless woods and across rough mine land. We see small farmhouses, fuel tanks, and family figures walking the property—stocky older men in caps, pairs of adults heading toward bulldozers, and workers refueling machines. Heavy equipment—bulldozers, excavators, draglines—begins to appear not just as mining tools but as instruments of site preparation: cutting primitive roads, grading slopes, and moving spoil. The narration about Jim’s return, his planning, and his family selling holdings overlays these scenes, suggesting that this is the moment when family land transitions from extraction to intentional redevelopment. The recurring question “Are you sure you want to retire?” is heard over active work, implying that instead of stepping back, someone (likely Compton or a family elder) is deeply engaged in a new, demanding project.

chapters.title: Mining Infrastructure & Abandoned Industrial Skeletons
chapters.summary: The film surveys the remaining industrial skeletons: large tipples, conveyors, processing buildings, office structures, tanks, and narrow‑gauge rail lines with side‑dump cars. Many appear inactive or abandoned, surrounded by winter vegetation and muddy roads. The audio label “Archival footage from Pete Dye Golf Club story (1978–2004)” is repeated over some of these shots, explicitly tying this industrial past to the club’s origin story. The visuals underscore how deeply the land was shaped by coal and how much physical and symbolic work will be required to convert this environment into a high‑end golf destination.

chapters.title: Closing Black Frames & Narrated Setup
chapters.summary: The final portion of the provided material consists largely of solid black frames while the core narration is repeated cleanly: the 1978 decline of mining, Jim Compton’s Clarksburg roots, his 20‑year marketing and advertising career, his return, and his realization that corporate West Virginia needed an upscale meeting place. The narration concludes with his decision to develop family land as relatives sold off their holdings, followed by the teasing question, “Are you sure you want to retire?” and the meta‑label, “Archival footage from Pete Dye Golf Club story (1978–2004).” These black‑frame segments function as an audio spine for the earlier visual montage and likely serve as a structural intro or outro in the larger documentary. The very last audio line, “Thank you for watching,” suggests this reel may also have been used as a standalone historical piece or temp assembly.

highlights.title: Narrative Spine: Jim Compton’s Biography in One Sentence
highlights.description: Over black frames, the narrator delivers a concise arc: Jim Compton, born and raised in Clarksburg, leaves for a 20‑year marketing and advertising career, then returns as a skilled professional who sees the need for an upscale corporate meeting place and looks to family land as his vehicle for change.

highlights.title: The Retirement Question Motif
highlights.description: The line “Are you sure you want to retire?” is first heard over black or simple transitional footage, then recurs over family winter scenes, baby close‑ups, and active construction shots. It functions as a thematic hook, suggesting that instead of retiring, a key figure chose to embark on the ambitious redevelopment that led to Pete Dye Golf Club.

highlights.title: Family in the Snow with Dog and Sled
highlights.description: A bundled child and a dark dog play in deep snow around a modest brick house, pulling a sled, tumbling, and being helped by an adult. The narration about mining’s decline and Jim’s life plays over this, vividly grounding the economic story in the texture of everyday family life.

highlights.title: Coal Trains and Tipples as the Old Backbone
highlights.description: Long strings of B&O coal cars, elevated tipples, conveyors, and dark coal piles dominate the frame while the narrator speaks of the “family backbones of the mining industry” fading. The imagery powerfully visualizes the industrial system that once sustained the region and now stands as a relic.

highlights.title: First Clear Signs of Land Transformation
highlights.description: Heavy equipment—bulldozers, excavators, draglines—works across muddy cuts and rocky corridors, with workers refueling machines and walking the site. These shots mark the shift from passive post‑mine landscape to active reshaping, foreshadowing the eventual creation of the Pete Dye Golf Club course.

highlights.title: Youth Football as Community Backdrop
highlights.description: Extended sequences of youth football games, with kids on benches, coaches on the sideline, and families in the bleachers, play under narration about Jim’s return and his vision for an upscale meeting place. The modest field and school buildings highlight the gap between existing community facilities and the corporate‑level venue he imagines.

highlights.title: Mining Pit Under Snow: The Land Before Reinvention
highlights.description: A large dragline swings its bucket over a snowy pit, terraced benches and bare trees framing a stark industrial winter landscape. The narrator speaks of the area being forced to reinvent itself, and the viewer sees exactly what must be reinvented.

PDGC_1994_Opening_of_the_back_nine_Bembe.title: Pete Dye Golf Club – 1994 Guest House & Back Nine Opening / Member‑Guest Tournament
PDGC_1994_Opening_of_the_back_nine_Bembe.content_type: Grand opening event, guest-house tour, and member‑guest golf tournament coverage
PDGC_1994_Opening_of_the_back_nine_Bembe.summary: This archival tape intercuts three main threads from late September and October 1, 1994 at Pete Dye Golf Club: (1) a guided interior tour of the brand‑new guest house led by interior designer Valerie Smith; (2) opening‑day festivities for the inaugural play of the completed 18 holes (back nine opening) and the 1994 Men’s Member‑Guest tournament; and (3) extensive on‑course portraits and introductions of members and guests. Shot and narrated largely by family friend and documentarian Louie Ellis, with on‑camera hosting help from Harris Holt and others, the footage captures both the physical spaces (guest house, course, lakes, mining‑heritage features) and the club’s social fabric (LaRosa family, staff, members, and out‑of‑town guests). It documents the club’s transition from long construction to full operation, emphasizing hospitality, community, and pride in realizing James D. LaRosa’s vision.

characters.name: Louie Ellis
characters.description: Shoots most of the footage, constantly talking to camera, prompting people for names, joking about not being paid and wanting breakfast, and signing his work as “Ellis Productions, Route 50, east on Bridgeport Hill.”

characters.name: Valerie Smith
characters.role: Interior designer of the guest house
characters.description: Introduced as being from Harrison County/Clarksburg, living in Atlanta. She designed the interior colors, window treatments, furniture, and most selections in the new guest house and gives a functional tour of a typical guest room and bath.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.description: Appears near the end identifying himself as “James D., Jimmy Joe’s dad,” calling himself “the chaplain” and expressing pride in the big day. Central symbolic figure of the opening.

characters.name: Jimmy (Jim) LaRosa
characters.description: Referred to as “Jimmy Joe,” “Jimmy LaRose,” and “James” in banter. He appears as a sharply dressed host at the member‑guest opening, interacting with guests and staff; his voice is heard welcoming players and acknowledging Ellis Productions.

characters.name: Harris Holt
characters.description: Identifies himself as “Harris Holt.” Teases Louie about not setting up the jelly and butter correctly, rearranges the buffet, and later explains to camera what’s happening with the carts and the grand opening round.

characters.name: Bill Stines
characters.description: Named on camera as “Bill Stein” (mispronunciation of Stines). He’s introduced as a friend of Jimmy LaRosa, “just here to help out,” and is thanked while Ellis plugs “video provided by Ellis Productions.”

characters.name: Carol Hart
characters.description: Introduces herself by name; sister to Ann Hart. Works the breakfast/buffet line and is asked if the jelly and butter are now arranged correctly.

characters.name: Ann Hart
characters.description: Introduces herself; works with Harris to rearrange jelly and butter. Appears multiple times around the food setup and tent.

characters.name: Julie Goodwin
characters.description: Introduces herself as “Julie Goodwin,” present “for the opening.” Appears with Clarice Burkhammer and Ann Hart as part of the morning crew.

characters.name: Clarice Burkhammer
characters.description: Introduces herself in the trio with Julie and Ann; part of the breakfast/opening crew.

characters.name: Chris (chef)
characters.description: Identified as “our chef, Chris… Kurtner.” Seen at the grill and buffet, acknowledged by Louie as “You’re a star.”

characters.name: Harris (unidentified suited host by lake)
characters.role: On‑camera host for intro by lake
characters.description: An older man in a light suit with a camera around his neck delivers the formal on‑camera introduction by the misty lake. Name not explicitly given in transcript; distinct from Harris Holt’s breakfast‑table persona but may be the same Harris in a different role.

characters.name: Multiple members & guests
characters.description: Dozens of men introduce themselves with name and hometown (e.g., Mark Tinsher, Phil Asmundsen, Parker Smith, Wally Uline, Jim Jackson, Bob DeMoss, etc.). They are filmed on tees and in carts during the 1994 Member‑Guest and back‑nine opening.

characters.name: Nancy Ellis
characters.description: Not seen speaking, but Louie and James D. address her directly in absentia, thanking her for support and “making it more available to us.”

characters.name: Pete Dye
characters.description: Not seen speaking in this tape, but repeatedly praised by Louie as the designer who “came to the rescue” and created “what a beauty” in the hills of West Virginia.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa (Jimmy Joe’s dad)
characters.description: Appears at the end calling himself “the chaplain” and “James D., Jimmy Joe’s dad,” expressing pride in the day and greeting Nancy Ellis.

chapters.title: 1. Ellis Productions Title & Guest House Interior Tour Setup
chapters.summary: The tape opens with an Ellis Productions title card and business card crediting “Louis P. Ellis, Producer/Director.” It then cuts to the new Pete Dye Golf Club guest house, where Valerie Smith is introduced as the Atlanta‑based interior designer with roots in Harrison County. Louie explains he will “scan” the room while Valerie describes it. She explains that the room is for individual guests with private exterior access, points out the cherry armoire from Friendly Furniture in Fairmont, the table for in‑room coffee and work, two queen beds, and golf‑themed prints loaned from a member’s private collection. The camera documents the beds, artwork, and a functional bathroom with double vanity, shower, and private water closet.

chapters.title: 2. Guest House Bedrooms, Living Areas, and Member‑Contributed Décor
chapters.summary: The tour continues through additional guest rooms and common areas. Valerie emphasizes that the bathrooms are “very functional” with plenty of mirrors and can comfortably accommodate two people. Louie notes there are eight beautiful bedrooms in the guest house and that the two Connecticut guests they just interviewed will be staying there. The camera shows more beds, bathrooms, a checkerboard inlaid into a table, and an outdoor deck on both floors. From the deck, Louie films the back nine under construction/completion and praises the view, calling it “awesome” and marveling at the coal from the real Columbia Mine and the line of coal cars used as a course feature. He repeatedly praises “Mr. LaRosa, Jimmy Joe and the crew… Pete Dye, what a beauty you have created here in the hills of West Virginia.”

chapters.title: 3. Lakes, Back Nine Landscape & Mining Heritage Features
chapters.summary: Louie documents one of the last man‑made lakes on the back nine, noting it is still filling and will be in play on October 1, 1994. He frames the course as a dream of the LaRosas that “Pete Dye came to the rescue” to realize. Scenic shots show ponds, fairways, wooded hills, and the line of coal cars that reference the site’s mining history. This B‑roll is intercut with or underlaid by Valerie’s continuing audio description of the guest house interiors, blending course scenery with hospitality details.

chapters.title: 4. Tent Setup, Breakfast Buffet & Opening‑Day Staff Introductions
chapters.summary: The date shifts to October 1, 1994. Early‑morning shots show large white tents, long banquet tables with white cloths, and a breakfast/refreshment setup near the course. Louie films the buffet line and jokes about hoping to get fed because he doesn’t get paid for video. He introduces several women working the opening: Julie Goodwin, Clarice Burkhammer, and Ann Hart. He teases one woman about hiding from the camera and captures candid smiles and nervousness. The atmosphere is anticipatory as staff finalize preparations for the back‑nine opening and member‑guest event.

chapters.title: 5. Harris, the Harts & Breakfast Line Comedy
chapters.summary: Louie continues around the breakfast area, introducing more staff. Carol Hart identifies herself and confirms Ann is her younger sister. Louie and Harris Holt joke about rearranging the jelly and butter correctly; Harris insists Louie “didn’t get this done correctly” so he and Ann had to fix it. Harris identifies himself on camera and directs Louie to “take a picture of this,” playing the bossy friend. Chef Chris is introduced at the grill. Louie repeatedly jokes about wanting proof that he got to eat and that the food is “on LaRose,” while Harris films him going through the line for a second helping. The segment ends with Louie filming a dramatic sunrise over the course, marveling at the rays and asking Harris to confirm how beautiful it is.

chapters.title: 6. Formal Lakefront Introduction & Sunrise Over the Course
chapters.summary: An older man in a light suit with a camera around his neck stands by a misty lake and delivers a formal on‑camera introduction: this is the showing of the new guest house at the official opening of Pete Dye Golf Club, owned by James D. and Jimmy Joe LaRosa, designed by Pete Dye, on October 1, 1994, filmed by Louie Ellis. This is intercut with scenic shots of waterfalls, ponds, and long lines of golf carts and guests assembling near the clubhouse. Louie later films the sunrise and fog over the lake, comparing the mist to “The Hounds of the Baskervilles,” while Harris explains that all the carts are for members and their guests teeing off on grand opening day, likely playing all 18 holes including the new back nine.
characters_present: Unidentified suited host by lake (possibly Harris in different attire)

chapters.title: 7. Guest House Guests & First Occupants: Mark Tinsher & Phil Asmundsen
chapters.summary: Inside or near the guest house, a club representative introduces two early arriving guests from Connecticut: Mark Tinsher (Stamford) and his guest Phil Asmundsen (Wilton). They got up at 5:30 to fly from New York. The host jokes that they don’t realize the honor—they are the first to stay in the guest house, and his own engagement was rescheduled to accommodate them for the second annual Men’s 1994 Member‑Guest and the inaugural opening of the back nine. There’s mention of a possible visit by Pete Dye depending on travel plans. Louie then shows the in‑room microwave, coffee pot, and stocked fridge for soft drinks, bottled water, snacks, and “a few beers,” joking about one guest being a part‑time preacher and not wanting to scare him. Louie notes there are eight bedrooms and that “when Jim does it, they do it right.”

chapters.title: 8. Member‑Guest Registration, Staff & Buffet Bar Details
chapters.summary: Louie roams between the guest house deck, buffet, and bar areas, filming staff and early guests. He captures Pam (greeted with “Buongiorno”), Ike Winter, and others. Harris Holt and Ann Hart again rearrange jelly and butter, ribbing Louie. Louie introduces Carol Hart and confirms her relation to Ann. Chef Chris is again shown. A suited man (likely Bill Stines) and Jimmy LaRosa appear at the registration area; Jimmy is described as “decked out like a page out of Esquire” and jokes that he “slept in the bunker last night.” Bill Stines identifies himself as “a friend of Jimmy LaRose’s just here to help out.” Louie plugs “video is provided by Ellis Productions, Route 50, east on Bridgeport Hill.” A bar table with liquor, wine, and glasses is filmed, as well as fruit bowls and décor, underscoring the club’s hospitality.

chapters.title: 9. Mass Player Roll‑Call: Member‑Guest Teams & Hometowns
chapters.summary: A large portion of the tape is devoted to Louie standing on a tee or staging area and systematically filming every member‑guest pairing as they introduce themselves. Each duo gives names and hometowns: Mark Tinsher & Phil Asmundsen (CT), Parker Smith & Wally Uline, Jim Jackson & Bob DeMoss, Tim Dyer & Dave Hanna, Mickey Trevino & Jim Westfall, Marty Roach & Lou Guest, Glenn Adrian & Ken Jeskowicz, Alex Chang & Randy Resnick, Nick Johnson & Dave Watson, Ron Blankenship & Pat Weaver, Ed Heflin & Len Shirley, Paul Gabriel & George Petitti, Jerry Kendrick & Don C. (Albany, GA), Jeff Lawrenson & Dave Allman, Jack Muscaro & John Pignetti, and many more. Louie jokes about bank robberies when players mention Morgantown, teases about being “wanted in five states,” and notes that Louie Allman made a hole‑in‑one on number 7 with a 7‑iron and had to buy drinks for the house. The roll‑call continues with players from West Virginia, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Georgia, Illinois, Nebraska, Florida, Maryland, and beyond, illustrating the club’s reach and the scale of the event.

chapters.title: 10. More Teams, Running Gags & Magician Interlude
chapters.summary: The introductions continue with more teams: Bill Eggert & Fred Summers (who boast they will “definitely win this event”), Bob Mays & Vince Simonetti, Don Gracie & Bob Quinn, C.E. White & Scott Runyon, Paul Cox & Ben Amon, Richard Cicchetti & Pete Gabriel, Tom Douglas & Roger Lohosick, Jeff Smith & Dan Pickens (joking about not being the wealthy Dr. Pickens), Frank Mazey & Rodney LaRose (Rodney defends his partner as “a great man”), Dr. John Tucker & Mark Fentye, Hugh Staley & Dan Bonar, Manny Alvarez & Brian Mosser, Jeff Keester & David Alvarez, Dale Ramsburg & Brian Amon, and many more. Kevin Dawson from Atlanta, Louie’s guest, performs a quick “magician” bit, pretending to push golf balls through someone. Louie keeps up a patter of jokes about Irish names, political campaigns (Jimmy Kan running for House of Delegates), and players’ hometowns, while also noting special feats like Louie Allman’s hole‑in‑one.

chapters.title: 11. Afternoon Foursomes & On‑Course Portraits
chapters.summary: Later in the day, Louie continues filming pairs and small groups on various tees and greens, now with timestamps around late morning and early afternoon. Players pose with clubs, sometimes in themed sweaters or bright outfits, and often joke or banter with Louie. Some are filmed mid‑swing or putting. The audio from Valerie’s guest‑house tour is sometimes overlaid on these visuals, indicating later editing or dubbing. The sequence shows the course in full use, with carts, fall foliage, and the new back nine in play, reinforcing the sense of a vibrant, well‑attended opening‑day tournament.
characters_present: Numerous unnamed or previously named golfers

chapters.title: 12. Closing: James D. LaRosa’s On‑Camera Blessing & Thanks to Nancy
chapters.summary: Near the end, Louie announces, “We keep the best for last,” and turns the camera on James D. LaRosa. James jokingly calls himself “the chaplain” and says that every time he goes around there are three signs saying “Praise the Lord.” He identifies himself as “James D., Jimmy Joe’s dad,” and says he’s having a big, special day and is proud of the whole organization. Louie prompts him to say something to Nancy Ellis; James greets “Mrs. Nance” and thanks Nancy for her support and for making things more available to them. Louie then cuts back to the back nine, declaring, “There we are folks, on the back nine, the first official day opening of the Pete Dye Golf Club. Isn’t that beautiful?” The tape ends with wind noise and repeated comments about “a lot of wind,” underscoring the raw, documentary nature of the footage.

highlights.title: Valerie Smith’s Functional Guest Room Tour
highlights.description: Valerie explains that the guest room is for individual guests with private exterior access, points out the cherry armoire from Friendly Furniture in Fairmont, the in‑room table for coffee and work, and two queen beds beneath member‑loaned golf prints.

highlights.title: First Guest House Occupants from Connecticut
highlights.description: Mark Tinsher and Phil Asmundsen, who flew in early from New York, are told they are the first to stay in the guest house. The host jokes that his own engagement was rescheduled to accommodate them for the second annual Men’s Member‑Guest and the inaugural opening of the back nine.

highlights.title: Louie’s Awe at the Back Nine & Coal Cars
highlights.description: From the guest house deck, Louie films the back nine and the line of coal cars, calling the view “awesome,” praising Mr. LaRosa, Jimmy Joe, and Pete Dye for creating such beauty in the hills of West Virginia, and noting the real coal from the Columbia Mine.

highlights.title: Harris & Ann ‘Fix’ the Jelly and Butter
highlights.description: Harris Holt scolds Louie for not setting up the jelly and butter correctly and, with Ann Hart, rearranges the items while narrating what they’re doing. Louie laughs and calls it “always Harris telling me what to do.”

highlights.title: Sunrise Over Pete Dye Golf Club
highlights.description: Louie films the sun rising over misty hills and the course, marveling at the rays and asking Harris if it isn’t beautiful. The timestamp and date are shown, anchoring the moment as the dawn of the official opening day.

highlights.title: Mass Player Roll‑Call & Running Jokes
highlights.description: Louie stands on a tee and records dozens of member‑guest pairs introducing themselves and their hometowns. He jokes about bank robberies, being “wanted in five states,” and Irish names, while also noting a hole‑in‑one and players’ long travels.

highlights.title: Kevin Dawson’s ‘Magician’ Bit
highlights.description: Kevin Dawson from Atlanta, introduced as Louie’s guest, pretends to push golf balls through someone’s body, demonstrating his “magician” skills for the camera.

highlights.title: James D. LaRosa’s Closing Blessing
highlights.description: James D. LaRosa calls himself “the chaplain,” identifies as “James D., Jimmy Joe’s dad,” and expresses pride in the big, special day. He greets Nancy Ellis and thanks her for her support, providing an emotional capstone to the opening‑day footage.

highlights.title: Declaration of the Back Nine’s First Official Day
highlights.description: Louie films the back nine and declares, “There we are folks, on the back nine, the first official day opening of the Pete Dye Golf Club. Isn’t that beautiful?” emphasizing the historic nature of the moment.

quotes.text: This is for individual guests. They can enter from an exterior door so they have private access.
quotes.speaker: Valerie Smith
quotes.context: Explaining the purpose and layout of a guest room in the new guest house during the interior tour.

quotes.text: There’s an armoire that they got at Friendly Furniture in Fairmont. It’s cherry. It’s to put their things in there. Later on, they can put a TV in there if they’d like.
quotes.speaker: Valerie Smith
quotes.context: Detailing the furnishings and future‑proofing of the guest room storage during the tour.

quotes.text: The prints that you see were from a guest, I’m sorry, a member that Jim LaRosa… she offered to let us use those. All the pictures that you’ll see in the bedrooms are part of this private collection.
quotes.speaker: Valerie Smith
quotes.context: Describing the origin of the golf‑themed artwork in the bedrooms and emphasizing member contributions.

quotes.text: When Jim does it, they do it right.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Commenting on the quality and completeness of the eight bedrooms in the new guest house.

quotes.text: Beautiful, Mr. LaRosa, Jimmy Joe and the crew, whoever. Pete Dye, what a beauty you have created here in the hills of West Virginia.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Filming the back nine and coal‑heritage features from the guest house deck, praising the LaRosas and Pete Dye.

quotes.text: A dream that the LaRosa had and Pete Dye came to the rescue. How do you like that, Pete?
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Narrating over shots of the back nine and lakes, framing the course as the realization of the LaRosa dream with Pete Dye’s help.

quotes.text: You boys don’t really realize the honor. You are the first. I was supposed to be the first, but my engagement was called off because of you two guys.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified club host (likely Jimmy LaRosa or senior staff)
quotes.context: Welcoming Mark Tinsher and Phil Asmundsen as the first official occupants of the guest house for the 1994 Member‑Guest.

quotes.text: Rescheduled so we could accommodate Mark and his guests to be with us for the second annual Men’s 1994 Member Guest Tournament and the inaugural opening of the back nine.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified club host (likely Jimmy LaRosa or senior staff)
quotes.context: Explaining the significance of the weekend and why the schedule was adjusted for the Connecticut guests.

quotes.text: You two guys have officially opened the 1994 member guest here at the Pete Dye Golf Club. Welcome here early morning. It’s about 7:30, and we’re so happy to be here.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified announcer at registration (likely Jimmy LaRosa or Bill Stines)
quotes.context: On‑camera welcome to the member‑guest participants at the breakfast/registration area.

quotes.text: First of all, you didn’t get this done correctly, so therefore Ann and I had to come over and do it.
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: Teasing Louie about the jelly and butter arrangement at the breakfast table while he and Ann Hart fix it.

quotes.text: Folks, that’s the sunrise over the Pete Dye Golf Club… Great day. You just look at that sight up there. Look at that sun gonna come in pretty soon. Isn’t that beautiful over there?
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Filming the early‑morning sunrise over the course on October 1, 1994, expressing awe at the scene.

quotes.text: All these people, all these carts are for the members and their guests who are teeing off, and this is the grand opening day for the Pete Dye Golf Club.
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: Explaining the scene of many carts and players assembling for the grand opening round on the back nine.

quotes.text: Now, Louie Allman made a hole‑in‑one yesterday on number seven using a seven iron. Isn’t that great? We’re very proud of him. Did he get a prize for that? He had to buy drinks for the house.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified announcer (likely club staff)
quotes.context: During player introductions, highlighting a recent hole‑in‑one and the tradition of buying drinks.

quotes.text: I’m Kevin Dawson. I’m from Atlanta, Georgia, Louie’s guest. I’m also the magician. You take the golf balls and go like that, they’ll go right through you.

quotes.text: Oh, I’m the chaplain. And every time I go around, there’s like three signs: Praise the Lord. And I’m James D., Jimmy Joe’s dad. I’m having a big, special day here today. I really got it going. I’m proud of the whole organization.

quotes.text: Hi, Mrs. Nance. I want to say hi to Nancy Ellis. Thank you, Nancy. Make it more available to us, your support.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Addressing Louie’s wife Nancy directly, thanking her for her support of the project and the family.

quotes.text: There we are folks, on the back nine, the first official day opening of the Pete Dye Golf Club. Isn’t that beautiful?
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Filming the back nine late in the tape, explicitly marking the historic first official day of full 18‑hole play.

PDGC_CBS_Promo_10-19-98.title: CBS Morning Bumper – Pete Dye Golf Club Reclaimed Coal Mine Spot
PDGC_CBS_Promo_10-19-98.summary: A 15-second CBS Morning bumper featuring the Pete Dye Golf Club in Clarksburg, West Virginia. A professional narrator contrasts typical American golf courses with this course, which was built on abandoned coal mine lands. Brief visuals show a spokesperson-like golfer on the green, a putting shot, and the mine entrance, before ending on a CBS Morning graphic with the tagline “there’s more to this MORNING.” The spot positions the club as a symbol of land reclamation and uses golf as a metaphor for “teeing off” the day with CBS.

characters.name: Unknown professional narrator
characters.description: Unseen professional voiceover artist delivering the scripted lines that describe the Pete Dye Golf Club and tie it into CBS Morning programming.

characters.name: Unidentified male golfer / spokesperson
characters.role: On-camera representative of Pete Dye Golf Club
characters.description: Middle-aged man in golf attire standing on the green and later at a mine entrance, visually representing the club and its reclaimed coal mine setting. No dialogue is heard from him; he appears only in silent shots under narration.

chapters.title: Production Slate and Audio Lead-In
chapters.summary: The clip opens with several seconds of black followed by a blue production slate labeled as a 15-second 'Morning Bumper.' The narrator’s voice begins over black, introducing the idea that most American golf courses look a certain way, setting up a contrast with Pete Dye Golf Club. This establishes that the footage is a finished TV promo rather than raw documentary material.

chapters.title: Introducing Pete Dye Golf Club on Reclaimed Coal Mine Land
chapters.summary: The visual content of the bumper begins: a man stands on a green near a flagstick, then a golfer is shown putting, followed by the same man standing at the entrance of an old coal mine. Over these images, the narrator explains that at Pete Dye Golf Club in Clarksburg, West Virginia, a golf course was built around abandoned coal mine lands, highlighting the reclamation story and the course’s unique setting.

chapters.title: CBS Morning Brand Tie-In and Close
chapters.summary: The spot concludes with a full-screen CBS Morning graphic reading 'there’s more to this MORNING' as the narrator says that on weekdays 'we tee off with CBS' because there is 'more to this morning.' The screen then goes to black, with extra black tail beyond the actual bumper content, indicating archival padding after the promo’s end.

highlights.title: CBS Morning tagline integration
