PDGC_Construction_8-31-93_thru_7-7-94-01.title: Pete Dye Golf Club – Earthmoving Years & Crew Portraits (18th Hole Focus, 1993–1994)
PDGC_Construction_8-31-93_thru_7-7-94-01.content_type: Construction footage with on‑site interviews and planning-room discussion
PDGC_Construction_8-31-93_thru_7-7-94-01.summary:
This archival segment documents the heavy-construction phase of the Pete Dye Golf Club, centered primarily on the 18th hole and, secondarily, on the 11th and 15th holes and future practice areas. Shot between 1989 and mid‑1994, it intercuts:
- Field footage of earthmoving, drainage installation, green and bank shaping, and lake construction.
- On‑camera narration and walk‑throughs by James D. LaRosa and other project leads.
- Planning-room conversations with Pete Dye and James D. LaRosa reflecting on design philosophy and specific holes.
- Candid portraits of equipment operators and long‑time crew (Joe Hall’s crew, Danny Harris, Skip Reel, etc.).

The narrative through-line is the transformation of a former coal property along Simpson Creek into a dramatic, strategic Pete Dye course, with special emphasis on the 18th fairway/green complex, the Simpson Creek bridge to #10, and the twin lakes on #15.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.description: Appears both in the field and in the wood‑paneled meeting room. In the field he stands on graded fairways and in lake basins, holding a microphone, explaining yardages, green revisions, lake depths, and construction logistics. In the office he sits in a blue cardigan, discussing design, finances, and staff like Joe Hall and Keith Sparkman.

characters.name: Pete Dye
characters.description: Seen in the indoor meeting segment (balding, glasses, beige sweater). He speaks at length about strategy, topography, the balance of the front and back nines, and the concept for the 17th green. His comments are philosophical and comparative (Crooked Stick, St Andrews, Augusta).

characters.name: Louie Ellis
characters.description: Usually behind the camera, but briefly seen in earlier segments in a red blazer and in some field shots. His voice is heard introducing segments and joking with James D. and crew. He is the one being called “Cecil B. DeMille” by Pete Dye.

characters.name: Keith “Sparky” Sparkman
characters.description: Identified repeatedly in narration as “old Sparky,” “one of the greatest people as far as greens are concerned.” Visually he appears in work clothes on dozers and on slopes, but often camera is too distant for a clear face. His work is the shaped greens, banks, and seeded slopes around 11, 16, 18.

characters.name: Joe Hall
characters.description: Mentioned by James D. as the foreman in charge of sand mix, drainage, and rock walls around tees. Seen with his “holy crew” at the 10th tee, in yellow shirt with his back to camera, taking a lunch break.

characters.name: Skip Reel
characters.description: Named by James D. as “operator extraordinaire” on the 15th lakes. Seen operating 631 scrapers hauling clay from the upper to lower lake and later bringing loads to the future practice range / executive par‑3 area.

characters.name: Danny Harris
characters.description: Identified on camera by James D. as “Danny Harris, operator of a 631 scraper… just learned to run this a couple weeks ago.” Seen driving a large scraper, then stopped so Louie can film him.

characters.name: Alon Kovachny
characters.description: Named repeatedly (also pronounced “Kovoshny/Kovachny”) as the landscape architect from WVU. Seen on the 15th tee in a white shirt among a group of men, and later standing with James D. and Skip Reel in the upper‑lake basin.

characters.name: Carson Davis
characters.description: Introduced by James D. standing beside his service truck in a dark shirt. Credited with keeping old equipment running and repairing scrapers that went down.

characters.name: Unnamed operators & crew (Joe Hall’s crew, sod crews, dozer operators)
characters.description: Numerous shirtless or T‑shirted men laying sod on steep banks, operating dozers, scrapers, rollers, and excavators, and taking lunch breaks. They are collectively credited for drainage, rock walls, tees, greens, and lake liners.

characters.name: Harris Holt
characters.description: Mentioned by James D. in other segments; here he is referenced in the office/lunch context but not clearly seen in this excerpt.

characters.name: Jack Anderson
characters.description: Mentioned by James D. as someone he is skipping lunch with to film with Louie; not clearly seen here.

characters.name: Alain Kovachny (duplicate spelling)
characters.description: Same as Alon Kovachny; appears in field segments on 15th tee and lakes.

chapters.title: 1. 18th Hole & Simpson Creek – First Pass (Aug 1993)
chapters.summary: Louie’s camera documents the raw state of the future 18th hole on August 31, 1993. From high, imperfect vantage points he shows drains being installed, banks cut along Simpson Creek, and early outlines of the 18th green and bridge to #10. He repeatedly orients the viewer: standing in the middle of the future fairway, at his own landing area, and near the 18th green looking across to #10. Heavy equipment (dozers, scrapers, rollers, excavators) clear brush, revamp the fairway, and form gravel‑based greens. Louie introduces greens man Keith “Sparky” Sparkman and points out seeded banks that look “painted white.”
characters_present: Unnamed operators & crew (Joe Hall’s crew, sod crews, dozer operators)

chapters.title: 2. Shaping 16 & 17, and Revising 11 & 12
chapters.summary: James D. appears on camera on the 11th green, explaining that Pete has moved it 30 yards to make a true three‑shot par‑5 of 625–630 yards. He describes the D9 dozer rough‑shaping for Pete, who will return to refine it, and praises Keith Sparkman’s work on steep banks and sod. He then walks viewers through the revised 12th (a 290‑yard one‑shot par‑4 with a blinding mound and pot bunker) and the dramatic 245‑yard downhill 16th par‑3 with a huge 7,500 sq‑ft green, plastic retaining walls, and a “blue bunker” crater 12 feet deep. He explains Pete’s intent: long hitters who hook will be punished in the blue bunker, while forward tees keep the hole fair for higher handicaps. Throughout, sod crews are shown working steep slopes, and James D. details gravel layers, plastic liners, and multi‑tee setups.
characters_present: Unnamed operators & crew (Joe Hall’s crew, sod crews, dozer operators)

chapters.title: 3. Winter Problems, Bridge Lowering & Maintenance Building (Feb–Apr 1994)
chapters.summary: Louie films a February 1994 landslide at the club entrance, documenting the “bad part” of construction and joking about Olympic skating on the frozen pond. In March he records the removal and lowering of the high bridge between #9 and #10 under Bob Andrews’ direction, with timestamps as each half is moved and reset. In April, James D. and others describe the new maintenance building being erected from a dismantled LaRosa Fuel structure, and Gary Grandstaff explains the small A‑frame shop and the new 60x180 maintenance facility. The segment also shows the first spring tournament carts lined up, and a brief office lunch where Jimmy LaRosa thanks secretaries and staff for helping the company pivot from coal to golf and real estate.
characters_present: Unnamed operators & crew (Joe Hall’s crew, sod crews, dozer operators)

chapters.title: 4. Practice Range, 10th Tee Rock Walls & Staff Intros (Spring 1994)
chapters.summary: James D. stands on the under‑construction practice range, explaining irrigation installation, topsoil needs, and how tees will be oriented to allow 300+ yard shots in multiple directions. He points out a red truck and yellow backhoe on #10 tee where Joe Hall’s crew is hand‑placing the final rock layer on the tee walls. He thanks Louie and Nancy for documenting the work. Later, he introduces Danny Harris (new 631 scraper operator) and Skip Reel hauling clay from the 15th lake to fill a future practice range or executive par‑3 area. In the clubhouse, Louie films a secretary/employee appreciation lunch where Jimmy LaRosa praises his team for navigating the shift from coal to golf development, and Louie jokes about his long‑standing “no charge” remark. Head pro Bill Steins is introduced and later explains a new deck addition for outdoor dining.
characters_present: Office staff (Regina/Stephanie Carter, John Belcaster, Pat Snyder, Rita Forsyth, Nancy Ellis)

chapters.title: 5. Lakes on 15 & Executive Par‑3 / Practice Range (July 1994)
chapters.summary: On July 1, 1994, James D. narrates from the rim and bottom of the 15th lake as scrapers and dozers install an 8‑inch clay liner to prevent leakage. He explains depths (3–16 feet), shelves for fish spawning, and plans for rock “fish houses” and submerged pine trees. He describes the upper lake, 11 feet higher, to create a waterfall effect and give Pete water from tee to green on the right side of #15. Landscape architect Alon Kovachny and operators Skip Reel and Randy Haddix are introduced in the upper lake basin. James D. then shows how clay from the upper lake is being hauled to fill a 25‑acre area that will become either a major practice range or an executive par‑3, pointing out the sand/mulch mixing plant, shale pile for drainage, and railroad ballast for roads and cart paths.
characters_present: Unnamed operators & crew (Joe Hall’s crew, sod crews, dozer operators)

chapters.title: 6. 11th Hole Extension & Sod on Steep Banks
chapters.summary: James D. stands on the 11th green area, explaining that Pete has lengthened the par‑5 from 570 to 615 yards and steepened the banks to create a dramatic, long three‑shot hole. He shows a huge bunker along the left side where Pete wants players to be able to walk up from bunker to green halfway along its length. Crews are shown raking and sodding extremely steep banks, using U‑shaped nails to hold sod in place. James D. notes that sod must be laid the day it arrives (from Ohio) and watered heavily, but this area is irrigated so they expect a good catch. He points out the professional tee for #12 above the 11th green and emphasizes that once the sod is down, the 11th will be essentially complete.
characters_present: Unnamed operators & crew (Joe Hall’s crew, sod crews, dozer operators)

chapters.title: 7. Practice Range & 10th Tee Rock Wall – Final Earthwork
chapters.summary: James D. gives a detailed tour of the practice range area, explaining irrigation, topsoil import, and tee orientations (up to 320 yards). He points to the rock wall on #10 tee where Joe Hall’s crew is placing a final 6‑inch rock layer by hand. He then walks Louie through a 25‑ to 30‑acre area across the river that will be regraded for a practice range or executive par‑3, showing the sand/mulch mixing plant, shale pile, and railroad ballast. He introduces Carson Davis, the master mechanic, and his service truck, crediting him with keeping old equipment running. Heavy scrapers and two small dozers are shown filling and leveling this area, with James D. explaining how they keep the surface level to avoid water holes.
characters_present: Unnamed operators & crew (Joe Hall’s crew, sod crews, dozer operators)

chapters.title: 8. Pete Dye & James D. – Design Philosophy & Back‑Nine Strategy (Oct 1989)
chapters.summary: In a wood‑paneled office/trailer on October 6, 1989, Pete Dye and James D. LaRosa sit at a table with Max Robertson and Bob Andrew nearby. Pete, in a beige sweater and glasses, speaks at length about the front nine’s drama and the subtler back nine, comparing Pete Dye GC to Crooked Stick, St Andrews, Augusta’s 16th, and other courses. He praises the site’s topography and vistas, saying there’s “nothing equal to this” in the U.S. He explains the concept for the 17th green—a huge, contoured surface where balls can roll 20–60 feet while staying on the green—and credits James D. for sparking the idea (though Pete reversed the original suggestion). He stresses that great courses give players room to find their ball even amid hazards, and jokes with James D. about not going broke or dying before the course is finished. They banter about Louie as “Cecil B. DeMille,” with Pete joking that Louie is repaying coal he once stole from LaRosa.

chapters.title: 9. 15th Upper Lake & Crew Portraits
chapters.summary: Back in the field, James D. stands in the upper lake basin of #15 with landscape architect Alon Kovachny, operator Skip Reel, and all‑purpose operator Randy Haddix, explaining the dam location, lake depths, and how clay from the upper lake is used to line the lower lake. He then moves to the left of the 15th lake, introducing Alon, himself, foreman Larry Reel (in a red shirt), and master mechanic Carson Davis with his service truck. James D. explains that without Carson, they couldn’t keep scrapers and dozers running. He shows scrapers being push‑loaded by a D9 and two small dozers spreading dirt faster than one big dozer could, and stops machines so Louie can film operators like Danny Harris and Skip Reel for posterity.
characters_present: Unnamed operators & crew (Joe Hall’s crew, sod crews, dozer operators)

chapters.title: 10. 18th Green & Banks – Final Contouring and Seeding
chapters.summary: Multiple passes over the 18th green complex show dozers and scrapers forming the green pad, gravel base, and steep surrounding banks. James D. and Louie repeatedly stand “right on 18 just about on the green” and point across Simpson Creek to #10 and the bridge. They highlight the old coal dump area, the new cart path and bridge from the championship tee, and the stone walls holding up #17 and #18 greens. Banks are seeded and sodded to prevent erosion and create a “painted white” look before grass comes in. James D. calls this one of the biggest golf holes in the world in terms of length, width, and visibility, and notes that the landing area is about where he would hit his own drive. Heavy emphasis is placed on Keith Sparkman’s work on greens and banks.
characters_present: Unnamed operators & crew (Joe Hall’s crew, sod crews, dozer operators)

chapters.title: 11. 15th Hole – Twin Lakes, Fairway Shaping & Fish Habitat
chapters.summary: James D. narrates from within the lower and upper lakes of #15, explaining clay liners, depths (up to 16 feet), shelves for spawning, and plans for rock “fish houses” and submerged pine trees. He points out a D9 pushing scrapers, the dam location for the upper lake, and flags marking tees. He explains that Pete wanted water visible from tee to green on the right side, and that they will pump water from Simpson Creek to fill the lakes. He notes that #15 is the last hole needing shaping and that Pete will return to approve or tweak the fairway. The segment ends with James D. standing with Alon Kovachny, Skip Reel, and Randy Haddix in the upper lake, and later with Alon, Larry Reel, and Carson Davis in the fill area for a future practice range or executive par‑3, underscoring the long‑term vision for additional golf on the property.
characters_present: Unnamed operators & crew (Joe Hall’s crew, sod crews, dozer operators)

highlights.title: Pete Dye on the uniqueness of Pete Dye GC
highlights.description: In the office, Pete Dye tells James D. that there is “nothing equal” to this golf course in the United States, citing its dramatic topography and vistas compared to courses like Crooked Stick, which he calls a cornfield with good strategy but no topography.

highlights.title: Explaining the radical 17th green concept
highlights.description: Pete describes the planned 17th green as a huge, contoured surface where balls can roll 20–60 feet while staying on the green, inspired by old greens at St Andrews and Augusta’s 16th. He credits James D. for sparking the idea, though he reversed the original suggestion.

highlights.title: James D. on the 630‑yard 11th hole
highlights.description: Standing on the 11th green, James D. explains that Pete has moved the green 30 yards to create a 625–630 yard par‑5, a true three‑shot hole. He points out the D9 dozer rough‑shaping for Pete and calls it “one of the biggest golf holes in the world” in terms of length, width, and visibility.

highlights.title: Lake 15 – engineering for fish and golf
highlights.description: James D. stands in the 15th lake basin, explaining clay liners, depths, fish shelves, and rock “fish houses,” and how they will pump water from Simpson Creek. He notes they’ll have about 10 acres of water between upper and lower lakes, both a strategic hazard and a fish habitat.

highlights.title: Secretary/Employee Day at Muriale’s
highlights.description: At a restaurant table, Jimmy LaRosa thanks secretaries and staff for helping the company pivot from coal to golf and real estate. Louie jokes about his long‑standing “no charge” remark, and staff are introduced by name, including head pro Bill Steins.
characters_involved: Office staff (Regina/Stephanie Carter, John Belcaster, Pat Snyder, Rita Forsyth, Nancy Ellis)

highlights.title: Pete Dye’s advice: “Don’t go broke or die”
highlights.description: In the office, Pete jokes with James D. that his only advice is “Just don’t go broke or die,” capturing the financial and personal stakes of the long construction project.

highlights.title: Introducing Danny Harris and Skip Reel
highlights.description: James D. stops a 631 scraper so Louie can film Danny Harris, a new operator who “just learned to run this a couple weeks ago,” and then films Skip Reel bringing another load from the lake, highlighting the operators’ skill and effort.

highlights.title: Keith “Sparky” Sparkman praised on camera
highlights.description: James D. points to a dozer operator and calls him “old Sparky,” saying he’s “one of the greatest people as far as greens are concerned,” while the camera shows his work on steep banks and green outlines.

quotes.text: “There’s nothing like this golf course in the United States. Nothing. I don’t know whether it’s the best or it’s the worst, but let’s put it this way: there’s nothing equal to this one today. The views, the vistas, the way it looks, the visual appearance—there’s not another golf course I’ve ever seen in the United States this dramatic.”
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: In the office trailer with James D., reflecting on the front nine and the site’s topography compared to other courses like Crooked Stick.

quotes.text: “Maybe 17 might be the best hole we’ll get done, the most talked‑about hole I’ve ever done. And Jim came up with the idea… He really did. I said make a small green. He said, ‘I’m going to make one four times bigger than it’s supposed to be.’”
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Explaining the concept for the 17th green and crediting James D. LaRosa for inspiring the idea, even though Pete reversed the original suggestion.

quotes.text: “When you build a golf course, you really got to build it twice, because you get it all formed, you get it seeded and planted, and then sometime later you go back and you undo the whole thing, which is what they have done here with 17 and 18.”
quotes.speaker: Field narrator (James D. or Louie, describing Pete Dye’s philosophy)
quotes.context: Voiceover while showing re‑grading of the 17th and 18th holes after initial seeding.

quotes.text: “This is going to be one of the biggest golf holes in the world in terms of length, width, and visibility.”
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Standing on the 11th fairway/green area, describing the revised 630‑yard par‑5 and its 120‑yard‑wide landing area.

quotes.text: “This type of work has been going on for 16 years… We think sometime around the middle of July we’ll be all seeded down and finally, after all these years, ready to tee it up.”
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Narrating from the 15th lake and practice range area about the long duration of earthmoving and the impending completion of seeding.

quotes.text: “The mistake I made in 1978, I told Jim, ‘No charge,’ and brother, he’s held me to it. But I’m so glad that I did it, and somewhere down the line he’ll remember me.”
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: At the secretary/employee lunch, joking about his decades of filming the project for free and his relationship with James D.

quotes.text: “You build a golf course like this, a really demanding piece of ground, and you finally get all the area around it cleaned up underbrush so a person can play the game… They don’t mind the bunkers, they don’t mind the water, they don’t mind the hazards, as long as you just get an area cleaned up where they can find a ball and they’ll beat it out of the ditches, they’ll beat it out of the bunkers. But you can’t let them slice off into the woods… As long as they can negotiate, they’ll play golf.”
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: In the office, explaining his philosophy that great courses are demanding but playable if players can find and advance the ball.

quotes.text: “We’re down to our last two or three weeks of construction. We think sometime around the middle of July we’ll be all seeded down and finally, after all these years, we’re just about ready to tee it up here in about two months.”
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Summarizing the endgame of earthmoving and seeding while showing topsoil being hauled to the practice range and 15th fairway.

quotes.text: “We may end up calling it Lake Reel in honor of their family name.”
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Standing with Larry Reel and others beside the 15th lakes, joking about naming the lake after the Reel brothers who built it.

quotes.text: “He used to steal coal off of Jim LaRosa… now his conscience has bothered him, so that’s why he’s doing this now.”
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Teasing Louie Ellis in the office, after calling him ‘Cecil B. DeMille’ and joking that his filming is payback for stolen coal.

PDGC_Grand_Opening.title: Pete Dye Golf Club – Tribute Banquet & Q&A with Pete and Jim (Honoring Pete & Alice Dye)
PDGC_Grand_Opening.content_type: Formal banquet / tribute ceremony with speeches and Q&A
PDGC_Grand_Opening.summary: This archival segment captures a formal evening banquet under a tent at Pete Dye Golf Club, likely tied to the club’s full opening in the early–mid 1990s. It centers on a heartfelt tribute to Pete and Alice Dye, with speeches by Jim (Jimmy) LaRosa, James D. LaRosa, Pete Dye himself, and other club staff and associates. The footage alternates between close‑ups of the Dyes and LaRosas at the head table and wider shots of members and guests. Speakers recount the 17‑year journey from the failed “Miracle Mountain” site to the reclaimed coal land along Simpson Creek, tell design war stories (tunnels, gob piles, oak trees), and explain the philosophy behind Pete’s architecture. There is also a membership/business overview and a Q&A where Pete discusses his 400 trips to West Virginia, regulatory challenges, and the club’s potential to host major championships. The tone is affectionate, humorous, and reflective, emphasizing family, perseverance, and a deep love of golf.

characters.name: Jimmy LaRosa
characters.description: Middle‑aged man in tan/light blazer and tie who welcomes guests, explains the 17‑year journey, introduces staff (Gary Grandstaff, Billy, Bill Steines, etc.), describes membership strategy, and formally introduces Alice and Pete Dye. He also tells the detailed “Miracle Mountain” and gob‑pile stories and asks Pete about trips and construction dates.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.description: Older Italian‑American man (likely the one with tinted glasses and dark blazer at the head table) who calls the course his “labor of love,” thanks Pete for spending all the money he had and could borrow, and recounts designing holes himself (like #18) and being overruled, plus the oak‑tree and gob‑pile anecdotes. He frames the 17‑year build as his life’s work.

characters.name: Pete Dye
characters.description: Older white‑haired man in a light sport coat and striped shirt at the head table. He jokes about not being called “Modest Pete,” thanks the on‑site team (Gary, Billy, Mark Shaw), tells the tunnel/Miracle Mountain story from his perspective, teases Jim about not being able to play golf, explains his design philosophy (subtleties, depressions, mounds, trees), answers questions about trips, government and housing‑development constraints, and assesses the club’s chances of hosting majors.

characters.name: Alice Dye
characters.role: Honored guest, co‑designer, subject of tributes
characters.description: Not clearly seen speaking in this segment, but repeatedly introduced and referenced. Pete recounts bringing Alice to see the finished course and her sharp critique of the 17th green (“Would you like it if somebody else had built it?”). She is presented as co‑author of the book and as a central part of the family’s devotion to golf.

characters.name: Gary Grandstaff
characters.description: Named and introduced by Jimmy as “Gary Grandstaff,” the superintendent who finalized construction, installed irrigation, and “grew the course in.” Pete later thanks “Gary” for putting up with him. Not clearly seen speaking on camera in this excerpt.

characters.name: Bill Steines
characters.description: Referred to as “Bill” or “Billy Steines,” introduced by Jimmy as the director of golf who elevated the level of play and operations. Mentioned again by Pete in his thanks to “Billy and Billy.” Not clearly heard speaking in this segment.

characters.name: Mark Shaw
characters.role: Author / collaborator on Pete & Alice’s book
characters.description: Introduced by Jimmy as “Mark Shaw, author of the book ‘Bury Me in a Pot Bunker.’” Mark corrects that Alice wrote the book and he only helped. He reads an inscription thanking Pete and Alice for the experience and praising their generosity and kindness.

characters.name: Unidentified membership/operations speaker (likely Jimmy LaRosa)
characters.description: Male voice (likely Jimmy again, in a more businesslike segment) explains that the club has ~340 members, 90 local, with a capped local category to create a national club; describes the 16‑bed members’ lodge and target membership of 600–700. He fields questions about capacity and defers construction‑trip questions to Pete and Jim.

characters.name: Unidentified questioners / members
characters.description: Off‑camera voices asking about construction start dates, number of Pete’s trips, Miracle Mountain, ambitions for majors, and visits from tour pros.

chapters.title: Welcome, 17‑Year Journey & Introducing the Dyes
chapters.summary: Inside a large white tent at dusk, members and guests mingle at round tables under chandeliers. Jimmy LaRosa (in a tan blazer) welcomes everyone on behalf of his father, Lois, Leanne, and himself, noting that after 17 years they are finally having the “official opening” of the Pete Dye Golf Club. He recalls asking Pete early on how good the course would be and being told he wasn’t “smart enough to see it,” then admits that now, after many memories, he can see what Pete saw and calls him a genius who spent all the money he had and could borrow—“and I wouldn’t have had it any other way.” Jimmy then delivers a warm introduction of the Dye family, describing decades of shared travel, visits to their homes, and their lifetime devotion to golf. He explains how golf creates a special environment and way of spending time with and caring for people, then formally introduces Alice Dye and Pete Dye as the honored guests.

chapters.title: Thanking the Team & Pete’s First Remarks
chapters.summary: Jimmy introduces key staff and collaborators: superintendent Gary Grandstaff and his wife Shirley, who finalized construction and irrigation and “probably spent more hours here than anyone but my dad”; Billy (club operations/membership), Bill Steines as director of golf, and others like John Rathole (first assistant pro), Parker Smith (media outreach), and his wife Leanne, “the prettiest one here,” for putting up with the project for years. He then introduces Mark Shaw, who clarifies that Alice wrote the book ‘Bury Me in a Pot Bunker’ and reads a heartfelt inscription thanking Pete and Alice for teaching him about love and believing in oneself. Pete takes the floor, joking about never being called “Modest Pete” and thanking Gary, “Billy and Billy,” the assistant pro, and Mark Shaw. He claims all the credit for the book, then begins telling the story of his first visit to the original site—“straight up and straight down”—and being led by Jim through a long railroad tunnel with a train due at four o’clock, underscoring the impracticality of that property.

chapters.title: From ‘Miracle Mountain’ to Simpson Creek: Choosing the Right Ground
chapters.summary: Pete and Jimmy trade versions of the “Miracle Mountain” story. Pete recalls that on the first 5,000‑acre mountain site they could barely fit a driving range and jokes about the black sand and the long tunnel with trains. Jimmy explains that Pete ultimately refused the job, saying no one would fly to Clarksburg to play golf unless the course was great, and that he couldn’t build a great course on that ground. Pete told him to call it “Miracle Mountain” because it would be a miracle if anyone wanted to play it. Hard‑headed, Jim briefly hired Gary Player’s design firm, but Pete’s honesty nagged at him. Studying USGS quadrangle maps, Jim found the Simpson Creek property—obliterated by strip and deep mining, with a smoldering gob pile where #10 now sits. He sensed Pete might like it, called him back, and Pete agreed to design it alone, quipping that “some people know how to design and some people know how to play.” Jim terminated the other design contract, with the other architect graciously acknowledging that if he wanted a great, non‑housing‑development course, Pete was the right choice. Jim also recounts trying to design #18 himself—spending $40,000 to build it uphill—only for Pete to call him a “dummy,” insist the hole must play down with the river and allow for galleries, and then spend another $40,000 to move the dirt back. The smoldering gob pile that became #10 is remembered as a moment when Pete briefly wondered if they could “play through the smoke” before deciding the heat would kill the grass, yet he still saw Disney‑like potential in the landscape.

chapters.title: Trees, ‘Subtleties,’ and Pete’s Design Philosophy
chapters.summary: Jim tells a 1979 story about seven huge oak trees on the left of what is now the #2 fairway. Finding a bulldozer about to push them into the river, he panics and stops the operator, insisting no one would remove such beautiful oaks. Pete’s superintendent, Lee Schmidt, thinks Pete ordered it; Jim demands he call Pete to “straighten it out.” The next morning all seven oaks are in the river. Jim is sick over it, but the resulting hole becomes one of their great holes, featured in coal and Japanese magazines. Pete jokes he thought they were box elders and defends his record as a tree lover, telling a Birmingham Country Club story where his son Peavy has already pushed over a big oak with a D9 while Pete is still trying to sell the board on removing it. Pete also recalls being accused of making #2 too tough and responding, “To hell with them… I give them a football field. I want them cutting their wrists by the time they get to the third hole.” Jim praises Pete’s “subtleties”—the purposeful depressions and mounds, like a small hollow front‑right of #3 green to catch under‑hit second shots. Pete teases Jim for using the word “subtleties,” but Jim insists every mound and sidehill lie is intentional. Asked about his most challenging courses, Pete says all courses are like his kids, but the hardest part today is government and housing developments. By contrast, at Pete Dye Golf Club the coal‑torn valley already suggested a routing—holes like #5 and #6 were “sitting there” from day one, with a stream easily redirected. He calls this ground a once‑in‑a‑lifetime opportunity that “will never happen again,” and says that’s why he kept coming back for 17 years.

chapters.title: Membership Vision & National Club Strategy
chapters.summary: Shifting from design stories to operations, Jimmy (or another club executive) explains that the club has approximately 340 members, about 90 of whom are local. The local category is closed to preserve a “true national golf club” character. The remaining members are national, international, and corporate, with representation from California, New York, Florida, Austria, Scotland, Hong Kong, St. Croix, and more. He describes the 16‑bed members’ lodge, built the previous year, as the turning point for national membership—allowing guests to stay on property and driving interest. In response to questions, he says the target membership is 600–700, with the program closing before they lose the ability to “take care of our members” or reduce them to “just a number.” Because distant national/international members visit less often, the club can accommodate more of them. When asked about construction timing and Pete’s trips, he defers to Pete and Jim.

chapters.title: 400 Trips, Breaking Ground & ‘Miracle Mountain’ Revisited
chapters.summary: In a Q&A, Pete notes he’s “been here over 17 years” and that if he comes back one more time he’ll hit about 400 trips—“about the total that some of my competitors make in their whole lifetime on all their jobs.” Jim answers that they broke ground in July 1978 but spent two years at the original mountain site, joking it took two years just to build a driving range. The “Miracle Mountain” story is retold from Jim’s angle: Pete refused the job, saying no one would fly to Clarksburg without a great course and that he couldn’t build one there; if Jim insisted, he should call it “Miracle Mountain Golf Course” because it would be a miracle if anyone wanted to play it. Jim admits he briefly hired Gary Player’s design firm for that site but couldn’t shake Pete’s honest assessment, leading him to search maps, discover Simpson Creek, and ultimately bring Pete back. He recounts Pete’s line about other designers—“some people know how to design and some people know how to play”—and the difficult but gracious termination of the prior design contract.

chapters.title: Gob Piles, Oak Trees & Making Tough Holes
chapters.summary: Jim elaborates on the coal‑country context: gob piles of slate and impurities from old mines, some smoldering for years due to sulfur ignition. He recalls Pete looking at the burning pile that became #10 and briefly wondering if they could “play through this smoke,” then deciding the heat would kill the grass but still seeing a “stroke of genius” in turning that wasteland into a dramatic hole—at one point remarking that Walt Disney would like it. Jim reiterates that he “never made a point” with Pete and lost every design argument. Another speaker (Bill, likely Bill Steines) tells the story of #2’s seven giant oaks being pushed into the river on Pete’s orders despite Jim’s protests, and how the resulting hole became one of their most celebrated. Pete defends his record as a tree planter and tells the Birmingham CC oak‑tree anecdote with his son Peavy. He also repeats his philosophy of giving players a “football field” but wanting them “cutting their wrists by the time they get to the third hole,” illustrating his willingness to challenge golfers. Throughout, Jim keeps returning to the idea that every mound, bunker, and sidehill lie has a reason—Pete’s “subtleties” that define the course’s character.

chapters.title: Pete on Government, Housing & Why This Site Is Unique
chapters.summary: Asked about his most challenging builds, Pete says the hardest part today is dealing with government and trying to fit courses into housing developments—juggling roads, lots, and playability. He contrasts that with the Pete Dye Golf Club site, where despite coal scars, the valley naturally suggested a routing: #5 and #6 were “sitting there,” a small stream could be redirected easily, and the hills created natural spectator mounding. He calls this ground something that “has never happened before, will never happen again” for him, and says that’s why he kept returning. He compares the course’s seasonal character to Augusta—great in March with azaleas—saying this course is effectively three different courses across spring, summer, and fall as conditions change. He emphasizes that, unlike cramped classics like Oakmont or Oakland Hills, this property has room for galleries and infrastructure, hinting at its suitability for major events.

chapters.title: Majors, Television & Pros Visiting the Club
chapters.summary: In a forward‑looking Q&A, someone asks about ambitions for majors like the U.S. Open, Ryder Cup, or PGA Championship. Pete explains that television has changed everything: with compact equipment, networks can now go to remote venues like Shinnecock or even the Dominican Republic (citing Shell’s Wonderful World of Golf) that once seemed impossible. He predicts that in 20–30 years, major championships will be more widely distributed because many classic clubs lack parking and infrastructure, and TV trucks will shrink to a single unit. He suggests that if Pete Dye Golf Club proves itself as a great course and retains space around Clarksburg for parking, its remote location won’t preclude majors. Asked about attracting current tour pros, Pete and Jim joke that they “don’t want any critics” and that while they’re “pretty dumb,” they’re “not stupid.” They note a few pros have visited—Bruce Devlin, Larry Ziegler, and Jim Jamieson (who worked there)—but imply they’re not courting a parade of touring pros to judge the course.

highlights.title: Jimmy’s Tribute: ‘He spent all the money I had…’
highlights.description: Jimmy LaRosa recounts asking Pete how good the course would be and being told he wasn’t smart enough to see it. Years later, he calls Pete a genius who “spent all the money I had and all the money I could borrow,” adding that he wouldn’t have had it any other way and thanking Pete directly.

highlights.title: Mark Shaw’s Inscription to Pete & Alice
highlights.description: Mark Shaw reads a personal inscription from the book ‘Bury Me in a Pot Bunker,’ thanking Pete and Alice for the honor of working with them and saying he learned what love and believing in yourself are all about, and that their generosity and kindness are their finest traits.

highlights.title: Jim Chooses Pete Over a Big‑Name Firm
highlights.description: James D. LaRosa describes hiring Gary Player’s design firm for the original mountain site, then being haunted by Pete’s brutally honest assessment that he couldn’t build a great course there. Jim studies maps, finds Simpson Creek, and ultimately fires the other firm to retain Pete, who says, “Some people know how to design and some people know how to play.”

highlights.title: The Smoldering Gob Pile Becomes Hole #10
highlights.description: Jim recalls showing Pete a smoldering gob pile across Simpson Creek—now the 10th hole. Pete briefly wonders if they can “play through this smoke” before deciding the heat would kill the grass, yet he still sees imaginative potential, even joking that Walt Disney would like it.

highlights.title: Seven Oaks in the River: Sacrificing Trees for Strategy
highlights.description: Jim tells how he stopped a bulldozer from pushing seven huge oaks into the river on #2, insisting it must be a mistake. After Lee Schmidt calls Pete, the trees are gone the next morning. Jim is sick over it, but the resulting hole becomes one of their most acclaimed. Pete later jokes he thought they were box elders and defends his record as a tree planter.

highlights.title: Pete on ‘Subtleties’ and Making Golfers Suffer
highlights.description: Jim praises Pete’s “subtleties”—small depressions and mounds that punish imperfect shots, like the hollow front‑right of #3 green. Pete jokes he has a hard enough time with players without Jim explaining the details, and recalls saying of #2, “To hell with them… I give them a football field. I want them cutting their wrists by the time they get to the third hole.”

highlights.title: Pete’s 400 Trips to West Virginia
highlights.description: In response to a question about how many trips he made, Pete says he’s been coming for over 17 years and that one more trip will make about 400—“about the total that some of my competitors make in their whole lifetime on all their jobs.”

highlights.title: Jim’s ‘Labor of Love’ and Never Winning an Argument
highlights.description: James D. LaRosa calls the golf course his “thing in life” and “labor of love,” saying he couldn’t have shared it with anyone but Pete. On the light side, he admits he tried to tell Pete how to design the course “over and over” but never won a single argument, finally conceding, “Okay, Pete, let’s do it your way.”

highlights.title: Pete: This Site Will Never Happen Again
highlights.description: Pete explains that unlike housing‑development courses, this coal‑scarred valley naturally suggested a routing and spectator mounding. He calls it a once‑in‑a‑lifetime piece of ground that “has never happened before, will never happen again” for him, and says that’s why he kept coming back.

highlights.title: Majors, TV Trucks & Clarksburg’s Future
highlights.description: Pete answers a question about majors by predicting that as TV equipment shrinks, majors will go to more remote courses. He cites Shinnecock and a Shell Wonderful World of Golf in the Dominican Republic, and says that if Pete Dye Golf Club proves itself and retains room for parking, being in Clarksburg won’t matter in 10–20 years.

quotes.text: He told me years ago, I said, Pete, don’t kid me, how good is it going to be? He said, you really want to know? And I said, yes. He said, well, you know, Jim, you’re not smart enough to see it. He said, I can see it. I said, you can’t.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa
quotes.context: Opening anecdote in Jimmy’s welcome speech, illustrating Pete’s blunt confidence in his design vision when the course was still only an idea.

quotes.text: When I think of all the memories that I had with him, I can see now what he saw then. And I think the man’s a genius. He spent all the money I had and all the money I could borrow. But I wouldn’t have had it any other way. Thank you, Pete. Thank you. Thank you.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa
quotes.context: Conclusion of Jimmy’s tribute, publicly thanking Pete for his vision and the sacrifices made to build the club.

quotes.text: This golf course is my thing in life, it’s my labor of love, and I don’t think that I could have shared it with anybody else in this manner than I have with you.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: James D. addresses Pete directly, describing the 17‑year project as the defining work of his life and praising their partnership.

quotes.text: Some people know how to design and some people know how to play. And he says, I can do it.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete’s reported response when Jim asked if he could work with the other design firm on the Simpson Creek site, asserting his confidence in handling the design alone.

quotes.text: If you do, call it the Miracle Mountain Golf Course. It would be a miracle if anybody wanted to play it.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete’s blunt verdict on the original mountain site, explaining why he initially turned down the job and pushing Jim to find better ground.

quotes.text: You dummy, don’t you see that the river’s going down and I want this hole to play down? Don’t go against nature.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete’s reaction when he saw Jim had spent $40,000 building #18 uphill; he insists on working with the natural fall of the land and space for galleries.

quotes.text: Gob is a coal slate and impurities that they separate from the coal and throw in a pile outside of a coal mine in the old days… this slate then catches fire and just smolders for years and years and years.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Jim explains the mining waste that once covered the property, setting up the transformation of a smoldering gob pile into the 10th hole.

quotes.text: I never met a man that can’t play golf that loves golf as much as Jim LaRosa. That’s a pretty strong statement.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete teasingly praises Jim’s passion for golf despite his poor playing ability, highlighting Jim’s emotional investment in the game and the club.

quotes.text: Before you all put them in the headlines I’ve knocked down, I’ve planted more trees than anybody in this whole world, probably the biggest tree lover ever, but every once in a while you get them on a golf course, it just drives you crazy.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete defends his reputation as a tree lover while justifying the removal of certain trees, like the seven oaks on #2, for strategic design reasons.

quotes.text: They say you’re making it too tough… he said, to hell with them, meaning the player. He says, what do they want? I give them a football field. And he says, anyway, I want them cutting their wrists by the time they get to the third hole.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa (quoting Pete Dye)
quotes.context: Jim recounts Pete’s philosophy on difficulty at the second hole, illustrating Pete’s willingness to challenge golfers severely.

quotes.text: All your golf courses are your kids, you know. You build one for a dirt golf course or a golf course like this.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete answers a question about his most challenging designs, likening all his courses to his children and emphasizing his attachment to each project.

quotes.text: When I walked in here and saw this ground, yes, it was all torn up from the coal, but you could see the routing going down and coming back… this will never happen again, has never happened before, will never happen again to me to have something like to build on a ground like this.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete explains why the Simpson Creek site was uniquely suited to a great golf course and why he kept returning over 17 years.

quotes.text: We have approximately 340 members at this time. Of those 340 members, about 90 of those are local, and that membership classification is closed… We don’t ever want our members just to become a number here.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa (operations segment)
quotes.context: Jimmy outlines the club’s membership structure and philosophy, emphasizing a national focus and personalized member experience.

quotes.text: I’ve been here over 17 years. I think if I make it back another time, I’ll make 400 trips. That’s about the total that some of my competitors make in their whole lifetime on all their jobs.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete responds to a question about how many trips he made to the site, highlighting his extraordinary personal involvement in this project.

quotes.text: I don’t think being in Clarksburg or outside of the mainstream of the metropolitan area in 10 or 15 years is going to make a lot of difference in major championships… hopefully 20 years from now there will still be some area around Clarksburg to park a car and things like that.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete discusses the future of major championships, television logistics, and why Pete Dye Golf Club’s remote location may not be a barrier if infrastructure is preserved.

quotes.text: Jim and I are pretty dumb, but we’re not stupid, are we Jim?
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete jokingly answers a question about inviting tour pros to critique the course, suggesting they’re not eager to bring in critics.

themes: Vision vs. skepticism – Pete’s ability to see a great course in devastated coal land long before others could, contrasted with Jim’s initial doubts.
Perseverance and long timelines – The 17‑year journey, 400 trips, and two years wasted on the wrong site before finding Simpson Creek.
Honesty and trust – Pete’s blunt refusal of the original site and Jim’s decision to trust that honesty over a more conventional design firm.
Transformation of landscape – Turning strip‑mined, gob‑pile‑scarred land into a world‑class golf course, reclaiming industrial wasteland.
Family and friendship – Deep bonds between the LaRosa and Dye families, shared travel, visits to homes, and multi‑decade collaboration.
Design philosophy and ‘subtleties’ – Pete’s intentional use of mounds, depressions, tree removal, and natural slopes to create strategic, demanding golf.
Love of golf beyond playing ability – Jim’s intense love of the game despite being, by Pete’s account, a poor golfer, and the Dyes’ lifelong devotion to golf.
Risk, sacrifice, and reward – Jim’s willingness to spend all he had and could borrow, and his later pride that he “wouldn’t have had it any other way.”
National club identity – The deliberate choice to cap local membership, build a lodge, and cultivate a national/international membership base.
Future of championships and media – Pete’s reflections on TV technology, infrastructure, and how remote courses like Pete Dye Golf Club could host majors.

PDGC_Member-Guest_Dinner___Dnace_at_Gree.title: August 21, 1993 Green Acres Dinner & Dance – Ellis Productions Coverage
PDGC_Member-Guest_Dinner___Dnace_at_Gree.content_type: social event / club dinner party with live band and dancing
PDGC_Member-Guest_Dinner___Dnace_at_Gree.summary: This video documents an August 21, 1993 dinner and dance held at “Green Acres,” filmed by Louis P. Ellis (Ellis Productions). It opens with a playful producer intro and business card, then moves into a well‑attended evening banquet: buffet and chef action stations, bar and dining room mingling, a live band, on‑stage remarks by a woman in a sequined dress, and extensive footage of guests dancing and socializing. The cameraman repeatedly credits Pam Iquina and employees for the dinner, jokes with guests (including calling someone “my lawyer, December G. Mousefield”), and circulates through the crowd offering greetings. The footage is purely social/celebratory—no construction or golf course imagery—though golf is referenced in conversation, tying the event back to the club context. The latter part of the tape is dominated by long, repetitive ambient audio (“Nice to meet you,” “My girl,” “The future”) over continuous shots of the dance floor and mingling guests, reinforcing the sense of a vibrant club community in 1993.

characters.name: Louis P. Ellis
characters.description: Older man in red blazer and glasses seen in the opening shot with a shoulder‑mounted camera and a director’s chair labeled “FILM DIRECTOR & PRODUCER LOUIS P. ELLIS.” He is the videographer throughout, providing playful narration and greetings.

characters.name: Pam Iquina
characters.role: Head of dinner preparation / kitchen lead
characters.description: Named repeatedly in the opening slate as responsible for the August 21, 1993 dinner along with “employees.” Not clearly identifiable on camera, but the buffet and chef shots visually represent her team’s work.

characters.description: Addressed directly as “Nancy” and “pretty girl” early in the footage; appears to be a well‑known guest or friend. Several women could be Nancy visually; exact match is uncertain.

characters.name: Band members (unidentified)
characters.description: Keyboardist, drummer, bassist, and at times a male vocalist providing live music for the evening. Frequently shown on stage behind dancers and during setup.

characters.name: Woman in black sequined dress (possible emcee/host)
characters.description: Short‑haired woman in a sparkly black/open‑back dress who is greeted early, then later appears on stage with a microphone, gesturing and addressing the audience. Likely helps host or perform during the program.

characters.name: “My lawyer, December G. Mousefield” (joking reference)
characters.description: An attendee whom Louis jokingly calls “my lawyer, December G. Mousefield.” Exact visual identity is unclear; the name appears to be playful rather than literal.

chapters.title: Ellis Productions Intro & Venue Establishment
chapters.summary: The tape opens with a playful self‑introduction by cameraman Louis P. Ellis, posing in a red blazer with his shoulder‑mounted camera and a director’s chair embroidered with his name and title. A close‑up of an Ellis Productions business card follows, listing video services and contact information in Clarksburg, WV. The scene then cuts to a nighttime exterior of a neon “Green Acres” sign, establishing the venue for the August 21, 1993 dinner and party.

chapters.title: Arrival, Bar Mingling, and Band Setup
chapters.summary: Inside Green Acres, timestamped 7:18–7:19 PM, guests in semi‑formal attire mingle at the bar and around tables. Louis greets people warmly (“Hi Nancy. Pretty girl.” “Hi honey. Nice dinner tonight.”), comments on being full from dinner, and encourages his companion to stay and hear the band. The camera alternates between the bar, dining tables, and the small stage where musicians and crew set up drums, keyboards, and cables. Staff move through the room, and Louis jokes about “my lawyer, December G. Mousefield” as he circulates. Close‑ups of guests, including a woman with dark curly hair and pearls, begin to personalize the crowd.

chapters.title: Buffet, Chef Action Station, and Food Spread
chapters.summary: The focus shifts to the culinary side of the evening. Louis repeatedly credits “dinner prepared by Pam Iquina and employees” while filming buffet pans piled with shrimp, lemon wedges, and other hot items under warm lighting. A chef in full whites and toque works at a live cooking station, stirring pans and plating food. These shots visually reinforce Louis’s praise of the “good spread” and highlight the staff’s effort behind the event.

chapters.title: On‑Stage Remarks by the Woman in the Sequined Dress
chapters.summary: Attention moves to the front of the room. A man in a suit appears at a microphone near a decorative fountain, then the woman in the black sequined dress joins him on or near the stage. She eventually stands alone at the mic, gesturing, waving, and interacting with the audience, likely giving remarks, a toast, or an introduction for the band. Floral arrangements and keyboards frame her, underscoring a semi‑formal program segment within the otherwise casual evening.
characters_present: Woman in black sequined dress (possible emcee/host)

chapters.title: Band Performance and Early Dancing
chapters.summary: The live band begins playing. Louis films the keyboardist, drummer, bassist, and at times a male vocalist on stage, then turns to the dance floor where the first couples start slow‑dancing under a chandelier. He continues to chat with his companion about the dinner and jokes about being ready to play golf, tying the social event back to the club context. Couples of various ages fill the floor, and Louis’s camera weaves between tables and dancers, capturing both the band and the growing crowd on the floor.

chapters.title: Dinner‑Dance in Full Swing: Couples and Crowd Atmosphere
chapters.summary: The heart of the tape is an extended montage of the dinner‑dance at full capacity. Couples in suits and dresses slow‑dance closely beneath the chandelier while tables with candles and glassware frame the edges. Louis’s audio is dominated by repeated greetings (“Nice to meet you”) and playful asides (“There’s my lawyer, December G. Mousefield”), suggesting he is being introduced around as he films. The same couples and individuals recur from different angles—an older man in a light jacket with a blonde partner, a woman in a light pantsuit raising her arms enthusiastically, a woman in a striped dress, and a woman in a wide‑brimmed hat—building a sense of a tight‑knit, multi‑generational club community enjoying the band and each other’s company.

chapters.title: Dense Mingling, Introductions, and Candid Reactions
chapters.summary: The camera moves off and on the dance floor into denser clusters of guests. Many shots show people shoulder‑to‑shoulder, talking, laughing, and occasionally reacting directly to the camera. Louis’s audio becomes a near‑continuous loop of “Nice to meet you,” overlaid on music and chatter, as he pans across faces and backs, capturing a receiving‑line‑like sequence of introductions. Several individuals recur—a woman in a light top and patterned skirt, a man in a dark jacket near her, a woman in a light patterned dress, and a man in a light shirt—giving continuity to the crowd. The final seconds fade to black, indicating a pause or end of this raw segment.

chapters.title: Black Screen Transition / Tape Break
chapters.summary: The last visible portion of this analyzed segment is largely black screen, likely representing a camera pause, lens cap, or end of this particular scene on the tape. Ambient audio may continue briefly, but no new visual content appears. This functions as a natural break before the tape moves on to other material (elsewhere on the archive, the narrator begins to talk about “the construction” or “conception” of the Golf Club, but that audio is not visually supported here).

PDGC_Opening_7-3-1993.title: Pete Dye Golf Club – Opening Era Ceremonies, Member Outing & Early Social Life (1993)
PDGC_Opening_7-3-1993.content_type: Grand opening ceremonies, member golf outing, on‑course interviews, and social/family events
PDGC_Opening_7-3-1993.summary: This archival reel centers on the 1993 opening era of Pete Dye Golf Club in Bridgeport/Clarksburg, WV. It intercuts a local TV news feature, indoor speeches, on‑course member play, a formal grand‑opening banquet with a Scottish pipe band, and extensive home‑video coverage of the first member play day. Key figures (almost certainly Jimmy LaRosa and James D. LaRosa) deliver mission statements and recognize Pete Dye, God/Mother Nature, and James D. as the driving forces behind the project. Director of Golf Jim Jamieson is formally introduced and explains the day’s format and handicap system. Members introduce themselves one‑by‑one, then head to the course, where Louie Ellis and friends film James D. and “JJ” hitting their first shots on their own course. Later sequences show a lakeside opening dinner with bagpipers, fireworks on July 3, 1993, and intimate family/clubhouse moments. The footage captures the transition from a 15‑year dream to a functioning, member‑driven club and documents the early culture, humor, and community around the LaRosa–Dye project.

Seen both indoors at breakfast/meeting and outdoors at ceremonies.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa (probable)
characters.description: Older white‑haired man in light golf shirts, often seated beside the main speaker at breakfast and later hitting ceremonial tee shots (“James D. on the tee”). Recognized as the father whose perseverance made the project possible.

characters.name: Jim Jamieson
