chapters.title: TV Sports Feature & Visual Intro to Pete Dye Golf Club
chapters.summary: A local TV sports anchor introduces the Pete Dye Golf Club’s opening after a decade in the making. Scenic B‑roll shows fairways, water features, the mine portal by a green, and a massive acre‑and‑a‑half bunker. A construction‑era photo and Pete Dye’s signature letter appear, along with a routing map. Bill Pulice, Director of Marketing, gives an on‑camera soundbite about each hole feeling private and the course becoming “your favorite place.” The sequence then cross‑fades into early‑morning clubhouse dining‑room shots dated July 3, 1993, setting up the internal ceremonies.

chapters.title: Indoor Breakfast Meeting – 15‑Year Journey & Mission Statement
chapters.summary: In a clubhouse breakfast setting (timestamped 7/3/93), a gray‑haired man in a striped polo—likely Jimmy LaRosa—addresses members and early stakeholders. He recounts that the project began 15 years earlier, notes Pete Dye’s absence due to a family retreat at Culver, Indiana, and relays Dye’s apologies and promise to return. He credits “the great architect in the sky” and Mother Nature for the land, and reads the club’s mission: to establish an international club of unparalleled stature, to honor the architect’s genius, to uphold golf’s traditions, and to be a model of successful club management. Attendees eat breakfast, shake hands, and listen attentively as he recognizes his father and other contributors.

chapters.title: Small‑Room Leadership Huddle – Gratitude & Future Focus
chapters.summary: In a smaller dining/meeting room, Jimmy LaRosa (probable) and a few core figures (including an older man in a striped golf shirt and another in a green polo) share an intimate recognition moment. The same themes are repeated in a more informal tone: Pete Dye sends his regards, is at a family retreat, and loves the property; God and Mother Nature are credited as the ultimate architects. The group laughs, claps, and gestures as the speaker pivots from the 15‑year struggle to what the club will become going forward.

chapters.title: Formal Introduction of Director of Golf Jim Jamieson
chapters.summary: Back in a larger dining/bar area, Jimmy LaRosa (probable) formally introduces Director of Golf Jim Jamieson. He lists Jamieson’s PGA Tour accomplishments—Western Open champion, high finishes in the Masters and PGA Championship, Quad Cities Open winner—and praises his character. Jamieson thanks the LaRosa family, calls the property unique, and dreams aloud about hosting celebrity events, a tour event, even Ryder Cup‑type competitions. He outlines the day’s special opening‑day format: first nine as two‑best‑ball, second nine as scramble, playing from different tees (Miners, Senior, Dye, Championship, Professional). He explains the dual handicap system (traveling vs. membership) and jokes about “phony handicaps,” then gives course‑care instructions and notes that the 8th green and fairway are still maturing.

chapters.title: Member Roll‑Call & Club Culture in the Dining Room
chapters.summary: After Jamieson’s briefing, the speaker asks everyone to stand and introduce themselves so members know who they’re playing with. One by one, men and a few women state their names, hometowns, and brief comments: Raymond Pizzillo calls the course a “mountain masterpiece”; Louie Bonasso notes he’s on the board of this “soon‑to‑be internationally renowned club”; others hail from Fairmont, Bridgeport, Morgantown, Austin, Dallas, Indiana (PA), Raleigh, Dallas, Washington, D.C., Ireland (assistant pro Patrick Garrity), and more. The Board of Governors—Lloyd Bonasso, Tom Amon, Steve Savodnik—is acknowledged. There’s light teasing (“I’m one of Jimmy’s outlaws”) and anticipation (“I’ve waited 15 years”). The tone is collegial and aspirational, cementing the club’s identity as both local and national in reach.

chapters.title: Pre‑Round Logistics, Marketing & Word‑of‑Mouth Push
chapters.summary: As breakfast wraps, Jamieson and the club leadership encourage members to help grow the club by inviting friends—“nothing works like word of mouth.” They mention caddies being used as spotters due to wet conditions and urge careful cart use. They thank Pat, Pam, and staff for breakfast and credit “Billy Pulice” for handling most of the membership marketing. Members are encouraged to bring potential members to any of the three leaders for information. The group then disperses toward carts to begin the day’s play.

chapters.title: First Member Play Day – Carts, Tee‑Off & Louie’s Commentary
chapters.summary: Home‑video style footage shows rows of carts and members heading out for the inaugural member play day (timestamped 7/3/93). Louie Ellis and Harris Holt banter as they film carts rolling by, joking about “we got their cart” and calling late arrivals “the last two, but the most important.” On the first tee, James D. LaRosa hits “right down the middle,” followed by “JJ” (Jimmy Joe/LaRosa) hitting his first drive on his own golf course. Clergy (“Monsignor,” “Father Ken”) tee off, with Louie joking about aiming for the waterfall. Louie and Harris capture multiple groups on various tees and greens, narrating shots, distances, and mishaps with affectionate humor. The course’s dramatic features—waterfalls, stone walls, creeks, huge bunkers—are repeatedly framed as players test the new layout.

chapters.title: On‑Course Play – Members, Bets & Friendly Needling
chapters.summary: Louie and Harris roam the course, filming tee shots, approaches, and putts on holes 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, and 8. They call out players by name—Raymond Pizzillo, Sam Oliverio, Bobby Farrell, Ralph Sutton, Danny DeMarino—and describe lies, distances, and hazards (“Everything on this side of that stone wall is rough… there’s a little creek that runs down through there”). Friendly wagers are in play (“We’re playing for a quarter a hole; I’ve got him down one already”), and one player jokes that he withdrew his bet so he doesn’t owe a quarter. They tease each other about intimidation and “El Diablo” working on the first tee. The commentary is light, self‑deprecating, and full of inside jokes, capturing the club’s early social fabric as much as the golf.

chapters.title: Louie & Harris as ‘Cecil B. DeMille’ and ‘Otto Preminger’
chapters.summary: In a playful on‑camera bit, two men—almost certainly Louie Ellis and Harris Holt—pose as famous directors “Cecil B. DeMille” and “Otto Preminger.” One says he’s been videoing the course since 1978 as a “non‑paid member” and praises James D. and Jimmy Joe as “two beautiful people.” The other calls the site “God’s country” and says he’s never had so much pleasure making a film. They joke about the camera still rolling and about this being “the only video you get in the world without charge, right Louie? As long as Nancy says okay, it’s okay.” This meta‑segment explicitly acknowledges the long‑term amateur documentation that underpins the archive.

chapters.title: More Member Golf – Par‑3s, Wild Pants & Course Features
chapters.summary: Louie continues filming on holes 4, 5, 7, and 17. He highlights a “beautiful par 3,” comments on Mike Delaney’s flamboyant pants, and notes distances (“Ray, 135 yards from here”). Shots into creeks, over stone walls, and from bunkers illustrate Pete Dye’s rugged design. Louie admires the clarity of the water and jokes about balls floating there. He films Jim Jamieson hitting a near‑perfect shot on a par‑3 and speculates about the first hole‑in‑one. The camera lingers on scenic vistas—lakes between holes, waterfalls, and long fairways—often just “so we want that to be on the film,” underscoring the desire to document the course’s beauty as much as the play.

chapters.title: On‑Course Interview with Congressman Alan Mollohan & Son
chapters.summary: Later in the day, Louie or Harris interviews Congressman Alan Mollohan and his young son Andrew on camera. Mollohan praises Jimmy LaRosa’s long‑term commitment and says it’s nice to see the vision coming to fruition; he calls the landscape beautiful and predicts the course will be beautiful as well. Andrew, age 12, is asked his handicap and gives a non‑answer (“We’re still figuring it out”), prompting a joking aside about “that’s a politician for you.” Mollohan notes Andrew has taken junior clinics and looks forward to playing the course. This segment situates the club within a broader civic context and shows political support for the project.

chapters.title: Lakeside Opening Dinner – Dignitaries, Bagpipers & Crowd
chapters.summary: Evening footage shows a formal lakeside dinner in honor of the Pete Dye Golf Club opening. Long rows of white‑clothed tables and folded napkins are set; a large crowd of members, families, and dignitaries gathers near a pavilion. Harris Holt narrates that this is “the dinner in honor of the Pete Dye Golf Club opening up” and points out dignitaries, including Congressman Alan Mollohan. A Scottish pipe band from Pittsburgh—the Syria Highlanders—arrives in full tartan regalia. Members of the band introduce themselves on camera (Tom Murray, Stuart Ball, Charlie Gladich, Bob Gordy, Bill Pfeiffer, Bill Gordy) and note their national reputation and competition wins. The band then marches and plays around the first tee and lakeside banquet area as a formal speech (likely Jimmy LaRosa) is heard in voiceover, again recounting the 15‑year journey, Pete Dye’s absence and family retreat, and the role of “the great architect in the sky” and Mother Nature. Families with children, including a suited man holding a little girl in a floral dress, are repeatedly framed, emphasizing the multi‑generational nature of the celebration.

chapters.title: Fireworks Over the Club – July 3, 1993
chapters.summary: Nighttime footage (timestamps 10:26–10:56 PM, 7/3/93) shows an extended fireworks display over the property—large red and gold bursts, rising comets, and scattered star‑like patterns. Over parts of this, the same speech audio about the club’s history, Pete Dye’s regrets at not attending, and thanks to God and Mother Nature is heard, creating a symbolic overlay of celebration and reflection. The fireworks likely coincide with Independence Day weekend and the club’s opening festivities. The sequence then cuts indoors to a late‑night clubhouse party: balloons, people filming each other, and a warm, seated interview with an older white‑haired man in a white polo (likely Jimmy LaRosa or another senior leader) who reiterates the 15‑year story and future vision. The night ends with candid shots of a gray‑haired man holding a young girl with a white bow, underscoring the family dimension of the celebration.

chapters.title: Closing Family Moments & Production Credit
chapters.summary: The final minutes intercut more fireworks bursts with intimate indoor family scenes. A gray‑haired man in glasses holds a young blonde girl with a white bow as they smile at the camera in a fluorescent‑lit clubhouse room. The same man appears again as the fireworks audio/narration continues, visually tying the club’s public story to private family joy. The reel ends with a close‑up of the Ellis Productions business card, crediting Louis P. Ellis as producer/director and listing his Clarksburg address and services (weddings, anniversaries, meetings, film‑to‑video transfers). This explicitly identifies the amateur production source of much of the archive and closes the loop on Louie’s long‑running documentation of the Pete Dye Golf Club story.

highlights.title: Mission & Objectives of Pete Dye Golf Club Read Aloud
highlights.description: In the breakfast meeting, the club leader reads a formal mission statement: to establish an international club of unparalleled stature, to honor Pete Dye’s genius, to uphold golf’s traditions, and to be a model of successful club management. The room listens quietly, underscoring the seriousness of the project’s ambitions.

highlights.title: Introduction of Director of Golf Jim Jamieson
highlights.description: Jimmy LaRosa introduces Jim Jamieson, listing his PGA Tour victories and major‑championship finishes, then jokes that “besides all that, he’s just a great guy.” Jamieson thanks the LaRosa family and talks about bringing in celebrity events and possibly a Ryder Cup‑style event.

highlights.title: First Tee – James D. & JJ Play Their Own Course
highlights.description: On the first tee of the new course, James D. LaRosa hits “right down the middle,” followed by JJ (Jimmy Joe) hitting his first drive on the course he helped build. Louie’s commentary emphasizes that this is JJ’s first time playing his own golf course, making the moment feel like a personal culmination of years of work.

highlights.title: Louie & Harris as ‘Cecil B. DeMille’ and ‘Otto Preminger’
highlights.description: Louie and Harris stage a mock interview as famous film directors, with Louie noting he’s been filming the course since 1978 as a “non‑paid member” and praising James D. and Jimmy Joe as “two beautiful people.” The bit is humorous but also reveals the depth of Louie’s long‑term commitment to documenting the project.

highlights.title: Congressman Alan Mollohan Praises Jimmy LaRosa
highlights.description: On camera at the lakeside event, Congressman Alan Mollohan speaks warmly about Jimmy LaRosa’s years of work and how meaningful the project has been to him. He says it feels good to see the vision coming to fruition and that Jimmy “deserves it,” while his son Andrew shyly answers questions about his golf and clinics.

highlights.title: Pipe Band Marches to the First Tee
highlights.description: The Syria Highlanders pipe band, in full tartan regalia, marches past the “1 PAR 4” tee marker and around the lakeside banquet area as a speech about the 15‑year journey and Pete Dye’s absence plays in voiceover. The visual pageantry and solemn music give the opening a ceremonial, almost sacred feel.

highlights.title: Fireworks & Tribute to ‘The Great Architect in the Sky’
highlights.description: During a nighttime fireworks display on July 3, 1993, the speaker’s voice is heard thanking “the man above,” the “great architect in the sky,” and Mother Nature, and relaying Pete Dye’s praise for the property. The combination of fireworks and spiritual language elevates the club’s story beyond business into something almost mythic.

highlights.title: On‑Course Interview with Older Leader in White Polo
highlights.description: In a quiet indoor interview, an older white‑haired man in a white polo (likely Jimmy LaRosa or another senior leader) calmly recounts the 15‑year project and emphasizes focusing on the future. He then recognizes Pete Dye, God, and Mother Nature. The intimate framing contrasts with the earlier public ceremony, giving a reflective, personal capstone to the narrative.

highlights.title: Children Learning Golf on the Tee
highlights.description: A toddler with a tiny club is helped by an adult woman on a tee box while other adults look on and laugh. The scene plays under narration about each hole feeling private and the course being “your favorite place,” visually tying the design philosophy to family experiences and future generations of golfers.

highlights.title: Closing Thanks from Louie & Nancy Ellis
highlights.description: Near the end of the day, Louie’s voice closes with a heartfelt sign‑off thanking James D. and Jimmy Joe LaRosa for the opening day and saying it “will always be remembered by all,” adding thanks and “God bless you” from himself, Nancy, their families, and friends. It encapsulates the gratitude and community spirit of the archive.

quotes.text: We are going to turn this golf club into one of the great golf environments of the world. With your help, and certainly with the help of management, we will be able to achieve our objectives.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa (probable)
quotes.context: Formal breakfast speech outlining the club’s mission and ambitions to members and early stakeholders.

quotes.text: It’s to establish an international golf club of unparalleled stature and coveted membership. To create a tribute to the genius of the architect. To be the foundation of an environment built on the values and tradition of the game. And to be a model of success for all clubs through the successful management of the club and its properties.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa (probable)
quotes.context: Reading the written mission and objectives of Pete Dye Golf Club to assembled members.

quotes.text: Thank you very much. I’d like to thank the La Rosa family for the opportunity to be here and to be a part of the Pete Dye Golf Club. This is quite a unique piece of property. If the back nine is anything like the front nine, this should be so special.
quotes.speaker: Jim Jamieson
quotes.context: Acceptance remarks after being introduced as Director of Golf.

quotes.text: Hopefully, we’re going to bring in celebrity events, maybe a tour event. We’d certainly like to host a Ryder Cup, a Curtis Cup, or a Walker Cup.
quotes.speaker: Jim Jamieson
quotes.context: Outlining long‑term aspirations for high‑profile competitions at the club.

quotes.text: From now on, from this day forth, you’ll have two sets of handicaps… You’ll have your traveling handicap… and then you’re also going to have a membership handicap. And that goes in a little black book. Right, Louie?
quotes.speaker: Jim Jamieson
quotes.context: Explaining the club’s handicap system to members at the opening play day, with a joking aside to Louie Ellis.

quotes.text: So Doc might be a 15 in Morgantown, but he’ll probably be 11 here. So don’t give me all these phony handicaps.
quotes.speaker: Jim Jamieson
quotes.context: Light‑hearted warning to members about inflating handicaps for the new course.

quotes.text: We’ve put a lot of love and tender care into the project, and we want it to be special for you all. So you all have to help us take care of the place out there.
quotes.speaker: Jim Jamieson
quotes.context: Course‑care appeal before members head out to play, noting unfinished sod and fragile new turf.

quotes.text: I had my brother here last Sunday… he’s been all over this country, and he happened to make one remark… He said, ‘This is the mountain masterpiece,’ and that sums it up in one sentence.
quotes.speaker: Raymond Pizzillo
quotes.context: Self‑introduction during the member roll‑call, quoting his brother’s reaction to the course.

quotes.text: I’ve waited 15 years.
quotes.speaker: Bob Farrell (probable)
quotes.context: Brief, emotional comment during introductions, referencing the long wait from project inception to opening.

quotes.text: Here’s the architect, right here. He’s the best.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified member (to camera)
quotes.context: On‑course remark as a key figure (likely Jimmy LaRosa) walks by carts before the round.

quotes.text: Ladies and gentlemen, in front of me, as you can see, on the left is Cecil B. DeMille, and on the right is Otto Preminger… I have done many pictures before, but never have I had so much pleasure in doing this one because this is God’s country. As you can see around you, all of the way, this really is God’s country.
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt (as ‘Otto Preminger’)
quotes.context: Playful on‑course skit with Louie Ellis, reflecting on filming the project and the beauty of the site.

quotes.text: I want to say I’ve been here since 1978… videoing this golf course, and it’s an honor to have been able to be part of this organization. I am actually a non‑paid member of this organization, but I’ve enjoyed doing business with Mr. James D. and Jimmy Joe, two beautiful people.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis (as ‘Cecil B. DeMille’)
quotes.context: Same skit, revealing Louie’s long‑term, unpaid commitment to documenting the club and his affection for the LaRosas.

quotes.text: First of all, we’re very proud of Jimmy La Rosa and his commitment to this golf course. I know he’s worked on it for years, and it’s been something that’s been very meaningful to him for a long period of time. It just feels very nice to see it coming to fruition. He deserves it.
quotes.speaker: Alan Mollohan
quotes.context: On‑camera interview at the lakeside event, praising Jimmy LaRosa’s perseverance and the realization of his vision.

quotes.text: This is going to be the dinner in honor of the Pete Dye Golf Club opening up. We can see a few dignitaries down through there. Among them is Alan Mollohan…
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: Narration as the camera pans across the lakeside banquet setup and crowd before the opening dinner.

quotes.text: My name’s Tom Murray. I’m a world‑class bagpiper from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Glad to be here.
quotes.speaker: Tom Murray
quotes.context: Self‑introduction of the lead piper from the Syria Highlanders pipe band before the evening ceremony.

quotes.text: This is a small representation of the Syria Highlanders pipe band from Pittsburgh. We’re a national‑renowned band. We’ve won competitions all over the country.
quotes.speaker: Charlie Gladich
quotes.context: Pipe sergeant introducing the band and its credentials on camera.

quotes.text: I’m very proud to say I’m probably the only one‑handed bagpiper in the world today.
quotes.speaker: Bill Gordy
quotes.context: Band member’s distinctive self‑description during introductions.

quotes.text: It’s time to say thanks to James D. and Jimmy Joe LaRosa for this day, the opening of the Pete Dye Golf Club, Clarksburg‑Bridgeport, West Virginia. Day will always be remembered by all. And from Louie and Nancy Ellis and your families, your friends, thanks. Good night, and God bless you.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Closing voice‑over at the end of the day’s footage, offering thanks and a blessing to the LaRosa family and club community.

Papa_Jim_Interview_Eastpointe_Shopping_C.title: Glen Elk & Pete Dye Golf Club Origins – Papa Jim, Virgil, and Early Course Construction
Papa_Jim_Interview_Eastpointe_Shopping_C.content_type: Mixed: neighborhood history tour, family/heritage interview, and golf course construction documentation
Papa_Jim_Interview_Eastpointe_Shopping_C.summary: This archival reel weaves together three main threads: (1) a narrated driving and walking tour of Glen Elk and Clarksburg, WV, documenting buildings and streets tied to the LaRosa and Rota families; (2) an intimate interview with James LaRosa Sr. (“Papa Jim”) and his son Virgil about immigration, coal, and business; and (3) extensive on‑site footage of the early construction and grow‑in of the Pete Dye Golf Club, including bridges, greens, bunkers, and fairways. Throughout, local friends and family (including the Ellis and Oliverio families) appear, and the narration constantly links the evolving golf course back to Glen Elk’s people, buildings, and memories.

characters.name: James LaRosa Sr. (Papa Jim)
characters.description: Elder LaRosa patriarch who immigrated from Italy, fought in both the Italian and U.S. armies, and built businesses in hotels, restaurants, real estate, and coal. In his 90s here, he gives a concise life story on camera.

characters.name: Virgil LaRosa
characters.role: Son of Papa Jim / coal and tipple operator
characters.description: Papa Jim’s youngest son. Speaks about working with his father in the coal business since 1950 and shows one of their coal tipple operations.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa (James D., JDL)
characters.description: Referred to in third person as the man who had the Elk Bridge building constructed and whose birthplace in Glen Elk is repeatedly pointed out. Also appears in construction-era segments discussing leveling a hill for commercial development and later in golf-course context.

characters.name: Jimmy LaRosa (Jimmy, Jimmy Joe, JJL)
characters.description: Appears in construction segments as “Jimmy” or “little Jimmy,” managing grading projects and later deeply involved in the golf course. Speaks about the three‑year earthmoving project and about wanting to capture the work on film.

characters.name: Gary Grandstaff
characters.description: Identified by name in the greens-construction segment. Explains sand sourcing, green construction, seeding strategy, and points out Pete Dye associate Keith Sparkman. Also seen working alongside crew, raking and grooving greens.

characters.name: Pete Dye
characters.description: Appears in later greens-construction segment (tan cap, tan sweater, glasses) speaking about the Clarksburg site, the potential of the land, and his long collaboration with shaper Keith Sparkman. His comments are framed by others as those of the course’s designer.

characters.name: Keith Sparkman (Sparky)
characters.description: Named repeatedly in the greens and bunker segments as the man who “painted” the contours and follows Pete from job to job. Seen on machines and on foot shaping greens and bunker faces.

characters.name: Louie Ellis
characters.description: Primary home‑movie documentarian. Frequently addresses “Louis” in third person, but also identifies himself (“This is Louie Ellis on the camera”) and jokes about not charging for his work. He appears briefly in intro shots in a red blazer as “director.”

characters.name: Harris Holt
characters.description: Named multiple times (“That’s Mr. Harris Holt my assistant and I’m Louie Ellis”). Provides structured narration on holes 1–6, explains fairway and green construction, and introduces segments (“We’re standing on the tee at number five…”).

characters.name: Unidentified Glen Elk narrator (likely a LaRosa/Ellis contemporary)
characters.description: Male voice and presence in car, often in red jacket, who drives through Glen Elk, points out buildings (Morocco Club, Elk Bridge, Lee Hotel, Parson Hotel, Coca‑Cola bottling works), and interviews local shop owners like the Oliverios.

characters.name: John and Angie Oliverio
characters.description: Introduced on camera at their doorway as “John and Angie Oliverio.” John is described as the oldest working printer in Harrison County. They chat about Glen Elk residences and Louis Rota’s habits.

characters.name: Louis Rota
characters.description: Does not speak on camera but is described repeatedly as living next to James D.’s birthplace and using his residence to nap and watch soap operas, with neighbors checking on him if he doesn’t appear.

characters.name: Jack DePue
characters.description: Introduces himself (“My name’s Jack DePue”) before a controlled blast, explains traffic stoppage, and comments on the shot’s success.

characters.name: Various unnamed construction workers
characters.description: Operate dozers, loaders, tractors, spreaders, and install silt fence, sod, and erosion netting throughout the course-construction segments.

chapters.title: Intro & Glen Elk: Morocco Club and Elk Bridge
chapters.summary: The tape opens with a brief “director” shot of Louie Ellis, then moves into a narrated driving and walking tour of Glen Elk. The narrator shows the burned‑out Morocco Club building, explains it will be demolished, and identifies it as a favorite building of Jim LaRosa (“Elk Bridge”). He points out the building where James D. was born, neighboring residences (including Louis Rota’s), and interviews John and Angie Oliverio at their doorway. The tour continues past the old Glen Elk Hotel, Lee Hotel, railroad station, markets, warehouses, and the Parson Hotel, layering personal memories (post‑WWII drinks, Silver Star stories) over a visual record of a declining but historically rich neighborhood.
characters_present: Unidentified Glen Elk narrator (likely a LaRosa/Ellis contemporary)

chapters.title: Glen Elk Street & Business Tour
chapters.summary: The car tour expands to more of Glen Elk and Clarksburg: Loya’s Market, the old Glen Elk Hotel (run by the narrator’s grandfather), Johnson Hardware, the railroad station, Ellis Brothers Market, the Cobleguard dry goods building, Morris Grocery/Merchants Wholesale, William R. Sharp Electrical, and early LaRosa/Mason contracting sites. The narrator repeatedly notes that many buildings are unsafe and slated for demolition. He emphasizes that this is a “history of Glen Elk,” and that the LaRosas, Rotas, and Masons all got their start here. The segment ends with a drive up Hogan Lane past Louis Rota’s home, the LaRosa family residence where James D. was born, and the Martin & LaRosa building (the old Home Hotel), whose name stone is filmed for posterity.
characters_present: Unidentified Glen Elk narrator (likely a LaRosa/Ellis contemporary)

chapters.title: Papa Jim & Virgil: Immigration, Coal, and the Tipple
chapters.summary: The film cuts to a more formal interview segment with “Papa Jim” (James LaRosa Sr.) and his son Virgil. Virgil explains he has worked with his father in the coal business since 1950 and that Papa Jim, now 90, is still “wearing me out.” Prompted to speak, Papa Jim gives a concise autobiography: he came to the U.S. in 1907, served in the Italian Army (1911–1912) and the U.S. Army in 1918, and has been in hotels, restaurants, real estate, and coal for 30 years. He expresses love for the country and people and notes he was born in 1891 and is now 91. The group then visits a coal tipple Virgil operates, explaining that Papa Jim originally bought it when it was the Rawhide Tipple. Louie Ellis, on camera, adds his own tribute to Papa Jim and the LaRosas.

chapters.title: Blasting & Commercial Land Development (Pre‑Golf)
chapters.summary: The focus shifts to a large earthmoving project: a hillside is drilled and blasted to create level commercial land. Jack DePue introduces himself and describes stopping traffic and firing the shot; the blast sends a huge dust cloud down the slope. Louie films the aftermath, joking that he can’t be fired because he’s not being paid. Jimmy LaRosa and his father James D. appear on site; Louie recalls giving Jimmy Cracker Jacks when he was a boy. Jimmy explains they’ve been working nearly three years to level the hill and create commercial ground for Clarksburg’s future, expecting enough level land for 10+ years of development. James D. adds that working with his dad, superintendents, and laborers has been a formative experience. Louie repeatedly emphasizes he’s filming “no charge” for historical reasons.

chapters.title: Dogs at Home & Early Golf‑Course Dogs
chapters.summary: A quieter domestic interlude shows LaRosa family dogs at a house and on the future golf property. Jim (likely James D. or Jimmy) introduces several dogs: Ranger, a pedigreed German Shepherd from Ohio; Jenny, a Weimaraner with a congenital defect that causes her to stumble; and Divot, a stray puppy Jimmy Joe found across Simpson Creek and adopted. Louie struggles to keep up with the fast‑moving dogs, joking about them being “movie stars.” These scenes humanize the LaRosas and show the property as a lived‑in space even before the course is finished.

chapters.title: Number 1 Green: Sand, Seed, and Pete Dye’s Shaper
chapters.summary: We move into detailed documentation of constructing the first green at the Pete Dye Golf Club. Superintendent Gary Grandstaff explains that it’s October 9, overcast, and they’re preparing to plant the first green. He describes applying rock phosphate and agricultural lime around the green to amend soil and dry the topsoil, while the green itself is built from a sand/peat mix blended off‑site. He explains the use of two bentgrass varieties (Pen‑cross on the green, Pen‑eagle on fairways) to create distinct color zones. Gary details the sand sourcing: a glacial deposit near Worthington (~12 miles away), washed on site and blended to USGA specs. He credits Pete Dye associate Keith Sparkman, who came from finishing the Kiawah Island Ryder Cup course, with hand‑finishing the contours. Louie films Gary working alongside the crew, raking and grooving the green by hand, and notes that most of the work is done manually “because they want to do it right.” Wind delays the bentgrass seeding, so they seed rough first and plan to seed the green when conditions calm.

chapters.title: Bridges 10 & 2: Structural Installation
chapters.summary: A dated segment (October 29–30, 1990) shows the installation of covered steel/wood bridges on holes 10 and 2. A crane lifts prefabricated spans into place over creeks and low areas, with workers guiding them onto trestles. A narrator (likely Harris Holt) explains that the bridge on #2 is the “sister bridge” to #10, designed by Clarence Robinson in Alabama and shipped by truck to provide shelter for golfers in rain or storms. He notes that from the #5 tee, distant smokestacks serve as a target line. The footage captures the precision of the lifts, the use of temporary supports, and the integration of these structures into the rugged valley landscape.

chapters.title: Hole 9: Sod on Steep Bunkers & Indian Summer
chapters.summary: On November 3, 1990, in unseasonably warm “Indian summer” weather (~75°F), the crew is sodding the steep bunker faces around the 9th green. The narrator (Harris) explains that the slopes are so steep they must use ladders to start the first rows of sod, then work down. Sod comes from a local farm (the old Digman farm). He points out Bogart, a dog who “thinks he’s in charge,” and again credits Keith Sparkman for the green’s contours. They are watering all grass on the course due to the dry weather and plan to water the new sod later that day. Topsoil is being brought in to finish the right edge of the green, and lime will be spread on the 9th fairway. Harris notes that after dozer work, Sparky uses a SmithCo unit to blend edges before final grassing. The fairway in front of the green was seeded 4–5 weeks earlier and is about to be mowed for the first time.

chapters.title: October 16–17, 1990: Holes 1–6 & 14–3–9 Fairways
chapters.summary: A narrated tour (by Harris Holt, with Louie filming) documents the rapid grow‑in of multiple holes. On October 16, they show the #1 fairway, already soft and lush despite its short life, and the #1 green ready for seeding. Harris points out the color differences between fairway, rough, and fringes, and notes #4 lake in the background. They then film the landing area of #2, remarking how magnificently the fairways have come up and recalling when the bank had to be sodded. From the #5 tee, Harris explains it’s a dogleg right and the only true par‑5; no one can reach it in two. He describes its three levels and shows early grass just emerging. From near #7 green, they look back over #5 from an elevated vantage, noting how green everything has become in just a week. They stop to film fresh deer tracks as a curiosity. On #6, they show the mine portal and stone wall separating rough from fairway, recalling earlier photos of Louie and Pete Dye there. They also film #4 (a short par‑3 over the lake), #3 (a slight dogleg right with a large waste bunker), and #9 tee, which offers a dramatic view down to Simpson Creek and a fairway lined with reclaimed trees. Harris repeatedly emphasizes the professionalism of the construction team and the speed of turf establishment.

chapters.title: Number 1 Tee & Greens 3–4: Sand Mix and USGA Specs
chapters.summary: Standing on the #5 tee of the #1 fairway on October 17, 1990, Harris explains that the #1 tees are in final construction. Four tee decks are visible; workers are placing the #1 tee mix, composed of 80% sand and 20% peat from a Worthington glacial deposit. He notes that the topsoil from that deposit is used around the course, while the sand is washed and blended on site to USGA specs. He points out the two different grasses on the fairways, visible by color. The tees will be seeded that night or the next day, completing #1. The camera then moves to #3 green under construction: trucks back in with sand/peat mix, which is spread by a Pete Dye shaper on a Case dozer. Harris explains that the sand layer is 8–10 inches thick and that the mix is washed and blended on site. He notes that “mostly everything you see on this course is West Virginian.” We then see #4 green at #4 lake, where Sparky (Keith Sparkman) uses a specialized contouring machine to put the final shape on the green and surrounds. Harris explains that Pete trusts Sparky’s judgment and that he follows Pete from job to job, possibly even being a physician by training. The segment ends with Pete Dye himself on camera, alongside Jim and others, talking about the Clarksburg site, the potential of the land, and Keith’s work, while Sam Oliverio films stills.

chapters.title: Pete Dye & Friends on Site: Reflections and Humor
chapters.summary: In a key on‑site gathering, Pete Dye (tan cap, tan sweater) stands with LaRosa family members and local friends on a partially built hole. Harris Holt and Louie Ellis are present with cameras. Pete praises the Clarksburg site, saying the potential here is greater than almost anywhere he’s seen, and notes that Keith Sparkman has been with him for 10–11 years, including on a recent oceanfront course with 10 holes on the sea and no houses. He jokes that they need to finish this course “before we all drop from this world.” Jimmy LaRosa speaks about the long project, Pete’s patience, and the endurance required. A guest references Pete’s Honors Course in Chattanooga and says there’s nothing like this site. There is joking about whether anyone will be allowed to take a divot and about free memberships for lawyers. The group poses for the camera, and Louie pans across each face. The tone is celebratory but also reflective, acknowledging the 11+ years already invested.

chapters.title: Grooving, Seeding, and Still Photos
chapters.summary: The final segment returns to detailed construction work. Gary explains that the crew is grooving the green with rakes to create a seedbed, then will roll it to close the grooves after seeding. He notes that Jim described Keith’s contouring as if it had been “painted on with a brush.” They seed rough with a blue/rye mix but delay bentgrass seeding due to high winds (9 million seeds per pound). Louie notes that most of the work is done by hand and praises the crew’s desire to “do it right.” The camera captures Gary working alongside laborers, undermining the stereotype of a superintendent as a distant boss. The film then cuts to a series of still photographs by Sam Oliverio, showing construction stages, bridges, and early course vistas. The tape closes with a quiet, personal vignette of an older man on the course kneeling with several dogs, while the audio continues to reference Glen Elk residences and local characters, underscoring that this is as much a family and community story as it is a golf‑course build.

highlights.title: Papa Jim’s Life Story on Camera
highlights.description: James LaRosa Sr. (“Papa Jim”), at age 91, delivers a concise, dignified account of his immigration from Italy, dual military service, and decades in business, expressing gratitude for America and its people.

highlights.title: Controlled Blast to Create Level Land
highlights.description: Blasting foreman Jack DePue stops traffic and detonates a hillside blast, sending a massive dust cloud down the slope. Louie jokes about not being paid and compares the shot favorably to another contractor’s work.

highlights.title: Jimmy LaRosa Explains the Three‑Year Hill Project
highlights.description: Standing on a newly leveled plateau, Jimmy describes the three‑year effort to level a hill for commercial land, emphasizing that they wanted to create long‑term development ground for Clarksburg and to capture the look “for posterity.”

highlights.title: Papa Jim’s Coal Tipple & Louie’s Tribute
highlights.description: From a house Papa Jim built on a hill, the camera pans over Virgil’s coal tipple and stockpiles. Louie Ellis turns the mic on himself to say it’s always been a pleasure to know the LaRosas and calls Papa Jim “the fellow that started it all.”

highlights.title: Gary Grandstaff’s Technical Walkthrough of #1 Green
highlights.description: Gary explains in detail the sand sourcing, blending, and seeding strategy for the first green, including bentgrass varieties and the decision to delay seeding due to wind. Louie quietly films Gary working with the crew, underscoring his hands‑on leadership.

highlights.title: Pete Dye’s On‑Site Reflections
highlights.description: Pete Dye, standing with LaRosa family and friends, praises the Clarksburg site, recounts Keith Sparkman’s loyalty and work on other courses, and jokes about needing to finish before they all “drop from this world.”

highlights.title: Harris Holt’s Tour of Holes 1–6
highlights.description: From various tees and vantage points, Harris narrates the emerging character of holes 1–6, pointing out mine portals, stone walls, multi‑level fairways, and deer tracks, and repeatedly marvels at how quickly the grass has come in.

highlights.title: Sodding the Steep Bunkers on #9
highlights.description: Workers carry ladders into steep bunkers to lay sod from the top down. Harris explains the logistics and credits the weather for allowing them to push late into the season, while Bogart the dog “supervises.”

highlights.title: Papa Jim’s Dual Service & Love for America
highlights.description: Papa Jim notes he served in both the Italian Army and the U.S. Army, and that he is “very happy for what I did” and that “the people love me 9 out of 10,” expressing deep affection for his adopted country and community.

highlights.title: Dogs on the Course with an Elder LaRosa
highlights.description: An older LaRosa kneels on the fairway with three dogs, petting them as other men stand in the background. The audio continues to talk about Glen Elk residences and neighbors, visually tying the family’s past to their new landscape.
characters_involved: James D. LaRosa (James D., JDL) or Jimmy LaRosa (Jimmy, Jimmy Joe, JJL)

quotes.text: My name is James LaRosa Sr. I came to this country in 1907. I’ve also been engaged in business, hotels, restaurants, real estate, the coal business the last 30 years. I’m very glad to be in this country. I served in the Italian Army from 1911 to 1912. I also served in the American United States War in 1918. I’m very happy for what I did, and happy that the people love me 9 out of 10. I would say I’m very glad that I love the country, I love the people, and I was born in 1891. I’m now 91 years old, and I’m happy to be here.
quotes.speaker: James LaRosa Sr. (Papa Jim)
quotes.context: Formal sit‑down interview segment with Papa Jim and Virgil, filmed outdoors near one of their coal operations.

quotes.text: Well, I’ve been working with my father since he got into the coal business in 1950. We’ve had a close association with one another, and we continue to do work. And he’s now reached the age of 90 years, and he’s still going strong. In fact, he’s wearing me out, and I think he’ll outlast me.
quotes.speaker: Virgil LaRosa
quotes.context: Virgil introduces his relationship with his father during the Papa Jim interview segment.

quotes.text: We’ve been here nearly three years, and we’re about finished. And I wanted to capture this look for posterity. It was a wild idea that Jimmy Joe and I had, and we decided to go ahead and do it, level this hill, and create a commercial piece of ground that the people of the greater Clarksburg area would always have available to them in the future.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa (James D., JDL)
quotes.context: On the leveled hilltop after the blasting project, explaining the purpose of the large earthmoving job Louie has been filming.

quotes.text: It’s been a real experience for me to go through something like this, working with my dad, with the men in the company, with the laborers to the superintendents. It’s just been a real experience for me, and one I wish everyone would be able to go through someday.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa (Jimmy, Jimmy Joe, JJL)
quotes.context: Standing beside his father on the newly created commercial plateau, reflecting on the project and teamwork.

quotes.text: Louis, the picture you’re taking now is the building where James D. was born. Did you say that was a house one time? Well, it looks like it’s been a building, but I mean, Jim’s family lived there when Glen Elk wasn’t as large as it is now.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified Glen Elk narrator (likely a LaRosa/Ellis contemporary)
quotes.context: Driving through Glen Elk, pointing out James D.’s birthplace and explaining that it served as a family home when the neighborhood was smaller.

quotes.text: Papa Jim La Rosa had this building built many years ago. It’s called the Elk Bridge. And it was his favorite thing. He liked it very much. And he wanted us to stay in the building as long as we could.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified Glen Elk narrator (likely a LaRosa/Ellis contemporary)
quotes.context: Street‑side explanation of the Elk Bridge building in Glen Elk, just before its demolition.

quotes.text: Louis, what you see the guys doing out there now is we’re just grooving the green for the seed bed. It lets the seed fall down in little grooves that those rakes are making, and then we’ll take a hand roller after we seed, close the grooves back up, and that’s the preparation for our seed bed.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: On #1 green, explaining the hand‑grooving process as workers rake the sand mix before seeding.

quotes.text: This green is a culmination of not only 12 years, but since I’ve been involved here at the Pete Dye Golf Club, we started searching for sand a little over a year and a half ago, and James D. managed to find some down in Worthington, which is about 12 miles away.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Detailing the sourcing and importance of the sand used in the first green’s construction.

quotes.text: Louie, the view that you have in your lens right now is the landing area of number two. You can see how the fairways have just come up so magnificently, and I remember when the bank was sodded. Now, if somebody had seen that before and after, then they would really understand why it had to be sodded.
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: Standing near #2, describing the transformation of the fairway and the decision to sod a steep bank.

quotes.text: Number five is a dogleg right, the only true par five on the course. There just isn’t anybody who can get to this hole in two.
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: On the #5 tee, explaining the strategy and difficulty of the hole while showing early grass growth.

quotes.text: Louie, we’re standing up here to the right of number seven green, looking back toward Four Lake. And the purpose of this is to show the number five hole from an elevated view. You can see how green everything is. I was out here last week, and everything was all still brown.
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: From an elevated vantage, illustrating how quickly the seeded fairways have greened up.

quotes.text: Louie, another individual who’s been involved here, not only on this green site, but the remaining green sites here at the club, Keith Sparkman. He’s worked for Pete Dye, came up here from finishing the greens on Kiawah Island, where next year’s Ryder Cup will be held. He’s the man that put the finishing touches on this green site.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Introducing Pete Dye’s shaper and crediting him for the final contours of the greens.

quotes.text: If you notice, most of this is being done by hand, and you know it takes a long time, but they want to do it right. That’s the way it’s being done here at Pete Dye’s golf course.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Voiceover as he films workers hand‑raking and grooving the green, emphasizing craftsmanship over speed.

quotes.text: We’re standing on the number five tee on the number one fairway, and what you see now is actually in the final stages of construction. There’s four tees right in the foreground—the one we’re standing on and then three more. And the number one tee will be the men that you can see working in the foreground, and they’re putting in the number one tee. The composition of this tee and the sand that’s on it came from a glacier deposit about 20 miles from here in Worthington.
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: Explaining the tee construction and sand sourcing on October 17, 1990.

quotes.text: I used to work on the truck in the summertime. Made $15 a week and didn’t know what I was going to do with all the money. How about that?
quotes.speaker: Unidentified Glen Elk narrator (likely a LaRosa/Ellis contemporary)
quotes.context: Driving past the old Coca‑Cola bottling works in Glen Elk, recalling summer work as a youth.

quotes.text: Louie, I want to thank you for taking these pictures of our operation. We’ll always appreciate having them, I know, for our own historical reasons. But you’ve been a friend down through the years, and what you’re doing now is awfully nice.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa (James D., JDL)
quotes.context: On the leveled hilltop, expressing gratitude to Louie for documenting the project.

quotes.text: Well, I’m glad to do it, but I know why he wants me to say one more time, no charge. No charge.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Responding to James D.’s thanks, reiterating that he’s filming as a friend and historian, not for pay.

themes: Family legacy and immigration
Transformation of land: from coal and Glen Elk to golf course
Community memory and neighborhood change
Hands‑on craftsmanship in golf‑course construction
Partnership between the LaRosa family and Pete Dye
Local pride and West Virginia identity
Intergenerational work (father–son projects)
Preservation of history through home‑movie documentation
Humor and warmth amid hard work
Integration of industrial/mining heritage into course design

Pete_Dye_Golf_Club.title: Nationwide Tour: 2004 Pete Dye West Virginia Classic TV Coverage & Trophy Ceremony
Pete_Dye_Golf_Club.content_type: Professional tournament broadcast and award ceremony
Pete_Dye_Golf_Club.summary: This video is a professionally produced Golf Channel broadcast package covering the inaugural 2004 Nationwide Tour Pete Dye West Virginia Classic at Pete Dye Golf Club in Clarksburg, West Virginia. It intercuts live tournament play, course and mining-heritage features, interviews with key figures (including Jimmy LaRosa and Pete Dye), large galleries and volunteer operations, and the full trophy presentation and winner’s interview with champion D.A. Points. The narrative emphasizes West Virginia’s coal-mining roots, the LaRosa family’s role in developing the course, Pete Dye’s design legacy, and the event’s rapid rise to premier status on the Nationwide Tour.

characters.name: Bob Wise
characters.description: Appears on camera in a branded golf shirt delivering an official welcome on behalf of the state, framing the tournament as important to West Virginia’s image and economic diversification.

characters.name: Brian Anderson
characters.description: Primary on‑air host in the broadcast booth, introduces the telecast, interviews Jimmy LaRosa, and frames the event’s significance and competitive storylines.

characters.name: Kurt (Curt) Byram
characters.description: On‑air analyst alongside Brian Anderson, comments on course design, scoring conditions, Pete Dye’s reaction, and the event’s status on the Nationwide Tour.

characters.name: Jimmy LaRosa
characters.role: President & CEO, Pete Dye Golf Club; developer
characters.description: Appears in sit‑down and on‑green interviews. Describes building the course with his father, the coal‑mining heritage, construction photos, and expresses gratitude for staff, volunteers, state, and coal industry support.

characters.name: Pete Dye
characters.description: Appears in archival interview/voiceover describing his philosophy for the closing holes (16–18) and is discussed extensively by commentators and Jimmy LaRosa as the mastermind behind the course.

characters.name: D.A. Points
characters.description: Featured extensively in highlights and live coverage as the runaway leader and eventual inaugural champion. Gives a full winner’s interview and interacts warmly with fans and volunteers.

characters.name: Nick Watney
characters.description: Shown on leaderboards and in highlights as an early leader and contender in the event.

characters.name: Vance Veazey
characters.description: Chasing D.A. Points in the third and final rounds; appears in multiple birdie/eagle highlight putts.

characters.name: Darron Stiles
characters.description: Contender with several key putts shown in highlights and leaderboards.

characters.name: Patrick Damron
characters.description: Younger brother of Robert Damron; appears in birdie highlight at the par‑3 16th.

characters.name: Jon Mills
characters.description: Shown making a long birdie putt as part of a strong round, tightening the leaderboard.

characters.name: Jerry Foltz
characters.role: On‑course reporter / trophy‑presentation host, The Golf Channel
characters.description: Leads the trophy ceremony, introduces sponsors and state officials, interviews Jimmy LaRosa and D.A. Points on the green.

characters.name: Doug Marquette
characters.role: West Virginia Sales Manager, Nationwide Insurance & Financial Services
characters.description: Identified on‑screen and introduced during the trophy ceremony as a key sponsor representative.

characters.name: John Snider
characters.description: Identified on‑screen as a co‑presenting sponsor from Arch Coal during the trophy ceremony.

characters.name: Dan Gerkin
characters.description: Identified on‑screen and thanked as co‑presenting sponsor from the National Mining Association.

characters.name: Betty Carver
characters.role: Commissioner of Tourism, State of West Virginia
characters.description: Introduced by name during the trophy ceremony as representing the state’s tourism office.

characters.name: Pete Dye Golf Club volunteers
characters.description: Large group in matching yellow shirts and caps; manage operations, scoring, and hospitality. Honored collectively and via a ‘Volunteer of the Week’ mention.

chapters.title: State Welcome & Event Introduction
chapters.summary: Governor Bob Wise delivers an on‑camera welcome, tying West Virginia’s coal‑mining heritage and new economic sectors to the inaugural Nationwide Tour Pete Dye West Virginia Classic. Golf Channel graphics and booth shots introduce the Nationwide Tour brand, the Pete Dye Golf Club, and commentators Brian Anderson and Kurt Byram. Early course beauty shots and mining relics (coal cars, mine tunnel) establish the coal‑to‑golf transformation theme.

chapters.title: Course, Coal Heritage & Early Round Coverage
chapters.summary: The broadcast blends live first‑round coverage with a feature on the site’s coal‑mining past. B‑roll shows coal tipples, mine tunnels, and a coal cart branded with the club logo. Commentators praise the LaRosa family’s backing and Pete Dye’s design. A narrated segment walks through the abandoned mine behind the 6th green and the cool tunnel between 6 and 7. Early leaderboards highlight Nick Watney and D.A. Points, and the booth frames the event as a future premier stop on the Nationwide Tour.

chapters.title: Jimmy LaRosa Interview & Construction History
chapters.summary: Jimmy LaRosa joins Brian Anderson and Kurt Byram on air. He describes overwhelming crowds and support from staff, volunteers, the state, and the coal industry. As archival photos and footage roll, he narrates construction scenes: building the 2nd hole, the rotary car dump and bridge on the 10th, and a bridge fire caused by creosote. He confirms that Pete Dye insisted on preserving coal‑mining artifacts when the family initially wanted to cover them up. The segment contrasts muddy earthmoving and derelict structures with the finished river holes and greens, underscoring the long transformation from mine site to ‘mountain retreat.’

chapters.title: Pete Dye Tribute & Rising Scoring Fireworks
chapters.summary: A Tuesday evening banquet honors Pete Dye, with ice sculptures, a plaque from the Nationwide Tour membership, and a social crowd in cocktail attire. Narration lists his famous designs and suggests many consider Pete Dye Golf Club his best. Tournament highlights show D.A. Points shooting 65–62 to seize a six‑shot lead, with Nick Watney, Vance Veazey, Darron Stiles, Patrick Damron, and Jon Mills chasing. The booth notes that soft, windless conditions have left the course ‘defenseless,’ to Pete Dye’s chagrin, as scores plunge to 17–19 under. A volunteer‑of‑the‑week vignette and a short Pete Dye interview about holes 16–18 (strong par‑3 16, controversial knobby‑green 17, and risk‑reward 18) deepen the design narrative.

chapters.title: Moving Day: Third‑Round Highlights & Community Support
chapters.summary: Third‑round coverage shows D.A. Points extending and then losing part of his big lead as Vance Veazey, Darron Stiles, Patrick Damron, and Jon Mills make birdies and eagles. Leaderboards and weather graphics frame ideal scoring conditions. The booth repeatedly emphasizes that the entire state has rallied behind the event, with busloads of fans, closed highway sections for parking, and big galleries despite rain. Shots of packed bridges, hillside crowds, and volunteer operations (lanyard distribution, check‑in tents) illustrate the logistical effort and community pride.

chapters.title: Championship Sunday: Final Round & D.A. Points’ Win
chapters.summary: Championship Sunday opens with perfect scoring conditions and a leaderboard showing D.A. Points at 21‑under with a six‑shot lead, tying a Nationwide Tour record. Highlights recap his birdies and bogeys as Vance Veazey and others close the gap. Live coverage follows Points’ final‑round approach and long putts on the 18th, with the amphitheater‑like green ringed by spectators and volunteers in yellow shirts. The booth notes that Points is one win away from a battlefield promotion and that local bars are advertising the telecast. After safely hitting the 18th green and two‑putting, Points clinches the inaugural title at 23‑under, greeted as a fan favorite who ‘thinks out loud’ on the course and is headed to the PGA Tour.

chapters.title: Trophy Ceremony & Sponsor / State Recognition
chapters.summary: On the 18th green, Jerry Foltz hosts a formal trophy ceremony around a coal‑cart champion’s trophy. He praises the event for exceeding heavy pre‑tournament hype and calls it a ‘world class event’ at a ‘world class facility’ with ‘world class support’ from the state. He introduces key figures: Doug Marquette (Nationwide Insurance), John Snider (Arch Coal), Dan Gerkin (National Mining Association), and Betty Carver (West Virginia Commissioner of Tourism). Jimmy LaRosa, identified as President & CEO of Pete Dye Golf Club, thanks the staff, volunteers, state, and coal industry, noting they decided to hold the tournament only eight months earlier. He invites the crowd to look around at everyone who supported the event and expresses humility and gratitude.

chapters.title: Champion’s Trophy Presentation & Interview
chapters.summary: Jimmy LaRosa jokingly warns D.A. Points that they’ll ‘do a blood test’ after his low scoring and notes the trophy is heavy as he hands over the 88‑pound coal‑cart. Points hoists it to cheers. In the winner’s interview with Jerry Foltz, he describes the week as the best start to any tournament in his life, admits battling himself on the final day, and credits calming down and sticking to his game plan to finish three‑under on the back nine. Asked about his many good breaks, he says that when you’re playing well you get good breaks, but that Sunday’s luck was more even than earlier in the week. He praises West Virginia’s hospitality and hopes it won’t be his last visit. Foltz notes that Points now has two wins and a second in his last four Nationwide starts, moves to the top of the money list, and is headed to the PGA Tour. The segment closes with Points thanking the crowd and signing autographs for volunteers and fans in yellow shirts.

highlights.title: Governor Bob Wise’s Statewide Welcome
highlights.description: Bob Wise appears on camera outdoors, welcoming viewers to the first annual Pete Dye West Virginia Classic, linking West Virginia’s coal‑mining foundation to its modern economy and outdoor tourism, and officially inviting all to the event on behalf of West Virginians.

highlights.title: Jimmy LaRosa Explains Keeping the Coal Heritage
highlights.description: In the booth, Jimmy LaRosa recounts how the family initially wanted to cover up the coal‑mining remnants, but Pete Dye insisted they be preserved. Archival photos of the rotary car dump and bridge on the 10th hole play as he describes a creosote fire that burned the original bridge, later rebuilt.

highlights.title: Mine Tunnel Feature Behind the 6th Green
highlights.description: A narrated feature shows the abandoned mine entrance and interior tunnel behind the 6th green, explaining that the temperature drops about a dozen degrees inside, making the walk from 6 to 7 ‘cool in more ways than one.’

highlights.title: Pete Dye on the Closing Holes
highlights.description: Pete Dye, in a pre‑recorded interview, explains his philosophy for finishing strong: 16 as a strong par‑3, 17 as a short but controversial par‑4 with a ‘knobby old green,’ and 18 as a long par‑4 that rewards a bold drive near the hazard with a clear view and short iron in.

highlights.title: D.A. Points’ Course‑Record 62 and Huge Lead
highlights.description: Highlights recap D.A. Points’ opening 65 and course‑record 62 on Friday, giving him a six‑shot lead at 17‑under. The booth jokes that he’s ‘public enemy number one in Pete Dye’s eyes’ as the course yields far lower scores than the architect expected.

highlights.title: Third‑Round Charge Narrows Points’ Lead
highlights.description: On Saturday, Vance Veazey, Darron Stiles, Patrick Damron, and Jon Mills make birdies and eagles, cutting D.A. Points’ six‑shot lead down to two by the turn. Graphics show Points at 20‑under with Veazey at 18‑under, creating real suspense heading into the back nine.

highlights.title: Championship Sunday Crowds ‘Lined Up for Miles’
highlights.description: Wide shots show cars parked along Meadowbrook Road and packed galleries on bridges and hillsides. The booth notes that a stretch of highway has been closed for parking and that fans are arriving by busloads, calling it an amazing scene for a first‑year event.

highlights.title: D.A. Points’ Winning Approach on 18
highlights.description: With a five‑shot lead, D.A. Points debates club selection with his caddie on the 18th fairway, choosing a 5‑iron instead of 4. He safely hits the right edge of the green, setting up an easy two‑putt to secure the title as the hillside gallery watches.

highlights.title: Jerry Foltz’s ‘World Class’ Praise at the Ceremony
highlights.description: During the trophy ceremony, Jerry Foltz tells the assembled crowd that the tournament received more pre‑tournament hype than any they’ve experienced and that they not only lived up to it but exceeded it ‘on every front,’ calling it a world‑class event, facility, and state support.

highlights.title: Jimmy LaRosa’s Humble Thanks
highlights.description: Jimmy LaRosa, standing beside the coal‑cart trophy, reminds the crowd that they decided to hold the tournament only eight months earlier. He says he is humbled and overwhelmed by the support, asks everyone to look around at those who made it possible, and specifically thanks staff and volunteers.

highlights.title: D.A. Points Hoists the 88‑Pound Coal‑Cart Trophy
highlights.description: LaRosa jokes that they’ll do a blood test on D.A. Points and that the trophy is heavy. Points lifts the 88‑pound coal‑cart trophy to cheers from volunteers in yellow shirts, laughing as he feels the weight.

highlights.title: Winner’s Interview: ‘Best Start’ of His Career
highlights.description: In his on‑green interview, D.A. Points calls it a fantastic week and says it started better than any tournament he’s ever played. He admits battling himself on Sunday but credits calming down and sticking to his game plan to finish three‑under on the back nine and hang on for the win.

highlights.title: Points on Luck, Breaks, and West Virginia Hospitality
highlights.description: Asked about his many good breaks, Points says that when you’re playing well you get good breaks, but that Sunday’s luck was more even than earlier in the week. He praises West Virginia as his first‑time visit, saying everyone has been supportive and nice, and hopes it won’t be his last time there.

quotes.text: West Virginia was built on a foundation of coal mining and now is a place of diverse economic resources including biometrics, research, tourism, and superb outdoor opportunities.
quotes.speaker: Bob Wise
quotes.context: On‑camera gubernatorial welcome tying the state’s mining past to its diversified present and outdoor appeal as he introduces the tournament.

quotes.text: Once a coal mining site, this beautiful golf course exemplifies West Virginia by providing a welcome destination for experienced tour professionals and tourists alike.
quotes.speaker: Bob Wise
quotes.context: Still in his opening address, explaining the transformation of the Pete Dye Golf Club property from mine site to golf destination.

quotes.text: The Pete Dye Golf Club is a collection of visually spectacular holes that will challenge and intimidate the very best players in the world. It’s been called Pete Dye’s finest work.
quotes.speaker: Unspecified Golf Channel narrator (network VO)
quotes.context: Voiceover during the opening montage over course beauty shots and coal‑heritage imagery, framing the course’s reputation.

quotes.text: It seems that the whole state of West Virginia has really gotten behind this event and good for them.
quotes.speaker: Brian Anderson
quotes.context: In the booth early in the broadcast, commenting on strong community and statewide support for the inaugural event.

quotes.text: And I think the key there is when you get the developer, the La Rosa family behind the event like they have, you know it’s going to be a first‑class event and it definitely is.
quotes.speaker: Brian Anderson
quotes.context: On‑air analysis crediting the LaRosa family’s backing as central to the event’s quality and organization.

quotes.text: Oh, I think we have. The crowds have been overwhelming. The support we’ve gotten from our staff and the volunteers and the state and the coal industry has just been wonderful. It’s just overwhelming, actually.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa
quotes.context: Live interview with Brian Anderson and Kurt Byram when asked if the event has exceeded his expectations.

quotes.text: That’s some of our men and equipment and some of Pete’s men there, building number two just down below the green and as we’re building up the fairway.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa
quotes.context: Describing archival construction photos of the 2nd hole during a feature on the course’s building phase.

quotes.text: You know, it’s interesting that I was talking to Pete Dye earlier this week, and he said the La Rosa family kind of wanted to cover up the coal aspect, you know, the coal mining aspect, but he demanded that you keep it, and now aren’t you glad you did?
quotes.speaker: Brian Anderson
quotes.context: Booth commentary to Jimmy LaRosa while showing coal‑heritage structures on the course.

quotes.text: Yeah, we certainly are. We’re fortunate that Pete took that perspective on the project, and it truly has added to the environment that we have here.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa
quotes.context: Response to Brian Anderson, affirming that preserving coal‑mining remnants enhanced the course’s character.

quotes.text: You know, I try to finish the golf courses strong. And I think 16 is a strong, certainly a strong par 3. You’re going to find 17 quite controversial, but it’s a short par 4 and it’s got a knobby old green, probably too knobby, but they’ll talk about it, certainly. But 18, I think, is a wonderful finishing hole.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pre‑recorded interview segment where Dye explains his design intent for the closing stretch at Pete Dye Golf Club.

quotes.text: Pete Dye wasn’t expecting 19‑under par at the turn on Saturday. You think he’s having trouble sleeping right now?
quotes.speaker: Brian Anderson
quotes.context: Reacting to D.A. Points reaching 19‑under during the third round, highlighting how low the scoring is relative to Dye’s expectations.

quotes.text: Apologies to Pete Dye. It’s a beautiful golf course. But if you give these guys, the quality of this field, soft, windless conditions, they are going to take advantage. That’s all there is to it.
quotes.speaker: Kurt (Curt) Byram
quotes.context: Analyst explanation for the unexpectedly low scores, defending the design while attributing scoring to conditions and field strength.

quotes.text: This golf course is legendary in these parts. It’s a beautiful Pete Dye golf course. And secondly, we’ve got a bunch of good players out there right now, and they’re out there to see them.
quotes.speaker: Kurt (Curt) Byram
quotes.context: Discussing why galleries are so large despite rain—local reverence for the course and the quality of the field.

quotes.text: Tuesday evening was a special one for golf course designer Pete Dye. Hundreds of people turned out to honor the man who is responsible for some of the world’s most memorable golf courses.
quotes.speaker: Unspecified Golf Channel narrator (network VO)
quotes.context: Voiceover introducing banquet footage honoring Pete Dye during tournament week.

quotes.text: Well this tournament received an advance billing and some pre‑tournament hype like no other tournament we’ve experienced, and I got to tell you, everyone on hand, you not only lived up to it, you exceeded it on every front.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Foltz
quotes.context: Opening remarks at the trophy presentation on the 18th green, addressing organizers, sponsors, and fans.

quotes.text: Congratulations to a world class event and a world class facility and world class support from your state.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Foltz
quotes.context: Continuation of his trophy‑ceremony praise, emphasizing the quality of the event, club, and state backing.

quotes.text: It was just eight short months ago that we decided to have this tournament, and I’m humbled and overwhelmed by your support. Just take one second to look around and look at everyone that has supported this event and we applaud you for supporting this thing. Thank you.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa
quotes.context: Speech during the trophy ceremony, reflecting on how quickly the event came together and thanking all supporters.

quotes.text: DA, I’m not sure what course you were playing, and we are going to do a blood test right after this, okay? But congratulations, an honor for us to bestow this award onto you.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa
quotes.context: Light‑hearted remark as he presents the heavy coal‑cart trophy to D.A. Points after his 23‑under performance.

quotes.text: Well, obviously it was a fantastic week for me. It started out better than I’ve started any other golf tournament in my life. And I battled myself a little bit today, but fortunately I calmed myself down and got back into my game plan and finished strong, shooting three under the back nine.
quotes.speaker: D.A. Points
quotes.context: Winner’s interview with Jerry Foltz, reflecting on his performance and mental approach in the final round.

quotes.text: When you’re playing well, you get good breaks. And today actually I could say that I got some good breaks and I got some not so good breaks, so today was pretty even. Earlier in the week was a little bit more favorable.
quotes.speaker: D.A. Points
quotes.context: Answering a question about the many fortunate bounces he received during the week.

quotes.text: All in all, West Virginia, this is my first time here and everybody’s been really, really supportive and everybody’s been so nice and a lot of fun, and hopefully this won’t be my last time here.
quotes.speaker: D.A. Points
quotes.context: Closing part of his winner’s interview, praising local hospitality and expressing desire to return.

quotes.text: Number one on the money list, number one in your hearts and the winner of the inaugural Pete Dye West Virginia Classic, D.A. Points.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Foltz
quotes.context: Ceremonial sign‑off at the end of the trophy presentation, summarizing Points’ status and win.
