Pete_Dye_Golf_Club_4-27-91_thru_10-10-91.title: Third Green & Early Course Construction – Pete Dye Golf Club (1991)
Pete_Dye_Golf_Club_4-27-91_thru_10-10-91.content_type: Construction footage with on‑site commentary, informal play, and course tour
Pete_Dye_Golf_Club_4-27-91_thru_10-10-91.summary: This archival segment documents the 1991 construction and early grow‑in of the third green and several adjacent holes at Pete Dye Golf Club, intercut with informal on‑course demonstrations and candid conversations. James D. LaRosa and companions walk and ride the site with cameraman Louie Ellis, explaining Pete Dye’s design philosophy—deep bunkers, severe green contours, and penal lakes—while superintendent Gary Grandstaff and Pete Dye’s greens builder Keith Sparkman appear in work sequences. We see heavy machinery shaping bunkers and greens, crews solving drainage problems, stone walls and mine portals being integrated into holes 5–8, and early play-testing shots across unfinished fairways and over water. The tone is technical but warm and humorous, with “Mon Senior” and other older golfers joking about needing ‘2,000 balls’ and balls going ‘plunk, plunk, plunk into the holy waters.’ The footage captures both the physical making of the course and the personalities who built and first played it.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.description: Older Italian‑American man who repeatedly narrates construction progress, explains Pete Dye’s intentions, introduces workers, and interviews guests. Often holds a handheld microphone and speaks directly to Louie behind the camera.

characters.name: Louie Ellis
characters.description: Family friend and self‑appointed documentarian. Rarely on camera but frequently addressed as “Louie” or “Loy,” asked to pan, zoom, and capture specific features. Occasionally jokes on mic about how much time he’s spent filming the course.

characters.name: Gary Grandstaff
characters.description: Seen on construction sites in work clothes, often with dogs nearby. Gives detailed explanations of green construction, drainage layers, and bunker finishing, and identifies crew members by name.

characters.name: Keith Sparkman
characters.description: Appears on greens under construction, sometimes camera‑shy. When on mic, he walks through pin locations and how contours feed balls to different tiers.

characters.name: Pete Dye
characters.description: Older man with white hair and glasses, labeled on screen in one segment. Speaks into a microphone about bunker shaping and how he wants misses to roll into sand.

characters.name: Monsignor O’Reilly (“Mon Senior”)
characters.description: Older man in white golf shirt and glasses, often standing beside LaRosa. Praised for his short game and compared to Chi Chi Rodríguez; jokes about needing thousands of balls and balls going into ‘holy waters.’

characters.name: Unidentified older golfer in yellow WV shirt
characters.description: Older man wearing a white Pete Dye Golf Club cap and bright yellow shirt with a large ‘W’ logo. Hits shots, explains difficulty of holes, and talks directly to camera about impossible pins and bends in greens.

characters.name: Harris Holt
characters.description: Identified by name in the transcript. Appears hitting approach shots on number five and narrating where the tees, landing areas, and green are, often with Louie filming.

characters.name: Gary’s dogs (Bogey, Rusty, Prince)
characters.description: Three dogs running around construction areas while Gary talks; he introduces them by name and backstory.

characters.name: Construction crew (Herb Hasselbacker, Arnold Chewing, Mike Renzelli, Clarence Eagle, Danny Harold, Mark Urso, Roy Randolph, etc.)
characters.description: Named and pointed out by Gary and Jim while operating dozers, Bobcats, loaders, and doing hand work on bunkers and green edges.

characters.name: Jim Fazio (from California)
characters.description: Older man in casual clothes, interviewed by LaRosa. Praises the course’s uniqueness and predicts national exposure.

characters.name: Unidentified older man in shirt and tie (likely a local dignitary or priest)
characters.description: Seen in a cart with blue jacket and tie, talking about the course while Louie films. Addressed as ‘Mon Senior’ in some sequences.

chapters.title: Intro & Third Green Under Construction
chapters.summary: The film opens with a credit shot of filmmaker Louie Ellis, then cuts to April 27, 1991, where James D. LaRosa stands in the fairway of the third hole with Monsignor O’Reilly. LaRosa explains that Pete Dye’s greens builder Keith Sparkman is shaping the third green. The camera shows a small red grading machine on the green pad and a D3 Caterpillar excavating a deep front bunker, while a Bobcat brings topsoil to build a ridge between upper and lower bunker levels. LaRosa explains Dye’s intent: missed shots should roll all the way down into the sand, and recovery shots must clear a high obstacle. He and the Monsignor banter about the difficulty of the lakes and the ‘impossible’ pin positions on a point of the green, noting that from some spots you can’t reasonably putt around the bend and may need a lofted shot instead.

chapters.title: Design Philosophy: Approaches Built Like Greens
chapters.summary: LaRosa walks Monsignor O’Reilly closer to the third green and clarifies that the first 30 feet that look like green are actually approach, but constructed to green specs (sand, gravel, drainage) so they won’t harden under traffic. This allows players to trust bump‑and‑run shots without crazy bounces. They discuss a unique ‘high rough’ hazard to be planted in weed‑free fescue and a man‑made lake that Pete Dye ‘saw’ on his first visit. The camera shows the aesthetic view down to the water. Later, Keith Sparkman steps in on the green and explains three distinct pinning areas, how slopes feed balls toward or away from pins, and why the back right peninsula pin will be so dangerous. LaRosa and companions joke about whether he’ll go for that corner pin and about a cormorant living on a rock island in the irrigation lake.

chapters.title: Bunker Shaping & Drainage Troubles on Seven
chapters.summary: The focus shifts to heavy construction: a D3 dozer builds the steep bank between the third green and its deep bunker, with LaRosa explaining how topsoil will be grassed and sand kept dry via subsurface drainage. He estimates seeding in mid‑June and playable turf in six weeks, with full maturity after a year of growing seasons. We then jump to May 20, 1991 on the seventh green, where standing water reveals a drainage failure in the rear third. Gary Grandstaff explains the USGA‑style profile—native clay, drain tile, gravel, and 14 inches of sand—and how they suspected a crushed or blocked tile. After exploratory digging and running sprinklers, they discover the issue is a compacted sand layer. Gary describes using a subsoiler every 24 inches to restore percolation. Equipment begins final contouring and excess sand removal as they prepare to plant.

chapters.title: Seventh Green & Stone Wall from the Georgian Mansion
chapters.summary: On May 25, 1991, LaRosa stands on the seventh green under construction and points Louie’s camera up to a new stone wall built for the back tee using cut stone salvaged from an 1842 Georgian mansion they demolished near the hole. He recounts the history of Wesley Smith and the Smith Chapel community and admits they probably shouldn’t have torn the house down. The back tee above the mine portal will be about 200 yards, reserved for very good players. Cameras show bunkers being built on the left of the green with a Smithco and a 450 Atlas Challenger dozer operated by Herb Hasselbacker. LaRosa notes Pete Dye will return to approve and add ‘subtleties.’ Gary appears with his dogs Bogey, Rusty, and Prince, explaining their rescue stories and how they run safely around machines. We also see Gary panning across holes 5 and 6, pointing out stone walls, Simpson Creek, new bunkers, erosion netting, and naming crew members doing hand work.

chapters.title: Course Tour with Harris Holt & Early Play on Front Nine
chapters.summary: Narrator Harris Holt appears wearing a Pete Dye Golf Club cap, announcing that he and Raymond Pozzolo will show how playable the course already is, even though it’s not open. They walk through number one’s five tee levels (pro, white, forward, and women’s tee), then ride a four‑wheeler on number two fairway. Louie briefly drives the cart for the first time, joking about needing a license. Harris and Raymond then describe number three (par‑4 dogleg right), number four (215‑yard par‑3 over water where ‘you can take off as much of the water as you want’), number five (three‑shot hole along Simpson Creek), number six (par‑4 with creek splitting fairway and rough), and number seven through nine. Harris hits shots on number five, including one that disappears into a depression ‘down the drainpipe,’ while Gary and others explain where tees, landing areas, and greens are. The segment ends with scenic views of number nine and a friend, James Frazier from California, praising the course as ‘one of the most beautiful holes in the country.’

chapters.title: Jim Fazio’s Endorsement & Technical Deep Dive on Seven
chapters.summary: LaRosa introduces his friend Jim Fazio from San Diego (originally from Clarksburg’s Norwood neighborhood). In an on‑camera interview, Fazio talks about how warmly Clarksburg still receives him and predicts the course will be ‘the most beautiful golf course in the United States,’ with unique features that will bring national exposure and strong word‑of‑mouth. LaRosa notes Fazio’s Depression‑era work ethic and hints they might do something together someday. After Jim rests, Gary resumes explaining the seventh green’s construction, pointing out workers Arnold Chewing and Mike Renzelli blending sand to uniform depth over gravel. He recounts the earlier drainage scare, the coal trucks hauling 20‑ton loads of mix, and how subsoiling solved the compaction issue. Gary then directs Louie’s camera across holes 5 and 6, identifying more crew (Mark Urso, Rick Sinyard, Ed Hurst) doing handwork on the six green hillside and describing the mine portal that players walk through from six green to seven tee, with steps up to the stone‑walled tees built from the Georgian mansion’s foundation.

chapters.title: Starting the Eighth Hole & Highwall Coal Seam
chapters.summary: On July 12, 1991, Gary reports they’ve finally started the eighth hole, the last to finish on the front nine. Louie’s camera shows a dramatic nine‑foot coal seam with a 60–70 foot highwall forming the right border of number eight—Gary notes it’s the only course he knows with a highwall. A D3 dozer operated by Herb Hasselbacker shapes a right‑front bunker while a red Mack truck hauls fill. Keith Sparkman has been reworking the left side of the green and adding new traps; drainage stacks behind the green show the emphasis on keeping the site dry. Gary explains they spent the first two days installing drainage so rain wouldn’t halt work, and that they’ll soon lay a gravel blanket and greens mix, then start irrigation on the fairway. Throughout, he mentions trying to avoid silt problems by working in small, clean areas. Intercut are shots of the 17th and 13th holes being roughed in, with Gary describing a huge, rolling 17th green with no bunkers but deep grass swales, and a reworked 13th par‑3 bank that Pete Dye loves.

chapters.title: From Raw Earth to Playable Holes: Six, Seven & Eight
chapters.summary: June 19, 1991 footage shows Simpson Creek running from behind six green to in front of six tees, with a rock wall and fairway grass planted the previous October. Gary points out three young workers (Mark Urso, Rick Sinyard, Ed Hurst) hand‑blending the right edge of six green where machines can’t reach. He explains that after birdie on six, players walk through the mine portal to reach seven tees atop the old mansion’s stone walls. Later, we see the fifth green site with new stone walls defining the right edge, bunkers being topsoiled and netted for erosion, and Gary naming crew members (Mike Renzelli, Clarence Eagle, Danny Harold, Herb Hasselbacker, Arnold Chewing, Mark Urso, Roy Randolph). Harris Holt then hits approach shots on number five, with one ball splashing or disappearing into a depression, while Gary and Louie laugh and use the shots to illustrate how well the new turf holds the ball. The segment closes with Gary’s panoramic explanation of five’s tees, landing areas, Simpson Creek, and the three‑shot route to the green.

chapters.title: Dogs, Pete Dye On‑Camera & Mon Senior’s Short Game
chapters.summary: A lighter sequence shows Gary introducing his dogs Bogey, Rusty, and Prince on the seventh green, explaining how they were rescued and now ‘know how to stay out of the way of the machines.’ We then see a labeled on‑screen interview with Pete Dye at the Larosa Golf Course in Clarksburg. Holding a microphone, Dye explains how a D3 Caterpillar is building a deep bunker in front of the green and how a Bobcat will bring topsoil to form a ridge between upper and lower bunkers so missed shots roll down into sand. He emphasizes that recovery from the sand will require hitting over a high obstacle. Throughout, LaRosa and others repeatedly praise ‘Mon Senior’ as terrific in sand, ‘just like ChiChi Rodriguez,’ and note that ‘all old timers started with a short game.’ Several sequences show an older golfer (likely Monsignor O’Reilly or the same ‘Mon Senior’) in a yellow WV shirt and Pete Dye cap hitting shots on unfinished fairways and tees, demonstrating how balls sit up on new turf and how demanding certain carries and bends in greens will be. They joke about needing ‘2,000 balls’ and balls going ‘plunk, plunk, plunk into the holy waters’ of the lakes along the fourth hole.

chapters.title: Technical Green Construction & Drainage Resolution
chapters.summary: Gary gives a detailed lesson on USGA green construction: 18 inches of native sub‑base, drain tile six inches below that, six inches of gravel, and 14 inches of sand mix. He walks Louie through the process of diagnosing and fixing a drainage problem on seven green—digging exploratory holes, running sprinklers, backfilling, then using a subsoiler to break up compacted sand. He notes that after subsoiling every 24 inches, water percolated fine and they were ‘back on an even schedule.’ We see workers checking sand depth to the gravel layer by hand to ensure uniform percolation. Gary also narrates the final contouring phase: removing excess sand, moving topsoil to finish bunker faces, and projecting seeding and first putts by September. LaRosa occasionally interjects, asking when they’ll be able to ‘plant this little golf ball’ and confirming that James D. wanted the drainage fix documented on video.

chapters.title: Course Tour: Fives, Sixes, Lakes & Industrial Backdrop
chapters.summary: Gary and Louie conduct a sweeping tour from the second landing area of number five, showing Simpson Creek, rock tees, and the fifth green bunkering. They then move to number six, where a stone‑lined creek runs from behind the green to in front of the tees, and to number seven’s stone‑walled tees above the mine portal. Later footage from October 10, 1991 shows finished or nearly finished holes with lakes, rock walls, and lush fairways, contrasted against twin smokestacks and an industrial plant in the distance. The commentary continues to stress how straight shots must be and how certain greens are ‘impossible’ for ordinary golfers, especially when flags are tucked on points or behind bends. The camera lingers on lakes, rock islands, and irrigation sprinklers, visually reinforcing the ‘holy waters’ jokes and the course’s rugged, post‑industrial setting.
characters_present: Unidentified older golfer in yellow WV shirt

chapters.title: Casual Play, Putting Demonstrations & Closing Reflections
chapters.summary: The final portion intercuts casual play with reflective commentary. Older golfers in yellow and dark shirts putt on newly built greens while discussing how certain pin positions force lofted chips or multiple putts around sharp bends. We see balls rolling on sloped surfaces, leaves on greens, and players retrieving balls from cups. Harris Holt and others hit tee shots over water and along fairways, demonstrating how well the new turf holds the ball. LaRosa and his companions continue to joke about lakes, ‘holy waters,’ and impossible shots from rough to tiny peninsula pins. In one interview, James Fazio from California calls the course ‘fabulous… picturesque… going to make history in the golf circles,’ saying it offers so much that even non‑golfers will come as tourists. The segment closes with Louie Ellis on camera, slightly disheveled, identifying himself and saying he’s enjoyed spending ‘a little over 1/7th’ of his life filming this ‘damn golf course’ and that it’s been nice doing the job for Mr. LaRosa, before signing off.
characters_present: Unidentified older golfer in yellow WV shirt

highlights.title: Explaining the Third Green’s Three Pin Areas
highlights.description: On the raw third green, Keith Sparkman walks LaRosa and Monsignor O’Reilly through three distinct pinning zones—front, left, and back peninsula—explaining how slopes will feed balls toward pins or leave brutal downhill chips.

highlights.title: Diagnosing & Fixing a ‘Heart Surgery’ Drainage Problem
highlights.description: Gary Grandstaff stands on a soggy seventh green, describing how they suspected a crushed drain tile, dug exploratory holes, then discovered a compacted sand layer and used a subsoiler every 24 inches to restore percolation.

highlights.title: Jim Fazio Predicts National Exposure
highlights.description: In a candid interview, Jim Fazio praises the course’s unique features and predicts it will be ‘the most beautiful golf course… in the United States,’ bringing national exposure and strong word‑of‑mouth business.

highlights.title: Gary Introduces Bogey, Rusty & Prince
highlights.description: On the seventh green, Gary Grandstaff introduces his three dogs, telling how Prince spent 10 years tied up before he bought her from a neighbor. The dogs run around the site as he notes they know how to stay clear of machines.

highlights.title: Pete Dye On Camera Explaining His Bunkers
highlights.description: Labeled on screen, Pete Dye stands with a microphone and explains how a D3 Caterpillar is building a deep bunker and how a Bobcat will create a ridge so missed shots roll down into sand, forcing players to hit over a high obstacle.

highlights.title: Through the Mine Portal to Seven Tee
highlights.description: Gary points out the timbered mine portal behind six green and explains that after making birdie, players walk through the portal and up steps to the seventh tees built on old Georgian mansion stone walls.

highlights.title: Harris Holt’s ‘Down the Drainpipe’ Shot
highlights.description: On number five, Harris Holt hits an approach that disappears into a depression. Laughing, he and Gary describe it as going ‘down the drainpipe,’ using the mishit to illustrate how the new contours collect water and balls.

highlights.title: Louie Ellis Reflects on a Decade Filming the Course
highlights.description: On camera, Louie jokes that he’s spent ‘a little over 1/7th’ of his life on this ‘damn golf course’ over ten years, but that he’s enjoyed every bit of it, and signs off as doing the job for Mr. LaRosa.

quotes.text: What Pete wants the player to do that misses a green, he wants them to roll all the way down into the sand where the bulldozer is.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa (describing Pete Dye’s intent)
quotes.context: Explaining the third green’s connected upper and lower bunkers while Louie films the D3 dozer in the deep front bunker.

quotes.text: The only thing is the first 30 feet of what appears to be green is not actually green. The green starts about where that first white stake is.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Clarifying to Monsignor O’Reilly that the approach is built to green specs but isn’t part of the official putting surface.

quotes.text: Five days ago we thought we had a drainage problem… The only problem we really had that had us stumped for a few days was a compacted sand layer. We’ve taken care of that problem… Everything’s straightened out and we’re back on an even schedule and ready to get it done.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Standing on seven green, Gary explains how they diagnosed and fixed a drainage issue using a subsoiler.

quotes.text: This is going to be the most beautiful golf course, I’m sure, in the United States… the features you have here are so unique, you will get national exposure.
quotes.speaker: Jim Fazio
quotes.context: Interviewed by LaRosa, Fazio praises the course’s uniqueness and predicts its future reputation.

quotes.text: He tells us what to do, and then we do it, and then he usually comes in and makes some last minute, I call it subtleties, that he puts into the course.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Describing Pete Dye’s process of giving instructions, then returning to refine holes like the seventh with subtle contour changes.

quotes.text: Louie, if you remember about five days ago, we had you out to take a picture of some film here of Seven with the sprinklers running with standing water. We thought we had a drainage problem…
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Reminding Louie of earlier footage as he documents the resolution of the drainage issue on seven green.

quotes.text: I just figured percentage‑wise, I’m a little over 1/7th of my life I’ve spent down this damn golf course… but I’ve enjoyed every bit of it.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Reflecting on a decade of filming the project while talking with LaRosa and friends.

quotes.text: This is going to be the most beautiful golf course… you’ve got a winner here, and you’ll be on top of the heap.
quotes.speaker: Jim Fazio
quotes.context: Continuing his endorsement, emphasizing word‑of‑mouth and repeat play.

quotes.text: You go in there after you walk off the back of number six after you made birdie, and on through the mine portal, and that brings you out over on seven tee.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Explaining the unique routing through a mine portal between six green and seven tee.

quotes.text: The house was a Georgian mansion built in 1842… we removed all of the house from the premises… except the four outside walls were a pink brick that probably, if it stayed, would give more character around this hole.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Describing the demolished Smith mansion and how its stone was reused for the seventh tee wall.

Pete_Dye_Golf_Club_9-5-92_thru_7-1-93-00.title: Irrigation, Cart Paths, and Temporary Clubhouse Build‑Out (1992‑1993)
Pete_Dye_Golf_Club_9-5-92_thru_7-1-93-00.summary: This archival reel documents multiple phases of Pete Dye Golf Club’s construction, centered on the 8th hole irrigation and earthwork, early cart‑path and road building, and the design and build‑out of the temporary clubhouse and support facilities between 1992 and mid‑1993. Much of the narration is provided on‑camera by James D. LaRosa (founder) and his son Jimmy LaRosa, with camera work by Louie Ellis. The footage moves from detailed technical explanations of irrigation trenches, wiring, and sand bedding, to cart‑path bases and Red Dog surfacing, to the interior layout and décor of the temporary clubhouse, and finally to paving, blacktopping, and a crew roll‑call just before opening. It interweaves heavy construction, quiet design decisions (wallpaper, fabrics, logo), and informal family/crew moments (dogs, jokes, missed Italian Festival) to show how the course and its infrastructure were built and who built them.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.description: Older Italian‑American man, often speaking directly to camera on construction sites and inside the temporary clubhouse, explaining irrigation, cart paths, clubhouse plans, and introducing workers.

characters.name: Jimmy LaRosa
characters.description: Younger man compared to James D., appears explaining tee construction, fertilizer applications, and walking viewers through progress on multiple holes.

characters.name: Louie Ellis
characters.description: Behind the camera for most of the reel; occasionally heard joking, prompting people, and being thanked on camera; appears briefly in reflections and is referenced by name.

characters.name: Nancy Ellis
characters.description: Not seen clearly but repeatedly thanked as Louie’s essential helper and for making coffee; referenced in jokes about laundry and hats.

characters.name: Sam Oliverio
characters.description: Appears with James D. near opening, joking about the opening date and being shown blacktopping work.

characters.name: Construction crew (various named workers)
characters.role: Equipment operators, carpenters, plumbers, office staff, mechanics
characters.description: Large group of men introduced by name in a roll‑call two days before opening; also seen throughout digging trenches, laying pipe, grading, paving, and building structures.

characters.name: Raymond (narrator of road/valet sequence)
characters.role: Explainer of road base and valet parking system
characters.description: Middle‑aged man narrating the road underlayment, compaction system, and valet parking layout, addressing Louie by name.

characters.name: Unidentified younger workers (red shirts, camo pants, etc.)
characters.description: Multiple younger men interviewed briefly or shown working (plate compactors, rakes, saws, trench work), some identified only by first names in roll‑call (e.g., Brad Stevens, Joe Hall, Mike Lankow).

chapters.title: Intro & Ellis Productions Credit
chapters.summary: Interior shots introduce Louis P. Ellis as cameraman/producer, followed by an Ellis Productions title card advertising his video services. This sets up that the following footage is his long‑term documentation of the Pete Dye Golf Club project.

chapters.title: September 5, 1992 – Irrigation and Shaping of the 8th Hole
chapters.summary: On Italian Festival Day 1992, James D. LaRosa stands on the raw 8th hole site and explains why the crew is working instead of attending the parade: they must finish irrigation, topsoil, and seeding before the growing season ends. The camera shows the dramatic strip‑mined high wall and future "grandstand" area, trenches for 36‑inch‑deep irrigation lines, white PVC pipes marking sprinkler heads and valves, and green control wires laid in the same ditch. Workers install pipe, wiring, and sand bedding to protect against rocks. Heavy equipment (dozers, excavators, trenchers) shapes the massive rock wall and bunker areas, while plate compactors finish bunker floors and green surrounds. James D. repeatedly calls the 8th "one of the 8 wonders of the golfing world" and details how sand, coal veins, and rock walls will influence play without "slicing the ball."

chapters.title: Tee Construction, Fertilizing, and Early Grow‑In (Spring 1993)
chapters.summary: Jimmy LaRosa and others walk Louie through progress on multiple holes: tiered tees on holes 2, 4, 5, and 8 are being finished with sand mix, drainage, and irrigation. A fertilizer rig applies the first fertilizer to greens and then to fairways and roughs. Jimmy notes deadlines (grass planted by May 1 to open in July) and shows liquid fertilizer being sprayed. Another narrator (Gerald Ramsburg) describes a five‑level tee system surrounded by a lake and a large green on a knoll, while a specialist shaper (Keith Speckman) uses a vibrating roller machine to finish the massive 8th green. The camera highlights a Pittsburgh coal vein exposed beside one of the largest bunkers on the course, reinforcing the coal‑mine motif.

chapters.title: Cart Path Base, Red Dog, and Road Underlayment
chapters.summary: James D. narrates the first cart path construction on the 1st hole: trucks from Guzzi’s Quarry deliver 3‑inch screened rock, spread six inches thick by dozer operator Steve Helmick over drainage pipes. He explains passing bays near tees and steps, and how Red Dog (burnt coal seam material) will be laid 2–3 inches thick on top. Separate sequences show the Red Dog pit behind the 10th green, where backhoes load trucks with burnt coal/clay used for cart paths, tying the material to the course’s coal‑industry theme. Raymond later explains a one‑mile entrance road underlayment: a combination of cinders, limestone, and railroad ballast is laid 12 inches thick, then compacted to six inches before three inches of blacktop and a one‑inch finish coat. A bulldozer pushes a spreader while a motor grader and roller follow, and Raymond praises Jim LaRosa’s compaction system. These scenes show the evolution from raw mine roads to finished access roads and cart paths.

chapters.title: Temporary Clubhouse: Exterior Walkways, Decks, and Bag Drop
chapters.summary: Through winter and spring 1993, James D. walks Louie around the temporary clubhouse: a mobile building brought from Michigan. Carpenters Frank Mazzi and Brad Stevens build a pressure‑treated wood walkway and front porch, which will be covered by a forest‑green canopy with the Pete Dye logo. A rear deck is framed to overlook the 9th green and 1st tee. James explains that the building is 28x66 feet and will house a grill room and pro shop, with locker rooms to be added against an existing A‑frame. He shows the bag‑drop building design (racks on all four sides) and a cart‑charging shed with wood structure and electric chargers. Painters stain the lumber Olympic Beechwood gray. Rock walls are built around the putting green to echo the course’s stonework. James points out landscaping—rhododendron, dogwoods, azaleas—and a planned waterfall structure where irrigation water from Simpson Creek will spill 20 feet, visible from the 1st tee.

chapters.title: Temporary Clubhouse Interior: Layout, Décor, and Pete Dye Exhibit
chapters.summary: Inside the temporary clubhouse, James D. gives a detailed tour: the grill room will seat about 40, with a pass‑through window from a small kitchen equipped with a drink dispenser. The far end will be the pro shop, with a dedicated Pete Dye exhibit space (portrait, photos, articles). He shows architectural drawings by Robert Pernell for men’s and women’s locker rooms, showers, and toilets to be added behind the building. Wallpaper and fabric samples are displayed: plaid below the chair rail, a nine‑inch border with Scottish golfers above, and spike‑proof granite‑gray carpet to evoke a conservative Pinehurst/Scottish feel that Jimmy wants. Fabric with vintage golf scenes is planned for window treatments. James also shows tile samples for locker room showers and bathrooms, and awning mockups with the Pete Dye Golf Club logo. Office interiors and a pro‑shop/grill layout are filmed, including a large conference table and cubicles in an administrative office. Throughout, James jokes with Louie about food service (“you cook the food, I’ll prepare the room”) and acknowledges Nancy’s role in getting Louie on site.

chapters.title: Dogs, Family Moments, and Informal Office/Clubhouse Life
chapters.summary: Interspersed with construction footage are informal scenes: James D. introduces his dogs—Buttons, Bogey, Rusty, Brassy, Heidi, Cold Dust—around the clubhouse and in Louie’s car, joking about paw prints on the seats. Dogs wander through the temporary clubhouse and office, appearing in doorways and on decks. Louie and James banter about Louie’s dirty pants and Nancy’s laundry, promising her two Pete Dye hats as "paycheck." In the office, a small dog trots across the carpet while the camera surveys cubicles and a large conference table. These moments humanize the project, showing the LaRosa family’s dogs and the casual, lived‑in feel of the developing club environment.

chapters.title: Telephone, Gas, and Water Infrastructure: 100‑Pair Cable and 8‑Inch Loop
chapters.summary: James D. documents utility work: a 100‑pair telephone cable is buried along the entrance road before blacktopping. A backhoe carefully digs near existing 10‑inch, 2½‑inch, and ¾‑inch water lines while two men guide the operator to avoid breaks. A telephone company plow machine pulls cable toward a green junction box, from which lines run a mile to the entrance. James explains that this will allow up to 100 phones at the club. Separately, an 8‑inch water line is installed along the 9th fairway to complete a full 8‑inch loop for front‑nine irrigation, replacing a partial 2½‑inch system that lacked pressure. Sand is stockpiled in the woods and used to bed and cover the pipe and electric lines to protect them from rocks. James and a worker named Kevin discuss thrust blocks and directional bends (45‑degree fittings) at corners to prevent joints from blowing out. Another sequence shows a 10‑inch high‑pressure line and a gas line being laid from the pump house to the back nine, again with sand bedding and careful separation for safety.

chapters.title: Red Dog Spreading and Entrance Road Blacktopping
chapters.summary: At the Red Dog pit behind the 10th green, James D. shows backhoes loading burnt coal/clay into trucks owned by local haulers (Denison, Castro, Aquino). On the course, Mike Lankow, a Pete Dye shaper, spreads Red Dog with a Komatsu dozer on cart paths and around the mine portal at the 7th hole. James explains they’re proud of the material, expect it not to turn to mud, and will compact it with a roller to support carts and mowers. Later, Raymond narrates the entrance road construction: seven trucks haul 18–22 tons each of a cinder/limestone/ballast mix. A bulldozer pushes a spreader that lays 12–14 inches of material, followed by a motor grader and roller to achieve high‑90s compaction. The road will receive three inches of blacktop and a one‑inch finish coat, creating a one‑mile, railroad‑ballast‑themed entrance consistent with the coal motif. On June 30, 1993, three days before opening, James D. and his lifelong friend Sam Oliverio stand by the clubhouse as Mountaineer Contracting blacktops around the clubhouse and the entrance road. Jim Halley (in a red striped shirt) supervises, and Neil Winters hand‑tamps edges the roller can’t reach. James explains they decided to cover Red Dog near the clubhouse with blacktop to avoid tracking red dust onto carpets.

chapters.title: Valet Parking, Club Drop, and Final Site Organization
chapters.summary: Raymond and James D. describe the valet parking area being created near the A‑frame clubhouse: members will drive to a club drop building where a valet removes their bags, then cars are parked in a designated area while clubs are loaded onto carts. The camera shows the six‑inch overlayment of cinders/limestone/ballast on an old, well‑compacted road, and the compaction system Jim devised. A roller flattens high spots after the spreader and grader. James D. stands on the clubhouse porch, pointing out the 9th green, wooded parking between trees to preserve a park‑like feel, the transformer compound that doubles as a bag‑drop backdrop, and the future permanent clubhouse site. He notes that cars will stay on the road while everything to the left becomes golf course and practice putting green. These sequences show the transition from pure construction site to a functioning club arrival experience.

chapters.title: Crew Portrait and Roll‑Call Two Days Before Opening
chapters.summary: On July 1, 1993, two days before opening, James D. assembles about 28 men in front of the No. 1 lake for a group portrait: equipment operators, carpenters, office staff, mechanics, and laborers. He says he wants to preserve the picture to remember the good times, hard times, and problems building the course. He then walks down the line with a microphone, having each man state his name: James D. LaRosa, John B. Angotti, Jerry Reel, Terry Hoke, Jason Hussar, Frank Mazzi, Dave Brown, Christopher Reel, Bob McCampbell, Randy Haddix, Bill Winans, Bruce McCullough, Neil Winters, Michael Shaw, Larry Brady, Jim Tonkrie, Kenneth Hofer, Rodney McQuain, Bob Andrew, Kevin Patton, “100 Mile An Hour” Mark G. Bias, Gary Messinger, Bud Higgins, Joe Hall, Brad Stevens, Jim Christie, Arnold Tuneen, Scott Tuneen, and others. James notes about 20 more men are out on the course and may be filmed later. He thanks Louie and Nancy for coming early and for their photography, saying it will be cherished for years.

highlights.title: Calling the 8th Hole an "8th Wonder"
highlights.description: James D. stands on the raw 8th hole site and declares that the tee end of the 8th will be "one of the 8 wonders of the golfing world," as the camera shows the massive strip‑mined high wall and future grandstand area.

highlights.title: Working Through Italian Festival Day
highlights.description: James D. explains that it is Italian Festival Day in Clarksburg, but the crew skipped the parade to work every day that month on irrigation and seeding, or they would lose the growing season.

highlights.title: Detailed Irrigation Trench Explanation
highlights.description: James D. describes the 36‑inch‑deep ditch, the sequence of laying green control wire, then pipe, then sand, and why sand bedding is needed to protect pipe and wire from rocks that may settle over time.

highlights.title: Red Dog Pit and Coal Motif
highlights.description: At the Red Dog pit behind the 10th green, James D. explains how a seven‑foot coal seam burned in place, cooking the clay above into Red Dog, which they now use for cart paths to tie the course to West Virginia’s coal heritage.

highlights.title: Temporary Clubhouse Décor – Scottish/Pinehurst Feel
highlights.description: James D. shows wallpaper and fabric samples with Scottish golfers and plaid patterns, explaining that Jimmy wants a conservative, quiet Scottish/Pinehurst look in the pro shop and grill, coordinated with spike‑proof gray carpet.

highlights.title: Waterfall Structure from Simpson Creek
highlights.description: James D. points out a concrete and rock structure near the first tee that will become a 20‑foot waterfall, using irrigation water from Simpson Creek as an amenity visible from the tee.

highlights.title: Group Portrait and Roll‑Call of 28 Men
highlights.description: Two days before opening, James D. lines up 28 men in front of No. 1 lake and has each state his name on camera, preserving a record of the team that built the course.

quotes.text: Today we’re working on the irrigation of the 8th hole. And it’s September the 5th, Italian Festival Day, but we need to work every day this month in order to get this hole upsoiled, irrigated, and seeded. Otherwise we’ll lose the whole growing season. So we missed the Italian Festival Parade this morning, but we’ll see you next year, I guess.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: On‑camera explanation at the 8th hole construction site about schedule pressure and working through a local holiday.

quotes.text: We’re looking at the T end of the 8th golf hole here, which we think this golf hole is going to be one of the 8 wonders of the golfing world.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Standing on the raw tee end of the 8th hole, describing its future significance while Louie films the dramatic high wall and fairway corridor.

quotes.text: The ditch is about 36 inches deep. We want to get below the crust. And then we put the wiring in and then we put the pipe. And then we put sand in… that gives a bed for the pipe and wire. So if there’s any rocks that end up in the ditch, sometimes you need a bed.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Narrating over close‑ups of irrigation trenches and workers laying pipe and control wire on the 8th hole.

quotes.text: This here is a border that goes on top of the chair rail… It’s a paper that gives you the so‑called Pinehurst feeling, which is a conservative, quiet Scottish look. It’s what Jimmy Joe wanted in his pro shop.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Inside the temporary clubhouse, showing wallpaper and fabric samples for the grill room and pro shop décor.

quotes.text: We have drawings for the temporary clubhouse here at the Pete Dye Golf Club designed by Robert Pernell, architect… Very, very good architect. He’s done other work for us in the past.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Pointing to architectural blueprints for the temporary clubhouse and locker rooms.

quotes.text: This is the first day that we’re putting fertilizer on the greens. They’ve been cut once, they’ve been limed twice, and as you can see up on 7 green there, he’s fertilizing number 7.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa
quotes.context: Jimmy explains spring agronomy work while Louie films a fertilizer rig on the 7th green.

quotes.text: What Mr. LaRosa is laying here is one mile of road… all this underlayment, three inches of blacktop, and then one inch of finish. And he will have one magnificent road into his work.
quotes.speaker: Raymond (road narrator)
quotes.context: Describing the entrance road construction and compaction system while Louie films trucks, spreader, grader, and roller.

quotes.text: We’re standing in front of number one lake at the Pete Dye Golf Club, two days before the opening. The men you see in the picture are some of the men that have worked with us to build this course… I wanted to preserve this picture so I can think of the good times and the hard times and the problems we’ve had during this course.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Introducing the assembled crew for a group portrait and roll‑call before opening day.

quotes.text: Someday I’ll be looking at this again and thinking of you, Louie, and Nancy, because you couldn’t get this done without her.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Inside the temporary clubhouse, thanking Louie and Nancy Ellis for their long‑term filming and support.

themes: Irrigation and underground infrastructure
Earthmoving and dramatic landform creation (high walls, bunkers, coal veins)
Use of coal‑related materials (Red Dog, ballast) to express local industry
Temporary clubhouse design, décor, and operations planning
Roads, cart paths, and valet/arrival experience
Family, friendship, and sacrifice (missing Italian Festival, dogs, informal banter)
Pride in craftsmanship and crew recognition
Long‑term documentation and legacy (Ellis Productions, blueprints, roll‑call)

Pete_Dye_Golf_Club_9-9-1992.title: Pete Dye Golf Club – Construction Tour & Hole 2/8/9 Walkthrough (1992)
Pete_Dye_Golf_Club_9-9-1992.content_type: Construction footage with on‑course narrated tour
Pete_Dye_Golf_Club_9-9-1992.summary: Archival VHS-era footage (dated September 1992) documents early and mid-stage construction at Pete Dye Golf Club, combined with on‑course narration intended for Pete Dye. The primary on‑camera/narrating voice walks cameraman Louie Ellis through holes—especially #2 and #8—and the multi‑tee complexes (gold, blue, white, red, ladies). He explains strategy, yardages, coal seam geology, mining remnants, drainage, and massive earthmoving, while occasionally addressing James D. LaRosa (“Jim”) and Pete directly. We see raw strip‑mine cuts, stacked boulder retaining walls, a mine portal, heavy equipment, dogs on site, and later some finished or nearly finished fairways (including #9). The tone is technical, proud, and personal, meant both as a progress report and a design check for Pete Dye.

characters.name: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)
characters.role: Primary on‑camera host and technical narrator of the construction tour
characters.description: Older man with short white/gray hair, wearing a plaid button‑down shirt and blue pants in some shots, often holding a microphone. He walks the site, stands on tees and in bunkers, and speaks directly to Pete Dye, to cameraman Louie, and to “Jim” (James D. LaRosa). He gives detailed yardages, design intent, and construction status.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa (Jim, James D.)
characters.role: Founder/owner; subject of commentary and visible on site
characters.description: Referenced repeatedly as “Jim” and “James D.” The narrator praises his vision and toughness. We see an older man in work clothes and cap walking construction areas with several dogs, and later leaving in a vehicle (“there goes the boss of all bosses… good old Jim”), strongly suggesting James D. LaRosa on site overseeing work with his family and dogs.

characters.name: Louie Ellis
characters.description: Identified explicitly in the narration as the person filming (“Louie… we call Cecil B. DeMille here in Clarksburg”). He is mostly behind the camera. The narrator notes Louie walked the ground with a bad hip to film this for Pete. Louie briefly speaks near the end, addressing Pete directly and joking about the job and being worked hard by Jim.

characters.name: Nancy Ellis
characters.description: Mentioned by name in the sign‑off (“He and his wife, Nancy, say hello to you”). Not seen clearly on camera in this excerpt but acknowledged as part of the filming effort.

characters.name: Pete Dye
characters.role: Intended recipient of the footage; course architect
characters.description: Not seen on camera in this material, but addressed constantly in second person. The entire walkthrough is framed as a visual report for Pete to review contours, drainage, bunkers, and green edges, so he can “tell us what to do over the phone.”

characters.name: Harris Holt
characters.description: Named multiple times (“Harris Holt says we’re 102 yards from the green… pretty exacting guy”; “How about the mic in front of me, Harris?”). He is off‑camera most of the time, occasionally warned about footing (“Watch it, Harris”). He provides precise yardages and likely holds the mic at one point.

characters.name: Bunker / Brutus (Pete’s dog)
characters.role: On‑site dog, part of course culture
characters.description: Described as “Pete’s favorite dog on this course, Brutus, or we call him Bunker. He’s half pit bull.” Seen around the 8th green/bunker area. Treated affectionately and called into frame by the narrator.

characters.name: Other dogs (site/family dogs, incl. ‘Bogey’)
characters.description: Several dogs (collie‑type, black‑and‑white, tan) roam the construction areas and finished turf. One is called “Bogey.” They appear frequently near Jim and the narrator, adding a casual, family atmosphere to the construction footage.

chapters.title: Opening titles and introduction (Louie’s film for Pete)
chapters.summary: Simple title and credit cards (“PETE DYE GOLF CLUB”; “DIRECTOR / PRODUCER / LOUIE ELLIS”) introduce the tape as Louie Ellis’s production. This frames the footage as a deliberate, authored record of the course for Pete Dye and the LaRosa family.

chapters.title: On‑course intro with Jim and dogs – Gold tee overview
chapters.summary: The narrator stands on a finished or nearly finished tee (gold tee) on a par‑4, 465‑yard dogleg right. He addresses “Jim” (James D. LaRosa) and notes family in the background. Two dogs run around. From an elevated vantage, he describes the fairway, a bunker at 240 yards, and the beauty of the trees, especially in fall. He then has Louie pan to show the gold tee’s boulder retaining wall and the built‑up blue tee below, explaining that many man‑hours and ingenuity went into constructing it. He points out Simpson Creek below and additional tees (white, red, ladies) along the right, and a distinctive rock that looks like a golf club near the end of hole #2.
characters_present: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

chapters.title: Hole #2 from above – Simpson Creek and multi‑tee strategy
chapters.summary: From high ground near the end of #2, the narrator explains that #2 is a dogleg left. Players must drive over Simpson Creek to a landing area and can “eat off as much as you want” of the creek/dogleg: the more you bite off, the shorter the second shot. He notes that the right side of the fairway has been sodded for easier maintenance. The camera shows construction equipment, raw graded areas, and the creek valley. He emphasizes the multiple tee sets (gold, blue, white, red, ladies) and how they align along the right side above Simpson Creek.
characters_present: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

chapters.title: Entering the 8th hole canyon – coal seam and strip‑mine wall
chapters.summary: The focus shifts to the dramatic par‑5 8th hole, carved into a former strip‑mine high wall. Standing about 115 yards from the flag in what will be a grass bunker, the narrator describes a 500‑yard par‑5 with a long sand bunker running to the green, a stone wall and stream behind the green, and a berm that may stop balls before the water. He points out the exposed Pittsburgh seam of coal—about eight feet thick—at the base of a 70‑foot high wall, with another 60–70 feet of trees above, creating a 120–130 foot vertical canyon. He explains that the bunker is about 315 yards off the tee, so it’s mainly a second‑shot hazard. The camera shows the coal seam, the towering wall, and active topsoil dumping and grading on the upper level, with plans to seed soon.
characters_present: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

chapters.title: Shaping the 8th green and acre‑plus bunker – drainage and coal seam
chapters.summary: Walking closer to the 8th green, the narrator discusses an open drainage ditch along the coal seam that Pete suggested might remain open for seepage water. He notes the fairway will be 40 yards wide, the bunker 60 yards wide—over 100 yards before the ditch. From about 30 yards short of the flag, he shows a grass bunker in front of the green, mounding and bunkering for water control, and how close the green edge comes to the coal wall (about 30 feet). He points out steep contours on the left of the green and sand bunkers 20 feet above the green on the hillside. He repeatedly asks Pete to review the film and advise by phone where the green edges and depressions should be. Pete’s dog “Bunker/Brutus” appears around the green and in the big acre‑plus bunker. The narrator has Louie pan up the wall to show its full 130–150 foot height and the canyon feel from the bunker floor. Trucks dump topsoil behind the green, and he shows a deep mine opening into the Pittsburgh seam, contrasting deep mining with strip mining and calling the seam “the most single valuable mineral deposit in the world.”
characters_present: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

chapters.title: Behind and beside the 8th green – cart paths, 9th tee rock, and canyon scale
chapters.summary: From behind the 8th green, about 30 feet behind the flag, the narrator shows the green’s contour, the coal seam just beyond, and disturbed areas where irrigation piping has altered the shape and must be re‑shaped. He points out the cart path behind a mound, the planned cart parking area, and the route down to the 9th tee. A large single standing rock marks the 9th tee location and visually separates #8 from #9. Then the camera moves to the left edge of #8, looking across the cavernous bunker. The narrator jokes that you could hide “20 D9s” (bulldozers) in there and notes that Jim, seen in the distance, gets smaller and smaller as he walks into the bunker, emphasizing its scale. Harris Holt gives an exact yardage (102 yards) from the fairway to the green. The narrator explains the contouring: mounds and bunkers 20–25 feet above the green on the left, multiple levels that ensure a second shot will finish somewhere visible rather than lost.
characters_present: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

chapters.title: Fine‑tuning 8th approach contours – multiple vantage points for Pete
chapters.summary: The team methodically documents the approach into #8 from various distances and elevations for Pete’s review. From about 45 yards, then 35 yards, then 35–40 yards from the pin but higher up near the bunkers, they show the two flat “landing” shelves and the drop‑offs between them. The narrator stresses that on the second shot “the ball’s going to be in here somewhere… can be seen,” which he calls unusual and desirable. He repeatedly says they hope Pete can see enough on film to tell them what to do over the phone. A dog named “Bogey” wanders into frame. They then climb up to the bunkers above the fairway to give Pete a high‑angle view back over the huge bunker and approach, hoping Pete will say “leave everything as it is.” The narrator jokes that Louie would say “are you kidding?” but insists the views should give Pete a good sense of the shaping.
characters_present: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

chapters.title: Louie’s sign‑off to Pete and panoramic views from above #8
chapters.summary: From high ground above #8, looking down toward #3, the narrator calls it “another beautiful Pete Dye job” and says “this is what the golfer sees.” We see Jim and his family heading to their “dogmobile” (a vehicle loaded with dogs); Jim honks the horn. Louie takes the microphone and speaks directly to Pete, saying it was nice doing the job and joking that with Harris Holt, James D., and Louie Ellis “how in the hell can you go wrong.” He adds “God bless you” and calls Jim “the boss of all bosses” who “worked the hell out of me today.” The narrator then captures another view of the hole as the sun angle changes, saying nobody expects such a dramatic course in Clarksburg and praising Pete’s “beautiful job.”
characters_present: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

chapters.title: Stone‑built ‘big boy’ tees and finished views of #9
chapters.summary: The camera returns to the stacked boulder retaining walls supporting the upper tees, which the narrator calls the “big boy tees.” He wants a close‑up so others can appreciate the work that went into them. He then pans down to the blue tees and across the surrounding trees. The footage includes more polished, grassed views of a fairway and green (identified as #9), with the sun now at a different angle than earlier in the day. The narrator notes that the changed light gives a different view and perspective of #9 and the surrounding trees, underscoring the course’s beauty in varying conditions.
characters_present: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

chapters.title: Raw construction montages – tees, fairways, coal walls, and mine portal
chapters.summary: Intercut throughout the tape are extended sequences of raw construction: graded dirt basins, steep cut banks, stacked boulder walls, exposed coal seams, and a rectangular deep‑mine portal framed in the cut face. Dump trucks unload topsoil; CASE bulldozers and other heavy equipment grade slopes and fairways. Stakes, pipes, and drainage ditches mark future greens, bunkers, and cart paths. The narrator overlays these visuals with descriptions of the gold and blue tees, the par‑4 dogleg right with a 240‑yard bunker, Simpson Creek below, and the multi‑tee system (white, red, ladies). He repeatedly emphasizes the “Grand Canyon” feeling of the 8th hole canyon, the difficulty of mowing 60‑foot banks, and the uniqueness of integrating the Pittsburgh seam of coal and mining history into the course. These sequences serve as a technical record of earthmoving and infrastructure before turf and finishing.
characters_present: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

chapters.title: Closing perspective shots and black‑frame transitions
chapters.summary: The tape ends with additional narrated views of a fairway (likely #9) and surrounding trees, with the narrator remarking on how the sun’s changed position gives a different perspective. Some sections are black frames with only audio, likely tape gaps or in‑camera edits, but the narration continues to reference the gold tee, boulders, dogleg right, and bunker at 240 yards. The overall close emphasizes the course’s visual richness and the pride in the construction work, leaving Pete with multiple angles to review.
characters_present: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

highlights.title: Explaining the 8th hole’s coal‑seam canyon
highlights.description: Standing in the future grass bunker on #8, the narrator shows the exposed Pittsburgh seam of coal and the towering strip‑mine high wall, describing how Pete directed them to strip the overburden to create a “Grand Canyon” feel. He quantifies the wall’s height and explains how a sliced second shot will end up in the canyon bunker.
characters_involved: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

highlights.title: Documenting the 8th green for Pete’s remote approval
highlights.description: From 30–60 feet around the 8th green, the narrator carefully walks Louie through the contours, depressions, and proximity to the coal wall, repeatedly saying “I hope you can see this, Pete” and asking Pete to tell them over the phone where to adjust the green edge and drainage ditch. Pete’s dog Bunker wanders through the shots, humanizing the technical walkthrough.
characters_involved: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

highlights.title: Revealing the scale of the acre‑plus bunker on #8
highlights.description: From the left edge of #8, the camera watches Jim walk into the massive grass/sand bunker until he becomes tiny. The narrator jokes you could hide “20 D9s” in there and notes that the bunker is partly grass, partly sand, giving a dramatic sense of the hole’s scale and intimidation factor.
characters_involved: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

highlights.title: Harris Holt’s precise yardage and the ‘can’t lose it’ second shot
highlights.description: Standing 102 yards from the 8th green (per Harris Holt’s measurement), the narrator explains the contouring that ensures a second shot will always finish in a visible area: “the ball’s going to be in here somewhere… can be seen.” This highlights a design philosophy of fairness despite the hole’s dramatic setting.
characters_involved: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

highlights.title: Louie Ellis’s heartfelt sign‑off to Pete Dye
highlights.description: High above #8, after extensive filming, Louie takes the mic and speaks directly to Pete: he says it was nice doing the job, jokes that with Harris Holt, James D., and himself “how in the hell can you go wrong,” and notes that Jim “worked the hell out of me today.” The narrator adds that Louie, with a bad hip, walked the ground for Pete, and that he and his wife Nancy send their regards.
characters_involved: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

highlights.title: Integrating mining history into the course narrative
highlights.description: Near the mine portal and coal seam, the narrator explains that the Pittsburgh seam is “the most single valuable mineral deposit in the world,” running from Pittsburgh to near Clarksburg. He contrasts deep mining (the portal) with strip mining (the high wall) and says this will give “another dimension to coal mining to this whole golf course,” explicitly tying local industrial history into the course’s identity.
characters_involved: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

highlights.title: Showcasing the ‘big boy’ tees and stonework
highlights.description: The camera lingers on massive stacked boulder walls supporting the upper tees, which the narrator calls the “big boy tees.” He wants a close‑up so others can appreciate the work and ingenuity that went into building them, underscoring the physical and aesthetic investment in the tee complexes.
characters_involved: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

highlights.title: Strategic explanation of Hole #2 over Simpson Creek
highlights.description: From an elevated view over #2, the narrator explains that players must drive over Simpson Creek to a landing spot and can “eat off as much as you want” of the creek/dogleg, with risk‑reward implications for the second shot. He praises #2 as a beautiful dogleg left and notes that every hole is well designed, giving Pete’s routing and strategy clear credit.
characters_involved: Unidentified course narrator (likely a LaRosa family member or senior project figure)

quotes.text: Pete, it was nice doing this job and I hope we did what you wanted. With Harris Holt here and James D. and Louie Ellis, how in the hell can you go wrong? See you later, Pete. God bless you.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Louie’s on‑camera sign‑off from high above the 8th hole, addressing Pete Dye directly after a long day of filming and walking the construction site.

quotes.context: As James D. LaRosa drives away with his family and dogs in their vehicle (“dogmobile”), the narrator affectionately comments on Jim’s demanding leadership on site.

quotes.context: Discussing the 8th hole’s fairway, massive bunker, and an open drainage ditch along the coal seam, while asking Pete to confirm where to terminate the ditch.

If you don’t want to eat off too much, then you have more club that you would have to use to get to the green.

Pete_Dye_Golf_Club_Spring_1989.title: Pete Dye Golf Club – Promotional & Design Overview Film (c. late 1980s)
Pete_Dye_Golf_Club_Spring_1989.content_type: Promotional course overview and design explainer video
Pete_Dye_Golf_Club_Spring_1989.summary: This video is a professionally produced promotional and design-overview film for the Pete Dye Golf Club and the planned Burning Embers Resort in Clarksburg, West Virginia. It combines narrated scenic footage of the nearly finished course, archival interview material with architect Pete Dye, voiceover statements from developer James D. LaRosa, and detailed map-based explanations of the strategy and variation of all 18 holes. The film emphasizes the drama of the reclaimed coal-mining landscape, the decade-long collaboration between LaRosa and Dye, and West Virginia’s potential as a resort destination. The latter half is a hole‑by‑hole strategic tour using routing maps and descriptive narration.

characters.name: Pete Dye
characters.role: Golf course architect and on‑camera interview subject
characters.description: Appears repeatedly in circular inset interview footage wearing a light bucket hat, glasses, and a light sweater or vest, holding a microphone while standing outdoors on the course with others. He speaks at length about the property’s drama, design strategy, and what makes great golf courses.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.role: Developer / founder, voiceover subject, inset portrait ID
characters.description: Identified on-screen by a circular inset portrait labeled “James D. LaRosa.” His words are heard in voiceover discussing his personal connection to the project, business rationale, and belief in West Virginia’s resort potential. He does not appear speaking live on camera in this excerpt, but his portrait is used over scenic B‑roll.

characters.name: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)
characters.description: Provides polished, broadcast-quality narration that introduces Clarksburg, Pete Dye, the Burning Embers Resort concept, and then walks through the strategy and yardages of all 18 holes. Voice is distinct from Pete Dye and James D. LaRosa and never appears on camera.

characters.name: Unidentified host / MC
characters.description: Appears beside Pete Dye in the circular inset interview shots as a balding man in a light shirt, sometimes holding or sharing the microphone. He does not have clear, attributable lines in the transcript but is visually present as the interviewer or event host.

characters.name: Unidentified associate in blue cap
characters.description: Stands next to Pete Dye in several inset shots wearing a bright blue cap and golf attire. Likely a club official, local dignitary, or project associate present during the interview/ceremony. No distinct dialogue is captured in the transcript.

chapters.title: Opening: Land, Vision, and Dramatic Setting
chapters.summary: The film opens with color bars and black, then a title card introducing the Pete Dye Golf Club, founder James D. LaRosa, designer Pete Dye, and the Burning Embers Resort in Clarksburg, West Virginia. A professional narrator describes Clarksburg and the 2,000-acre property as the perfect canvas for Pete Dye’s creativity. Aerial shots and scenic views of the valley, ponds, and early course shaping are intercut with an inset portrait of James D. LaRosa, who speaks in voiceover about his personal pride in building the project in his hometown and his belief in West Virginia’s potential for resort development. On-screen text quotes Pete Dye praising the property as the most dramatic he has ever seen, establishing the land’s uniqueness and the decade of labor invested by developer and designer.
characters_present: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

chapters.title: Pete Dye on Great Courses and the West Virginia Topography
chapters.summary: Scenic shots of finished and in-progress holes, rivers, rockwork, and the reclaimed mining landscape play under extended commentary from Pete Dye. In circular inset interview footage, Dye, wearing his signature bucket hat, speaks at a microphone with a small group beside him. He explains that great golf courses often have dramatic natural features like oceans or mountains and argues that the topography of this part of West Virginia is equally irreplaceable. He contrasts it with flat regions like Illinois, Ohio, deserts, or Florida where topography must be manufactured. Dye emphasizes that at Pete Dye Golf Club every hole has a distinctive look, strong strategic variation (short, long, different), and a powerful surrounding atmosphere. He notes the coal mine background on some holes and the use of native rock, stressing that the course is now receiving the “small touches” that make it feel truly finished, unlike many rushed developments.
characters_present: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

chapters.title: Finishing Touches, Number 4, and the Dramatic Arrival Experience
chapters.summary: Continuing in interview mode over sweeping course shots, Dye elaborates on what a “finished” golf course means to him. He criticizes projects that are opened for play after only six months of construction, arguing they are playable but not finished. He praises the ongoing rock work and detailing on hole 4, which he says has always been a great hole with a mountain backdrop but is only now visually reading as finished. He then describes routing the 18th hole back toward the clubhouse and how building the entrance road has created a powerful sense of atmosphere. Drawing a comparison to Augusta National’s Magnolia Drive, he claims the drive into Pete Dye Golf Club—from Smith Chapel, turning back along the entrance road—feels equally or even more impressive, making visitors feel they are “going to something.” He concludes that what has been created in the middle of West Virginia is “unheard of,” likening its appeal to, and even surpassing, established destinations like White Sulphur Springs, while being more accessible.
characters_present: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

chapters.title: Transition to Technical Segment: Title and Hole-By-Hole Strategy Intro
chapters.summary: After Dye’s atmospheric comparison, the film introduces a more technical section. A graphic title card appears: “Strategies & Variations of the 18 Holes” with the Pete Dye Golf Club emblem. The narrator frames the upcoming segment as a close-up look at the strategy and variation of all 18 holes designed by Pete Dye. This marks a shift from broad promotional storytelling and interview material to a structured, instructional walkthrough of the course layout.
characters_present: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

chapters.title: Front Nine Strategy: Holes 1–9
chapters.summary:
Using a detailed routing map and a pointer, the narrator walks through the front nine. For each hole, the camera focuses on the drawn fairways, greens, water features, and Simpson Creek, while the narrator gives yardages, pars, and strategic advice:
- Hole 1 (397-yard par 4, dogleg left): Introduced as a preview of the course’s excitement, challenge, and natural beauty.
- Hole 2 (439-yard par 4, dogleg left): Tee shot crosses Simpson Creek; strategy is to stay left to open the second shot (around a six-iron) into the green.
- Hole 3 (367-yard par 4, slight dogleg right): Typical play is three-wood and eight-iron to a small green; grass mounds in front punish short approaches.
- Hole 4 (215-yard par 3 over a rock-lined lake): A visually beautiful, strategic par 3 where the front is open, allowing players to run the ball in.
- Hole 5 (628-yard par 5, dogleg right): Described as a “monster” hole; players can cut the corner over Simpson Creek on the third shot to save about 30 yards if they dare.
- Hole 6 (341-yard par 4, straightaway): The shortest par 4, but a very tight driving hole demanding an accurate tee shot to the right of a walled stream bed; a coal mine portal is visible behind the green, and players must pass through a real coal mine for 140 feet to reach the 7th tee.
- Hole 7 (155-yard par 3): Played from an elevated tee above a coal mine portal; surrounding mounding creates an unusual yet fair hole.
- Hole 8 (504-yard par 5, dogleg left): The only hole where the green is not visible from the tee; a hidden 1.5-acre bunker awaits sliced second shots.
- Hole 9 (465-yard par 4, dogleg right): Called “awesome,” requiring a 180-yard carry over Simpson Creek from an elevated tee and then at least a two-iron to a three-tiered green protected by bunkers.
The visuals remain focused on the map, with occasional cutaways to course features, while the narration is purely strategic and descriptive.
characters_present: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

chapters.title: Back Nine Strategy Part 1: Holes 10–13
chapters.summary:
The map-based walkthrough continues for the early back nine, with the narrator describing each hole’s character and strategy while the pointer traces the routing:
- Hole 10 (450-yard par 4, dogleg right): A spectacular, ominous-looking hole where a string of coal mine cars turns the hole off the drive and a 25-foot vertical waterfall guards the green’s right side. Despite its appearance, it is described as fair, with a bailout area left of the green.
- Hole 11 (570-yard par 5, slight dogleg left): Extremely wide, offering ample room and recovery opportunities for errant shots.
- Hole 12 (370-yard par 4, straightaway): Strategy is to avoid going too far right; a large camelback-shaped mound can leave players blind to the green, making it a potential birdie or bogey hole.
- Hole 13 (185-yard par 3): The view is called breathtaking, “Mother nature at her greatest,” and the hole is compared to the famous Redan hole in Scotland. It slopes front-to-back and right-to-left, with a large bunker behind the green.
The visuals remain on the routing map, occasionally zooming in on individual holes as the narrator emphasizes both natural beauty and strategic nuance.
characters_present: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

chapters.title: Back Nine Strategy Part 2: Holes 14–16
chapters.summary:
The narrator continues the hole-by-hole description for the mid-to-late back nine, again using the course map and pointer:
- Hole 14 (440-yard par 4, dogleg right): Tees are elevated directly above the landing area, and the entire hole is framed by a stone wall, evoking “shades of Scotland.” It is described as a potential birdie hole.
- Hole 15 (505-yard par 5, slight dogleg right): From the tee, players see a magnificent view with a 10-acre lake bordering the right side. The second shot will “flirt with the water,” emphasizing risk–reward along the lake.
- Hole 16 (250-yard downhill par 3, “the incomparable 16th”): A long downhill par 3 where the tee shot carries over an expansive fairway to a green plateaued on the right. A bailout area short and left allows for an easier pitch if players choose safety over aggression.
The map zooms in on these holes, particularly highlighting the stone wall framing 14, the large lake on 15, and the dramatic downhill nature of 16, reinforcing the course’s visual drama and strategic variety.
characters_present: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

chapters.title: Closing Holes and Tournament Ambition: Holes 17–18 and Final Pitch
chapters.summary:
The film concludes with descriptions of the final two holes and a summative promotional message. Over continued map imagery and scenic shots, the narrator explains:
- Hole 17 (430-yard par 4): A slightly uphill drive leads to potentially downhill lies due to rolling terrain. The green is large enough to hold approach shots but is well bunkered.
- Hole 18 (450-yard par 4, “the magnificent 18th”): From an elevated tee, players drive across Simpson Creek, which borders the left side of the fairway. The second shot comes from an ample landing area, but players must favor the left side to have an open approach to the green. The right side is a contoured hillside designed to accommodate up to 30,000 spectators, explicitly evoking dreams of hosting major tournaments.
The narrator closes by stating that the vision of James LaRosa and the genius of Pete Dye have combined to create a unique opportunity in central West Virginia, and thanks viewers for sharing in the excitement. The final tone is aspirational, positioning the club as both a world-class golf experience and a potential major championship venue.
characters_present: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

highlights.title: Pete Dye’s Praise for the Property’s Drama
highlights.description: Over sweeping aerial views of the valley and course corridors, on-screen text and audio present Pete Dye’s emphatic praise that he has never seen anything more dramatic than this piece of property, underscoring the uniqueness of the West Virginia site.

highlights.title: Coal Mine Integration and Tunnel Between Holes 6 and 7
highlights.description: The narrator explains that after playing the tight par-4 6th hole, with a coal mine portal visible behind the green, players must pass through a real coal mine for 140 feet to reach the 7th tee, visually tying the course to its mining heritage.
