highlights.title: Dye’s Concept of a ‘Finished’ Golf Course
highlights.description: In interview footage, Pete Dye contrasts rushed developments with his long-term approach, explaining that many courses open for play before they are truly finished. He praises the ongoing rock work and detailing on hole 4 and the course as a whole, emphasizing the importance of small touches that give each hole individual character.

highlights.title: Comparison to Augusta National’s Magnolia Drive
highlights.description: Dye compares the entrance drive to Pete Dye Golf Club—starting at Smith Chapel and winding back to the clubhouse—to Augusta National’s Magnolia Drive, asserting that the drive into this course is equally, if not more, impressive and creates a powerful sense of going “to something.”

highlights.title: Hole 10’s Coal Cars and Waterfall
highlights.description: The narrator describes the 10th hole as a spectacular 450-yard par 4 where a string of coal mine cars turns the hole off the drive and a 25-foot vertical waterfall protects the green, blending industrial heritage with dramatic golf design.
characters_involved: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

highlights.title: Spectator Hill on the 18th for Major Tournaments
highlights.description: In describing the 18th hole, the narrator notes that the right side of the fairway is a contoured hillside capable of holding up to 30,000 spectators, explicitly linking the design to ambitions of hosting major tournaments in central West Virginia.
characters_involved: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)

quotes.text: I don't think I've ever seen anything more dramatic than this piece of property. I don't know how else you can say it. There isn't anything more dramatic than this.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Displayed as an on-screen quote over aerial footage and echoed in narration to emphasize the uniqueness of the West Virginia site.

quotes.text: All great golfers, you know, what makes great golf courses usually have the Pacific Ocean on one side or the Atlantic Ocean on the other side or a mountain or something that it's hard to reproduce. Well, the general topography right through here, you know, of this part of the country, you can't reproduce it.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Spoken in on-site interview footage while scenic shots of the course and surrounding hills play, explaining why this inland property can stand alongside famous seaside courses.

quotes.text: So when you play this golf course or a golf course like this, I mean, it's different. You feel like you're a million miles away from any given place and you can't look in any direction and not have a great vista.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Part of Dye’s extended commentary on the course’s atmosphere and vistas, over shots of fairways, rivers, and hills.

quotes.text: Now every hole here has a distinctive look to it and a great background. So then if we can come up with a variation of the holes and make the strategy as good as any golf course in the country and you have a strategy along with what's here naturally, it's the hillside, the mountainside, and work it into it.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Explaining his design philosophy for Pete Dye Golf Club, emphasizing both strategic variety and integration with the natural terrain.

quotes.text: When you have a hilly golf course, there's a lot of real hilly golf courses that are not good strategy golf holes. But out here, I assure you that every golf hole we have out here, we have a terrific variation of strategy — short, long, different.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Defending the strategic quality of the course despite its hilly terrain, over visuals of contoured fairways and valleys.

quotes.text: Most golf courses, you come into an area like this, it's hard to get it done to where it really looks like a finished product. And now we're getting this getting closer and closer where it looks like every hole has been finished.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Discussing the long-term effort and detailing required to make the course feel truly finished, rather than merely playable.

quotes.text: A lot of times when the golf course is open for play or a developer jumps in and you've got six months to build a golf course, you have to get it open the day after tomorrow. It's not really — it's open for play, but it's not finished.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Critiquing rushed golf developments while contrasting them with the decade-long build at Pete Dye Golf Club.

quotes.text: Well, this golf course, in my opinion now, is getting all the small touches that you need to give it an individual character.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Praising the current stage of refinement at Pete Dye Golf Club, particularly the detailing that gives each hole its own identity.

quotes.text: For example, the work they've done on number four. Well, four has been sitting there as a great golf hole for almost four years. And now that we're starting to make it look more like a finished hole, everybody starts to see it.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Using hole 4 as a case study in how visual finishing work reveals the quality of an already-strong design.

quotes.text: You know, a golf course is like Augusta National. It's a great golf course and it has a certain atmosphere. But just going in Magnolia Drive, it's impressive. And so it doesn't have anything to do with strategy, golf course, or anything, but it's just a little short drive. Well, I assure you that the drive coming into this golf course is equally, if not more so, impressive.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Comparing the entrance experience at Pete Dye Golf Club to Augusta National’s Magnolia Drive, emphasizing the importance of arrival atmosphere.

quotes.text: So you start right out at the Smith Chapel and make that turn, and then when you start to get back that road, you feel the minute you make that turn to go back there that you're going to some place, you're going to something.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Describing the emotional impact of the entrance road and how it sets expectations for the course experience.

quotes.text: You created something here in the middle of West Virginia that is unheard of.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Summarizing the uniqueness and ambition of the project in a region not typically associated with world-class golf.

quotes.text: The Pete Dye Golf Club in Clarksburg, West Virginia, is the first phase of the planned Burning Embers Resort and Conference Center. It is the result of a visionary developer, James La Rosa, who acquired the land and sought out the famous architect.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)
quotes.context: Opening narration over title cards and early course imagery, introducing the project’s scope and crediting the developer.

quotes.text: For the planned Burning Embers Resort project, it is significant to me personally to have this project located in my home state and hometown. But as a businessman, the project represents more than personal satisfaction.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Voiceover from LaRosa, accompanied by his inset portrait over scenic course shots, expressing both personal pride and business perspective.

quotes.text: I believe in West Virginia's potential for recreational and resort development. Our geographical location in proximity to major metropolitan areas, our existing modern highway and air travel transportation system, our natural and unspoiled scenic beauty are desirable features for those looking for a special place to relax and gather for business and recreational reasons.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: LaRosa articulates the strategic case for the Burning Embers Resort and Pete Dye Golf Club as part of a broader vision for West Virginia tourism and recreation.

quotes.text: Ten years of labor and commitment by the developer and designer have been invested in this project.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)
quotes.context: Narration over aerial and scenic shots, emphasizing the long timeline and partnership between LaRosa and Dye.

A very tight driving hole demanding a long accurate tee shot to the right of the walled stream bed which separates the fairway from the rough. This creates an interesting second shot. A coal mine portal is visible behind the green. Upon finishing this hole, the player must pass through a real coal mine for 140 feet to get to the seventh tee.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)
quotes.context: Part of the hole-by-hole strategic narration, highlighting the integration of the site’s coal mining heritage into the playing experience.

quotes.text: Number ten is a spectacular hole. It is a 450-yard par four dogleg right. A string of coal mine cars turns the hole off the drive, and a 25-foot vertical waterfall protects the green on the right. Number ten is an ominous-looking hole, but is very fair with a bailout area to the left of the green.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)
quotes.context: Describing the dramatic visual and strategic elements of the 10th hole during the back-nine overview.

quotes.text: Number eighteen, the magnificent 18th. Beautiful, breathtaking. A 450-yard par four from an elevated tee across Simpson Creek which borders the left side of the fairway. The player's second shot will be hit from an ample landing area but he will need to be on the left side to be open to the green. The right side of the fairway is a contoured hillside allowing up to 30,000 spectators. Provision for 30,000 spectators evokes dreams of major tournaments.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)
quotes.context: Final hole description, explicitly linking the design of the 18th to aspirations of hosting major tournaments.

quotes.text: The vision of James La Rosa and genius of Pete Dye have combined to create a unique opportunity in central West Virginia. Thanks for letting us share this excitement with you.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified professional narrator (likely Harris Holt or similar)
quotes.context: Closing statement of the film, summarizing the partnership and inviting viewers to share in the project’s excitement.

Collaboration between visionary developer (James D. LaRosa) and legendary architect (Pete Dye)
Importance of natural topography and atmosphere in golf course greatness
Long-term perseverance and commitment (ten years of development)
Regional pride and economic development in West Virginia

Pete_Dye_Golf_Course_10-16-90_thru_6-14-.title: Pete Dye Golf Club – Construction & Course Tour, Oct 1990–May 1991
Pete_Dye_Golf_Course_10-16-90_thru_6-14-.content_type: construction footage with on‑course commentary and informal interviews
Pete_Dye_Golf_Course_10-16-90_thru_6-14-.summary: This tape is a long-form, home‑movie style construction chronicle of the Pete Dye Golf Club during 1990–1991. It combines extensive on‑course narration by Louie Ellis and Harris Holt with visual documentation of earthmoving, green and bunker construction, bridge and tunnel installation, sod work, drainage fixes, and early turf grow‑in. There are also informal interviews and cameos with workers, dogs, and at least one visiting friend (Jim Fazio). The footage moves hole‑by‑hole (especially 1–9), repeatedly along Simpson Creek, and around major features like the #4 lake and the signature “River Kwai” bridge. It captures both the technical side of building a Pete Dye course and the personal, family‑style atmosphere around the LaRosa project.

characters.name: Louie Ellis
characters.role: On‑site cameraman, narrator, and informal interviewer
characters.description: Appears at the very start in a red blazer as “FILM DIRECTOR & PRODUCER LOUIS F. ELLIS,” then mostly behind the camera. His voice introduces the tape, dates the footage, and frequently hands the mic to others. He jokes about spending a seventh of his life on the course and signs off as the volunteer documentarian.

characters.name: Harris Holt
characters.description: Frequently identified by name (“Mr. Harris Holt is at the mic”). He provides polished, hole‑by‑hole descriptions of fairways, greens, bunkers, and construction details, often directing Louie where to point the camera. He is seen on camera in a white golf shirt with glasses, holding a microphone while describing views along Simpson Creek and the tees of #2 and #5.

characters.name: Gary Grandstaff
characters.description: Named multiple times (“Gary Grandstaff”) and appears on‑camera in work clothes. He explains green construction profiles (sand/peat mix, gravel, drain tile), erosion netting, sod logistics, and drainage troubleshooting on greens #6 and #7. He also narrates a panoramic pan from the second landing area of #5, pointing out stone walls, bunkers, and his dog Bogart.

characters.name: Keith “Sparky” Sparkman
characters.role: Pete Dye’s greens shaper and contour specialist
characters.description: Referred to as “Sparky” and “Keith Sparkman,” seen working a small Smithco machine around greens (#4, #6, #7, #3). Others describe him as Pete Dye’s trusted greens man who travels from course to course, putting final contour on greens and bunker faces. Rumored in the narration to have an MD degree.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.role: Founder / owner, on‑camera host and explainer
characters.description: Not named explicitly in every shot, but appears as an older, well‑dressed man in some interview segments and as the person being praised by others. He is referenced in third person (“Mr. LaRosa requested you to come with me,” “Jim here I have to say… he’s been very successful… come up the hard way through the Depression”). He participates in on‑site commentary and is the “head honcho” Harris greets.

characters.name: Jimmy LaRosa
characters.description: Appears in later 1991 segments (e.g., April 27 and May 25) as a middle‑aged man in a white golf shirt and glasses, standing with Monsignor O’Reilly and later with Gary. He explains the construction of the 3rd green, bunker strategy, and pin positions with Keith Sparkman, and later discusses drainage problems and fixes on #7 green.

characters.name: Monsignor O’Reilly
characters.description: Older man in clerical or casual attire seen with Jimmy LaRosa on April 27, 1991 at the 3rd hole. He jokes about needing 2,000 balls and “plunk, plunk, plunk into the holy waters,” and critiques the difficulty of certain pin positions and lake carries.

characters.name: Jim Fazio
characters.role: Visiting friend from San Diego, on‑camera guest
characters.description: Identified by name (“I’m standing here with a good friend of mine, Jim Fazio from San Diego, he’s originally from Clarksburg”). Middle‑aged man in casual clothes. He praises the course’s uniqueness and predicts national exposure and strong business, calling it “the most beautiful golf course… in the United States.”

characters.name: Unidentified bulldozer and loader operators
characters.role: Equipment operators shaping fairways, greens, and bunkers
characters.description: Multiple shirtless or T‑shirted men operating CASE dozers, D3 Caterpillars, front‑end loaders, and skid‑steers. They push and level sand mix on greens, shape bunkers, and grade fairways near Simpson Creek and the #4 lake.

characters.name: Unidentified labor crew (Arnold Chewing, Mike Renzelli, etc.)
characters.role: Hand‑finishing crew around greens and bunkers
characters.description: Named by Gary: “the little one is Arnold Chewing… the strong, muscular fellow is Mike Renzelli.” They appear as small figures raking, probing sand depth, and blending edges by hand around greens #5, #6, #7 and bunkers. They ensure uniform sand depth and smooth transitions between sand and topsoil.

characters.name: Bogart, Rusty, Prince, Bogey (dogs)
characters.description: Several dogs appear repeatedly: a Dalmatian (Bogart/Bogey), a brown dog Rusty, and an older dog Prince. Gary introduces them as his “assistants,” explaining he brings them daily and they know how to stay out of the way of machines. They are often seen near bunkers, fairways, and bridge work.

chapters.title: Intro & October 16, 1990 – First Look at Holes 1–2–5–7–9
chapters.summary: Louie Ellis opens the tape in a red blazer as “Film Director & Producer,” then cuts to October 16, 1990 on‑course footage. He and Harris Holt document the rapid grow‑in of the #1 fairway and green, the landing area of #2 along Simpson Creek, and early shaping and seeding on #5, #7, and #9. They highlight color differences between fairway, rough, and fringes, praise how soft the turf already feels, and repeatedly reference Simpson Creek and the future #4 lake. Harris describes #5 as a dogleg right, the only true par‑5, with three distinct levels and unreachable in two. They also show deer tracks, early bunker forms, and the dramatic drop from #9 tee down to Simpson Creek.

chapters.title: October 17, 1990 – Building #1 Tee & #3 Green, #4 Green Contours
chapters.summary: On October 17, 1990, the camera returns to #1 from the #5 tee, showing four tee decks under construction and workers installing the main #1 tee. Louie explains the tee mix (80% sand, 20% peat) sourced from a glacial deposit farm Jim LaRosa bought near Worthington, noting they wash and blend the sand on site to USGA specs. He films #3 green under construction: a CASE dozer operated by a “Pete Dye man” spreads the sand/peat mix while coal trucks dump 25‑ton loads. At #4 green on #4 lake, Gary Grandstaff and “Sparky” (Keith Sparkman) are seen shaping contours and bunker faces with a Smithco machine and a White farm tractor. Louie explains Sparky’s role as Pete Dye’s trusted contour specialist, rumored to be an MD, and shows how he smooths and redistributes sand to create subtle breaks and pin areas.

chapters.title: October 29–30, 1990 – Bridges at #10 and #2, Mine Structures & Simpson Creek
chapters.summary: Late October footage focuses on installing two major steel bridges over Simpson Creek at #10 and #2. Louie and Harris film cranes backing bridge sections into place, workers bolting them down using embedded plates, and discuss load capacity (21‑ton bridge, strong enough to hold people packed side‑by‑side). They pan to an old coal tipple and mine cars, explaining how coal was tilted and dumped into rail cars, tying the course to its mining heritage. Harris points out distant power plant smokestacks used as aiming targets off #5 tee. They also show a covered bridge concept to protect golfers from rain, and note that most materials and sand are sourced from West Virginia. Dogs wander through the scenes, and Louie jokes the footage is “going to NBC.”

chapters.title: November 3, 1990 – Sod on #9, Mix on #6, Erosion Netting & Drainage
chapters.summary: On a warm “Indian summer” November 3, Harris and Gary document sod installation on #9 green’s steep bunker faces, where crews use ladders to lay the first rows. Gary points out Bogart the dog “thinking he’s in charge,” and identifies Keith Sparkman on the green, whose contouring they’ve been working on for days. They show lime being spread on #9 fairway and explain that hand‑liming is only for wet spots. Over at #6 green, Gary narrates as Mike (the dozer operator) probes sand depth to ensure uniform 14" of mix over 6" of gravel and drain tile. They highlight first use of erosion netting on steep banks and around a “goldfish pond” bunker, noting it cuts stabilization costs by about 60%. Gary describes cutting drainage trenches in bunkers and mowing newly seeded fairway for the first time.

chapters.title: April 27, 1991 – Designing & Explaining the 3rd Green with Monsignor O’Reilly & Keith Sparkman
chapters.summary: By April 27, 1991, Jimmy LaRosa stands in the fairway of #3 with club chaplain Monsignor O’Reilly, explaining the under‑construction 3rd green. They discuss its short par‑4 strategy, deep front bunker, and a ridge between upper and lower bunkers that forces errant shots to roll all the way down into sand. Monsignor jokes he’ll need 2,000 balls and that shots will go “plunk, plunk, plunk into the holy waters” of the man‑made lake Pete Dye envisioned on his first walk. Keith Sparkman walks them through three pinning areas—front, left, and a tough back peninsula guarded by a bunker—explaining how slopes will feed or repel shots. They clarify that the first 30 feet of what looks like green is actually approach built to green specs so it never hardens under traffic. Later, Jimmy and Keith show a D3 dozer shaping the bank between bunker and green, discuss drainage lines, and estimate when the hole will be playable (mid‑June for first putts, full maturity next spring).

chapters.title: May 1991 – #7 Green Drainage Fix, #6 & #7 Technical Profiles, Stone Wall & Historic House
chapters.summary: In May 1991, Gary and Jimmy revisit #7 green, where earlier sprinkler tests showed standing water on the rear third. Gary explains the USGA‑style profile: 18" to native clay, drain tile 6" below that, 6" gravel, then 14" sand mix. They suspected a crushed or separated tile, dug a hole, and found no tile issue; instead, a compacted sand layer was restricting percolation. Using a subsoiler every 24", they broke up the layer and restored drainage. Gary notes sprinklers now run for hours with no puddling. They also show a big track hoe installing additional drain tile to set up more of Keith Sparkman’s contouring. On #7 tee, Jimmy describes a stone wall built from the foundation of an 1842 Georgian mansion they tore down, regretting its loss but reusing its stone. He explains the back tee above the mine portal will be ~200 yards, reserved for very good players. Dogs Bogey, Rusty, and Prince are introduced as Gary’s daily companions. Gary then narrates a pan from the second landing area of #5, pointing out the stone wall on #7 tee, Simpson Creek, the green‑side bunkering on #5, erosion netting, and crew members (Mike Renzelli, Arnold Chewing, Herb Hasselbacher, Mark Urso, Clarence Eagle, Danny Harold, Roy Randolph) working around the green.

chapters.title: May 25, 1991 – #6 & #7 Greens, Subsoiling, and On‑Camera Interviews (Gary & Jim Fazio)
chapters.summary: On May 25, 1991, Gary stands on #6 green explaining that it’s the eighth green they’ve put mix on that year. Mike is probing sand depth and finishing grading with a dozer; Sparky will follow with his Smithco to blend edges. Gary details the layer system again and notes they’re out of sand, making #6 a critical test of remaining stock. He describes using coal trucks to haul 20‑ton loads of mix and how they discovered the compacted sand issue on #7 by backfilling a test hole and re‑running water. After subsoiling every 24", drainage worked fine. A big track hoe arrives to install more drain tile for Keith’s contouring. Louie then turns the mic to Gary, who directs a pan across #5 and #6: remnants of topsoil piles, a sprinkler running on #6, the stone wall on #7 tee, topsoil stockpiles, #5’s second landing area, Bogart the dog, a worker picking rocks, Simpson Creek, and the green‑side and forward bunkers on #5 with new stone wall defining the right edge. Later, Jimmy appears with his friend Jim Fazio from San Diego (originally from Clarksburg). Fazio praises the hospitality, calls Louie an essential part of it, and predicts the course will be “the most beautiful golf course… in the United States,” with unique features that will bring national exposure and strong word‑of‑mouth business. Louie jokes he’s spent one‑seventh of his life on the course and has enjoyed every bit of it.

chapters.title: Late May 1991 – #7 Green Drainage Recap & Gary’s Technical Deep Dive
chapters.summary: Gary returns to #7 green to recap the drainage issue and solution in more detail. He stands with Arnold Chewing and Mike Renzelli blending edges by hand, checking sand depth to the gravel layer to ensure uniform percolation. He recounts how they suspected a crushed tile, dug into the green, found no tile problem, then discovered a compacted sand layer. After subsoiling the entire green profile every 24", water percolated fine. He notes sprinklers ran for hours the previous day with no puddling, and they’re now back on schedule. A big track hoe arrives on the hill to install additional drain tile to support more of Keith Sparkman’s finished contouring. Jimmy and Gary then appear together with Harris Holt and Louie, with Harris introduced on camera. Harris asks Gary to spell his last name (“Grandstaff”), and Gary directs Louie to pan left across topsoil piles, sprinklers on #6, the stone wall on #7 tee, #5’s second landing area, Bogart, a worker picking rocks, Simpson Creek, and the bunkering and stone wall on #5 green. This segment cements Gary as the technical voice of the course’s construction.

chapters.title: Closing Segment – Harris’s Practice Shots on #5 & Louie’s Sign‑Off
chapters.summary: In a lighter closing sequence, Harris stands in the landing area of #5 with a club and hits practice shots toward the under‑construction green site. He narrates his own misses and adjustments, joking about excuses and how well the ball sits up on the new turf for such a young course. Louie and Gary banter about where the ball went (“down the drain pipe into the depression”) and tease a camera‑shy worker who runs from the lens. Harris points out Roy Randolph waving near the green and notes how the fairway turf already plays well. The tape ends with Harris describing the #5 landing area and green construction one more time, and Louie fading out with a sign‑off as “your film director and producer,” promising to see viewers on the next tape.

highlights.title: Louie’s self‑introduction as volunteer filmmaker
highlights.description: In an interior shot, Louie appears in a bright red blazer beside a director’s chair labeled “FILM DIRECTOR & PRODUCER LOUIS F. ELLIS,” then immediately cuts to on‑course narration, establishing himself as the long‑term volunteer documentarian of the project.

highlights.title: First detailed explanation of USGA green construction
highlights.description: Louie films #3 green as a CASE dozer spreads an 80/20 sand‑peat mix. He explains that the sand is washed and blended on site to USGA specs, sourced from a glacial deposit Jim LaRosa bought, and that each truck carries ~25 tons. This becomes a recurring technical reference point for later greens.

highlights.title: Introducing Sparky, Pete Dye’s greens shaper
highlights.description: At #4 green, Louie and Gary show Keith “Sparky” Sparkman on a Smithco machine, describing how Pete Dye trusts him to put final contour on all his greens and bunkers. Louie repeats the rumor that Sparky has an MD degree but chose to shape golf courses instead.

highlights.title: Bridge installation over Simpson Creek at #10
highlights.description: Cranes and crews maneuver a heavy steel bridge section into place over Simpson Creek. Louie jokes with workers (“Go ahead and wave, this is going to NBC”), and Harris explains the bridge’s capacity and purpose for carts and people, while dogs wander through the scene.

highlights.title: Gary’s first use of erosion netting
highlights.description: On #6 green, Gary proudly points out banks covered with erosion netting above sod, explaining it’s their first use of the material at Pete Dye Golf Club and that it cuts stabilization costs by about 60%. He notes its success and promises more of it as they go along.

highlights.title: Monsignor O’Reilly’s “holy waters” joke
highlights.description: Standing by the man‑made lake on #3, Monsignor O’Reilly jokes that he’ll need 2,000 balls and that shots will go “plunk, plunk, plunk into the holy waters,” adding humor and personality to the design discussion.

highlights.title: Keith Sparkman’s pin‑position masterclass
highlights.description: Keith walks Jimmy and Monsignor across #3 green, explaining three pinning areas, how slopes will feed or repel shots, and how back‑right is a small, bunker‑guarded peninsula most players will avoid. It’s a rare, on‑camera design lesson from Pete Dye’s greens man.

highlights.title: Diagnosing and fixing #7 green’s drainage
highlights.description: Gary recounts how sprinklers revealed standing water on the rear third of #7 green. After suspecting a crushed tile and digging a test hole, they discovered a compacted sand layer. Using a subsoiler every 24", they restored percolation. It’s a candid look at problem‑solving mid‑construction.

highlights.title: Jim Fazio’s national‑exposure prediction
highlights.description: On #7, visiting friend Jim Fazio tells Jimmy LaRosa that Pete Dye Golf Club will be “the most beautiful golf course… in the United States,” with unique features that will bring national exposure and strong word‑of‑mouth business. He emphasizes he’s been all over the world and says it “in all sincerity.”

highlights.title: Harris’s practice shots on #5 and banter with Louie
highlights.description: Harris hits approach shots from the #5 landing area toward the not‑yet‑finished green, joking about misses and how the ball “went down the drain pipe into the depression.” Louie and Gary tease him and point out Roy Randolph waving near the green. It’s a light, human end to a technical tape.

quotes.text: And now some showing of the Peat Dye LaRosa Golf Course from 10‑16‑90 through 6‑14‑91. Thank you, and this is Louie Ellis. It is Tuesday, October the 16th, 1990.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Opening narration over the first on‑course footage, establishing the time span and Louie’s role as documentarian.

quotes.text: We’re looking at the number one fairway, which is outstanding for the very short period of time that it’s been here. You can see the difference in the greens, in the color of the green, from the fairway to the rough to the fringes of the fairway.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Describing the condition of the #1 fairway on October 16, 1990, while panning across the newly grown turf.

quotes.text: That fairway is just so soft, it just seems like it’s been here for about five years. It has taken a very short period of time for this to green up.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Continuing his assessment of the #1 fairway’s rapid establishment and playability.

quotes.text: Absolutely, Louie, the view that you have in your lens right now is the landing area of number two. You can see how the fairways have just come up so magnificently, and I remember when the bank was sodded.
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: Harris takes over narration to describe the landing area of #2 and recall earlier sod work on the banks.

quotes.text: Now, if somebody had seen that before and after, then they would really understand why it had to be sodded.
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: Explaining the dramatic visual difference sod made on steep banks along the fairway.

quotes.text: You can see the little bridge in the background that sort of looks like the bridge on the River Kwai.
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: Pointing out a distinctive small bridge over Simpson Creek near #2, using a movie reference to describe it.

quotes.text: What he does, he just contours the ground. That’s after it gets it ready for planting. When he’s finished, then the planting crew will come in to plant the grass. Now Pete Dye has a lot of confidence in this man. He just says go ahead. If Sparky says it’s alright, it’s alright with Pete.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Describing Keith “Sparky” Sparkman’s role shaping #4 green and Pete Dye’s trust in his contouring work.

quotes.text: This is going to be the most beautiful golf course, I’m sure, in the United States, because you have certain features here… the features you have here are so unique, you will get national exposure… you’ve got a winner here, and you’ll be on top of the heap.
quotes.speaker: Jim Fazio
quotes.context: On‑camera praise from visiting friend Jim Fazio, predicting national recognition for Pete Dye Golf Club.

quotes.text: Five days ago we thought we had a drainage problem, and we had water puddling on the surface of the green… We brought the subsoiler in and literally did a subsoil profile of the entire green every 24 inches, turned the water back on, and it works fine. So the only problem we really had that had us stumped for a few days was a compacted sand layer, and we’ve taken care of that problem.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Explaining how they diagnosed and fixed a drainage issue on #7 green by subsoiling the sand layer.

quotes.text: I just figured percentage‑wise, I’m a little over 70, one‑seventh of my life I’ve spent down this damn golf course… but I’ve enjoyed every bit of it.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Joking on camera with Jim Fazio and Jimmy LaRosa about how much time he’s devoted to filming the project.

quotes.text: Louie, we’re standing on the tee at number five. Simpson Creek’s out here on the right. You can see how the grass is starting to come up. If you point your camera down very, very low, you can see…
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: Orienting the viewer at #5 tee and directing Louie to capture close‑up detail of the emerging turf along Simpson Creek.

quotes.text: Monsignor here wouldn’t be any problem for him because he’s terrific in the sand. He’s just like Chi‑Chi Rodriguez. He’s got a good short game. All old timers start with a short game.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa
quotes.context: Light‑hearted comment while explaining the deep front bunker on #3 green to Monsignor O’Reilly.

quotes.text: The lake that you see in the back is man‑made. Pete saw that lake the first day he walked out here in his imagination. He thought that should be a lake.
quotes.speaker: Jimmy LaRosa
quotes.context: Explaining how Pete Dye envisioned the #3 lake from his first site visit, underscoring Dye’s design eye.

quotes.text: This is the eighth green now this year that we’ve put mix on… We’re presently out of sand this year. This is kind of our critical green since we’re finishing up here on six to see if we need any more sand or if we have a sufficient amount on here now.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Describing the status of #6 green construction and sand inventory in November 1990.

quotes.text: These guys really know what they’re doing. They set that bridge there probably in about an hour this morning. It’s just really incredible.
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: Admiring the efficiency of the crew installing the Simpson Creek bridge at #10.
