Documentary intent (multiple vantage points, date stamps, explicit narration for future viewers)

Pete_Dye_Golf_Course_10-9-90_thru_11-3-9.title: First Greens and Bridges, Birthplace and Town – Pete Dye Golf Club Archive (Oct–Nov 1990)
Pete_Dye_Golf_Course_10-9-90_thru_11-3-9.summary: This archival reel intercuts early construction of the Pete Dye Golf Club (especially the first greens and several bridges) with documentary visits to James D. LaRosa’s birthplace and family-related buildings in Glen Elk/Clarksburg. Shot between October 9 and November 3, 1990 (with some town/location shots dated late October and December), it combines on‑site technical narration about agronomy and earthmoving with personal reminiscence about LaRosa’s roots and local landmarks like the Morocco Club, the Home Hotel, and the Martin & LaRosa building. The main on‑course voice is superintendent Gary Grandstaff, while off‑course narration and camera work are by family friend Louie Ellis, with additional commentary from Harris Holt. The footage shows the first green being built and seeded, bridges and culverts being craned into place, sod going onto steep bunkers, and the sixth and ninth greens under construction, alongside street‑level tours of LaRosa’s birthplace, family home, and former social clubs.

characters.name: Gary Grandstaff
characters.description: Seen and heard extensively on the construction sites explaining green construction, sand sourcing, seeding, sod work, erosion netting, and bridge progress. Often referred to simply as “Gary” and explicitly called “the superintendent.”

characters.name: Louie Ellis
characters.description: Identifies himself in the opening title and in several asides (“This is Louie Ellis…”). Operates the camera across construction and town segments, occasionally appears on camera with a microphone, and conducts interviews and location IDs.

characters.name: Harris Holt
characters.description: Appears around the bridge installations, giving detailed explanations of how the bridge is bolted down, its weight (21 tons), and design/engineering details. Also helps narrate town/building history and prompts others to speak.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.role: Founder; subject of birthplace and family‑home segments
characters.description: Not clearly seen speaking in this reel, but repeatedly referenced (“Jim,” “James D.,” “Papa Jim”). Buildings tied to him are shown: his birthplace, the Martin & LaRosa building, the Home Hotel, and his family home with lion statues.

characters.name: Jimmy (Young Jim) LaRosa
characters.description: Referred to as “young Jim” and “Jimmy Joe” in anecdotes (e.g., “Bill Endress, Jimmy Joe’s uncle”). Not clearly visible or speaking in this specific reel, but present in the narrative as the next generation.

characters.name: Keith “Sparky” Sparkman
characters.description: Named repeatedly as the man who finished the contours on the first and ninth greens and will “come over with his Smithco” to blend edges. Seen on camera working on green and bunker faces, though not speaking.

characters.name: Mike (dozer operator)
characters.description: Identified by Gary as “Mike… the gentleman that spreads the mix on the greens as the trucks bring it in.” Seen on the dozer on the sixth green, probing for depth and doing finish grading.

characters.name: Arnold
characters.description: Mentioned by Gary as “Arnold out there in the fairway… catching some of the wet spots where we can’t get over with our tractor.” Visible in fairway with a spreader or bag, but not speaking.

characters.name: Bill Endress
characters.description: Introduced as “Jimmy Joe’s uncle… down from Barberton, Ohio… been here for the last 12 years watching it come along.” Not clearly singled out visually, but present on site.

characters.name: John & Angie Oliverio
characters.description: Named in the town segment as “John and Angie Oliverio.” They stand in a doorway and speak with Louie/Harris about the Elk Bridge building and local history.

characters.name: Louie Rhoda (Rota)
characters.role: Local character tied to Glen Elk buildings
characters.description: Spoken about in the town segments as a colorful local who “held court” at the Home Hotel and uses a nearby residence for naps and soap operas. Not clearly identified on camera here.

characters.name: Unidentified older narrator (friend of LaRosa / band fiddler)
characters.role: Storyteller about Morocco Club & Home Hotel
characters.description: Provides first‑person reminiscences about the Morocco Club, Home Hotel, and playing in a band called the Rhythm Boys; jokes about being “only the fiddler” when the place was raided. Likely a local friend of the LaRosa family, possibly Harris or another elder, but not definitively matchable to a named character.

characters.name: Bogart (dog)
characters.description: Dalmatian dog seen repeatedly near the ninth green and drainage work; Gary identifies him by name (“That’s Bogart sitting there. He thinks he’s in charge but he’s not real sure.”).

characters.name: Unidentified bridge crew & crane operators
characters.description: Multiple workers in hard hats and work clothes guiding bridge spans, bolting plates, and signaling cranes. They do not provide narration but are central to the bridge sequences.

chapters.title: Opening & First Green: Soil, Sand, and Seeding (Oct 9, 1990)
chapters.summary: The reel opens with a title card from Louie Ellis and moves immediately to October 9, 1990, where superintendent Gary Grandstaff explains the planting of the very first green at Pete Dye Golf Club. He details the use of rock phosphate and agricultural lime around the green, the layout of pink flags marking Pencross bentgrass on the green and Pen Eagle bentgrass on the fairways, and the sourcing and blending of sand from Worthington. Crews are shown raking, grooving the green for seed, and attempting to seed rough mixes while wind delays bentgrass seeding.

chapters.title: Grooving, Seeding & Wind Delay; First Bridge Work (Oct 9 & Oct 30, 1990)
chapters.summary: Gary narrates the grooving of the first green to create a seedbed and describes how a hand roller will close the grooves after seeding. He praises Keith Sparkman’s hand‑finished contours and notes that wind is too strong to spread the ultra‑light bentgrass seed, so they seed the blue/rye rough mix instead. The footage then jumps to October 30, 1990, showing a large culvert/bridge structure and crews staging equipment and a bridge span for installation over Simpson Creek, with Louie and Harris beginning to appear around the bridge work.

chapters.title: Simpson Creek Bridge at #10: Dogs, History & Heavy Lifts
chapters.summary: Louie and Harris document the installation of a major bridge over Simpson Creek at the 10th hole. Gary comments on the beautiful day and predicts finishing one bridge and moving to another. Harris explains the old coal tipple structure across the creek and narrates the delicate process of bolting the 21‑ton bridge sections to plates with half‑inch bolts. Multiple angles show cranes swinging the spans into place, guy wires taut, and workers guiding the bridge. Mr. LaRosa’s three dogs roam the site, becoming a recurring visual motif as Gary and Harris talk about the work and the stone wall. The sequence ends with a second, similar bridge at #2 being shown in place and described as a covered bridge that will protect golfers from rain and storms.

chapters.title: Ninth & Sixth Greens: Sod, Steep Bunkers, and Erosion Netting (Nov 3, 1990)
chapters.summary: On November 3, Gary narrates work on the ninth and sixth greens. At #9, steep bunker faces are being sodded using ladders because trucks can’t reach the slopes; sod is hauled by loader and laid by hand. Gary points out Bogart the Dalmatian and credits Keith Sparkman’s contouring of the green and bunkers. He notes topsoil being brought in on the right edge and lime being spread on the ninth fairway. At #6, Gary introduces Mike, who spreads the sand/peat mix and probes for depth on what is the eighth green they’ve mixed that year. He explains they’re nearly out of sand, making #6 a critical check. He describes using erosion netting above sodded banks and around a “goldfish pond” bunker to stabilize slopes and save about 60% on seeding and bank stabilization costs, and outlines plans to trench and drain that bunker floor before winter.

chapters.title: Town & Birthplace Tour: Morocco Club, Elk Bridge, Home Hotel, and Martin & LaRosa
chapters.summary: The film shifts from the course to Glen Elk/Clarksburg, documenting buildings tied to James D. LaRosa’s life. A burned or unsafe building that once housed the Morocco Club is shown; an older narrator recalls post‑war drinks there with Jimmy Gasson and the Panettas and jokes about being in a band, the Rhythm Boys, when the Home Hotel was raided for illegal whiskey. Louie and Harris film John and Angie Oliverio at a doorway as they talk about the Elk Bridge building, which Papa Jim loved and wanted preserved, and about John Oliverio being the oldest working printer in Harrison County. They show the building where James D. was born (with on‑screen text “JAMES BORN HERE”), Louie Rhoda’s nearby nap/soap‑opera residence, and the former Home Hotel with its basement slow gin fizzes and Louis Rhoda “holding court.” The camera lingers on the “Martin & LaRosa” stone panel dated 1920, tying the LaRosa name to the town’s commercial architecture.
characters_present: Unidentified older narrator (friend of LaRosa / band fiddler)

chapters.title: James A. LaRosa’s Family Home & Lions; Return to Greens and Dozers
chapters.summary: The town tour continues with the Home Hotel and then moves to James A. LaRosa’s home, described as where “all the LaRosas grew up.” The narrator notes Jim’s pride in the house, his work to keep it livable, and the lion statues out front “as if to stand guard.” This personal, emotional segment is intercut with more bulldozer footage back on the course, where Gary describes back‑blading windrows of mix onto the green and using remaining material to blend edges after topsoil is brought in. The juxtaposition ties LaRosa’s family legacy and physical home to the meticulous shaping of his dream golf course.
characters_present: Unidentified older narrator (friend of LaRosa / band fiddler)

chapters.title: Sixth Green Finish Grading & Closing Reflections
chapters.summary: The final minutes focus on Mike finishing the sixth green with the dozer. Gary explains that Mike left a windrow of mix around the outside during initial work and is now back‑blading that windrow into areas that are shy of mix, with the remainder used to blend edges once topsoil is brought in. He notes that this is the eighth green they’ve mixed that year and that they’re checking whether remaining sand is sufficient. The reel then returns to town and family imagery: the Elk Bridge building, James D.’s birthplace, and James A. LaRosa’s home with its lion statues. An older narrator shares a personal story about playing fiddle at the Home Hotel with the Rhythm Boys and nearly being taken in during a raid, and closes by affirming how dear James A. LaRosa’s home is to “young Jim.” The segment ends with a “Thank you for watching,” signaling the close of this compilation reel.
characters_present: Unidentified older narrator (friend of LaRosa / band fiddler)

highlights.title: First Green Layout and Sand Story
highlights.description: Gary stands on the bare first green on October 9, 1990, explaining the pink flags that mark the Pencross bentgrass green and Pen Eagle bentgrass fairway, and recounts how James D. LaRosa found suitable sand in Worthington, 12 miles away, which they wash on site and blend with peat and fertilizer at “15 Lake.”

highlights.title: Grooving the Green and Fighting the Wind
highlights.description: Crews hand‑rake grooves into the first green to create a seedbed. Gary explains how they’ll roll the grooves closed after seeding, then notes that high winds are preventing them from spreading the ultra‑light bentgrass seed (9 million seeds per pound), forcing them to seed only the blue/rye rough mix for now.

highlights.title: 21‑Ton Bridge Over Simpson Creek
highlights.description: Harris and Gary narrate as a 21‑ton bridge section is craned into place over Simpson Creek at #10. Harris explains the half‑inch bolts and plates that must align perfectly, while Gary marvels at how quickly the crew set the first span and predicts finishing and moving to the next bridge by day’s end.

highlights.title: Bogart the Dalmatian Supervises #9
highlights.description: On November 3, the Dalmatian Bogart sits near the ninth green as crews use ladders to sod steep bunker faces. Gary jokes that Bogart “thinks he’s in charge but he’s not real sure,” while describing how they’ll water all the new sod later that day.

highlights.title: Erosion Netting Innovation at #6
highlights.description: Gary points out newly sodded banks and areas covered with erosion netting near the sixth green and a “goldfish pond” bunker. He explains that this is their first use of erosion netting at Pete Dye Golf Club and that it cuts seeding and bank stabilization costs by about 60%.

highlights.title: Morocco Club & Rhythm Boys Raid Story
highlights.description: In front of the old Morocco Club/Home Hotel building, an older narrator recalls playing fiddle with his band, the Rhythm Boys, when the place was raided for illegal whiskey. He laughs about convincing the police he was “only the fiddler” so they’d let him go, and notes he never played there again, calling it “a lot of fun, though. A lot of memories.”
characters_involved: Unidentified older narrator (friend of LaRosa / band fiddler)

highlights.title: Martin & LaRosa Building – 1920 Legacy Stone
highlights.description: The camera zooms in on the stone panel reading “MARTIN LAROSA” and the date 1920 atop a three‑story brick building. Over this, narration explains that the Home Hotel was once a fine establishment and that the building carries the LaRosa name, linking James D.’s family to the town’s commercial history.

highlights.title: James A. LaRosa’s Home and Guardian Lions
highlights.description: A lingering series of shots shows James A. LaRosa’s large family home, with close‑ups of the lion statues flanking the front steps. The narrator notes that “this is where all the LaRosas grew up,” that Jim has worked hard to keep it livable, and that the lions stand guard “to keep anybody inside from harm.”
characters_involved: Unidentified older narrator (friend of LaRosa / band fiddler)

highlights.title: Ninth Green Sod and Steep Bunkers
highlights.description: Workers carry ladders into deep bunkers at the ninth green to lay sod on extremely steep faces. Gary explains they can’t get trucks down there, so they use a loader to ferry sod and ladders to reach the first rows without tearing anything up.

highlights.title: Sixth Green Critical Sand Check
highlights.description: On the sixth green, Gary explains that this is the eighth green they’ve mixed this year and that they’re “presently out of sand,” making #6 a critical test to see if they have enough mix. Mike probes the depth and then begins finish grading with the dozer as Gary outlines the sequence of Sparky coming in with a Smithco to blend edges.

quotes.text: It's October the 9th. It's a Tuesday. It's been overcast off and on mist today. We're going to go ahead and try and get number one green planted. It's our first green here on the golf course.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: On‑site introduction to the first green construction sequence, standing on the hillside above the unfinished green.

quotes.text: You can see the pink flags, Louie. They're for the green area, which will be planted in Pencross bentgrass that has a blue‑green color. And then outside of those, the inner circle of pink flags, will be planted in Pen Eagle bentgrass, which is what we presently have on number one fairway and as all the fairways will be planted.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Explaining the layout and turf varieties for the first green and surrounding fairway while walking and raking on the sand surface.

quotes.text: This green is a combination of not only 12 years, but since I've been involved here at the Pete Dye Golf Club, we started searching for sand a little over a year and a half ago. And James D. managed to find some down in Worthington, which is about 12 miles away.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Reflecting on the long planning horizon and crediting James D. LaRosa for sourcing suitable sand as the camera shows the shaped green cavity.

quotes.text: Well, Louie, it's a beautiful day. What else can I tell you? It's almost November, I guess. And I'm going to say here probably towards the end of the day we ought to have this one finished up and moving over to two. These guys really know what they're doing. They set that bridge there probably in about an hour this morning. Just really incredible.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Standing near the Simpson Creek bridge installation, commenting on the crew’s efficiency and the plan to move on to the next bridge.

quotes.text: That is the superintendent doing his share and more.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Louie turns the camera on Gary, who has been narrating, to show him working alongside the crew on the green, praising his hands‑on involvement.

quotes.text: Louie, what you see the guys doing out there now is we're just grooving the green for the seed bed. It lets the seed fall down in little grooves that those rakes are making. Then we'll take a hand roller after we seed, close the grooves back up, and that's preparation for our seed bed.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Describing the manual grooving process on the first green as workers rake parallel lines across the sand surface.

quotes.text: Right now we're just seeding down the rough mix, which is a combination of blue and ryegrass. The wind kind of has us at a standstill for the bentgrass. You can see the little flags blowing like crazy and we can't put it down. Bentgrass is real light. There's about 9 million seeds to the pound. It's just too windy right now.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Explaining why they are delaying bentgrass seeding on the first green due to high winds while proceeding with rough seeding.

quotes.text: This is the bridge that's being put in, crossing Simpson Creek at number 10. First half of it is up. The second half is just about underway. Louis, if you'll… well, you don't have to swing around yet, but I can see the bridge now being backed up. It's a beautiful day for picture taking. What's a beautiful day for anything? That stone wall on the other side of Simpson Creek is outstanding.
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: Standing near Simpson Creek, Harris narrates the status of the #10 bridge installation and admires the stone wall across the creek.

quotes.text: That section is 21 tons. That knowledge came to us through the courtesy of Gary Grandstaff.
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: While explaining the crane operation and counterbalancing, Harris notes the weight of the bridge section and credits Gary for the information.

quotes.text: Hi, Louie. It's November the third. I guess it's Indian summer this time of year. I don't know, but it sure as heck is nice. It's better weather than Florida is having right now. Just perfect. Probably about 75 degrees. We're getting a little sod down here on the ninth green.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Opening his November 3 update while showing crews sodding the steep bunkers around the ninth green.

quotes.text: You can see the guys carrying around ladders. The bunker faces are so steep that we have to use ladders in order to climb up and start the first few rows of sod until we can get it down far enough where they can reach and not tear anything up.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Describing the practical challenges of sodding very steep bunker faces at the ninth green.

quotes.text: Off to the right of the green or to the left of the dozer is an area that we sodded, and above the sod we used erosion netting, which is our first use of that material here at the Pete Dye Golf Club. We've really had a tremendous amount of success with it. As for cost savings, it cuts our seeding and planting and stabilization of bank areas by about 60%, so you'll be seeing more of that as we go along.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Explaining the introduction and benefits of erosion netting on banks near the sixth green and a front bunker.

quotes.text: Hello Louie. Here's what we have left of Jim's building after Lou carelessly was doing some work with a blowtorch. I don't know how old this building is, but it has fond memories for me because the old Morocco Club used to be there.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified older narrator (friend of LaRosa / band fiddler)
quotes.context: Standing in front of the damaged Morocco Club building, introducing its history and hinting at a recent fire or damage incident.

quotes.text: I used to have a little band called the Rhythm Boys, and we were over here playing dances, and at that time, you know, we did a little… I guess the places did a little illegal. Today it's legal, but then it wasn't, to sell a little whiskey, and they raided the Home Hotel. Well, that wasn't so bad, but they're going to take the band too. I had a hell of a time convincing these cops that, hell, I'm only the fiddler around here… They let me go, but that's the last time I ever played over here. A lot of fun, though. A lot of memories.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified older narrator (friend of LaRosa / band fiddler)
quotes.context: Recounting a humorous and nostalgic story about playing music at the Home Hotel when it was raided for illegal liquor.

quotes.text: Louie, this is James A. La Rosa's home. This is where all the La Rosas grew up. Jim is very proud of this. He's done a lot of work on the inside in order to keep the home livable. It's a very impressive home. The lions are out front there as if to stand guard to keep anybody inside from harm. I've been in the home when young Jim lived there. I'm sure it's very dear to Jim's heart.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified older narrator (friend of LaRosa / band fiddler)
quotes.context: Voiceover while the camera shows James A. LaRosa’s family home and its lion statues, emphasizing its emotional importance to the LaRosa family.

quotes.text: Louie, the picture you're taking now is the building where James D. was born.
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: Identifying the run‑down brick building in Glen Elk as James D. LaRosa’s birthplace during the town tour.

quotes.text: You can see up there at the top of the building, Louie, it says Martin and La Rosa, and the building was built in 1920. When the Home Hotel was in its heyday, it was a nice establishment.
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: Pointing out the “Martin & LaRosa” inscription and date on the former Home Hotel building, tying it to the LaRosa family history.

themes: Long-term perseverance in building a dream course
Technical craftsmanship in golf course construction (greens, bunkers, bridges)
Family legacy and immigrant roots (LaRosa family story)
Interplay between industrial/coal heritage and new landscape (coal tipple, smokestacks, reclaimed land)
Community and friendship (Ellis, Holt, Oliverios, Rhoda)
Innovation in agronomy and construction (custom sand mix, erosion netting)
Nostalgia for local social life (Morocco Club, Home Hotel, Rhythm Boys)
Pride in place (birthplace buildings, Martin & LaRosa block, family home)
Hands-on leadership (superintendent and owners working alongside crews)

Pete_Dye_Golf_Course_Construction_6-18-1.title: Tipple, Tracks, Lakes, and Life: Early Construction & Course Walkthrough at Pete Dye Golf Club
Pete_Dye_Golf_Course_Construction_6-18-1.content_type: Construction footage with on-site narration, informal interviews, and environmental/feature documentation
Pete_Dye_Golf_Course_Construction_6-18-1.summary: This archival reel covers a broad slice of early Pete Dye Golf Club development, centered on integrating the site’s coal-mining heritage into the course. Narrators (primarily John B.N. Gotti and James D. LaRosa) and cameraman Louie Ellis document restoration of the old coal tipple and mine tracks, shaping of fairways and greens, installation of utilities, creation of lakes and fountains, and stocking of ponds with triploid carp. The footage alternates between wide construction vistas, close-ups of heavy equipment and workers, informal family/friend cameos, and later, more polished on-camera explanations of course features and mining-themed elements like mine cars, ventilation fans, and the mine portal tee. The reel also captures the evolving No. 10 corridor (roadbed, tee, clubhouse site), the 4th and 18th holes, and the 7th mine-portal tee, while preserving the personalities of the LaRosa team, site supervisors, and Louie’s humorous presence as the unpaid documentarian.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.description: Appears multiple times explaining design decisions (coal cinder bunkers, 4th and 18th holes, mine-themed features) and speaking directly to Louie. Older Italian-American man in dress shirt and tie or casual short-sleeve shirt, often authoritative but warm.

characters.name: John B.N. Gotti
characters.description: Primary voice in many segments, often opening with “recognize as being built by J.D. La Rosa.” Appears in red cardigan with tie and sunglasses, and also in more casual shirts. Walks viewers through tipple, tracks, fairways, and clubhouse/tee siting.

characters.name: Louie Ellis
characters.description: Behind the camera for most of the reel; occasionally appears swinging a sledgehammer on the track, joking about being unpaid, or in group shots. Distinctive humorous asides (“no charge,” “I was here since 3 o’clock, Nancy”).

characters.name: Harris Holt
characters.role: On-site assistant / explainer, later professional narrator voice
characters.description: Identified by name while standing in bunkers and explaining cinder playability and fertilizer/topsoil operations. Also appears in later segments as the calm, technical voice describing seeding, Chapel Valley mix, and wildlife.

characters.name: Jimmy LaRosa
characters.role: James D.’s son and project co-manager
characters.description: Referred to as “Jim,” “Jimmy,” or “James Jay.” Appears in group introductions on the 4th fairway with PB Dye and others; also referenced when Louie jokes about never charging him.

characters.name: Max Robinson
characters.description: Named repeatedly as Pete Dye’s “eyes, ears, arms, and legs.” Appears on No. 16 and No. 11 greens with John and cousin Andrew, often quiet but acknowledged as the man who forms the holes with machinery.

characters.name: PB Dye
characters.description: Appears in the later group on the 4th fairway when James D. introduces “P.B. Dye” as having made a major contribution. Younger man in golf/construction attire.

characters.name: Pete Dye
characters.description: Not clearly visible in this reel but frequently referenced as the designer approving and changing greens, specifying Scottish bunkers, and having many top-100 courses.

characters.name: Gary Davis
characters.description: Named as the man who brought triploid carp from Pittsburgh; appears at the pond edge handling fish bags and coordinating acclimation.

characters.name: Bob Andrew
characters.description: Named as holding a cup of water to acclimate fish; appears at pond edge helping pour lake water into bags.

characters.name: Harris (Holt) – seeding narrator
characters.role: Technical explainer of seeding and fertilizer
characters.description: Describes Chapel Valley mix, topsoil depths, fertilizer “fog,” and wildlife (turkeys, ducks). Likely same Harris Holt, sometimes addressed simply as Harris.

characters.name: Unidentified construction workers (Mike Ranzelli, Jack Oswald, Jack Dempsey, Larry Reel, Herb, etc.)
characters.role: Track layers, tipple carpenters, utility crew, fertilizer crew
characters.description: Multiple workers are named in narration (Ranzelli, Oswald, Dempsey, Larry Reel, Herb) while seen at the tipple, on the roadbed, laying cable, or operating equipment. They are not individually distinguishable in all shots but are part of the documented crew.

characters.name: Nancy Ellis
characters.description: Not seen, but repeatedly addressed by Louie and James D. as proof that Louie was on-site “since 3 o’clock.”

chapters.title: Restoring the Tipple and Laying the Mine Track (No. 10 Corridor)
chapters.summary: The reel opens with John B.N. Gotti narrating as Louie films the old coal tipple and adjacent roadbed that will become a signature mining-themed corridor along the 10th hole. Workers (identified as Mike Ranzelli, Jack Oswald, Jack Dempsey and others) repair the tipple floor and lay narrow-gauge track on limestone ballast. Rusted mine cars are shown in detail, including stamped numbers used to credit miners. John explains that the cars will be filled with real coal from the property and parked on the track to separate the practice range from the 10th fairway and visually “turn” the hole. He points out where the clubhouse will stand in a clump of trees and where the rock base for the 10th tee sits on the opposite bank. Louie briefly stages himself swinging a sledgehammer on the track for laughs, and family/friends pose on the roadbed while John explains the theme and routing.
characters_present: Unidentified construction workers (Mike Ranzelli, Jack Oswald, Jack Dempsey, Larry Reel, Herb, etc.)

chapters.title: Utilities, Lakes, and No. 4 / No. 18 Construction
chapters.summary: Focus shifts to infrastructure and water features. A rural electrification crew lays three-phase cable in a trench to power the pump house for the No. 4 lake and an exhibition mine between holes 6 and 7. John identifies LaRosa Fuel’s man Larry Reel among the utility workers. On No. 4, he explains the lake’s aeration system, floating pump/fountain, and the plan to attract ducks and wildlife. Harris Holt and others describe burying electric lines to the lake and exhibition mine. On No. 18, Harris narrates topsoil spreading, fertilizer application that looks like “fog,” and seeding with a Chapel Valley mix (fescues and annual rye) to stabilize slopes. Heavy equipment (dozers, loaders, trucks) is shown moving topsoil from stockpiles to fairways, with James D. and Harris later walking viewers through the 18th fairway’s finished seedbed and adjacent 17th fairway and tees.
characters_present: Unidentified construction workers (Mike Ranzelli, Jack Oswald, Jack Dempsey, Larry Reel, Herb, etc.)

chapters.title: Touring Greens and Holes 3, 4, 11, 12, 16, and 7
chapters.summary: John and Louie conduct a walking tour of several holes under construction. On No. 4, they show the par-3 green beside the three-and-a-half-acre lake, with mounding behind and a mine ventilation fan on the hill as a visual target. On No. 3 and No. 16 (a 250-yard par 3), John introduces cousin Andrew from Brooklyn and shaper Max Robinson, praising Max as Pete Dye’s “eyes, ears, arms, and legs” and predicting he’ll be a famous designer. They emphasize that No. 16 is largely a natural hole. On No. 11 (a 570-yard par 5), John highlights the elevated, man-made green and unique bunkering, noting how Max matched man-made contours to natural mounding. On No. 12, he explains Pete’s intent to give the hole a Scottish flavor with deep bunkers reminiscent of Scotland. Max prompts John to recount Pete Dye’s global portfolio (Japan, Dominican Republic, Switzerland, France) and his dominance in top-100 course rankings. Later, they visit the 7th hole’s mine-portal tee: the tee sits above a real mine portal, with orange flags marking a smaller, pear-shaped green Pete has ordered, and new cart paths and tees (gold and blue) relocated for better alignment and cart access up to the 8th tee mound.
characters_present: Unidentified construction workers (Mike Ranzelli, Jack Oswald, Jack Dempsey, Larry Reel, Herb, etc.)

chapters.title: Group Portraits and Professional Team on the 4th Fairway
chapters.summary: The footage includes several group shots of key project figures. On a finished or nearly finished 4th fairway beside the lake, James D. introduces his son James Jay (Jimmy), PB Dye, golf professional Drew Pearson, long-time surveyor Ed Tiefman, and shop operations coordinator John Angotti. Behind them, he points out the 4th green, mounding, the lake, the mine fan, and the hill apex Pete Dye aligned behind the green. Earlier, another group (in casual shirts and polos) poses near a pond and stone wall, while John continues narrating about the tipple, roadbed, and No. 10 tee. Louie steps in front of the camera to joke about never being paid since 1978 and about filming family weddings, while others vouch that he also didn’t charge for those. These scenes humanize the project, showing the LaRosa family, friends, and professional staff proud of the emerging course.
characters_present: Unidentified construction workers (Mike Ranzelli, Jack Oswald, Jack Dempsey, Larry Reel, Herb, etc.)

chapters.title: Coal Cinder Bunkers and Experimental Materials on No. 1
chapters.summary: James D. records a dated segment (October 6, 1987) on the 1st fairway explaining an experimental use of coal cinders in bunkers. He shows two truckloads of jet-black cinders from a wet-bottom utility furnace, noting their metallic sheen and black-green contrast against turf. A roll of fabric paper in the bunker base prevents mud from contaminating the cinders. He explains that seven large bunkers on No. 1 may each require about 20 tons of cinders. Harris Holt steps into the trap to test footing and ball lie, reporting that the cinders are quite soft; James speculates that rain and gravity may compact them over time. They discuss possibly mixing sand and cinders or going all-sand if playability is acceptable. This chapter captures the club’s willingness to experiment with materials that echo the site’s coal heritage.

chapters.title: Seeding, Wildlife, and the 18th / 17th Complex
chapters.summary: Harris Holt narrates over views of the 18th fairway’s dark seedbed and adjacent lighter topsoil areas, explaining the seeding process: spring-tooth harrow, chain mat, seed, fertilizer, and rock phosphate, with no mulch needed at that time of year. He notes 5–10 inches of topsoil over good subsoil and a Chapel Valley mix of fescues and annual rye to quickly green the course and prevent erosion. The camera captures wild turkeys feeding on new grass on the 10th fairway, and Harris lists local wildlife—squirrels, wild turkey, deer, groundhog, fox, and ducks on Simpson Creek—remarking that foxes likely keep rabbits away. He points out the 18th green (recently planted), the 17th fairway and green, the 18th tees across the river, and a windmill installed as a visual target on No. 17. This section underscores the course’s emerging ecology alongside its construction.

chapters.title: Fountains, Mine Fans, and No. 4’s Finished Look
chapters.summary: Attention returns to the 4th hole. James D. and Harris demonstrate the newly installed floating fountain in the No. 4 lake, describing its three-horsepower motor and sunburst spray pattern. They explain its dual purpose: aerating water to support fish and reduce algae, and providing aesthetic drama visible from the tees. James notes that triploid carp have been added to eat algae, cattails, and shoreline vegetation. He then directs Louie to pan up to the mine ventilation fan on the hill behind the green, explaining its real function in pulling methane and bad air from coal mines and how Pete Dye aligned it directly behind the flag as a star-shaped visual target. Pete also aligned the apex of the natural West Virginia hill behind the fan with the green, something James says “the Sovereign couldn’t duplicate.” This chapter shows how industrial artifacts and natural landforms are composed into a striking golf vista.

chapters.title: Mine Portal No. 7 Tee and Adjusting Greens & Tees
chapters.summary: The camera revisits the mine portal that serves as the 7th tee. John explains that the main tee is above the portal, with three additional tees down the right side. Orange flags mark Pete Dye’s changes to the 7th green, reducing its size and reshaping it into a pear form after deciding it was too easy. He points out the walk-off area to carts, the planned cart path up the hill, and the relocated gold and blue tees on the 8th tee mound, moved about 50 feet away from trees to create more room for the path and better alignment with the fairway. Survey stakes and small signs (e.g., “PAR 3 185 YDS 16 GREEN”) appear throughout, marking future greens and tees. This chapter captures the iterative nature of Dye’s design process and the detailed routing work done on-site.
characters_present: Unidentified construction workers (Mike Ranzelli, Jack Oswald, Jack Dempsey, Larry Reel, Herb, etc.)

chapters.title: Triploid Carp Stocking and Pond Ecology
chapters.summary: A substantial portion of the reel documents stocking triploid carp into the No. 1 and No. 4 lakes. James D. stands at the No. 1 lake with a box of fish (about 25 per bag), explaining that Gary Davis brought them from Pittsburgh after they were flown from Arkansas by breeder Bill Whiting. Bob Andrew and others pour lake water into the shipping bags to acclimate the fish and reduce shock. James notes that the carp are sterile, require state permission to import, won’t reproduce or bite hooks, and eat only green vegetation (algae, cattails, shoreline plants). He warns that if they escaped into streams and reproduced, they could upset ecological balance by stripping banks of vegetation. The men carefully release the fish, speculating about survival after the flight and drive, and James records the time and date (5:40 p.m., October 7) on camera. Similar procedures are repeated at the No. 4 lake. This chapter shows the club’s deliberate approach to water quality and environmental management.

chapters.title: On-Camera Reflections: Roadbed, Clubhouse, and No. 10 Tee
chapters.summary: In several stand-up segments dated October 6, 1987, John B.N. Gotti appears on camera (in a red cardigan and later in plaid flannel) with a microphone, summarizing the project for posterity. He explains that the roadbed beside the tipple will carry tracks and mine cars, that limestone ballast matches the original mine construction, and that Pete Dye insisted on laying the track exactly as before. He points out, often over B-roll of fairways and ponds, that a clump of trees at the end of the roadbed will host the clubhouse and that a rock base on the opposite bank is the No. 10 tee—“that’s where you start.” He repeatedly credits Louie Ellis as the “Clarksburg Cecil B. DeMille,” emphasizes that Louie works “no charge,” and jokes about having shelves full of tapes labeled “LaRosa.” These segments explicitly frame the footage as a historical record the LaRosas and Dyes will want to revisit in future years.

chapters.title: Wildlife, Windmill, and Final Landscape Overview
chapters.summary: The reel closes with more polished landscape shots: the 4th green and lake with fountain, the 10th fairway corridor with roadbed and mine cars, the windmill and construction pad near the 17th/18th complex, and long views down valleys showing creeks, rock cuts, and shaped fairways. Harris and James D. talk about wild turkeys, ducks, deer, foxes, and other wildlife that have already begun using the course. The windmill is highlighted as a visual target on No. 17. The final shots of fountains, stone walls, and mounded fairways contrast sharply with the early raw earthmoving scenes, underscoring the transformation from stripped mine land to a fully realized Pete Dye golf landscape rooted in West Virginia’s coal heritage.

highlights.title: Integrating the Coal Tipple and Mine Cars into No. 10
highlights.description: John stands on the roadbed beside the old coal tipple, explaining that restored tracks and authentic mine cars filled with coal from the property will separate the practice range from the 10th fairway and visually “turn” the hole. He points out where the clubhouse and 10th tee will sit relative to the tipple and roadbed.
characters_involved: Unidentified construction workers (Mike Ranzelli, Jack Oswald, Jack Dempsey, Larry Reel, Herb, etc.)

highlights.title: Louie’s Sledgehammer Performance on the Track
highlights.description: Wearing a dress shirt and tie, Louie theatrically swings a sledgehammer on the newly laid mine track while off-camera voices tease that he’s “never did a day’s work in his life” and is “overpaid at 33 cents an hour.”

highlights.title: Max Robinson and the Natural 16th Hole
highlights.description: On the 16th par-3, John introduces Max Robinson as Pete Dye’s “eyes, ears, arms, and legs,” noting that the hole lies largely where it was naturally found. Max quietly predicts it will be one of the best holes on the course as Louie pans from green to tee to show its natural contours.

highlights.title: James D. Explains Coal Cinder Bunkers
highlights.description: Standing on the 1st fairway on October 6, 1987, James D. LaRosa explains the experimental use of jet-black coal cinders in bunkers, showing two truckloads of cinders and the first bunker filled with them. He discusses aesthetics, playability concerns, and the fabric layer used to keep mud from contaminating the cinders.

highlights.title: Triploid Carp Stocking Ceremony
highlights.description: At the No. 1 lake, James D., Gary Davis, and Bob Andrew carefully acclimate and release triploid carp from shipping bags into the water. James explains their Siberian origin, sterile status, and role in controlling algae and cattails, while Louie records the exact time and date for the record.

highlights.title: Fountain and Mine Fan Behind the 4th Green
highlights.description: James D. and Harris switch on the new floating fountain in the 4th lake, then pan up to the star-shaped mine ventilation fan on the hill behind the green. James explains its real mining function and how Pete Dye aligned it and the hill’s apex behind the flag to create a unique mining-themed vista.

highlights.title: On-Camera Stand-Up: Roadbed, Clubhouse, and No. 10 Tee
highlights.description: In a red cardigan with microphone in hand, John B.N. Gotti delivers a concise on-camera explanation of the roadbed, limestone ballast, future clubhouse in the trees, and the rock base that will be the No. 10 tee, explicitly framing the footage as something the LaRosas and Dyes will want to see “down through the years.”

highlights.title: Louie’s ‘No Charge’ Monologue
highlights.description: Louie steps in front of the camera to address Pete Dye directly, presenting the tape “the boys, the LaRosas, requested” and repeating that it’s “no charge” by orders. He jokes about having shelves of tapes labeled “LaRosa, LaRosa, LaRosa” and signs off with his trademark humor.

quotes.text: These coal cinders… are out of a wet bottom furnace, electric utility plant, and they have a metallic finish to them, and they'll kind of glisten when the sun shines. We just hope that the ball doesn't sink too deep in them when they're hit very high and land hard.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Explaining the experimental coal cinder bunkers on the 1st hole and their aesthetic and playability implications.

quotes.text: What you see here must be approved by Pete Dye. Now when he comes in to look at this, if it's not what he wants, then he informs Max on how to change it.
quotes.speaker: John B.N. Gotti
quotes.context: Describing Max Robinson’s role and Pete Dye’s final authority over shaping on the 12th hole.

quotes.text: Max had just told us that Pete Dye is one of the top three designers in the United States, or in the world probably… and that he probably has more golf courses in the top 100 than any architect.
quotes.speaker: John B.N. Gotti
quotes.context: On the 12th fairway, relaying Max Robinson’s assessment of Pete Dye’s stature and global work.

quotes.text: Personally, he's number one in my books, but when it comes from people like Max, who's been on hundreds of golf courses working with him, should know.
quotes.speaker: John B.N. Gotti
quotes.context: Continuing his praise of Pete Dye’s design legacy while standing on the 12th landing area.

quotes.text: We're all very proud of it. We know we're going to have the greatest golf course in the world. We're not going to quit until we get to that point.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Group scene near the 4th/10th corridor, expressing the LaRosa team’s ambition for the course.

quotes.text: Since 1978… you haven't gave me a dime. And Max, I'll tell you why he hasn't gave me a dime, because I don't want it.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Louie joking on camera about never charging the LaRosas for decades of filming, emphasizing his friendship and voluntary role.

quotes.text: This tipple was actually standing here when we first came onto this project back in 1978 or ’79… and now we're going to incorporate it into the background and the theme of this golf course.
quotes.speaker: John B.N. Gotti
quotes.context: Explaining the decision to preserve and reuse the old coal tipple as a central visual element along the 10th hole.

quotes.text: These fish… are special fish that you need the permission of the State Department of Natural Resources to have them brought into the state. They will not multiply… and they won't eat anything but grass or anything green.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Describing triploid carp being stocked into the No. 1 lake and their ecological role in controlling algae and cattails.

quotes.text: We like the wildlife down here. There's squirrel and wild turkey and deer, groundhog, fox… and then there's some dark ducks on the river too on Simpson Creek.
quotes.speaker: Harris Holt
quotes.context: Commenting on the wildlife already inhabiting the course while overlooking the 18th and 10th fairways.

quotes.text: These pictures were taken by the one and only L.P. Ellis. And you were really here today since 3 o'clock, Nancy. I'll vouch for you, Louie.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Thanking Louie for his filming and reassuring Nancy Ellis on camera that Louie was indeed on the course all afternoon.

themes: Integration of coal-mining heritage into golf course design
Family-driven vision and perseverance (LaRosa family)
Collaboration with Pete Dye and on-site shapers like Max Robinson
Experimental use of materials (coal cinders, limestone ballast)
Environmental stewardship and water management (lakes, fountains, carp)
Wildlife coexistence with a high-end golf environment
Documentary impulse and memory (Louie’s long-term filming, dated stand-ups)
Iterative design and refinement (changing greens, tees, and routing)
Pride in West Virginia landscape and industrial history
Community and friendship among workers, family, and professionals

Pete_Dye_Golf_Course_Highlights_And_Inte.title: Pete Dye Golf Club – Early Construction, Interviews, and Course Overview (Composite Reel)
Pete_Dye_Golf_Course_Highlights_And_Inte.content_type: Mixed: construction documentary, on‑site interviews, hospital/personal segment, and scenic course feature footage
Pete_Dye_Golf_Course_Highlights_And_Inte.summary: This reel is a composite of early and mid‑1980s footage documenting the development of the Pete Dye Golf Club: on‑site interviews with James D. LaRosa and collaborators, extensive construction and earthmoving scenes, underground mine/portal work, early test play on unfinished holes, a personal hospital segment after James D.’s accident, and later beauty shots of finished lakes, stone walls, and fountains. The through‑line is James D. LaRosa explaining the long, coal‑mine‑influenced build, Pete Dye’s design, and the technical and emotional effort behind turning a former mining property into a world‑class golf course.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.role: Course founder / owner / primary on‑site narrator
characters.description: Older white‑haired man, often in a white V‑neck T‑shirt or light polo, frequently holding a handheld microphone. Seen in construction areas, at scenic overlooks, and in a hospital gown with his arm in a cast, explaining the project’s history, design, and progress.

characters.name: Louis (Louie) Ellis
characters.description: Middle‑aged man, balding with glasses, often in a light short‑sleeve shirt or dark shirt with sunglasses, holding a wired microphone. Introduces the film (“without pay”), interviews James D. and others, and is repeatedly thanked for documenting the project.

characters.name: Jimmy (Jimmy Joe) LaRosa
characters.description: Younger than James D., appears in light button‑down shirts on hillsides and fairways, sometimes holding a mic. Explains specific holes, earthmoving operations, and technical aspects like coal seam removal and creek cleaning.

characters.name: Pete Dye
characters.description: Older man with light/white hair, seen on‑site in a sweater and bucket hat, speaking into a microphone about the property’s drama, strategy, and finishing touches. Also appears hitting test shots on a par‑3 under construction.

characters.name: P.B. Dye
characters.description: Younger Dye family member, appears in a group on the 4th fairway with James D. and others, credited with a major contribution to construction and tee placement.

characters.name: Max Robinson
characters.description: Seen on‑site in work clothes and hard hat, referenced repeatedly as “Max” or “Maxie,” described as Pete’s on‑site superintendent who carries out Dye’s instructions and shapes fairways.

characters.name: Dick Pasala
characters.description: Man in work clothes interviewed on a fairway, explaining seedbed preparation, fertilizer, and erosion control. Identifies himself as an agricultural consultant.

characters.name: Frank Etterey (Frank Gettery)
characters.role: Friend, coal broker, and golf official
characters.description: Older gentleman in casual clothes on the 13th tee, giving a long, articulate critique comparing the course to Pine Valley and Winged Foot, and praising its uniqueness and shot‑making demands.

characters.name: Raymond Brasilla
characters.description: Appears with James D. near the coal‑mine hole, offering comments about the quality of a particular hole and his background in golf associations.

characters.name: Harris Holt
characters.description: Off‑camera assistant referenced by name when asked to turn on the lake fountain; not clearly seen but heard or mentioned.

characters.name: Bob Andrew
characters.description: Construction superintendent praised after a successful dynamite blast; appears briefly on camera after removing his hat and glasses.

characters.name: Unnamed hospital visitor (likely family or associate)
characters.role: Support figure during James D.’s recovery
characters.description: Older man in short‑sleeve shirt seen leaning over James D.’s hospital bed, checking his wristband or signing something; silent but visually present as support.

chapters.title: 1. Film Introduction & Purpose
chapters.summary: Louis Ellis introduces himself as the unpaid film director and producer and explains that the viewer is about to see a 30‑minute tape of the development and construction of the LaRosa Pete Dye Golf Course. He identifies James D. and Jimmy Joe LaRosa as owners and situates the course between Clarksburg and Bridgeport, WV. Early shots include a collage/title card, then cut to James D. in an office and on‑site, explaining that the project has been underway for nine years and is entering its 10th year, aiming for play in 1989 on 235 acres within a 1,000‑acre tract, with three lakes and Simpson Creek integrated into four holes.

chapters.title: 2. Early Construction Overview & Coal‑Mine Concept
chapters.summary: James D. describes how the course is being built on former strip and deep coal mine land and how coal‑related features are intentionally incorporated: a preserved coal tipple, a portal between the 6th green and 7th tee that carts must drive through, coal‑cinder bunkers, and a mine‑water waterfall at the 10th green. B‑roll shows graded fairways, rock walls, creek cleaning with loaders and bulldozers, and the early shaping of holes 2, 4, 5, 6, 9, 10, 12, 13, 15, and 18. Jimmy LaRosa narrates heavy equipment operations (Michigan loaders, D9s, scrapers, pans) and explains plans to dam Simpson Creek to maintain a 90‑foot‑wide water corridor. Shots include dynamiting old bridge abutments, building a re‑used steel bridge, and constructing service roads and stone walls from on‑site rock.

chapters.title: 3. Branding & Image: Ann Timmerman and Lenora Riley
chapters.summary: On a winter day in February 1988, James D. stands with designer Ann Timmerman (Dye Designs, Denver) and consultant Lenora Riley (Clarksburg Arts Center) on the course. He explains they are developing logos and artistic concepts to create an image worthy of a Pete Dye Golf Club. Ann praises the land and calls it the most beautiful Pete Dye course she’s seen, noting the contours and long‑term finesse. Lenora jokes that she and Ann can hold their own with Pete and Jim. James D. responds with mock stubbornness about making it a male club, then concedes that women will win. The segment underscores the importance of branding and aesthetics alongside construction.

chapters.title: 4. On‑Site Design Walks with Pete Dye & Crew
chapters.summary: Pete Dye appears on‑site with James D., Jimmy, Max Robinson, and others, walking fairways and tees. They discuss final grades, tying tees together, and subtle changes on holes 3, 4, 5, and 14. Pete hits test shots on the par‑3 4th over a partially built lake, joking about wanting players “cutting their wrists by the time they get to the third hole.” He praises the property as the most dramatic he’s seen, noting that unlike flat courses in Illinois or Florida, here every direction offers a great vista. He explains that great courses combine strategy with unforgettable surroundings and that this course will feel like being “a million miles away.” He compares the entrance drive to Magnolia Lane at Augusta and says the atmosphere rivals or exceeds famous destinations like White Sulphur Springs. The crew also inspects the coal‑mine portal between 6 and 7, the waterfall at 10, and the dramatic 13th hole contours.

chapters.title: 5. Coal Seam, Mine Portals, and Family History
chapters.summary: James D. and Jimmy document the deep mine between 6 and 7, walking through the portal with lights powered by a generator. They show coal seams, roof bolts, old locust posts, and wire hangers for trolley wires, explaining how the mine was hand‑mined with pick, shovel, drilling, and mule‑drawn cars. James D. points out Cook’s Mine across Simpson Creek, where his mother and Alex’s mother lived after emigrating from Italy, noting the sentimental significance of building a golf course on the same ground 80 years later. Outside, heavy equipment loads the Pittsburgh coal seam at the 8th green area; Jimmy explains coal quality (ash and sulfur percentages) and that the coal is trucked to Harrison Power Station and blended to meet sulfur specs. The footage ties the course’s identity to the region’s coal heritage and the LaRosa family story.

chapters.title: 6. Agronomy & Seeding: Dick Pasala and Fairway Prep
chapters.summary: Agricultural consultant Dick Pasala is interviewed on a fairway while a D8 with a cultivator and a white fertilizer tractor work behind him. He explains that topsoil placed the previous winter has compacted and must be loosened to prepare a seedbed, then fertilized and seeded. Hillsides will be seeded in fall to prevent erosion; flat areas will be winterized and then fairways planted after irrigation is installed. He notes his background in seedbed preparation and growing grass in many soil types. Jimmy and others hit practice shots on rough dirt to test lies and ball reaction. The segment shows the technical, staged approach to turning raw earth into playable turf.

chapters.title: 7. Creek Cleaning, Bridges, and Simpson Creek Engineering
chapters.summary: Jimmy narrates extensive work in Simpson Creek: a Michigan 275 loader drives in the creek, scooping silt, coal fines, tires, and debris, building a temporary road under water. Bulldozers push silt up the banks. Old abutments are jackhammered and blasted to clear obstructions. Plans are described to build a 12‑foot dam downstream to make the creek navigable for boating and fishing, and to pump water into a large settling lake (15th) and then to a smaller lake near the clubhouse for irrigation. A re‑used steel bridge from Thornton, WV is installed, with heavy foundations to carry any future load. Shots show the new green bridge, trucks crossing, and rock‑lined banks. James D. repeatedly explains that a dam will keep the creek at a constant 90‑foot width, preserving its integrity as a wide creek/river while serving the course’s strategic and aesthetic needs.

chapters.title: 8. Lake 15 Excavation & Rock Walls
chapters.summary: James D. stands in the bottom of the future 7–10 acre 15th‑hole lake, explaining that they’ve been hauling 4,000–5,000 cubic yards of dirt per day for 30 days to build bunkers and mounds around the course. He stands on four feet of rock that will be removed and used to build 1,400 feet of rock wall along the 14th fairway and a half‑mile rock wall along the entrance road. Scrapers and dozers move material around the site. He describes the lake’s depth (16 feet near the green) as ideal for fish and as a settling basin for pumped creek water before it feeds the irrigation system. The camera shows Caterpillar 631 pans being pushed by tractors, rock walls along #1 and #8, and a sample wall for #14 that will be shown to Pete for approval. The segment emphasizes how on‑site rock is repurposed to give the course fortress‑like character.

chapters.title: 9. The Coal‑Mine Hole (#6) and Coal‑Tipple Feature
chapters.summary: On the 6th hole, James D. shows the tee, fairway, and the portal that players must drive through to reach the 7th tee. He points out the old coal stockpile and equipment across the creek where his mother first lived in America. He explains that the short par‑4 has a stone wall separating fairway and rough, coal‑cinder bunkers, and a mine portal as a transitional feature. Monsignor Riley jokes about parring the hole. Later, Johnny B. and Jimmy show the old coal tipple at #10, explaining how cars were rotated and dumped, and how the tipple will be preserved as a visual element. A proposed bridge from #10 tee across the river to the back nine is shown from the future clubhouse site. The footage ties the course’s visual drama to authentic mining relics.

chapters.title: 10. Expert Opinions: Frank Etterey & Raymond Brasilla
chapters.summary: On the 13th tee, James D. introduces his longtime friend Frank Etterey from New Rochelle, a coal broker and golf official. Frank delivers a detailed critique: he calls the development unique in a coal‑mining/light‑manufacturing region, notes that the course is surrounded by worked‑out mines, and praises Jim for hiring Pete Dye with no expense spared. He emphasizes that every hole is unique, not flat, and not in sight of adjoining holes; bad shots end up in trees and meadows, not other fairways. He mentions the exhibition coal mine and rotary car dump as integral, non‑gimmicky features. He compares the course favorably to Pine Valley and to his home clubs (Wykagyl and Winged Foot), calling it a shot‑maker’s course that will become one of the best‑known in the U.S. Raymond Brasilla also appears, praising a coal‑mine‑to‑river par‑4 as one of the finest holes for good golfers, requiring two fantastic shots. These testimonials validate the course’s design and ambition.

chapters.title: 11. Pete Dye on Strategy, Atmosphere, and Finishing Touches
chapters.summary: Pete Dye gives an extended on‑camera explanation of what makes the course special: the dramatic topography, the feeling of being a million miles from anywhere, and the fact that every hole has a distinctive look and background. He stresses that great courses combine strategy (short/long variation, contouring, bunkering) with what happens outside the playing corridor. He notes that many hilly courses lack good strategy, but here every hole has strong strategic variation. He talks about finishing details—rock work on #4, the 18th hole being worked back to the clubhouse, and the impressive entrance road starting at Smith Chapel. He compares the drive‑in to Augusta’s Magnolia Lane and says the atmosphere and finished feel here surpass other destinations. He also jokes that every time he returns, it’s like a new piece of ground to work with and that he hopes they never truly finish. This chapter includes shots of the Redan‑like par‑3 with keyhole visuals, the “China Wall” mound separating holes, and the high‑tension tower used as a sightline.

chapters.title: 12. Hospital Segment: James D.’s Tree‑Clearing Accident
chapters.summary: In a hospital room dated October 11, 1987, James D. appears in a gown with his right arm in a large padded cast. He calmly recounts his accident: during the last day of tree clearing behind #8, a leaning poplar was being pushed by a bulldozer. He had left the area to check another machine, then chose an easier path back, arriving just as the tree was cut and pushed. He “didn’t even know what hit” him as the 40‑foot tree fell. The segment intercuts his narration with shots of flowers and family visitors, including a seated woman in a dark dress and a man leaning over his bed checking his wristband. James D. thanks Louie for preserving events on video and notes that Nancy (likely Nancy Ellis) supports Louie’s work. The hospital footage underscores the personal cost and resilience behind the decades‑long project.

chapters.title: 13. Lakes, Fountains, and Triploid Carp
chapters.summary: Back on the course, James D. stands by the 4th‑hole lake and explains the installation of a 3‑horsepower floating fountain with a sunburst spray. He describes its dual purpose: aerating the water to support fish life and reducing algae. He notes that they’ve just stocked triploid carp, sterile grass‑eating fish that won’t reproduce or be caught on a rod, and can grow up to four feet if food is abundant. He explains the lake’s size (about 3.5 acres, 8‑foot average depth) and plans to move the fountain closer to the tee so the spray comes into play visually. Louie is asked to hold the mic toward the spray to capture the sound. Scenic shots show the fountain, stone walls, and reflections, illustrating the finished aesthetic of the water features that were earlier just excavations.

chapters.title: 14. Closing Scenic & Summary of Effort
chapters.summary: The reel closes with more beauty shots of ponds, stone walls, and the fountain, intercut with James D.’s voice summarizing that the course is now green, roughs are grassed, and only fairway landing areas, bentgrass, and irrigation remain. He repeatedly notes, “We’ve did many things on this,” hinting at the breadth of work. The final images reinforce the transformation from raw coal‑scarred land to a lush, water‑rich golf environment. Throughout, Louie is thanked as “Cecil B. DeMille of Clarksburg” and “No charge Ellis,” and James D. remarks that someday these pictures will be valued for posterity when the ground is green and people are enjoying golf on it.

highlights.title: Pete Dye calls the property the most dramatic he’s seen
highlights.description: On a hillside with James D. and the crew, Pete Dye says he’s never seen anything more dramatic than this piece of property and that every direction offers a great vista, comparing the entrance drive favorably to Augusta National’s Magnolia Lane.

highlights.title: Frank Etterey’s Pine Valley comparison
highlights.description: Frank Etterey delivers a detailed, thoughtful monologue on the 13th tee, praising the course’s uniqueness, shot‑making demands, and separation of holes, and saying he personally prefers this hilly, hardwood‑lined course to Pine Valley’s pine barrens.

highlights.title: James D. recounts his tree‑clearing accident from a hospital bed
highlights.description: In a hospital gown with his arm in a cast, James D. calmly explains how a 40‑foot poplar tree struck him during the last day of tree clearing, emphasizing that it was his fault for walking back into the work zone. Flowers and family visitors underscore the seriousness and support around him.

highlights.title: First official picture of the lake fountain
highlights.description: James D. stands by the 4th‑hole lake as Harris turns on the new floating fountain. The sunburst spray erupts, and James explains its aeration and algae‑control functions, as well as the recent stocking of triploid carp.

highlights.title: Coal seam loading at #8 and tying the course to mining
highlights.description: Jimmy narrates as a Caterpillar 245 backhoe loads Pittsburgh seam coal into trucks at the 8th green area. He explains coal thickness, ash and sulfur content, and how the coal is blended at Harrison Power Station, linking the course’s construction to the region’s mining economy.

highlights.title: Walking through the mine portal between 6 and 7
highlights.description: With lights powered by a generator, the camera follows James D. and a miner through the No. 6–7 portal, showing coal seams, roof bolts, and old timber supports. James explains how carts once ran on rails and how golfers will someday drive carts through this same tunnel.

quotes.text: “We’ve been working on the golf course for about nine years. This will be the 10th year and hopefully the year that we complete the course so it’s ready for play in 1989.”
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Office and on‑site interviews where James D. outlines the long development timeline and target opening year.

quotes.text: “We built this course on 235 acres of ground. It’s part of a thousand‑acre tract of ground. It’s going to have three lakes. Simpson Creek winds through the course and comes into play on four holes.”
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Introductory explanation of the course’s physical scale and integration with Simpson Creek.

quotes.text: “We’re going to put a dam in the creek so we don’t have the constant width of about 90 feet. And that way it will keep its integrity as a wide creek or river.”
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Describing planned water management to maintain a broad, river‑like feature through the course.

quotes.text: “I don’t think I’ve ever seen anything more dramatic than this piece of property. I don’t know how else you can say it. There isn’t anything more dramatic than this.”
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: On‑site with James D. and crew, praising the property’s topography and vistas.

quotes.text: “When you play this golf course… you feel like you’re a million miles away from any given place, and you can’t look in any direction and not have a great vista.”
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Explaining how the surrounding landscape contributes to the course’s greatness, beyond strategy and green contours.

quotes.text: “Most golf courses, you come into an area as big as this, it’s hard to get it done to where it really looks like a finished product. Well, this golf course, in my opinion now, is getting all the small touches that you need to give it an individual character.”
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Discussing the importance of finishing details—rock work, mounding, entrance road—in giving the course a unique, finished feel.

quotes.text: “What I’ve seen here today is a very unique development… Every hole is unique in that it is not flat. It isn’t in sight of the adjoining holes… It’s a shot maker’s golf course. If you hit a bad shot, you’re going to be penalized.”
quotes.speaker: Frank Etterey
quotes.context: On the 13th tee, giving his professional and personal assessment of the course’s design and challenge.

quotes.text: “Some people are trying to compare this course to Pine Valley. I don’t think you can compare any course to another one unless they were built by the same architect and they’re essentially identical… I personally prefer a golf course like this… that is hilly and full of hardwood trees.”
quotes.speaker: Frank Etterey
quotes.context: Explaining why the Pete Dye Golf Club stands on its own merits and suits his preferences better than Pine Valley.

quotes.text: “I had an accident. It was my fault. I was walking where I shouldn’t have been walking… Just at the time I got to where they were working, this particular tree that was leaning, they had just cut it in two and it was on its way down with the force of the bulldozer. So I didn’t even know what hit me.”
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: From his hospital bed, recounting the tree‑clearing accident behind the 8th hole that injured his arm.

quotes.text: “This lake is about three and a half acres in area and it averages about eight foot in depth… It aerates the water to keep the water so it would support fish life and also to cut down on the algae.”
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Describing the 4th‑hole lake and its floating fountain, explaining both aesthetic and ecological functions.

quotes.text: “We’ve done this work with the use primarily of scrapers and bulldozers and we’ve hauled it anywhere from 500 to 1,500 feet away from this lake and put it where it was needed.”
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Standing in the bottom of the 15th‑hole lake, explaining how lake excavation material was reused to shape bunkers and mounds around the course.

quotes.text: “I can tell you this: I’ve seen a lot of golf facilities throughout the country, and this undoubtedly is probably one of the finest golf holes for a real, real good golfer… Most fantastic sight, I’m very impressed.”
quotes.speaker: Raymond Brasilla
quotes.context: Commenting on a coal‑mine‑to‑river par‑4 hole, emphasizing its challenge and visual impact.

quotes.text: “With my longtime friend Jim LaRosa, with whom I’ve done business over 30 years, I’m tickled to death to see Jimmy doing something for this part of West Virginia. He is developing what will in time become, I’m sure, one of the best‑known courses in the United States.”
quotes.speaker: Frank Etterey
quotes.context: Closing his testimonial, expressing confidence in the course’s future reputation and pride in LaRosa’s achievement.

quotes.text: “We know we’re going to have the greatest golf course in the world. We’re not going to quit until we get to that point.”
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: Standing with P.B. Dye, Drew Pearson, and others on the 4th fairway, expressing the team’s ambition and determination.

quotes.text: “These wonderful pictures are taken by Louie Ellis, the one and only Louie Ellis. He’s been my friend and accommodated me so much over these last few years on this golf course.”
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: At the coal pit, thanking Louie for documenting the project and emphasizing the value of the footage for posterity.
