Pete_Dye_WV_Classic_Nationwide_Tour_July.title: Nationwide Tour Broadcast: Pete Dye West Virginia Classic & Related Golf Channel Programming
Pete_Dye_WV_Classic_Nationwide_Tour_July.content_type: Televised professional tournament coverage with commercials and studio segments
Pete_Dye_WV_Classic_Nationwide_Tour_July.summary: The video is a long-form capture of Golf Channel programming centered on the 2004 Nationwide Tour Pete Dye West Virginia Classic at Pete Dye Golf Club in Clarksburg, WV. It includes live and taped tournament coverage, player interviews, course features (including the abandoned mine tunnel), sponsor and tourism spots, Golf Central news updates, and promos for other golf events and products. The core narrative follows second-round play at Pete Dye Golf Club, highlighting contenders like D.A. Points, Bryce Molder, Nick Watney, Paul Gow, Gavin Coles, Darron Stiles, Todd Demsey, Jeff Gove, Kevin Johnson, and others, while also featuring an on-course interview with course superintendent Gary Grandstaff and a lighthearted “Teed Up” trivia segment with Steve Runge. Much of the runtime is occupied by national commercials (equipment, financial services, mining, tourism, home security, etc.), but the central throughline is professional tournament play on Pete Dye’s namesake course and the broadcast framing around it.

characters.name: Brian Anderson
characters.description: Primary booth host for the Golf Channel’s Nationwide Tour coverage, introducing segments, recapping scores, and interviewing guests.

characters.name: Kurt Byram
characters.description: On-air analyst in the booth with Brian Anderson, providing technical commentary on swings, strategy, and course design; often addressed as “Kurt.”

characters.name: Jerry Foltz
characters.description: Ground-level reporter (“Foltzy”) providing yardages, lie descriptions, and player interviews; also hosts the “Teed Up Cup” trivia segment.

characters.name: Val Skinner
characters.description: LPGA veteran providing on-course analysis, especially on approach shots, green complexes, and player mindset; often addressed as “Val.”

characters.name: D.A. Points
characters.description: Professional golfer and central figure in the tournament narrative; shoots 65 in round one and contends for his second win of the year, repeatedly shown hitting approaches and putts and discussed as a key storyline.

characters.name: Bryce Molder
characters.description: Young star with multiple recent top-10s; co-leads at -11, featured in multiple highlight packages (birdies at 6, 8, 9, 12, etc.).

characters.name: Nick Watney
characters.description: 24-year-old pro who shoots a course-record 63; co-leads at -11 and is tracked closely on the leaderboard and in highlights.

characters.name: Paul Gow
characters.description: Australian pro repeatedly shown hitting approaches and putts, often from the 9th and 10th holes; discussed for his playoff record and birdie chances.

characters.name: Gavin Coles
characters.description: Australian player nicknamed “the angry ant,” featured on several shots (notably at the 5th and 6th) and in on-course commentary about his unique swing technique.

characters.name: Darron Stiles
characters.description: Player at -7 who is repeatedly shown on holes 14–17, including key par saves and birdie attempts; discussed as a recent graduate from the tour seeking a return to the PGA Tour.

characters.name: Todd Demsey
characters.description: Tall, smooth-swinging pro highlighted for his “pure swing” and ball-striking; shown on holes 15, 16, and 17 with birdie tries.

characters.name: Jeff Gove
characters.description: Former tour winner, shown playing a delicate 4th shot from rocks by water on 15 and an approach at 18.

characters.name: Kevin Johnson
characters.description: Pro featured on 15, 17, and 18 with approaches and putts; his position relative to the cut line is discussed.

characters.name: Ryuji Imada
characters.description: Contender shown multiple times on the 9th and 10th holes; commentators compare his yardages and lies to Paul Gow’s.

characters.name: Gavin Coles
characters.description: Australian pro featured on par-5 5th and 6th holes with wedge and putt sequences; discussed as normally a very fast player.

characters.name: Ty Tryon
characters.description: Young pro shown saving par on 18 and making the turn at even par; his grouping and hopes for a big week are mentioned.

characters.name: Bill Lunde
characters.description: Player at the 13th par-3, highlighted for a near-flagstick tee shot and prior near-win at Lake Erie Charity Classic.

characters.name: Mark Wurtz
characters.description: Player shown on 12 and 13 with strong ball-striking and birdie putts; described as having missed only one green.

characters.name: Hunter Haas
characters.description: Featured on the 10th hole with a difficult birdie putt and described as having an up-and-down day.

characters.name: Charles Warren
characters.description: Highlighted for excellent iron play and birdie chances, especially at the 14th and 15th holes.

characters.name: Gary Grandstaff
characters.role: Course superintendent, Pete Dye Golf Club
characters.description: On-camera guest interviewed about course preparation; explains bunker sand replacement, firmness goals, and working with PGA Tour officials.

characters.name: Steve Runge
characters.role: Nationwide Tour player / “Teed Up Cup” participant
characters.description: Golfer featured in a lighthearted trivia segment hosted by Jerry Foltz; answers general-knowledge questions and is shown with humorous lower-third labels.

characters.name: Kraig Kann
characters.description: Golf Central / Sprint Post Game host in studio, delivering Open Championship updates and promos.

characters.name: Mike Ritz
characters.description: Host in Orlando studio delivering Golf Central updates on the Open Championship (voiceover over leaderboard graphics).

characters.name: Craig Cann
characters.description: On-air personality promoting Open Championship postgame coverage and American Century Championship; appears in studio and promo segments.

characters.name: Gary Grandstaff
characters.description: Interviewed on-course about course conditioning and setup for the Nationwide Tour event; explains bunker work and cooperation with PGA officials.

characters.name: Skip Kendall
characters.description: Mentioned and shown on Golf Central leaderboard as Open Championship leader at -7; not part of Pete Dye event but in news segment.

characters.name: Pete Dye
characters.description: Not seen speaking, but repeatedly referenced by commentators as the designer of Pete Dye Golf Club and its “18 most memorable holes.”

chapters.title: Commercial Block & Return to Nationwide Tour Coverage
chapters.summary: The video opens in the middle of a Golf Channel commercial block: ads for golfdiscount.com (Adams GT 363 drivers and Tight Lies fairway woods), Fidelity Active Trader Services, and Dave Pelz’s putting DVD play over generic golf imagery. The broadcast then transitions back to Nationwide Tour coverage, showing Jimmy Walker’s missed birdie at 18 and Paul Gow’s bunker shot and resulting birdie putt at the 9th. Early leaderboard graphics identify the event as the Pete Dye West Virginia Classic, with D.A. Points leading after a 65. The visuals and audio confirm this is a televised Nationwide Tour event at Pete Dye Golf Club, not raw club-shot footage.

chapters.title: Front-Nine Action & Course/Mine Feature
chapters.summary: Coverage cycles through multiple players on the front nine: Ryuji Imada’s precise iron at the 9th, Mark Wurtz’s strong play at the 12th, Brad Adamonis’ blind second shot at 18 (a Pete Dye design feature where the flag is hidden), and others. A narrated feature segment highlights the coal-mining heritage of West Virginia and the abandoned mine tunnel behind the 6th green at Pete Dye Golf Club, emphasizing the course’s unique integration of mining history. Commercials for Porsche, MAC Burrows drivers, Open Championship Week, PlayGolfAmerica, and various sponsors intersperse the golf action.

chapters.title: Nationwide Tour Round 1 Highlights & Leaderboard Context
chapters.summary: The broadcast settles into a rhythm of showing live shots and taped highlights from the first round: D.A. Points’ 65, Nick Watney’s course-record 63, Bryce Molder’s birdie run, and strong play from players like Warren Schutte, Jeff Gove, and others. The commentators praise Pete Dye Golf Club’s design and the LaRosa family’s role in developing a first-class venue. Multiple leaderboard graphics show the depth of the field and the cut line at -1. Golf Central updates and Open Championship promos appear, along with sponsor IDs for Nationwide, West Virginia Tourism, National Mining Association, Cleveland Golf, Srixon, and others. The course’s coal cars and mine remnants are shown as part of the club’s visual identity.

chapters.title: Second-Round Coverage: D.A. Points, Molder, Watney in Contention
chapters.summary: The telecast moves into live second-round coverage. D.A. Points continues his strong play, making birdies at 2, 3, 5, and 6 to reach -10 and tie Bryce Molder at the top. Highlights show Molder’s birdies at 6, 8, 9, and 12, and Watney’s birdie at 18 and eagle try at 8. The commentators discuss how soft conditions and lack of wind have made Pete Dye Golf Club “ripe for scoring,” noting that Pete Dye himself might be uneasy about the low scores. They also emphasize the course’s strategic demands, such as the blind 18th approach and the multi-contoured 17th green. Numerous other players—Paul Gow, Ryuji Imada, Mark Wurtz, Hunter Haas, Franklin Langham, Scott Gutschewski, Todd Demsey, Jeff Gove, Kevin Johnson, Ty Tryon, Bill Lunde, Charles Warren—are shown hitting approaches and putts, illustrating the course’s variety and difficulty.

chapters.title: Course Conditions Interview with Superintendent Gary Grandstaff
chapters.summary: During a lull in live action, Brian Anderson and Kurt Byram introduce Gary Grandstaff, the superintendent of Pete Dye Golf Club. In an on-camera interview by the lake, Grandstaff explains that they changed the sand in 106 bunkers just a month before the event, compacting them to firm up conditions. He notes that rain early in the week softened the greens more than intended, making birdies easier and long putts rare. He credits the PGA Tour staff for helping with course preparation and expresses pride in the course as a “treasure” for West Virginia. The segment underscores the behind-the-scenes effort to present a championship-caliber Pete Dye design and how weather can thwart those intentions.

chapters.title: Mid-Round Grind: 10th and 15th Holes, Cut-Line Drama
chapters.summary: The coverage focuses on some of Pete Dye Golf Club’s toughest holes. The 10th is repeatedly described as the hardest hole on the course, with only eight birdies and many doubles; players like Hunter Haas, Scott Gutschewski, Franklin Langham, and others struggle with its mounded green. The par-5 15th is shown as a reachable but dangerous hole, with players like Darron Stiles, P.H. Horgan III, Charles Warren, Kevin Johnson, and Gavin Coles laying up or going for it in two, often leaving tricky pitches near water and rocks. The 17th’s controversial multi-humped green is diagrammed on-screen, with Kurt Byram’s telestrator showing how balls can roll off if distance control is off. Leaderboard graphics and commentary track the cut line at -1 and how players like Kevin Johnson, Troy Matteson, Todd Demsey, and others are hovering around it.

chapters.title: Golf Central Updates & Open Championship Context
chapters.summary: Several Golf Central update segments appear, hosted from Orlando and studio sets, providing scores and analysis from the 133rd Open Championship at Royal Troon. Leaderboards show Skip Kendall leading at -7, with Thomas Levet, K.J. Choi, Barry Lane, Vijay Singh, Ernie Els, Colin Montgomerie, Mike Weir, Retief Goosen, Phil Mickelson, Tiger Woods, and others in pursuit. These updates are intercut with Nationwide Tour coverage, reinforcing the Golf Channel’s broader coverage of professional golf. Promos for Open Championship Week, Sprint Post Game, and PGA TOUR.com Tour Pass appear, along with sponsor IDs for Grey Goose, Circuit City, and others. This situates the Pete Dye West Virginia Classic within the larger professional golf calendar.

chapters.title: “Teed Up Cup” Trivia Segment with Steve Runge
chapters.summary: Jerry Foltz hosts a lighthearted “Teed Up Cup” trivia contest with Nationwide Tour player Steve Runge. In a nine-question format, correct answers count as birdies and wrong answers as bogeys. Runge correctly answers questions about Payne Stewart’s 1991 U.S. Open win at Hazeltine, Alfonso Soriano as All-Star Game MVP, Chewbacca as Star Wars’ famous Wookiee, and John Elway’s jersey number (7), but misses others like Elsie the Cow’s company (Borden), the Gila monster, Motor Trend as Car of the Year magazine, and Loretta Lynn as the subject of Coal Miner’s Daughter. Foltz jokes about his own major appearance at Hazeltine and encourages viewers to send in trivia questions. The segment humanizes the players and adds levity to the broadcast.

chapters.title: Back Nine Push: D.A. Points, Stiles, Demsey, Gove, Johnson
chapters.summary: Returning to live coverage, the broadcast tracks key contenders on the back nine. D.A. Points continues to “pour them in,” making his fourth birdie and joining Bryce Molder at -11. Darron Stiles saves par on 16 and 17 to stay at -7, keeping his hopes alive. Todd Demsey is praised for his pure swing and strong ball-striking, making birdies and solid pars on 15–17. Jeff Gove plays a delicate 4th shot from rocks by the water on 15 and hits a solid approach at 18. Kevin Johnson’s approaches and putts on 15, 17, and 18 are shown, with his position relative to the cut line discussed. Justin Bolli’s creative use of the putter from off the green at 14 is highlighted as an example of Pete Dye’s design allowing multiple short-game options. The commentators repeatedly note how the course encourages creativity rather than forcing only high flop shots from thick rough.

chapters.title: Course Design Praise & Closing of the Day’s Window
chapters.summary: As the day’s coverage window nears its end, Brian Anderson and Kurt Byram reflect on Pete Dye Golf Club as a “par 72, 7,200-yard masterpiece in the mountains of coal country” and note that Pete Dye himself considers it 18 of his most memorable holes. They praise the LaRosa family for creating a first-class event and remark on the strong galleries and golf-hungry community in Clarksburg, West Virginia. They discuss the scoring conditions (soft greens, little wind) and how players like D.A. Points, Bryce Molder, and Nick Watney have taken advantage. The broadcast signs off with Anderson noting that D.A. Points is going after his third career win and second of the year, and that they’ll be back the next day for more coverage. The final minutes include more shots of D.A. Points, Paul Gow, Jeff Gallagher, Ryuji Imada, and Kevin Johnson, as well as a Golf Central update and promos, before the recording ends.

highlights.title: D.A. Points’ Birdie Run to Tie the Lead
highlights.description: D.A. Points, already coming off a 65, makes back-to-back birdies at 5 and 6, then another at the 6th in the second round to reach -10 and tie Bryce Molder at -11. His putting is described as confident and decisive, with the commentators noting he’s “not missing the center of the hole.”

highlights.title: Gary Grandstaff Explains Championship Course Setup
highlights.description: Course superintendent Gary Grandstaff is interviewed lakeside about preparing Pete Dye Golf Club for the Nationwide Tour. He explains that they replaced sand in 106 bunkers and compacted them to firm up conditions, but early-week rain softened the greens more than intended, making birdies easier. He credits the PGA Tour staff for their help and calls the process “a lot of fun,” underscoring pride in the course as a West Virginia treasure.

highlights.title: Feature on the Abandoned Mine Tunnel Behind the 6th Green
highlights.description: A narrated feature describes how coal mining underlies the Pete Dye Golf Club property and shows the abandoned mine tunnel behind the 6th green. The camera moves through the timbered entrance and down the cool, dim corridor, with a sign reading “ABANDONED AREA #2 NORTH – DO NOT PROCEED.” The narration notes that the tunnel is about a dozen degrees cooler and is a unique way to walk from the 6th to the 7th.

highlights.title: Darron Stiles’ Clutch Par Saves on 16 and 17
highlights.description: Darron Stiles faces difficult up-and-downs on the par-3 16th and par-4 17th. At 16, he plays from a tough bunker lie and saves par with a solid putt. At 17, after a misjudged wedge that catches a mound and leaves a tricky chip, he again holes a par putt. The commentators note he “just made one just like this on the 16th” and praise his putter for keeping him at -7 and in contention.

highlights.title: “Teed Up Cup” Trivia with Steve Runge
highlights.description: Jerry Foltz drags Steve Runge “kicking and screaming” from a rainy practice session to play the Teed Up Cup trivia game. Runge answers questions about Hazeltine, Alfonso Soriano, Chewbacca, and John Elway correctly, but misses others like Elsie the Cow’s company and the Gila monster. Foltz jokes about his own major at Hazeltine and encourages viewers to send in questions. The segment shows a lighter side of tour life and player personalities.

highlights.title: Commentators Praise Pete Dye Golf Club and LaRosa Family
highlights.description: In the booth, Brian Anderson and Kurt Byram call Pete Dye Golf Club “a par 72, 7,200-yard masterpiece in the mountains of coal country” and note that Pete Dye considers it 18 of his most memorable holes. They credit the LaRosa family for making it a first-class event and remark on the strong Thursday galleries, saying the entire state seems excited and “really behind it.”

quotes.text: It’s a great venue. Pete Dye did a really good job with the design of this golf course. I think he thinks it may be one of his best. And you knew with the developers, the LaRosa family behind it, it was going to be a first class event.
quotes.speaker: Kurt Byram
quotes.context: Booth discussion early in second-round coverage, reflecting on day-one impressions and the quality of Pete Dye Golf Club and its ownership.

quotes.text: These guys are really good. Everything that we’ve done to try and stop them really hasn’t worked.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: On-course interview about course setup and how soft conditions and wide fairways have allowed low scoring despite efforts to firm up bunkers and greens.

quotes.text: The fairways are wide. I haven’t seen but three players in the rough, I believe, and watching them hit into the greens has just been phenomenal. There aren’t any long putts, and making birdie out there is pretty easy, as you can tell by the scores.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Continuing his explanation of how the course is playing during the Nationwide Tour event.

quotes.text: It’s kind of funny, you know, you come to a new venue like this, and of course it’s a Pete Dye golf course. You know, the expectations are what get these guys. I heard some guys say it’ll be, you know, 18 under. And then I heard somebody else say, ‘Oh, I think even par is good. I’d like to get it at even par and sit on it.’
quotes.speaker: Kurt Byram
quotes.context: Booth commentary on how players misjudged scoring expectations at a new Pete Dye venue, given soft conditions and low scores.

quotes.text: These guys are good, and it’s all right to see a few birdies. The USGA has a serious infatuation with even par, all right? That was made pretty clear this year.
quotes.speaker: Kurt Byram
quotes.context: Discussion about scoring philosophy in professional golf, contrasting the Nationwide Tour event with the recent U.S. Open at Shinnecock.

quotes.text: He’s the toughest, most tenacious, never-give-up son of a gun I ever worked for.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Referenced by the commentators as a known quote about James D. LaRosa; not spoken directly in this footage but part of the broader Pete Dye Golf Club story.

quotes.text: He’s not missing the center of the hole. Yes, pouring them in. His fourth birdie, and again back-to-back birdies. He did it at two and three, and now at five and six.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Foltz
quotes.context: On-course commentary as D.A. Points continues a hot putting streak to climb the leaderboard.

quotes.text: Well, it’s better to be convinced than to be correct, they say. I think both is better.
quotes.speaker: Jerry Foltz
quotes.context: Commenting on Gavin Coles taking extra time over a short putt at the 5th, reflecting on the psychology of reading putts.

quotes.text: Oh yeah, the theme here is bump, bite, and roll—and please get close to the hole. How many elephants are in this green, guys? Six.
quotes.speaker: Val Skinner
quotes.context: Describing the extremely contoured 17th green at Pete Dye Golf Club as Darron Stiles faces a difficult third shot.

quotes.text: We’ve learned an awful lot on course preparation from the PGA themselves, and they helped us tremendously to prepare the golf course, and it’s been fun.
quotes.speaker: Gary Grandstaff
quotes.context: Explaining collaboration with PGA Tour officials in setting up Pete Dye Golf Club for the Nationwide Tour event.

Some_Highlites_of_the_Pete_Dye_-_LaRosa_.title: Pete Dye Golf Club – Early Construction, Design Vision, and Family Archive Reel
Some_Highlites_of_the_Pete_Dye_-_LaRosa_.content_type: Mixed archival reel (construction documentation, design presentation, interviews, family/club life, and scenic course footage)
Some_Highlites_of_the_Pete_Dye_-_LaRosa_.summary:
This reel is a long-form archival compilation spanning early 1980s through late 1980s, documenting the conception, construction, and early maturation of the Pete Dye Golf Club. It intercuts:
- On‑site construction footage (earthmoving, bridge/abutment building, river and creek cleanup, pond/lake creation, grading of fairways and greens).
- Design presentations using a hand-built clay model and a professional course master plan and clubhouse elevation drawings.
- Numerous informal interviews and thank‑you segments with the LaRosa family, associates, and workers, almost all directed to or by filmmaker Louie Ellis.
- Underground/mine‑portal tours and industrial heritage shots (tipple, LaRosa Fuel Co. portals, rotary car dump) that will become part of the course’s identity.
- Family and social moments (pets, group portraits, joking around, handing out a symbolic dollar, raspberry patch visit).
- Later scenic footage of the completed or nearly completed course, including lakes, waterfalls, stone walls, dramatic valley holes, and autumn vistas.

The through-line is the LaRosa family’s decades-long effort to reclaim a strip‑mined, coal‑scarred valley and, with Pete Dye, turn it into a world‑class, self-contained golf course. Louie Ellis’s camera and running “no charge” joke become part of the story itself, as everyone acknowledges that these tapes are being made consciously for posterity.

characters.name: Louie Ellis
characters.role: Filmmaker, on‑camera host, and informal interviewer
characters.description: Appears repeatedly as the man behind and sometimes in front of the camera. Often in casual shirts or a red cardigan, holding a handheld microphone, joking about doing the filming 'no charge.' He prompts others to speak, introduces segments, and later presents a finished tape to Pete Dye.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.role: Founder / owner, on‑site narrator and interview subject
characters.description: Older, white‑haired man in dress shirts, sometimes with a red tie, sometimes in a white V‑neck T‑shirt or tan coat. He narrates construction at Simpson Creek, explains the clubhouse and lake plans, praises workers, and often thanks Louie. He appears both in construction-era footage (early 1980s) and later scenic/stocking/fountain sequences.

characters.name: Jimmy (Jimmy Joe) LaRosa
characters.description: Younger than James D., appears in construction scenes in light shirts and slacks, sometimes with a mic. He explains fairway grading, mine‑portal routing between 6 and 7, and later gives progress updates (e.g., on 17th green seeding). He also appears in group shots and with Pete Dye on holes.

characters.name: Pete Dye
characters.description: Older man with white hair, often in casual golf clothes and cap. He appears in on‑course discussions (e.g., at the coal‑mine hole and later when asked to rate the course), talking about strategy, self‑contained design, coal heritage, and comparisons to Scottish courses and St Andrews.

characters.name: Max Robinson
characters.description: Appears in construction meetings with Pete and the LaRosas, often in work clothes and cap. He is referenced by name in narration and occasionally speaks about dirt‑moving and teamwork.

characters.name: Frank Etterie (Frank Gettery)
characters.role: Longtime friend and outside golf voice
characters.description: Older man in light blue polo or sport shirt, glasses, sometimes in a sport coat. He stands on the 13th tee and gives a long, articulate critique of the course, comparing it to Pine Valley, Winged Foot, and Scottish courses, and praising Jim LaRosa’s ambition.

characters.name: Raymond (Raymondo Frazzilio)
characters.description: Middle‑aged man in golf attire (mentioned as 'Raymondo Procelio/Frazzilio'), interviewed on No. 2 fairway. He comments on the quality of a hole coming from a coal mine opening across the river.

characters.name: Various construction workers (Mazzee brothers, Larry, Steve Helmig, etc.)
characters.description: Appear in hard hats, work shirts, and jeans around bridge abutments, dozers, and excavators. Named in narration (Louie Mazzee, Frank Mazzee, Sam Mazzee, Larry, Steve Helmig) while working on drain lines, mounds, and bridge supports.

characters.name: Gary Davis & Bob Andrew
characters.description: Appear at the No. 1 lake during fish stocking and fountain startup. Gary is mentioned as bringing triploid carp from Pittsburgh; Bob Andrew is asked to turn on the fountain pumps.

characters.name: Anthony Ellis
characters.description: Introduced by Louie on camera as his 'backup man' with phone number given, in case anything happens to Louie. Appears briefly in a family-style segment.

characters.name: PB Dye
characters.description: Appears in a later group shot on the 4th fairway, introduced as having made a major contribution to construction. Dressed in golf/work clothes, standing with James D., Jimmy, Drew Pearson, and others.

characters.name: Drew Pearson
characters.role: Golf professional assisting with finish work
characters.description: Introduced in the 4th‑fairway group as a golf professional helping with tee locations and finish work. In golf attire, standing with PB Dye and the LaRosas.

characters.name: Ed Fuseman (Fiefman)
characters.description: Introduced in the same 4th‑fairway group as the long‑time surveyor for the company, in work clothes, holding plans or tools.

characters.name: John Angotti
characters.description: Appears in multiple segments as 'Johnny B.' or 'John Angotti,' often in work clothes, helping coordinate operations and appearing in group shots and interviews.

chapters.title: 1. Louie’s Role & Early 1982 Construction at Simpson Creek
chapters.summary: The reel opens with a posed shot of Louie Ellis as 'Film Director & Producer,' then cuts to July 4, 1982 on-site interviews at the raw Meadowbrook/Pete Dye site. James D. LaRosa and others thank Louie for filming 'for our own historical reasons' and joke about 'no charge.' The camera then documents a burned railroad/road bridge on the lower end of No. 9 fairway, heavy equipment cleaning decades of strip‑mine silt from Simpson Creek, and bulldozers shaping the future clubhouse area, first tee, and 18th green. Narration explains plans to dam the creek, deepen it for boating and fishing, and rough‑grade all 18 fairways by late 1982 for a 1984 opening.

chapters.title: 2. Underground Mine, Coal Heritage & Routing of Holes 6–7
chapters.summary: The film moves into the coal‑mine heritage of the property. We see the LaRosa Fuel Co. portals and the rotary car dump (tipple) that once rotated coal cars to empty them. James D. and Jimmy explain that golf carts will travel through a deep mine between the 6th green and 7th tee, making the mine an integral part of the routing. Pete Dye, Max Robinson, and the LaRosas walk the 6th fairway, discuss blocking off an old road, and debate whether golfers should be forced through the mine. Pete praises the property as 'the most dramatic' he’s seen and jokes about West Virginians and hillbillies. They also discuss coal cinder bunkers, stone walls, and how the course will echo Scottish coal‑yard features like St Andrews’ road hole.

chapters.title: 3. 1983–1985: Creek Cleaning, Bridge Building & Entrance Road
chapters.summary: By 1983–85, the footage shows more organized earthmoving: end loaders and scrapers cleaning Simpson Creek, D9 and D6 dozers pushing silt to build up fairways and future sod farms, and workers installing large drain pipes under fairways. James D. narrates in detail how sediment, coal fines, and trash are removed, how abutments are jackhammered and blasted, and how a salvaged steel bridge from Thornton, WV is repurposed over Simpson Creek for both play and maintenance. We see the entrance road near Jimmy Joe’s house, sulfur water from an old Consol mine, and the first glimpses of shaped fairways (No. 2, No. 18 landing area) with temporary play and fertilizer spreading. Interviews with workers and friends (e.g., Raymondo Frazzilio) praise specific holes and the overall potential of the course.

chapters.title: 4. Pete Dye on Strategy, Self‑Contained Design & Greatness
chapters.summary: On a partially grassed front nine, Pete Dye is finally captured on tape. Standing with James D. and Jimmy, he calls himself 'Mr. LaRosa’s assistant' and describes the property as unequaled: a self‑contained golf course with no houses, dramatic hillsides, and distinctive vistas on every hole. He explains what makes great courses—natural backdrops, strategic variety, and finished details—and compares the coal‑mine and rock features here to Scottish precedents (sleepers, coal yards at St Andrews). He predicts that if they finish as planned, this will be a truly great golf course. The LaRosas and Max discuss final grading tweaks, ladies’ tees, and how little remains to fix on the front nine.

chapters.title: 5. 1985–1986: Seeding, Mounding & Outside Voices
chapters.summary: Mid‑80s footage shows the course taking shape: topsoil, lime, phosphate, and seed being applied around the 17th green; rye overseeding for erosion control; and permanent bluegrass/bentgrass interfaces explained by a superintendent. Jimmy notes they’re as far along as ever and hope to open in about a year. On No. 12, James D. and operator Steve Helmig build a mound that will create a blind shot if you play too safe off the tee. We see the Mazzee brothers building bridge abutments, and more drainage and stonework. Longtime friend Frank Etterie (from New Rochelle/Winged Foot) gives a detailed, glowing critique of the course, comparing it favorably to Pine Valley and Scottish classics, and praising Jim LaRosa’s determination to create a first‑class, shot‑maker’s course in a coal‑mining region.

chapters.title: 6. Lakes, Fountains, Triploid Carp & Finished Water Features
chapters.summary: Attention shifts to the creation and refinement of the course’s lakes. We see the No. 1 lake with a floating fountain unit; James D. explains its dual purpose: aeration for fish life and algae control. Special triploid carp from Arkansas (via Pittsburgh) are acclimated and released into the lake under the supervision of Gary Davis and Bob Andrew, with Louie filming up close. Later, James D. stands by the lake as the two Otterbine fountains are turned on for the first time, describing their 15–18 foot 'rocket' spray and planned colored lights for nighttime views from the future clubhouse. Scenic shots show the completed spillway, rock cascades, and misty lakes with ducks and geese, contrasting sharply with earlier muddy creek footage.

chapters.title: 7. Family, Pets & Louie’s Running 'No Charge' Gag
chapters.summary: Interspersed with construction are intimate family and social moments: Louie films dogs and cats around a house and fenced yard; an older man in a tan coat (likely James D.) holds and introduces multiple cats ('Tiger,' 'Bunker,' 'Coldust,' 'Silky'), joking that this is 'the other side of Jim LaRosa’s life.' Louie introduces his nephew Anthony Ellis as his 'backup man' and gives his phone number on camera. In another scene, Louie theatrically hands James D. and friends a single dollar bill, insisting on proving on TV that he 'paid to take the movies.' Group shots on the old tracks and at the raspberry patch show the extended LaRosa/Ellis circle laughing, hugging, and acknowledging that Louie has been filming 'no charge' since 1978.

chapters.title: 8. Industrial Heritage: Tipple, Rotary Car Dump & LaRosa Fuel Portals
chapters.summary: The film documents the industrial structures that will become part of the course’s identity. We see the old rotary car dump (tipple) where coal cars were rotated and emptied, and the LaRosa Fuel Co. No. 6 and No. 7 portals. James D. explains how cars came from the hill, were dumped, and coal loaded into trucks. The group (LaRosas, friends, and Louie) stands at the portals, connecting the site to their immigrant and mining heritage. They explain that the exhibition mine and tipple will be preserved as tourist‑like attractions and integrated into holes (e.g., the coal‑mine portal visible behind the 6th green). This industrial past is explicitly linked to Scottish coal‑yard precedents and to the course’s unique character.

chapters.title: 9. Clay Models & Master Plans: Visualizing Holes 8 & the Clubhouse Core
chapters.summary: A hand‑built clay model on the grass is used to explain a dramatic redesign of the 8th hole: a high wall around the green, a 'Grand Canyon effect' from the putting surface, and a cavernous bunker bottom filled with coal cinders. James D. notes that Pete Dye said most great holes lack the 'frame' this wall will provide. Later, indoors, a professional scale model and a large colored master plan are shown. A presenter (likely James D. or an architect) points out the clubhouse, 18th green, 1st tee, 9th green, 10th tee, practice tee, putting green, chalet/temporary office, entrance garden with rock flower bed and fountain, two rock islands and fountains in the four‑acre lake, and parking for 250 cars. The model and plan are used to explain circulation, vistas, and how Simpson Creek winds along 18 and into the property.

chapters.title: 10. 1987–1988: Fine‑Tuning, Group Portraits & Course Maturity
chapters.summary: By 1987–88, the course is largely shaped. We see Steve Helmig building a mound on the right side of the 12th fairway to create a blind approach for safe tee shots. The Mazzee brothers and others build bridge abutments with rebar and concrete. Group portraits at the lake (timestamped 9.15.87) show James D., Jimmy, John Angotti, and other staff and pros lined up, laughing and chatting. Another winter 1988 segment shows James D. in a coat and hat explaining the high rock wall and cut at No. 9 and the surrounding wooded acreage. Scenic shots of autumn fairways, misty lakes, and dramatic valley holes (including the incomparable 16th and the magnificent 18th) show the course approaching its finished form, with stone walls, waterfalls, and framed vistas fully realized.

chapters.title: 11. Hole‑by‑Hole Narrated Slide/Video Tour (1–18)
chapters.summary: The reel concludes with a structured, narrated tour of all 18 holes, using a combination of slides, plan views, and scenic footage. A professional‑sounding narrator (likely Harris Holt or a similar voice) reads a prepared description: No. 1 (400‑yard par 4 with safe right drive or long carry over eight traps), No. 2 (440‑yard par 4 over Simpson Creek), No. 3 (405‑yard par 4 with small target green), No. 4 (215‑yard par 3 along a huge stone wall), No. 5 (620‑yard par 5, true three‑shotter), No. 6 (345‑yard par 4 with tight drive and coal‑mine portal behind the green), No. 7 (155‑yard par 3 from elevated tee to shallow plateau), No. 8 (505‑yard par 5 with blind second and cavernous trap), No. 9 (465‑yard par 4 over Simpson Creek), No. 10 (450‑yard par 4 over waterfall and cliff), No. 11 (570‑yard par 5 with two landing areas), No. 12 (370‑yard par 4, potential world‑class drive‑and‑pitch), No. 13 (185‑yard par 3 similar to North Berwick’s Redan), No. 14 (440‑yard par 4 with natural stone wall), No. 15 (505‑yard par 5 with lake right and stone wall left), No. 16 (250‑yard par 3 over a breathtaking vista), No. 17 (430‑yard par 4 with rolling lies and bunkered green), and No. 18 (450‑yard par 4 over Simpson Creek with hillside gallery for 30,000 spectators). The narrator then signs off, and Louie Ellis, as 'film director and producer,' wishes viewers good night and 'God bless y’all.'

highlights.title: James D. thanks Louie for filming 'for our own historical reasons'
highlights.description: On July 4, 1982, standing on a raw construction site near Simpson Creek, James D. LaRosa looks into Louie’s camera and thanks him for taking pictures of 'our operation,' saying they’ll always appreciate having them for historical reasons and noting that Louie has been a friend for years.

highlights.title: Pete Dye calls the property 'the most dramatic' he’s seen
highlights.description: On a partially grassed front nine, Pete Dye, flanked by James D. and Jimmy, says he’s never seen anything more dramatic than this piece of property and that if this isn’t a great golf course, he doesn’t know what is. He emphasizes the self‑contained nature of the course and the combination of strategy and natural vistas.

highlights.title: Frank Etterie predicts national recognition for the course
highlights.description: Standing on the 13th tee, longtime friend and Winged Foot member Frank Etterie gives a detailed, thoughtful critique, calling the development unique, praising Pete Dye’s design and Jim LaRosa’s 'no expense spared' approach, and predicting that the course will become one of the best‑known in the United States.

highlights.title: First fountains and triploid carp in No. 1 lake
highlights.description: At the No. 1 lake, James D. explains the purpose of the floating fountains and special triploid carp, then we see the first fountain turned on, shooting a 'rocket' spray into the air. The group listens to the sound of the water and jokes about whether the wall will wash away, while James D. thanks engineer George Duffer for assuring them it would work.

highlights.title: Clay model of the 'Grand Canyon' 8th hole
highlights.description: James D. kneels over a clay model on the grass, explaining how the 8th green will be framed by a high wall, with a deep coal‑cinder bunker creating a 'Grand Canyon effect.' He notes that Pete Dye said most great holes lack such a frame and predicts this will be one of the most dramatic holes on the course.

highlights.title: Pete Dye on coal, Scotland, and sleepers
highlights.description: In a conversation near the coal‑mine hole, Pete explains that using railroad ties ('sleepers') and coal features is nothing new—Scots did it a hundred years ago to stop erosion and that St Andrews had a coal yard at the 17th road hole. He says Jim is 'just restoring' things done in the old country, tying the course’s coal heritage to golf history.

highlights.title: Frank Etterie compares the course to Pine Valley and Winged Foot
highlights.description: Frank describes the course as a shot‑maker’s layout where bad shots are penalized by trees and meadows rather than adjacent fairways. He notes that while some compare it to Pine Valley, he prefers this hilly, hardwood‑lined style, similar to the course he grew up on, and says everything is being done 'in a first‑class way.'

highlights.title: Louie presents a finished tape to Pete Dye
highlights.description: In a later segment, Louie, jokingly called 'Cecil B. DeMille of Clarksburg,' hands a VHS tape to Pete Dye, saying the LaRosas requested he have it and that, 'unfortunately,' he must say again 'no charge.' Pete thanks him, and James D. says they value the photography because they’ll want to see it down through the years.

highlights.title: Narrated hole‑by‑hole tour crowns the project
highlights.description: A professional voice narrates each hole’s yardage, par, and strategic character over slides and footage of the finished course, culminating in the 'magnificent 18th' with room for 30,000 spectators. The program ends with Louie Ellis signing off as film director and producer, wishing viewers good night and 'God bless y’all.'

quotes.text: Louie, I want to thank you for taking these pictures of our operation. We’ll always appreciate having them, I know, for our own historical reasons, but you’ve been a friend down through the years, and what you’re doing now is awfully nice.
quotes.speaker: James D. LaRosa
quotes.context: On-site in 1982 near Simpson Creek, James D. addresses Louie directly, acknowledging that the filming is being done as a favor and as a conscious historical record of the project.

quotes.text: Well, I’m glad to do it, but I know why. He wants me to say one more time, no charge, and it’s really an honor to be between two fellas.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Louie responds on camera, joking about his unpaid work and expressing his own honor at being part of the LaRosa/Pete Dye project.

quotes.text: I don’t think I’ve ever seen anything more dramatic than this piece of property. I don’t know how else you could say it. There isn’t anything more dramatic than this.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Standing with James D. and Jimmy on the front nine, Pete describes the uniqueness of the West Virginia site, emphasizing its topography and vistas.

quotes.text: All great golf courses… usually you have the Pacific Ocean on one side or the Atlantic Ocean on the other side or mountains or something that is hard to reproduce. When you play this golf course or a golf course like this, I mean, it’s different. You feel like you’re a million miles away from any given place and you can’t look in any direction and not have a great vista.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: In a longer on‑camera explanation, Pete outlines what makes great courses and why this self‑contained, mountainous site fits that criterion.

quotes.text: This was a dream of James D. LaRosa and without his help and Jimmy Joe, without their backing or ideas, I just can’t think of the proper words to explain it. But this area as a whole should be deeply grateful to these two gentlemen because for the future of this area, they have made it possible for it to be remembered and known worldwide.
quotes.speaker: Unnamed narrator (likely a family friend or associate)
quotes.context: Standing on an island in the future lake, a friend takes time to credit James D. and Jimmy for the vision and impact of the project on the region.

quotes.text: What I’ve seen here today is a very unique development… He is developing what will in time become, I’m sure, one of the best‑known courses in the United States. That’s his goal, that’s his ambition, and if there’s one thing about Jim LaRosa, when he makes his mind up to do something, nothing is going to stand in his way.
quotes.speaker: Frank Etterie
quotes.context: On the 13th tee, Frank, a Winged Foot member and USGA committee man, gives a long assessment of the course and Jim LaRosa’s determination.

quotes.text: You start thinking about this golf course… I don’t see how you get 18 holes any better. Now, nine holes ain’t better than this nine over here. I really don’t.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Talking informally with James D. and Max, Pete expresses his belief that the front nine they’ve built is as good as any nine holes anywhere.

quotes.text: This straightaway hole has the potential to become one of the great drive and pitch holes in the world, in the class of the second and eighth holes at Pine Valley.
quotes.speaker: Narrator (course overview voice)
quotes.context: During the hole‑by‑hole narrated tour, the narrator describes No. 12’s strategic potential, comparing it to famous holes at Pine Valley.

quotes.text: The incomparable 16th, a 250‑yard par 3… This hole will be one of the best par threes in the world.
quotes.speaker: Narrator (course overview voice)
quotes.context: The narrator highlights the drama and difficulty of the 16th hole during the closing course overview segment.

quotes.text: Well, we are at the end of our program and from Louie Ellis, your film director and producer, I hope you’ve enjoyed this tape as much as we have doing it for you. Good night and God bless y’all.
quotes.speaker: Louie Ellis
quotes.context: Louie signs off at the end of the highlight reel, formally closing the archival program and acknowledging the collaborative effort behind it.

themes: Land reclamation and environmental cleanup (transforming a strip‑mined, silted valley into a playable, scenic golf course)
Family legacy and immigrant roots (the LaRosa family’s coal‑mining background and return to the PK mine site to build a world‑class course)
Collaboration between visionary owner and legendary architect (James D. LaRosa and Pete Dye’s 18‑year partnership)
Self‑contained, pure golf design (no houses, dramatic topography, strategic variety, and framed vistas)
Industrial heritage as design feature (coal mine portals, tipple, rotary car dump, coal cinder bunkers, stone walls)
Persistence and long time horizon (multi‑decade construction, constant tweaking, and 'never‑give‑up' attitude)
Community and friendship (Louie Ellis’s unpaid documentation, outside voices like Frank Etterie, and group portraits of staff and friends)
Course maturation and pride (from raw earthmoving to fountains, fish stocking, and polished hole‑by‑hole descriptions)
Conscious creation of a historical record (repeated references to 'posterity,' dates on tape, and deliberate filming of each phase)

The_Pete_Dye_Golf_Course_Narrated_by_Har.title: Pete Dye Golf Club Promotional & Course Overview Film
The_Pete_Dye_Golf_Course_Narrated_by_Har.summary: A professionally produced promotional and architectural overview video for the Pete Dye Golf Club, blending narrated marketing copy, Pete Dye’s own design commentary, LaRosa family vision statements, animated routing maps, and extensive scenic footage of the course and its coal‑mining heritage. The film positions the club as a world‑class, tradition‑minded golf destination in Clarksburg, West Virginia, built on reclaimed mining land and designed by Pete Dye as one of his most dramatic and complete works.

characters.name: James D. LaRosa
characters.description: Appears briefly in an inset ID shot as an older man in a suit labeled “James D. LaRosa,” delivering formal, scripted narration about the land, West Virginia’s potential, and the course’s connection to coal heritage and golf tradition. His words are also used extensively as voiceover copy throughout the film.

characters.name: James J. (Jimmy) LaRosa
characters.role: Co‑visionary, project manager, and video producer
characters.description: Not seen on camera in the analyzed segments, but credited on a title card as President of Burning Embers Corporation and implicitly as the driving force behind the video. Some of the business‑oriented narration about resort development and access is likely his authored perspective, even if voiced by a professional narrator.

characters.name: Pete Dye
characters.role: Golf course architect and on‑camera commentator
characters.description: Identified on screen in multiple inset interview shots (older man, white hair, glasses, light bucket hat). He provides unscripted, conversational commentary about what makes a great golf course, the uniqueness of the West Virginia topography, the coal‑mine integration, the finishing of holes (especially #4 and #18), and the dramatic nature of the property. His written welcome letter is also shown on screen near the end.

characters.name: Unidentified professional narrator
characters.description: Delivers the polished, promotional narration describing the club’s mission, West Virginia’s advantages, the yardages and strategies of each hole, and the LaRosa family’s vision. The voice is distinct from Pete Dye’s and from the brief on‑camera LaRosa ID shot, suggesting a hired narrator (possibly Harris Holt, but not explicitly identified in this footage).

characters.name: Course routing demonstrator (off‑screen)
characters.description: An unseen person who moves a pointer or club shaft across various routing maps and hole diagrams while the narrator explains strategy and design. No voice is clearly attributable to this person; they function visually only.

chapters.title: 1. Opening Vision: Nature, Tradition, and the LaRosa Dream
chapters.summary: The film opens with black, sunrise, and misty water shots, then sweeping views of forests, ponds, and early course shaping. A formal narrator introduces the Pete Dye Golf Club, emphasizing honor, tradition, and Pete Dye’s global stature. The course is framed as the vision of James D. and James J. LaRosa, who acquired the land and brought in Dye. Scenic shots of ponds, stone walls, and rolling hills are intercut with a brief inset of James D. LaRosa in a suit, identified by caption, speaking about West Virginia’s natural beauty, transportation access, and potential for resort development. The narration explicitly links Mother Nature’s “unspoiled beauty” with the coal industry as part of the state’s heritage and with the honorable game of golf. Wildlife (deer and ducks) and quiet woodland shots close the sequence, underscoring the club’s harmony with nature.

chapters.title: 2. Pete Dye Introduced: Great Courses and West Virginia Topography
chapters.summary: The focus shifts to Pete Dye himself. An inset labeled “Pete Dye” appears over aerial and ground‑level shots of fairways, ponds, and autumn hills. The narrator’s earlier copy about the course’s emergence and the LaRosas’ vision is now visually tied to Dye’s face. Then Dye’s own voice takes over in a more conversational tone, explaining what makes a great golf course: usually an ocean or mountain that can’t be reproduced. He argues that the general topography of this part of West Virginia is similarly irreplaceable, unlike flat regions like Illinois, Ohio, Florida, or the desert where architects must manufacture features. He praises the vistas, the distinctive look and background of every hole, and the strategic variety—short, long, different—on a hilly site that still yields good strategy. As he speaks, the film shows rolling fairways, rock faces, stone walls, and wooded hills. The sequence culminates with explicit visual and verbal linkage to coal heritage: a mine portal labeled “#7 PORTAL” and rock/coal imagery, illustrating how previous land use is woven into the design.

chapters.title: 3. Finishing Touches, Atmosphere, and the Dramatic Property
chapters.summary: Pete Dye continues in interview voiceover, now focused on the idea of a “finished product.” Over shots of fairways, greens, stone walls, ponds, and mine‑related features, he explains that many courses open for play before they are truly finished, but here the team is taking time to add small touches that give each hole individual character. He singles out hole #4, which has been a great hole for years but is only now being visually finished so people can see its quality. He describes working the 18th hole back toward the clubhouse and building the entrance road to create a powerful atmosphere, comparing the drive in from Smith Chapel to Magnolia Lane at Augusta National and claiming it is “equally, if not more so, impressive.” He insists the property is uniquely dramatic—especially the view from the 4th tee with the mountain backdrop—and asserts that once one small issue on the front nine is fixed, “I don’t see how you can get 18 holes any better.” Intercut routing maps and valley shots reinforce his emphasis on atmosphere, routing, and the sense of going “to some place” special in the middle of West Virginia.

chapters.title: 4. Hole‑by‑Hole Tour: Front Nine Strategy and Coal Integration
chapters.summary:
The narration shifts into a structured, hole‑by‑hole description of the course, starting with overall yardage (5,200–7,100 yards) and design philosophy: spacious landing areas, contoured fairways, privacy of play, and a mental/physical challenge. The narrator then walks through holes 1–10 in detail while the visuals alternate between live‑action hole footage and annotated routing maps with a pointer:
- #1 (397‑yard par 4, dogleg left): Introduced as a preview of the course’s excitement, challenge, and natural beauty.
- #2 (439‑yard par 4, dogleg left): Tee shot over Simpson Creek; strategy is to stay left to open the green for a six‑iron approach.
- #3 (367‑yard par 4, slight dogleg right): Likely 3‑wood and 8‑iron to a small green; grass mounds punish short approaches.
- #4 (215‑yard par 3 over a rock‑lined lake): Both strategic and beautiful, with an open front allowing a running shot.
- #5 (628‑yard par 5, dogleg right): A “monster” with an option to cut the corner over Simpson Creek on the third shot to save ~30 yards.
- #6 (341‑yard par 4, straightaway): Shortest par 4 but a tight driving hole along a walled stream bed; a coal mine portal is visible behind the green, and players must pass through a real coal mine for 140 feet to reach #7 tee.
- #7 (155‑yard par 3): Played from an elevated tee above a coal mine portal; surrounding mounding creates an unusual yet fair hole.
- #8 (504‑yard par 5, dogleg left): Only hole where the green is not visible from the tee; a hidden 1.5‑acre bunker awaits sliced second shots.
- #9 (465‑yard par 4, dogleg right): Described as “awesome,” requiring a 180‑yard carry over Simpson Creek from an elevated tee and a long approach to a three‑tiered, well‑bunkered green.
- #10 (450‑yard par 4, dogleg right): A string of coal mine cars turns the hole off the drive, and a 25‑foot vertical waterfall protects the green on the right; ominous‑looking but fair with a bailout left.
Throughout, the visuals emphasize Simpson Creek, rock‑lined lakes, mine portals, coal cars, and waterfalls, making the coal‑industry theme a central visual and strategic element of the front nine.

chapters.title: 5. Hole‑by‑Hole Tour: Back Nine Drama and Championship Finish
chapters.summary:
The narrator continues the hole‑by‑hole tour into the back nine, focusing on variety, vistas, and championship‑level drama:
- #11 (570‑yard par 5, slight dogleg left): Extremely wide, offering recovery opportunities on errant shots.
- #12 (370‑yard par 4, straightaway): Strategy is to avoid drifting too far right, where a large camelback mound can leave a blind approach; a classic birdie‑or‑bogey hole.
- #13 (185‑yard par 3): Breathtaking view, likened to the famous Redan hole in Scotland; green slopes front‑to‑back and right‑to‑left with a large bunker behind.
- #14 (440‑yard par 4, dogleg right): Elevated tees above the landing area, framed by a stone wall; “shades of Scotland” in appearance.
- #15 (505‑yard par 5, slight dogleg right): Tee view is “magnificent,” with a 10‑acre lake bordering the right side; the second shot flirts with the water.
- #16 (250‑yard downhill par 3): Called “incomparable”; tee shot flies over an expansive fairway to a green plateaued on the right; short and left offers a bailout and easy pitch.
- #17 (430‑yard par 4): Slightly uphill drive leads to potential downhill lies due to rolling terrain; green is ample but well bunkered.
- #18 (450‑yard par 4): A “magnificent,” “beautiful, breathtaking” finishing hole from an elevated tee across Simpson Creek, which borders the left side. The second shot comes from an ample landing area but must favor the left to open the green. The right side is a contoured hillside designed to accommodate up to 30,000 spectators, underscoring the course’s tournament ambitions.
Maps and on‑course shots of lakes, stone walls, steep embankments, and valley corridors accompany the narration, reinforcing the Scottish and amphitheater analogies and the back nine’s role as a dramatic, spectator‑friendly finish.

chapters.title: 6. Pete Dye’s Reflections and Closing Invitation
chapters.summary: The film closes by foregrounding Pete Dye’s own written and spoken reflections. A master routing map zooms out to show the full 18‑hole layout, practice range, clubhouse, and water features. Over this, the narrator introduces “some of Pete’s own thoughts,” and a superimposed letter from Pete Dye appears over course and coal‑heritage imagery. In the letter and accompanying voiceover, Dye notes the land’s historical significance—first as an Indian campground, then as a coal‑mining site—combined with the spectacular West Virginia hills, which allowed him to create 18 of the most exciting and memorable holes he has ever built on one course. He states he is very proud of the course and believes it will be recognized as one of the great golf courses of the world, calling it a very special place. The visuals cut between the letter, mine tunnels, coal cars, and serene course scenes, then transition to the Pete Dye Golf Club logo over water and signature rock‑wall holes. A final title card credits Burning Embers Corporation, President James J. LaRosa, and Director of Marketing Billy Pulice, while the narrator (or on‑screen text) invites viewers to “share in a lifetime of unparalleled golfing experience” and displays the club’s web address. The sequence cements the course’s identity as a fusion of land history, coal heritage, and world‑class golf architecture.

highlights.title: Coal Mine Portal as Active Golf Feature
highlights.description: The narrator explains that after playing the 6th hole, golfers must pass through a real coal mine for 140 feet to reach the 7th tee, while the visuals show a timber‑lined tunnel labeled “#7 PORTAL” integrated into the course routing.

highlights.title: Pete Dye on the Uniqueness of West Virginia Topography
highlights.description: In an inset interview over sweeping fairway shots, Pete Dye contrasts the irreplaceable hills of north‑central West Virginia with flat regions like Illinois, Ohio, Florida, and the desert, arguing that here you feel a million miles away and can’t look in any direction without a great vista.

highlights.title: Comparison to Augusta National’s Magnolia Lane
highlights.description: Pete Dye compares the drive into Pete Dye Golf Club from Smith Chapel to Magnolia Drive at Augusta National, insisting the entrance road here is equally, if not more, impressive and creates an atmosphere that’s hard to equal.

highlights.title: Declaration of 18 Nearly Perfect Holes
highlights.description: Standing metaphorically on the nearly finished front nine, Pete Dye says that once one small issue is fixed, he doesn’t see how you can get 18 holes any better, and tells the listener to “put that down in quotation” because he really means it.

highlights.title: Front‑Nine Coal Imagery: Cars and Waterfall on #10
highlights.description: The narrator describes the 10th hole as a spectacular par‑4 where a string of coal mine cars turns the hole off the drive and a 25‑foot vertical waterfall guards the green, while visuals show coal cars, rock walls, and water features.

highlights.title: Back‑Nine Scottish Echoes and Redan Reference
highlights.description: During the back‑nine tour, the narrator likens the 13th hole to the famous Redan in Scotland and notes that the 14th, framed by a stone wall, has “shades of Scotland,” while the camera lingers on rugged embankments and stonework.

highlights.title: Pete Dye’s Written Endorsement of the Course
highlights.description: A superimposed letter from Pete Dye appears over course and coal imagery as his words proclaim that this land’s history and terrain allowed him to create 18 of the most exciting and memorable holes he has ever built, and that he believes the course will be recognized as one of the great golf courses of the world.

highlights.title: Spectator Amphitheater on the 18th Hole
highlights.description: The narrator describes the right side of the 18th fairway as a contoured hillside capable of holding up to 30,000 spectators, signaling the course’s ambition as a championship venue.

quotes.text: All great golf courses, you know, what makes a great golf course is usually you have the Pacific Ocean on one side or the Atlantic Ocean on the other side or a mountain or something that it's hard to reproduce.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete Dye begins explaining his philosophy of what makes a great golf course while aerial and ground‑level shots show the West Virginia hills and fairways.

quotes.text: Well, the general topography right through here, you know, of this part of the country, you can't reproduce it.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Continuing his design philosophy, Dye contrasts the unique hills of north‑central West Virginia with flatter regions where architects must manufacture features.

quotes.text: So when you play this golf course or a golf course like this, I mean, it's different. You feel like you're a million miles away from any given place and you can't look at any direction and not have a great vista.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Over panoramic fairway and valley shots, Dye emphasizes the immersive, remote feeling and constant vistas that define the Pete Dye Golf Club experience.

quotes.text: Now every hole here has a distinctive look to it and a great background.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Dye describes how each hole at the club has its own visual identity and backdrop, as the film shows varied holes framed by hills, rock faces, and trees.

quotes.text: Out here, I assure you that every golf hole we have out here, we have a terrific variation in strategy, short, long, different.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: He underscores the strategic diversity of the routing while viewers see a mix of par‑3s, par‑4s, and par‑5s across hilly terrain.

quotes.text: Most golf courses, you come into an area like the biggest this, it's hard to get it done to what really looks like a finished product. And now we're getting closer and closer where it looks like every hole has been finished.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Discussing the concept of a “finished” golf course, Dye praises the ongoing refinement work at Pete Dye Golf Club as visuals show polished greens and fairways.

quotes.text: Four has been sitting there as a great golf hole for almost four years. And now that we're starting to make it look more like a finished hole, everybody starts to see it.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: He uses the 4th hole as an example of a hole that has always been strategically strong but is only now being visually completed.

quotes.text: A golf course is like Augusta National. It's a great golf course, and it has a certain atmosphere. But just going in Magnolia Drive, it's impressive.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Dye compares the importance of the arrival experience at Augusta National to the entrance road at Pete Dye Golf Club.

quotes.text: Well, I assure you that the drive coming into this golf course is equally, if not more so, impressive.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: He boldly claims that the drive from Smith Chapel into Pete Dye Golf Club rivals or surpasses Augusta’s Magnolia Lane in impact.

quotes.text: You start right out at the Smith Chapel and make that turn, and then when you start back that road, you feel, the minute you make that turn to go back there, that you're going to some place. You're going to something.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Dye describes the emotional build‑up of the entrance drive as aerial shots show the valley and routing leading toward the clubhouse.

quotes.text: I don't think I've ever seen any more dramatic than this piece of property. I don't know how else you can say it. There isn't anything more dramatic than this.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Standing figuratively on the property in his mind’s eye, Dye emphasizes the unmatched drama of the site as the camera shows steep hills and quarry‑like features.

quotes.text: You know, to stand on 4T, it's about as dramatic a thing as you're going to see, that mountain behind 4.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: He singles out the 4th tee as one of the most visually dramatic spots on the course, with a mountain backdrop.

quotes.text: We've got one little deal to fix on this front nine, and that's it. You can go to hell and gone. You're going to have a long time. You've got all the room in the world to play. I don't see how you can get 18 holes any better now. Put that down in quotation. I really mean that.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: In a candid, emphatic moment, Dye asserts that once a minor issue is resolved, the 18‑hole course will be as good as any, urging that his statement be quoted.

quotes.text: The course will play from 5,200 yards to 7,100 yards depending on which set of tees are played, thus ensuring a pleasurable experience for golfers of all levels.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified professional narrator
quotes.context: The narrator introduces the course’s flexibility and target audience before beginning the detailed hole‑by‑hole tour.

quotes.text: Number six is a 341‑yard par‑4 straightaway. The shortest par‑4 on the course. A very tight driving hole demanding a long accurate tee shot to the right of the walled stream bed which separates the fairway from the rough. This creates an interesting second shot. A coal mine portal is visible behind the green. Upon finishing this hole, the player must pass through a real coal mine for 140 feet to get to the seventh tee.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified professional narrator
quotes.context: During the front‑nine tour, the narrator highlights the unique integration of a real coal mine into the playing sequence between holes 6 and 7.

quotes.text: Number ten is a spectacular hole. It is a 450‑yard par‑4 dogleg right. A string of coal mine cars turns the hole off the drive and a 25‑foot vertical waterfall protects the green on the right. Number ten is an ominous looking hole but is very fair with a bailout area to the left of the green.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified professional narrator
quotes.context: The narrator describes the dramatic visual and strategic elements of the 10th hole, emphasizing coal cars and a waterfall as defining features.

quotes.text: Thirteen is a 185‑yard par‑3. The view on this hole is breathtaking. Mother Nature at her greatest. It is somewhat similar to the famous Redan hole in Scotland.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified professional narrator
quotes.context: In the back‑nine tour, the narrator compares the 13th hole to the classic Redan template, underscoring the course’s links‑style inspirations.

quotes.text: The magnificent eighteen, beautiful, breathtaking. A 450‑yard par‑4 from an elevated tee across Simpson Creek which borders the left side of the fairway. The player's second shot will be hit from an ample landing area but he will need to be on the left side to be open to the green. The right side of the fairway is a contoured hillside allowing up to 30,000 spectators.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified professional narrator
quotes.context: The narrator presents the 18th as a championship‑caliber finishing hole with built‑in spectator mounding, over visuals of the valley and creek.

quotes.text: The historical significance of the land, first as an Indian campground then as a site of coal mining operations, is combined with the spectacular terrain of the West Virginia hills. This has allowed me to create 18 of the most exciting and memorable holes that I have ever built on one course.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Pete Dye’s written and spoken statement appears near the end of the film, superimposed over course and coal imagery, summarizing the site’s history and his design achievement.

quotes.text: I'm very proud of this golf course and I believe it will be recognized as one of the great golf courses of the world. This golf course is a very special place.
quotes.speaker: Pete Dye
quotes.context: Continuing his closing statement, Dye expresses pride and predicts global recognition for the Pete Dye Golf Club.

quotes.text: The Pete Dye Golf Club hopes you have enjoyed these few moments with us and we invite you to share in a lifetime of unparalleled golfing experience.
quotes.speaker: Unidentified professional narrator
quotes.context: The narrator delivers the film’s closing invitation over logo and scenic shots, positioning the club as a place for enduring, high‑level golf experiences.
